Steinberg wanted to see if firsthand, ``The image of so many students being forced through the final tunnel, where a solitary student emerges at the end, a victor, while the others slink off in defeat.'' For Steinberg, this was nothing short of Shakespearean. It was also, he thought, an example of ``so much that goes on in organized mass education.'' From kindergarten on, we teach children that humiliation is in their bones, waiting to break out. As she now recalls the moment, the judge, a man, looked at her and said, ``I don't have any use for either lady law professors or legal aid clinics.''   Well, she thought, ``I'm certainly getting off on the right foot here.''   The lawyer recounted the incident on Thursday night as she accepted a Servant of Justice award at the annual dinner of the Legal Aid Society of New York at the Waldorf-Astoria.   The ``lady lawyer,'' Hillary Rodham Clinton, then added: ``I always have a little trouble getting my footing in new settings, in case you haven't noticed. But I sort of just stay until I get it figured out.''   NEW YORK -- Francine Shore was, as she says, ``up at bat'' at a cash machine this week when she realized that the machine wasn't ready for her. It was still asking if another transaction was wanted, and when she pushed ``No,'' a card popped out. No other customers were in sight, but a man acting as an unofficial doorman told her that he had seen a man jump into a cab.   She looked at the card, which was from Lloyds Bank; the name on it was Rufus Sewell   By a coincidence hard to believe, Ms. Shore, a one-time casting assistant, not only recognized the name, still somewhat obscure in this country, but knew where to find the man.   She had seen Sewell, an Irish actor, in the movie ``A Man of No Importance'' and was about to see him in ``Translations,'' the Brian Friel play now on Broadway.   She called the company manager at the theater and told him the story, and he sent a messenger for the card. Ms. Shore enclosed a note prefaced, ``Only in New York.''   The next day the actor responded: a bouquet was delivered to her apartment in Chelsea with a thank-you note that ended, ``Only in New York indeed.''   By the way, Sewell, who calls himself a klutz, has also lost two wallets and a small shoulder bag in his seven weeks in New York.   ``By the end of the day, I'm always one thing short,'' he said.   The day may come when Prince Charles will open his mouth and say something nonflammable, but it hasn't yet arrived. The prince spoke on Thursday at the opening of a British Council campaign to preserve the worldwide dominance of the English language and, by The Times of London report, said that American English was ``very corrupting.''   Elaborating on his view of American influence, he continued: ``People tend to invent all sorts of nouns and verbs and make words that shouldn't be. I think we have to be a bit careful; otherwise the whole thing can get rather a mess.   ``We must act now to insure that English -- and that, to my way of thinking, means English English -- maintains its position as the world language well into the next century.''  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19950324.0257 type=story > <HEADLINE> CONNER CATCHES MIGHTY MARY </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> SAN DIEGO  (BC-AMERICAS-CUP-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> "	"nyt_eng_199503.gz"

(NYT)  (BC-NATIONAL-BRIEFS-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> It is hard to imagine a public figure whose death would inspire such universal grief as that of Franklin D. Roosevelt. Roosevelt's death at 3:35 p.m. on April 12, 1945, will be commemorated on Wednesday in ceremonies both in Hyde Park, N.Y., where he is buried in a hemlock-enclosed rose garden on the grounds of his boyhood home, and in Warm Springs, Ga., where he died of a cerebral hemorrhage while having his portrait painted in watercolors. ``I have a terrific headache,'' Roosevelt said with his final words, before collapsing.   Eighty-three-year-old Millie Ashley of Wabbaseka, Ark., remembers weeping. ``I was working in the cotton patch,'' she said. ``After President Roosevelt got to be president it got to be pretty good because he did a minimum wage so people could live. When he started, we got 35 cents for a hundred pounds, working sun to sun when you were chopping. We was getting $2.35 when he died. When I heard the news, I thought, 'Well everything's gone now.' ``   Albert Gore Sr., the vice president's 87-year-old father, was a congressman in Washington at the time. ``I was up the street from where we lived and I think I was en route to a laundry to get some shirts,'' he said. ``I met a man who was weeping deeply and loudly and with tears flowing plentifully. He had just heard about the death of President Roosevelt. This, of course, was a shock to me. I did proceed to recover my shirts and then I returned and my dear wife and I together privately wept ourselves.''   NEW YORK (NYT) -- The Plaza Hotel, long a symbol of fashion and grandeur and more recently a trophy in the high-stakes arenas of real estate and global deal-making, is being sold to a Saudi Arabian prince and a Singapore-based company.   The sale price for the landmark 800-room hotel at 59th Street and Fifth Avenue near Central Park is said to be about $325 million -- at least $55 million less than the price paid in 1988 by Donald J. Trump, whose sagging fortunes were a crucial factor in the transfer.   The sale, which has been rumored for weeks, was announced Tuesday in Singapore by CDL Hotels International Ltd., the hotel arm of the Hong Leong Group.   CDL said it has formed a joint venture with an entity controlled by Saudi Arabian Prince Alwaleed bin Talal bin Abdulaziz Saud that will join Trump and a group of banks as partners in Plaza Operating Partners Ltd., which owns the Plaza Hotel.   INFLATION VANISHED IN MARCH   WASHINGTON (NYT) -- In an unexpectedly benign report, inflation vanished at the producer level in March as both energy and food prices turned down, government figures showed Tuesday.   Not only was the price of finished products unchanged for the month, the best performance since October, goods at earlier stages of production settled back to a pace that calmed jitters that had developed from sharp price increases since late last year. March marked the end of the fourth year of economic recovery and expansion following the 1990-1991 recession.   ``The United States still does not have any serious inflationary problem,'' commented Lacy Hunt, chief economist at HSBC Holdings in New York, parent of Marine Midland. ``There's an ample supply of goods and services and companies keep finding ways to make productivity gains.''   When the erratic energy and food components removed, the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods edged up just one-tenth of 1 percent in March, also the skimpiest in five months.   Tuesday's figures, if followed Wednesday by similar restrained consumer prices, where services are a sizable component, would seem to further reduce the possibility that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates anytime soon, analysts said.   YPSILANTI, Mich. (NYT) -- From dozens of conversations around the country -- in small North Carolina towns, in the wealthy desert outskirts of Phoenix, in union strongholds outside Detroit and on a college campus in Boston, what emerged this week was a sense that those who had framed the Republican Contract With America were far more enthusiastic about it than the people with whom they had supposedly made it.   ``It's just a political strategy,'' said Lonnie Parcell, a 50-year-old customer at Stacy's Diner in Pittsboro, Mass.   Michael Marshner, 43, a disabled truck driver who voted Libertarian in the last election, said he did not trust the new Republican leaders. ``They ought to call it the contract out on America,'' he said. ``How can you believe them? Everything they say falls through or doesn't come through. What happened to the Brady bill? What happened to the Gramm-Rudman Act? That was supposed to fix everything. The biggest thing that's out of control is the politicians.''   But others were less cynical. Asked about the contract by a reporter, plenty of people praised the Republicans' legislative agenda and the House's passage of it under the promised 100-day deadline. ``For the first time in 40 years there's been a change in direction,'' said Jim Bruner, a tax attorney, and a Republican, from Scottsdale, Ariz.   But while the Republicans have set the national agenda, with their Contract the talk of Washington, out in the country, beyond the Beltway, it seemed almost incidental to people's lives.   ``Yeah, I heard about that contract,'' said Donna Allen, owner of the Sweet Licks ice cream parlor. ``What the heck is that?  </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19950411.0216 type=story > <HEADLINE> `STUART SAVES HIS FAMILY': TWO-STEP COMEDY </HEADLINE> <DATELINE>  (BC-STUART-FILM-REVIEW-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> "	"nyt_eng_199504.gz"

"26733"	"we"	"thought"	" Petitioners argue that absence of perceived endorsement was material in Lamb's Chapel and Widmar. We did state in Lamb's Chapel that there was ``no realistic danger that the community would think that the District was endorsing religion or any particular creed,'' 508 U. S., at --- (slip op., at 10). But that conclusion was not the result of empirical investigation; it followed directly, we thought, from the fact that the forum was open and the religious activity privately sponsored. See ibid. It is significant that we referred only to what would be thought by ``the community'' not by outsiders or individual members of the community uninformed about the school's practice. Surely some of the latter, hearing of religious ceremonies on school premises, and not knowing of the premises' availability and use for all sorts of other private activities, might leap to the erroneous conclusion of state endorsement. But, we in effect said, given an open forum and private sponsorship, erroneous conclusions do not count. So also in Widmar. Once we determined that the benefit to religious groups from the public forum was incidental and shared by other groups, we categorically rejected the State's Establishment Clause defense. 454 U. S., at 274. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199506.gz"

If you have questions, contact Judy Holland or Eric Rosenberg at 202-298-6920 or 202-298-6320.  (Slug includes the HNS designation.)  NATIONAL NEWS (``a'' category)  HIDDEN-HANDGUNS (Austin, Texas) _ Leaving their guns behind and carrying notebooks instead, more than 150 Texans showed up for the first training class offered by the state to those who want to teach others how to get a hidden-handgun license. By LAURA TOLLEY.  CABLE-CARS (San Francisco) _ With his silver and turquoise Native American jewelry dangling from his chest as he guides a cable car in San Francisco, Gordon Engler is the picture of civic nonconformity. City officials want him and his funkily dressed colleagues back in their brown uniforms. By the San Francisco Examiner.  ALAMO-SOLDIERS (San Antonio) _ Davy Crockett wore a fur cap and defiantly swung a rifle nicknamed ``Old Betsy.'' James Bowie created a deadly knife and fought from his sickbed. None of those fabled Texians survived the March 6, 1836, Battle of the Alamo. But what about the victors? By CHRISTOPER ANDERSON.  SPORTS (``s'' category)  BASEBALL-WWII (San Antonio) _ Unfamiliar men filled the familiar uniforms of baseball. Sometimes their own managers, mocked them. More than one executive was driven to throw up his hands in exasperation at the sinking level of talent. That was about 50 years ago. By DAVID KING.  OUTDOORS-COLUMN (San Francisco) _ Memories have a way of eating at your mind, but it is the here and now that can bring every cell in your body back to life. So it is at Pacifica on the Bay Area coast, where fishing went from heaven to hell over the past 20 years, but in the past week has suddenly become something like Valhalla, an angler's paradise. By TOM STIENSTRA.  COMMENTARY (``k'' category)  SALTER-COLUMN (San Francisco) _ Wow, I thought, this must be one of those openings of another glamorous celebrity restaurant chain. The line of people ran all the way down one city block, then snaked around the corner. It was a line for one of the fastest-growing chains of theme restaurants in the United States. By STEPHANIE SALTER.  TRAVEL (``t'' category)  SANTA-FE-TRAVEL (Santa Fe, N.M.) _ It's a family thing at The Bishop's Lodge. The Thorpe family, which has owned and operated the resort since the early 1900s, caters to families. By JULIE COOPER.  LIFESTYLE (``l'' category)  WICKER-LIVING-ROOM (Undated) Once relegated to the porch and the sun room, the wicker family has moved into the polite society of the living room. By MADELEINE McDERMOTT HAMM.  GARDENING-COLUMN (Undated) _ Q: How do you control stink bugs on vegetables? We prefer an organic approach, but anything that would not make the vegetables unsafe to eat would be OK. Answers to this and other gardening questions. By KATHY HUBER.  FIREFLIES-CHASING (San Antonio) _ Mention fireflies and many adults can recall fluorescent swarms darting through backyards or flying through the countryside at nightfall. Chasing fireflies, also known as lightning bugs, on a summer evening was common for generations. By BRENDA RODRIGUEZ. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19950718.0151 type=story > <HEADLINE> IBM 2ND-QTR NET MORE THAN DOUBLES, BEATING ESTIMATES (UPDATE3) </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> Armonk, New York, July 18 (Bloomberg) (BC-EARNS-IBM-UPDATE3-BLOOM) </DATELINE> <TEXT> "	"nyt_eng_199507.gz"

Stories are moving in category shown at end of each budget item.  Lifestyle, Entertainment  GRETA _ WASHINGTON _ Of all the characters that have emerged from the O.J. Simpson trial, none is perhaps as unlikely a media celebrity as Greta Van Susteren. With her long, straight schoolgirlish hair and solid-as-a-gavel insights, the 5-foot-3-inch litigator has become a familiar sight to OJTV addicts. She is CNN's on-air legal analyst, providing play-by-play for the Simpson trial. (e)  ONBOOKS _ undated _ BOOK NOTES: Writer and professional storyteller J.J. Reneaux of Athens, Ga., is one of the authors contributing to ``Little Folk,'' a new line of children's folklore being launched this week by August House of Little Rock. Reneaux's book, ``Why Alligator Hates Dog,'' is based on a Cajun folk tale about a crafty canine who consistently outwits a pompous gator. On many days, the refurbished, comfortable train is virtually empty except for retirees seeking to relive rail's golden era and parents with kids looking for some fun. (l)  OLY-FOODMAIN _ ATLANTA _ It's not that the milk was bad. It was cold. And to see it come spitting out of the mouths of foreign athletes who had never tasted cold milk before was just one of those lessons in culinary diversity that's shaping the menu planning for next summer's Olympic Village dining hall. ``It was surprising the first time I saw it,'' remembers Lew Sprague, of his first taste of feeding Olympians. Since that first exposure at the 1980 Winter Games in Lake Placid, N.Y., to people who knew only shelf-stable, nonrefrigerated milk, Sprague, who's in charge of feeding the athletes at the Atlanta Games, has learned a lot about the world's feeding habits. The Family numbers about 160,000. (s)  Commentary  NETHAWAY-COLUMN _ WACO, Texas _ I'm white so I think O.J. got away with murder. Forget free will. That's my genetically predetermined position. Until the verdict was read, I would not have believed it. But it must be so. For months polls showed blacks and whites were 180 degrees apart. Whites thought Simpson was guilty. Blacks thought he was innocent. The polls, I thought, were flawed attempts to extract permanent meaning from fleeting sentiments. Snapshots do not reflect the big picture. But after watching the televised reactions of blacks and whites to the announcement of the verdict, I've begun to think that the polls actually gave a clear view of the big picture. (k)  YOUNG-COLUMN _ WACO, Texas _ Across the country the experience was nearly uniform. If the audience was white, it sat in silence _ a ``sickening silence'' as one reporter described things at the Los Angeles PD. If the audience was black, the cheers deafened. Judging by the noise meter, Simpson verdict reactions could have been the most jarring and pronounced evidence of racial polarization in the country's history. "42409"	"I"	"thought"	" Judge Vieri Guy Volterra ordered all three men held without bail. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19951211.0589 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-LEAH-PERSONALS-SFCHRON) </DATELINE> <TEXT> (Eds: This story also moved in the ``a'' national news file) By LEAH GARCHIK c.1995 San Francisco Chronicle  PICTURING THE NEW YORKER  Every week, the New Yorker's Lee Lorenz shuffles through 3,500 cartoons, sorting and choosing to come up with 20 that will appear in the magazine.  Lorenz, who was art editor of the New Yorker from 1973 to 1993 and is cartoon editor nowadays, talked last week about his new book, ``The Art of the New Yorker, 1925 to 1995'' (Knopf; $40).  Q: How have New Yorker covers changed under the Tina Brown regime?  A: ``The biggest change is that they are being commissioned. On the editorial side, covers were always meant to be a graceful introduction to the magazine, and not a selling tool. Now, they are seen as a way of grabbing your attention, particularly on the newsstand. And they are more tied to the editorial content of the magazine, which they never used to be.''  Q: How has the subject matter in cartoons changed?  A: ``Cartoons depend on cliches. Some things have become too far out of date: Images of the businessman with his secretary, the `get ready' man (carrying the `end of the world is nigh' sign). ... We phased out the bum on the street with a little sign, because nowadays the person on the street is really a homeless person. It's not a neutral figure. ... The wife waiting behind the door with a rolling pin is out the window. ...  ``We have more on politics than we used to have. If there were serious issues, like Vietnam, we didn't want to echo that in cartoons. But there was a deliberate editorial decision to change, and now we're edging up to something that comes close to a political cartoon.''  THE MYSTERY OF JANE AUSTEN  After nearly 200 years of resting in peace, Jane Austen, this year's Frida Kahlo, is popping up everywhere.  ``Sense and Sensibility,'' ``Persuasion'' and ``Pride and Prejudice'' are new movies, notes Entertainment Weekly, and the author is such a hot commodity that she's about to star in her own mystery series.  In April, Bantam Books will publish ``Jane and the Unpleasantness at Seagrave Manor,'' which the publisher says will be the first in a series in which Austen serves as a crimefighter. The author is Stephanie Barron, described by the publisher as ``a lifelong admirer of Jane Austen's work.''  THE BEATLES ON THE HAIGHT  Bruce Bellingham of San Francisco watched a videotape of the ``Beatles Anthology'' over the weekend and pricked up his ears at the mention of his town.  ``I was all for going there,'' said John Lennon, recalling the summer of 1967, ``and living in the Haight, you know. I mean, in my head, I thought, `Well, hell, acid's in, so let's go. I'll go there and we'll make music and all that.' But of course it didn't come true in the end. George went over.''  ``I went to the Haight-Ashbury,'' recallsGeorge Harrison, ``expected it to be this brilliant place, and it was just full of horrible, spotty, drop-out kids on drugs.''  FLASH  _ Princess Diana was in New York last night to receive a humanitarian award from United Cerebral Palsy of New York, but she received specific orders from Buckingham Palace to keep her lips zipped. No more interviews.  _ Sorry to be so fuzzy on this _ if you want certainty in items, read the obits _ but People magazine, which always knows whereof it speaks, has contradicted the Washington Post's report that Steve Martin and Diane Keaton are an item. According to People, Keaton wasn't even in Washington when the Washington Post said the pair had requested adjoining rooms.  _ Noa Ben-Artzi, 18, told Newsday that there have been contracts offered, but she hasn't yet decided whether she'll write a book about her grandfather, Yitzhak Rabin.  Knopf senior editor Jonathan Segal, who had announced the deal, said, ``If she wants to delay, that's her prerogative.''  Meanwhile, composer Marvin Hamlisch has written ``Noa's Song,'' which he told the New York Times ``is about the importance of listening to children who are wise beyond their years.'' The composition was performed Sunday at a tribute to Rabin in New York. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19951211.0590 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-LEAH-PERSONALS-SFCHRON) </DATELINE> <TEXT> (Eds: This story also moved in the ``l'' lifestyle file) By LEAH GARCHIK c.1995 San Francisco Chronicle  PICTURING THE NEW YORKER  Every week, the New Yorker's Lee Lorenz shuffles through 3,500 cartoons, sorting and choosing to come up with 20 that will appear in the magazine. Now, they are seen as a way of grabbing your attention, particularly on the newsstand. And they are more tied to the editorial content of the magazine, which they never used to be.'' Some things have become too far out of date: Images of the businessman with his secretary, the `get ready' man (carrying the `end of the world is nigh' sign). ... But there was a deliberate editorial decision to change, and now we're edging up to something that comes close to a political cartoon.'' No more interviews.  _ Sorry to be so fuzzy on this _ if you want certainty in items, read the obits _ but People magazine, which always knows whereof it speaks, has contradicted the Washington Post's report that Steve Martin and Diane Keaton are an item. According to People, Keaton wasn't even in Washington when the Washington Post said the pair had requested adjoining rooms.  _ Noa Ben-Artzi, 18, told Newsday that there have been contracts offered, but she hasn't yet decided whether she'll write a book about her grandfather, Yitzhak Rabin. "54739"	"she"	"thought"	" ``So, when Hewitt came along, she thought, `I've raised the kids, now it's my turn to have a life.''' </P> "	"nyt_eng_199604.gz"
"54886"	"I"	"thought"	" Seven mothers in their 30s recently gatheredin a 10-mat room in an apartment building in a residential area near Jiyugaoka Station in Tokyo.    They discussed business, including advertising and how to recruit more people for their network, while their children played nearby.    The room is the head office of M-Net Japan, a company of women that does market research for companies and sells goods through a network of 1,300 homemakers. Its president is Mayumi Tomizawa, 35.    For a year after it was established, it leaned heavily on the mail to recruit more people for its marketing network. But in March it opened a home page on the Internet.    The name of the home page is Pop'n Planet. It offers mothers a place for business exchanges. In the ''planet'' in the frame, information about railway lines along which many members live is available.     Companies can place ads in the ''office building'' corner of the page. In the ''department store'' corner, children's goods and clothing are sold by mail order.    Several members conversant with computers and the Internet created the home page.    When they were first thinking of using a computer network to generate business, the women ''met'' via their personal computers late at night.    In the beginning, they didn't know whether they could generate business by using multimedia. But when they sent questionnaires to those involved in their network-marketing efforts, they found that more than 30 percent had personal computers at home.     A computer can help many mothers with small children, who have little free time and cannot go out when they want, get information they need.    ''In the daytime, when our husbands are at work, the personal computers are idle, so we can use them whenever we like,'' Tomizawa said. ''If mothers show an interest in working at home, companies will come around, too.''    Office Will, a company established by women in Ota Ward, will start a talent bank, JMB, to look for work that women can do at home. It will use a home page to recruit talent.    Its workers will translate, edit and do accounting consultation via personal computers. It has already received an order from a Tokyo company to create a home page.    Company representative Mutsumi Okuyama, 37, has formed a group to help working women. ''Hearing that women the same age as myself are being targeted in company restructuring, I thought, `Let us women create a means by which women who are fired can find work,''' she said.    The Internet is allowing small companies to tap the skills of women in their 30s _ an age range that has been under-represented in the work force because of the women's family commitments.    In Japan, most working women are in their 20s, having just graduated from high school or college, and their 40s, when many return to work after raising children.    ''We can include women in their 30s who have the will and energy to work but who need time to rear their children,'' Okuyama said. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960410.0368 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-ASAHI-BUDGET (EDITORIAL)) </DATELINE> <TEXT> FOR RELEASE: WED., APR. 10, 1996 LOWER HOUSE BUDGET DEBATE MUST NOT BE SIDETRACKED C.1996 Asahi News Service  Asahi Shimbun said in an editorial:     Lower House deliberation on the fiscal 1996 budget draft,  which includes a 685 billion yen ($6.5 billion) allocation for liquidating seven  jusen housing loan companies, is in its final phase. The ruling  coalition is prepared to vote the bill out of the Lower House Budget Committee soon.    It is, of course, unreasonable to needlessly prolong the debate. One rule of parliamentary democracy is to vote on a bill after thorough discussion. A budget bill deserves to be expedited especially because the national budget has a direct bearing on the daily lives of the citizenry.    Having said all that, however, we cannot endorse a vote on the budget bill now.    That is because neither the administration nor the ruling coalition parties have answered the key question of why taxpayers should have to pay for dealing with the jusen companies. If for no other reason than to thwart their apparent hope that the people, who oppose the expenditure, would be resigned to it eventually, we must continue to raise the question.    A promotional brochure from the Finance Ministry claims that ''The government's measures to deal with the jusen companies, including the expenditure of public money, are indispensable for protecting your savings.''    Honestly, we are stunned. Has the Finance Ministry said clearly, if just this once, that the expenditure of public funds is intended to protect depositors in general?    If the Finance Ministry goes so far as to suggest that banks and other financial institutions will be imperiled unless the jusen companies are liquidated with tax money quickly, it should specify which institutions are at risk. Without doing that, the ministry cannot avoid criticism for having issued a document that arouses public concern.    Nor has it been made clear how much more public money will need to be spent in future years. The only solution is to strike the allocation of taxpayers' money for jusen and set a time limit for establishing a rule that could be applied to all the bad loans that trouble the nation's financial institutions.    In the Diet, the movement has been neither discussion about the heart of the jusen problem nor constructive discussion toward finding a breakthrough.    Instead, the wrangling between the ruling parties and the opposition Shinshinto (New Frontier Party) is shifting away from the question of deleting the jusen line from the budget draft to the question of whether to call Koichi Kato, secretary-general of the Liberal Democratic Party, to testify.    Kato is accused of having received and concealed a donation of 10 million yen from a former vice president of Kyowa, a now-bankrupt manufacturer of structural steel framing. The suspicions have been fortified by claims of a former chairman of Kato's support group to the effect that he saw the money change hands.    Kato is the man who must bear the blame for his unwillingness to clear the suspicion. Although he has said he would follow the Budget Committee's decision, he is primarily responsible for determining the policies of the ruling coalition. Kato thus cannot shun criticism that he is being evasive. He should accept the summons to testify with good grace.    At the same time, we cannot condone the Shinshinto attitude of predicating a vote on the budget bill upon a requirement to have Kato testify. Even if Kato is called, the budget jusen allocation is unreasonable.    There is rampant speculation that Shinshinto hopes to cut a deal with the LDP that would trade demands for Diet testimony, since Shinshinto knows that the LDP would never accept having Kato testify, in exchange for not bringing Daisaku Ikeda, honorary president of the influential lay Buddhist organization Soka Gakkai, to the stand to testify on an unrelated matter. If Shinshinto's demand is thus questionable, so is the demand of the LDP, which, knowing the Shinshinto vulnerability on this point, insists on having Ikeda summoned.    The ruling and opposition parties should agree upon summoning Kato promptly after passing the budget bill in the Lower House and, furthermore, hold serious talks on how to deal with the main issue of handling the jusen companies. The Japanese Communist Party has urged that the parent banks of the troubled jusen companies pay more. That suggestion is worth study by the ruling coalition and Shinshinto.    When the Diet proceedings got back on track some time ago, the coalition and Shinshinto agreed to abide by the united opinion in the course of budget bill deliberations, and agreed that a vote on the bill would not be rammed through. That agreement should be upheld now. (Asahi Shimbun, April 10) </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960410.0371 type=story > <HEADLINE> FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE </HEADLINE> <DATELINE>  (BC-ASAHI-BUDGET-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> "	"nyt_eng_199604.gz"

"55093"	"she"	"thought"	" ``It would create a jurisdictional nightmare and it would create more disputes than the one in front of this court today,'' Ms. Kramer said. She described a sheaf of documents detailing anonymous islanders who, she thought, placed the island fully within New York's control. Newborns (birth certificates issued by New York). Newlyweds (married in New York). The dead (death certificates issued in New York). Voters (Ellis Island was part of a New York election district). Taxpayers (records going back to 1790). </P> "	"nyt_eng_199604.gz"

Slaney is best remembered for being accidentally tripped by South African Zola Budd at the '84 Olympics. . . . Even though '92 Olympian Dave Johnson finished 17th at last summer's U.S. championships, Dan O'Brien still sees Johnson has his toughest foe in the Olympic decathlon. ``He's consistent,'' O'Brien said. ``And if he's healthy and in shape, nobody can put field events together like he can. Dave always shows up in an Olympic year.'' U.S. selections: Men's and women's trials for most events are June 14-23 at the Olympic stadium. "55478"	"he"	"thought"	" The letters also tell a great story about important and politically committed lives in the midst of some of the defining events of our century. After they came to America, Weill (who was Jewish) and Lenya (who was not) spoke and wrote to each other in English; they reserve some of their choicest scorn for emigres who remained in their own cliques in this country, refusing to find American friends and become Americans, the way Weill and Lenya did. Although there are still people who feel that Weill ``sold out'' to Broadway and Hollywood, the composer knew exactly what he was doing. In Hollywood, Weill wrote, ``There is only one way to get on here; you have to take everything with a great sense of humor and make fun of it (to yourself, because you mustn't show it!) and just enjoy the beautiful scenery and make money.'' The money, he thought, would enable him to do the important work he was meant to do, ``something significant again, by my former standards.'' Weill takes heart from the letters of Verdi _ which his own resemble in their businesslike practicality. </P> "	"nyt_eng_199604.gz"

"60703"	"I"	"thought"	" I took the book to bed one night and settled in, prepared to savor, but the soup was pretty thin, I thought, and full of artificial ingredients. Some of the stories were clearly parables or homilies. Other stories may have been true but nevertheless had an apocryphal quality because the prose was so overblown. There were heartwarmers about people snatched from the brink of suicide by a kind word. There were tear-jerkers about children courageously battling life-threatening illnesses. There were rags-to-riches stories worthy of Horatio Alger. Some stories were funny, some were touching. But many were maudlin, and many more were simple-minded. A lot of ``Chicken Soup for the Soul'' could be called ``Mush for the Brain.'' </P> "	"nyt_eng_199605.gz"

Non-Olympics stories are listed below.  Stories are moving in category shown at end of each budget item.  Olympics  EDITORS: Below are 10 stories from the Atlanta Journal-Constitution Olympics team. Every item is moving to Sports queues. WARNING: Some stories also will move to other departments of your newspaper as indicated by a category letter in par enthesis at the end of the item. Copy is handled in Atlanta by Tom Bennett at 404-526-5471. Photos and graphics are available through the NYTNS. For copy reruns, call the Cox Washington Bureau at 202-331-0900. For further information, call J im Bentley, managing editor of the Cox News Service, at 912-635-3650.  OLY-RAIL _ undated _ OLYMPICS IN BRIEF: Sports minister Guy Drut has ordered France's Olympic synchronized swimming team to drop any references to the Holocaust in its controversial routine. (s)  OLY-LITERARY _ ATLANTA _ An International Celebration of Southern Literature is under way in Atlanta. (s, e)  OLY-CYCLE _ TREXLERTOWN, Pa. _ Ten months after getting kicked off the national squad for throwing a major temper tantrum, Erin Hartwell earned a strong measure of redemption by winning a spot on the U.S. Olympic cycling team. Hartwell, who turned 27 last week, won the men's kilometer time trial in 1 minute 4.48 seconds, a track record at the Lehigh Valley Velodrome. (s)  OLY-ROW _ ATLANTA _ U.S. rowing team decries lack of monitors. (s)  OLY-GYMMEN _ KNOXVILLE, Tenn. _ Not so long ago, when he was still strapped into his plastic ``turtle shell'' body cast, the fused bone still healing in his spine, Scott Keswick had his first real chance to reconsider why he'd spent 18 years of his life pursuing gymnastics. Spinal surgery will do that to a guy, especially when he is a former Olympian and, somehow, wants to be one again. (s)  OLY-GYMWOMEN _ undated _ GYMNASTICS: Miller leads U.S. championships after compulsories. (s)  OLY-BEACH _ BALTIMORE _ Karolyn Kirby and Liz Masakayan _ once the most dynamic duo on the beach _ were supposed to be a lock for Olympic gold in 1996. That was before they split up last summer. Now, neither will be coming to Atlanta. (s)  OLY-TORCH _ HENRYVILLE, Ind. _ As the torch traveled through southern Indiana Wednesday on its way to Kentucky, it passed in front of Henryville High on graduation day. All 43 graduating seniors met the torch wearing their black robes. (s )  OLY-TICKET-QNA _ undated _ Refunds, swaps, seating and other ticket issues. (s)  OLY-TICKETS _ ATLANTA _ Before you finish setting your Olympic plans, reconsider where you think you'll be sitting. Starting times have changed for sessions in most sports, and some of the rescheduling came too late to fix tickets. As a result, Olympic officials printed about 170,000 tickets with wrong times. (s)  Lifestyle, Entertainment  POT-SURVEY _ undated _ Two new surveys by the National Institute on Drug Abuse and the Partnership for a Drug Free America found this things. (l)  POT-HONESTY _ undated _ Honesty is best policy for parents, experts say. (l)  POT-ADULTS _ undated _ Grass isn't always greener, say adults who've been there. (l)  REAL-LIFE _ WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. _ Sweet childhood is over in our house. I have not seen this fact on television or read about it in the paper. I am pulling this news from a much more genuine source: my heart.  In just a few months, my 5-year-old will begin his public school education in a trailer park _ for how else can you describe those hideous portables? (l)  NETWATCH.VACATION _ You probably already know that the Internet is a vast resource of research material on what to do and where to stay. But you can also use the Internet for other kinds of information that might be useful for your vacation. (l)  FAT _ undated _ The results are in from the latest fat-finding mission: Cinnamon rolls and cheesecake are land mines of fat and calories. (d)  PHANTOM _ undated _ MOVIES: On-screen `Phantom' fades fast. (e)  BILLYZANE _ undated _ Low-profile actor taking a big leap as comic-book hero in $60 million flick. (e)  TREND _ undated _ Want to live longer? You might seek advice from the Japanese, who have the longest life expectancy in the world, according to new U.S. Census Bureau rankings that compare the world's largest developed nations. (l)  National  NETWATCH.NEWS _ undated _ Attorney General Janet Reno has proposed the formation of an FBI-led emergency response team to deal with the threat of terrorist attacks that could disable the nation's computer networks, including those that connect banks, telephones and even the national electrical power grid. (a)  HEALTH _ undated _ Physicians and their male patients routinely avoid talking about sexual problems and emotional issues, according to a Gallup survey released Wednesday. (a)  VOUCHERS _ AUSTIN, Texas _ Black, Hispanic leaders oppose school vouchers. (a)  CHARLESFORT _ undated _ Archaeologists have found the long-sought roots of French history in the United States. They were just a chip shot off the fairway on the eighth hole of the U.S. Marine Corps' Parris Island golf course. (a)  KINDRED-COLUMN _ ATLANTA _ As moths to the flame, soldiers flew to the war. It was a war they thought would soon be over. Win this battle, they thought, and we can get out of here. (a)  Business  HOTEL _ MIAMI BEACH, Fla. _ Six years after an African- American tourism boycott tarnished South Florida's image, officials hope to break ground soon for a black-owned hotel that many believe will symbolize a new era of interracial cooperation. The venture _ one of the first major hotels for Miami Beach in three decades _ also will cap a significant turnaround for a once-trendy vacation spot that fell on hard times during the 1980s because of dropping property values, a spiraling crime rate and an aging population. (f)  Sports  See Olympics section.  SCHOTT _ PHILADELPHIA _ Cincinnati Reds owner Marge Schott faced Major League Baseball's ruling body on Wednesday, fighting to keep her team. Baseball's 10-man executive council set a one-week deadline to decide whether to remove Schott from the day-to-day operation of the Reds. (s)  Commentary  YOUNG-COLUMN _ WACO, Texas _ If, as Newton Minow forecast in 1962, television has become a vast wasteland, the vacuity of AM radio has become as gaping as Rush Limbaugh's vast waistband. Once the harbor for the ear of everyman, AM is becoming the equivalent of CB radio, trained to narrow brotherhoods with jargon unto themselves. (k)  LEIBOWITZ-COLUMN _ PHOENIX _ ``Amtrak train No. Two, the Sunset Limited,'' the ticket agent tells the hundred or so people waiting trackside. ``This is the last eastbound train leaving Phoenix. The last eastbound train.'' Ever, he means. As in very last. As in gone. (k)  LATHAM-COLUMN _ undated _ Sometimes late at night, when I cannot sleep, I listen to the radio preachers. It is better than the best tranquilizer and it most definitely is not habit forming. There is no danger of an overdose. (k)  For answers or resends, call the Cox News Service at 202-331-0900. (s)  OLY-LITERARY _ ATLANTA _ An International Celebration of Southern Literature is under way in Atlanta. (s, e)  OLY-CYCLE _ TREXLERTOWN, Pa. _ Ten months after getting kicked off the national squad for throwing a major temper tantrum, Erin Hartwell earned a strong measure of redemption by winning a spot on the U.S. Olympic cycling team. Hartwell, who turned 27 last week, won the men's kilometer time trial in 1 minute 4.48 seconds, a track record at the Lehigh Valley Velodrome. (s)  OLY-ROW _ ATLANTA _ U.S. rowing team decries lack of monitors. (s)  OLY-GYMMEN _ KNOXVILLE, Tenn. _ Not so long ago, when he was still strapped into his plastic ``turtle shell'' body cast, the fused bone still healing in his spine, Scott Keswick had his first real chance to reconsider why he'd spent 18 years of his life pursuing gymnastics. Spinal surgery will do that to a guy, especially when he is a former Olympian and, somehow, wants to be one again. (s)  OLY-GYMWOMEN _ undated _ GYMNASTICS: Miller leads U.S. championships after compulsories. (s)  OLY-BEACH _ BALTIMORE _ Karolyn Kirby and Liz Masakayan _ once the most dynamic duo on the beach _ were supposed to be a lock for Olympic gold in 1996. That was before they split up last summer. Now, neither will be coming to Atlanta. All 43 graduating seniors met the torch wearing their black robes. (s )  OLY-TICKET-QNA _ undated _ Refunds, swaps, seating and other ticket issues. (s)  OLY-TICKETS _ ATLANTA _ Before you finish setting your Olympic plans, reconsider where you think you'll be sitting. Starting times have changed for sessions in most sports, and some of the rescheduling came too late to fix tickets. As a result, Olympic officials printed about 170,000 tickets with wrong times. Last month it opened its first store in Thailand, in the country's second-largest city, where Carrefour opened its first store in March. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960624.0412 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-WILL-SMITH-IN-`INDEPENDENCE-DAY'-PAGEUP-ART-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> WILL SMITH CELEBRATES ``INDEPENDENCE DAY'' Includes a color slide of Will Smith in a scene from ``Independence Day.'' By CINDY PEARLMAN World rights except Chicago (Distributed by New York Times Special Features)  What is it about Will Smith and aliens?  He battles extraterrestrial invaders in his role as a cocky, gifted Marine fighter pilot in ``Independence Day,'' opening July 3.  But while awaiting release of that film, which might be the summer's biggest hit, Smith is in a muggy New York City, on the set of ``Men in Black'' _ and he's chasing aliens again.  ``Men in Black,'' co-starring Tommy Lee Jones, is based on a popular comic book. It casts Smith as a New York City police officer recruited by the Men in Black, an elite force who combat aliens living among us.  ``I must have been crowned the alien man,'' Smith says with a laugh. ``The next thing you'll hear is that I've signed up for `Alien 4' with Sigourney Weaver. The poster will read, `Will Smith IS the Alien.'''  Alien-fighting is a strange business.  ``Tommy Lee Jones is my partner,'' explains Smith over the phone from his trailer on the set. ``This morning, Tommy Lee blew this guy's head off in front of me. I was about to arrest Tommy Lee for murder. All of a sudden his victim's head grew back.  ``It's pretty creepy stuff.''  Filming the $70-million ``Independence Day'' was less bizarre, he says. In fact, it was downright boring.  ``When I would look in the sky, I didn't see the aliens. They were put in later with a computer,'' Smith says. ``So I'd be standing there looking at nothing but clouds and then I would have to freak out.''  Even the air combat scenes were exercises in imagination.  ``There were no other jets or little green guys flying them,'' he says. ``I was just sitting there in this easy chair throwing my body around and yelling, `Explosion!' or `There must be 12,000 aliens in that spaceship!'  ``Anyone could do it at home.''  Given his apparent specialization in alien movies, what does Smith think about real-life ETs?  ``I just think it is arrogant for us to believe we are the only life force (in the universe),'' he answers. ``How can we think we're it?  ``I have to say that my dreams are getting a little weird. I'm getting beamed to a lot of places. Weird little people show up. I think, `Will, you have to get a hobby or something.' I just can't stop thinking about aliens.  ``Everywhere I go, it's the same thing. I'm in a restaurant and the waitress will say, `Will, do you want fries with that and do you believe in aliens?' People seem very excited about it.''  After six years as television's ``Fresh Prince of Bel Air,'' Smith is excited about a movie career that has taken off. Offers are pouring in, including a sequel to ``Bad Boys'' (1995), his hit action film that cracked the $100 million mark.  ``It's funny. This June marks my 10th anniversary in show business,'' the 28-year-old says. ``In many ways it seems like I just started. Then I have days where everything just seems to be happening too quickly.''  Smith was born in Philadelphia, where he grew up with two sisters and a brother. His mother worked with the school board, his father at an ice company.  Despite his raffish charm and quick wit, Smith was not the class clown as a boy, he says.  ``I was a little shy, especially with women. I was interested in computer engineering. Math was my best subject, and I thought I'd have a nice little 9-to-5 job someday.''  It was his hobby that derailed those plans: In his spare time, Smith liked to rap.  ``It was just something to do,'' he recalls. ``I started rapping at age 12, but I never had big plans to cut a record or anything.''  In 1986, Smith and Jeff Townes formed a group, D.J. Jazzy Jeff and The Fresh Prince. During his senior year of high school, a talent scout from Jive records heard their music. One month before high-school graduation, Jive released the duo's first record, ``Girls Ain't Nothing But Trouble.''  The group earned a 1988 Grammy Award for best rap performance for ``Parents Just Don't Understand,'' the hit single from their second album, ``He's the DJ, I'm the Rapper.'' They also won a Grammy for the single ``Summertime,'' from their fourth album, ``Homebase,'' which was released in 1991 and went platinum.  When producing legend Quincy Jones heard their music and called Smith to offer him the lead role in ``Fresh Prince of Belair,'' the rapper didn't have to think twice.  ``At the time, I thought, `Why not? I'm just so very good. I'm talented, I should have a TV series.' I'm so cocky!'' he says.  ``After six years on `Fresh Prince,' I'm gonna miss it a little bit,'' Smith admits. ``I do keep in touch with everyone. Our job was to have fun on that set and there are wonderful memories. You just can't spend your life looking back.''  Throughout the run of the series, Smith had used his hiatuses for film roles in such features as ``Where the Day Takes You'' (1992), ``Six Degrees of Separation'' (1993) and ``Made in America'' (1993). Now, with the series having ended, he can be a movie machine if he likes.  ``All these offers roll in,'' he says. ``It's hard to know what to do or who to trust to steer me in the right direction.  ``I trust me. That's the only person you can really trust in this business. People in this business just want to make money off you, and usually it's not in your best interests. I'm excited about a movie career, but cautious too.''  In an effort to revive his musical career, he plans to spend more time in New York, which wasn't possible during the run of ``Fresh Prince.''  ``There is just no creative inspiration in Los Angeles. It pulls my creativity down,'' Smith says. ``There's a huge difference between New York and Los Angeles in the way rap music is performed. In New York, I feel there is more hope in the music and more comedy. That's what I like.''  The end of the series will also give him more time to spend with his son, Willard C. Smith III, nicknamed ``Trey.'' Smith is divorced from his son's mother and is currently dating actress Jada Pinkett, who stars this summer in ``The Nutty Professor.''  Feeling a little played out, Smith says he will take the rest of the summer off after ``Men in Black'' wraps.  ``Jada and I talk about doing something together. We've got to strengthen the relationship first. You must get yourselves together first, before you put a movie in the mix. Otherwise you just get too stressed out.''  Not that Smith isn't enjoying his success.  ``I'm not shy with girls anymore,'' he says. ``Seriously, for the first time in my life, I feel that women like me. There was always the other guy. I was always told, `Will is fun and he makes me laugh.' I was always the best friend and it stunk. Now women like me better.''  And why not? You never know when you may need to chase away some aliens, and Will Smith is a good man to have around for that sort of thing.  But not to hear him tell it. This Independence Day, his plans don't involve any world-saving.  ``I'll be at the barbecue,'' he says. ``I'm the grill man. The only thing I'll be saving is the hamburgers from falling into the flames.'' c.1996 Cindy Pearlman  (Cindy Pearlman is a Chicago-based free-lance writer.) ------------------------------------------------- </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960624.0413 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-HOOTIE-AND-THE-BLOWFISH-PAGEUP-ART-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> ATTN MIDWEST: IL./MICH./MO./OHIO/TENN./WIS. HOOTING AND HOLLERING: ON THE ROAD WITH HOOTIE AND THE BLOWFISH Includes a color slide of the band Hootie and the Blowfish and a sidebar listing the band's July tour dates in the Midwest. By JEANNE WOLF (Distributed by New York Times Special Features)  No tuxedos for Hootie and the Blowfish, not even when they appeared on the Grammys or sang for royalty in Monaco.  ``We're just not a tux band,'' lead singer Darius Rucker explains. ``We've borrowed tuxes for some shows because it was a respect thing, but that's not us.''  No problem for this astoundingly successful band. They can wear and sing whatever they want in the wake of their record-setting first album. More than 13 million copies of ``Cracked Rear View'' (1994) were sold, and the record was still on the charts when they went back to the studio to record their much-awaited follow-up album, ``Fairweather Johnson.''  It's no coincidence that this very American group headed off on a European tour shortly after the new album came out in May.  ``We wanted to get away from all the hype and everything,'' Rucker says bluntly, ``'cause, you know, hype sucks.''  The band has encountered plenty of hype _ unsurprisingly so, given that theirs was the second-best-selling debut album in recording history, trailing only Boston's 1976 first effort.  But with the hype came intimidatingly high expectations for their second album, along with fears of the dreaded ``sophomore jinx'' which has made many artists' second albums into disappointments. Many predicted that these South Carolina college buddies, more used to playing minor clubs and small gigs all over the South, would crumble under the pressure.  But Rucker says that when they hit the studio they were fearless.  ``We had a lot of ideas and we weren't worried about it. We were just ready to do another album and we weren't scared at all.''  The group also was ready for flak from critics, who have never really been kind to them.  ``We worried about the critics at first, but not any more,'' Rucker says. ``We figured out that the media didn't sell our record. First it was the music and then it was the radio and then people just seemed to like it.''  ``We had pressure on ourselves, but from a different angle,'' agrees bassist Dean Felber. ``We're a live band and we wanted to tour, and in order to do that we needed new songs. And we were kind of worn out on the old stuff.  ``All of the pressure we put on ourselves is easier pressure to handle than when it's outside sources pushing you in a certain direction. We got to pick our own course.''  Felber says the group was braced for inevitable, probably unfavorable comparisons to its first album.  ``You can't expect something like that twice,'' he says. ``We didn't expect it the first time, you know _ it was kind of a gift. It was timing or whatever.''  He shrugs.  ``To create that twice in a row ... I don't know if that could be done.''  Guitarist Mark Bryan says that they were eager to try some new ideas.  ``I'm proud that we're still growing. I'm proud of our songwriting abilities, which are maturing,'' he says. ``I enjoy the songs from `Fairweather Johnson' the way I enjoyed the songs from `Cracked Rear View' when we first wrote them.  ``Most of all, I enjoy everyone getting together and playing. We can still have fun together and also make our music better.''  ``Fairweather Johnson'' has been in the top five since its debut. Now, as the group hits the road, Bryan looks forward to the chance to bring the new songs to live audiences.  ``We are trying as hard as we can to be anti-hype,'' he says. ``It's much more fun to just worry about your music and just play and not read about yourself every day.''  All the band members stress the group's commitment to live performances and present themselves as anti-stars _ working-guy musicians devoid of star glitter.  ``A six-week European tour, and two nights before I'm like, `OK, I gotta pack,''' Felber says. He claims that his secret to traveling comfort is to bring only two weeks' worth of clothing and do laundry every two weeks.  Bryan tries to see as much as he can in each new city they visit. He also calls home every day.  ``I try to talk to my wife every night,'' he says. ``It's important to keep yourself involved in your life back home.''  Drummer Jim ``Soni'' Sonefeld sums up his slant on the European experience:  ``It's pretty here but I can't afford a hamburger _ $38 for a burger! That's wild!''  ``We are not used to these four-star hotels,'' Felber says with a smile. ``You gotta understand, the nicest place in town in a lot of the cities we play is just an ordinary motel. I keep kidding that we don't really belong in this kind of luxury.''  And how do these hot young rockers spent their time on the road? Do they trash hotel rooms, party into the night or cruise the night scene?  No, because it might interfere with their real passion: This may be the world's only rock band which also makes up a foursome for golf.  ``Everyone asks us if success spoiled us,'' Sonefeld says. ``About golf, I can say yes! We get to play some of the nicest courses in the country and sometimes in the world.  ``We know there are people that are much more deserving who would die to play on these courses and they can't. We've been playing them for free, and we stink. We've been spoiled in that world.''  Another unusual aspect of this band is that, at least from an outsider's perspective, they reveal few signs of artistic or personal conflicts. To all appearances, all four Blowfish get along amazingly well, exchanging good-natured barbs and clearly enjoying what they do. Their only real conflicts arise from business discussions:  ``The biggest chafe these days is just trying to separate business from our music, 'cause business has become a big part of it,'' Sonefeld says. ``There's a lot of responsibility that comes with success and you've got to sit there and sort it out.  ``Though counting money isn't the biggest problem in the world to have, it can chafe people the wrong way when you're tired and you've just finished a big concert and the last thing you want to discuss is payroll taxes and investments.  ``We are all truly grateful, but we're in this for the music,'' he continues. ``And when you have to get into all these business details it can be a bit of a pain in the (butt), and tempers run a little short.''  He grins.  ``It's not a joking matter, (but) we're such lighthearted people and we still want to joke sometimes. I admit I'm the worst at it.''  Onstage, though, any lingering annoyance disappears, Sonefeld says.  ``It's not about money. It's not about anything in the world other than playing the music. That's the reason we all got together in the first place. It's what brings you back to the first time you ever had a gig together, you know. You've got your instrument, you've got your microphone and the crowd gets going. It's great!''  So great, in fact, that the musicians occasionally can't believe it, Rucker says. They are a long way from taking it for granted.  ``We were sitting around last night just having a beer,'' Rucker says, ``and thinking, `This is all part of the fantasy.'  ``And it's like I never want to wake up. Because I swear this is a dream, and one day my alarm's gonna go off and I'm going to be waking up in Charleston, S.C. and heading to the Music Forum to play a show.'' c.1996 Pentacom Productions  (Jeanne Wolf, who is based in Hollywood, reports on the entertainment industry for television, radio and print outlets.)  -0- SIDEBAR: HOOTIE AND THE BLOWFISH ON TOUR  This summer's tour will bring Hootie and the Blowfish to sites throughout the United States, including the following July dates: July 7, Mears, Mich.; July 8, Nobelsville, Mich.; July 9, St. Louis, Mo.; July 10, Kansas City, Kan.; July 12, Tinley Park, Ill.; July 13, East Troy, Wis.; July 14, Columbus, Ohio; July 16-17, Clarkston, Mich.; July 18, Cleveland, Ohio; July 21, Nashville, Tenn.; July 23, Cincinnati, Ohio; July 26, Burgettstown, Penn.; July 27-28, Bristow, Va.; July 30-31, New York City. The tour continues through September 22. ------------------------------------------------- </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960624.0414 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-LOU-DIAMOND-PHILLIPS-TAKES-THE-THRONE-PAGEUP-ART-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> LOU DIAMOND PHILLIPS, RIDING HIGH Includes a color slide of Lou Diamond Phillips in a scene from ``Courage Under Fire.'' By IAN SPELLING (Distributed by New York Times Special Features)  Lou Diamond Phillips is on a roll, again.  The actor made an early splash in 1987 as rock legend Ritchie Valens in ``La Bamba'' and the next year scored in ``Stand and Deliver'' and ``Young Guns.''  He then endured a long commercial drought, including a couple of failed films _ ``Ambition'' (1991), which he co-wrote, and ``Shadow of the Wolf'' (1992). He also directed a film, ``Sioux City,'' which has yet to be released.  But the down cycle seems to be ending, thanks to his acclaimed performance in the Broadway revival of ``The King and I'' and his powerful supporting role in the upcoming film ``Courage Under Fire.''  So what happened? It's a puzzlement, as the play's King Mongkut might say. Others, though, might point to poor timing, wrong choices and old-fashioned bad luck.  ``It got frustrating sometimes because I'd say to myself, `My abilities are not any less than they were and I'm no less of an actor now than I was in 1987,''' the gregarious Phillips says, relaxing in jeans and a black-and-white polo shirt as he sits in his dressing room at Manhattan's Neil Simon Theater, where ``King and I'' has been running since its April opening. ``It's really all about who's on the cover of a magazine right now.  ``I did three films in the last few years that didn't have a chance to breathe, which opened one weekend and were gone the next. I also directed a couple of independent films.  ``So I've always been working, but I've never been in the studio stable and never been a guy with a three-picture deal. There's a perception that my career was on a higher level, but it was perceived as higher than it really was, because most of my hits were negative pickups (independent films bought and released by a studio).  ``I'm grateful for that and for the good press I've always gotten, because it makes me a known quantity to people. Anyway, the point is I stuck in there, and it's paying off now.''  Indeed it is. At 34, Phillips has been basking in the praise heaped on his energetic portrayal of the King in ``The King and I,'' not only for his talent but also for his moxie in tackling a role so associated with the late Yul Brynner.  Phillips, who acted on stage during his formative years growing up in Arlington, Texas, admits it was naive of him, but he went into ``King and I'' believing audiences and critics would not judge him by Brynner's standard.  ``I felt the show would be wonderful and that people would be swept away by it,'' says Phillips. ``I had a certain amount of confidence that what I'd do with the role would be different and, therefore, accepted as a reinterpretation.  ``I also realized that one and, possibly, two generations never saw Mr. Brynner on Broadway or in the film, and they might be open to seeing a new version of the play.  ``I knew I might take a few hits, but I could see what (director) Christopher Renshaw was doing and I could see what Donna Murphy, who has legendary status on Broadway, was doing with Anna.  ``So I thought all that would help shield me, and I was right. People essentially said, `This is an American classic, it's wonderful, and why should it be buried with Mr. Brynner?'''  Phillips, who last month lost the Tony Award for Best Actor in a Musical to Broadway fixture Nathan Lane, is signed to remain with ``King and I'' until next April. He does, however, have a contract stipulation that allows him time off should a desirable film role come along.  Still, audiences can see Phillips back on the big screen in ``Courage Under Fire,'' opening nationwide on July 12. The film stars Denzel Washington as Lt. Col. Serling, assigned to investigate the death in battle of Capt. Walden (Meg Ryan), a Medevac pilot nominated for a posthumous Medal of Honor.  Serling's investigation leads him to interview the men in Walden's unit, each of whom offers a different version of what unfolded during the rescue mission in which Walden perished. Among those Serling encounters is the bitter Monfriez, played by Phillips.  ``Monfriez is a good soldier who marches and shoots well and is brave,'' Phillips says. ``He's a lot of the things that make up what everybody expects of a great American GI.  ``When he's thrown into a situation beyond his control, one where what he was taught doesn't apply, things become very difficult for him. The pinnacle of that is his inability to take orders from a woman, to deal with the fact that he's outranked by someone who doesn't have his experience or battle savvy, but does have more compassion.  ``You essentially have a soldier dealing with input _ input from a woman _ that no other soldier in any other war has dealt with.''  Phillips realized when he read the script that Monfriez could be an intriguing character, but that if he didn't play him carefully he could become a cliche.  ``As much as people will learn to loathe Monfriez, they will also understand him,'' Phillips says. ``They will, at times, feel for him, and that's one of the brilliances, not only of the screenplay but also of what (director) Ed Zwick has done.  ``Monfriez, like the film, is not black-and-white. Even the people who are perceived to be bad guys have lost and been wounded, and behave the way they do because of what happened to them.  ``A lot of people are used to seeing me play good guys, and that may be part of the reason Ed cast me. People will have expectations because of my past work, and we really put a twist on that, which is great.''  Though the characters played by Washington and Ryan never meet, Phillips shared scenes with both actors. He says that they are stars for a reason.  Specifically, he notes, they were professional, prepared and there was ``magic when they turned it on'' before the camera.  ``It was a real pleasure to watch them,'' he says. ``I think I've done some of my best work in the piece, and they had something to do with that.  ``Ed's direction was important, the level of the material was superior, but perhaps it also had to do with the fact that I felt so incredibly challenged to come up against such terrific talents as Meg and Denzel.''  In a perfect world, Phillips notes, ``Courage'' would lead to other big-screen opportunities for him. Until the film fates have their say, however, he's content to star in ``The King and I,'' returning after each performance to the rented townhouse he shares with his wife Kelly, along with a rottweiler and three Dobermans.  Phillips and his wife, a makeup artist, have been married for two years. Previously he was married to ``La Bamba'' assistant director Julie Cypher, who is now in a relationship with singer Melissa Etheridge.  Phillips politely declines to talk about Cypher or their marriage, preferring instead to discuss life with Kelly.  ``Kids are definitely in the future,'' he says. ``They're something we want very badly.  ``Things are just slowing down now, that whole whirlwind of award ceremonies, luncheons and the play's opening. Kelly and I finally got back into a pool hall to play a few games.  ``That's how we met, at a pool hall in L.A., over a shot of tequila. We're just getting to the point where we're carving out a semblance of a life outside the show and my responsibilities to it.''  All in all, Phillips admits with a sheepish smile, life is good right now.  ``Life has always treated me nicely,'' he says. ``I always felt like I'm the luckiest person I could ever meet.  ``I've got to say 1996 has been a milestone. I felt that way when it started and I'll feel that way when it ends. This is a year to remember and I'm just enjoying the ride.'' c.1996 Ian Spelling  (Ian Spelling is a New York-based free-lance writer.) ------------------------------------------------- </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960624.0415 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-ANOTHER-`POINT-OF-VIEW''-PAGEUP-ART-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> ``P.O.V.'' _ IDIOSYNCRATIC AND PROUD OF IT Includes a color slide of Sokly ``Don Bonus'' Ny in a scene from the documentary film ``AKA Don Bonus'' on ``P.O.V.'' By LAWRIE MIFFLIN c.1996 The New York Times (Distributed by New York Times Special Features)  At the start of ``AKA Don Bonus,'' his first-person documentary about his refugee family's life in San Francisco's bleakest neighborhoods, the 18-year-old filmmaker Sokly ``Don Bonus'' Ny says it was hard to live his life and videotape it at the same time.  ``Especially with my family,'' he says, speaking to his own camcorder. ``We're from Cambodia, and we're pretty traditional. Talking about family secrets to the public _ we don't do that.''  American television doesn't do much of that, either. But ``P.O.V.,'' the public-television series that will broadcast Ny's film on June 25, does. ``P.O.V.'' consistently presents films that talk about some of America's most closely guarded family secrets.  They are secrets mined from the most sensitive of subjects, ranging from race to homosexuality to class conflict to physical afflictions such as Tourette's syndrome or Alzheimer's disease, both of which were topics of ``P.O.V.'' films last year. The Alzheimer's film, Deborah Hoffmann's ``Complaints of a Dutiful Daughter,'' was nominated for an Academy Award.  Named after the cinematic shorthand for ``point of view,'' ``P.O.V.'' screens several hundred independent, nonfiction films each year and chooses about a dozen for its PBS season, which is in the summer. Usually, the subject or the perspective is one that would not be found elsewhere on television.  One of the most controversial presentations on ``P.O.V.'' was Marlon Riggs' 1991 film ``Tongues Untied,'' a frank and unapologetically erotic portrayal of black male homosexuals. In a film aired this June, the subject was Audre Lorde, a black lesbian and an outspoken and influential poet who died of cancer in 1992 at the age of 58.  Unlike ``Tongues Untied,'' which was nonfiction but with dramatic enactments, music and poetry woven in, ``A Litany for Survival: The Audre Lorde Story,'' by Ada Gay Griffin and Michelle Parkerson, is a conventional documentary. But it tells the story of a passionately unconventional woman.  Born in New York of West Indian parents, Lorde first conceived of her poetry as purely private expression. Later, as she came to terms with her homosexuality _ but not before she married and had two children _ she realized she could ``take poetry and use it'' publicly, she says, ``not as propaganda, but as a way of altering feelings and lives.''  She became a teacher, a leader known in feminist circles around the world and a poetry coach to many other women. In the film, Adrienne Rich, a more eminent poet, says, ``Many poems of mine are much better because of Audre's criticisms.''  This season, many ``P.O.V.'' offerings concern conflicts about ethnicity, race or cultural identity. The series, in its ninth season, will present 11 films this summer, as well as two fall specials. They are ``Palante Siempre Palante! The Young Lords,'' a history of the militant Puerto Rican civil-rights group, and ``Maya Lin: A Strong Clear Vision,'' about the architect who designed the Vietnam War Memorial. The latter won the 1995 Academy Award for best documentary feature, but has never been on television until now.  Six of these 13 films are co-presentations with groups that help underwrite minority filmmakers' work. Ny's film, ``AKA Don Bonus,'' is also a presentation of the National Asian-American Telecommunications Association, for example. The Audre Lorde film is a co-presentation of the National Black Programming Consortium and the Independent Television Service.  ``(A) multicultural or minority independent film that is challenging, either in the way it's filmed or in its content, is very difficult to get televised, on public television or any other kind of television,'' says Mable Haddock, executive director of the National Black Programming Consortium, which also raises money to help producers make their films.  ``For that reason, `P.O.V.' is very, very important to independent minority producers.''  This sort of co-presentation arrangement also involves a publicity campaign for a film. Cautioning that ``the African-American community is not a monolith,'' Haddock says her group helped to direct promotional materials to segments of that community that might be interested in a certain film, and alerted them to screenings and discussion groups. It also tells ``P.O.V.'' about films that merit consideration for the series.  Similar consortiums help Hispanic, Asian-American and American Indian filmmakers.  ``Many people don't know who Audre Lord was, for example,'' Haddock says. ``We may know the importance of these artists, because we're inside this community, and often we know the filmmakers and whether they can pull it off.''  Suzanne Singer, the executive director of ``P.O.V.,'' gives two reasons why most of this season's films concern minorities.  ``Partly it's our mission to present voices not often heard on commercial television,'' she says. ``And this year there happened to be lots of really strong films coming from those communities. The Asian-American community in particular had a real flowering of very strong films this year, and we have four in the series.''  Ny's film is unusual in format, being essentially a video diary. It feels raw, like a home movie, and intensely candid.  For example, Ny didn't edit out a scene of himself crying in the car of Chandara, his older brother. When Sokly was 3, Chandara carried him out of the Cambodian jungle as the family escaped the Khmer Rouge. Here in America, Chandara is so preoccupied with his job and his wife and children that he cannot help Sokly and their younger brother with the problems overwhelming them in the ghetto.  ``Even though it's a Cambodian family in San Francisco's Tenderloin district, it's about immigrant experience too, and in some ways everyone in America can relate to that,'' Singer says. ``A lot of our films are about what it means to be an American or about identity.''  ``P.O.V.'' films have won many awards _ Emmys, Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University Awards, Peabodys and three Oscars _ but some of the more provocative subjects have prompted letters and phone calls complaining to PBS. Some PBS executives have even expressed discomfort about certain ``P.O.V.'' topics.  ``As society changes, risky programming becomes even riskier to make and even more difficult to get on the air,'' Haddock says.  ``For me, `P.O.V.' is a beacon. Along with ITVS and the minority consortia, it's giving us some new voices that wouldn't otherwise have an opportunity to be heard.''  And, she adds, ``Isn't that what the PBS commercial says, `If we don't do it, who will?'''  (Lawrie Mifflin writes for The New York Times on cultural matters.) ------------------------------------------------- </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960624.0416 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-HEALTH-NEWS-ON-THE-WEB-PAGEUP-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> TAPPING INTO THE WORLD OF WEB INFORMATION CAN KEEP YOU HEALTHY By PEGGY NOONAN c.1996 Longevity (Distributed by New York Times Syndicate.) EDITORS: Please note ``(T)'' in the computer addresses below equates to a tilde sign, which cannot be transmitted into newspaper computer systems).  Within the reaches of the information superhighway lies the World Wide Web, a vast subsystem that's even faster and easier to access than the Internet.  Since its creation in 1989, the Web has exploded into hundreds of thousands of home pages, or Web sites. The possibilities for researching a particular health topic boggle the mind.  No matter which home page you start with, by following hypertext clues (text that's colored to lead you to other sites at the click of a mouse), you can end up browsing everything from the National Institutes of Health to research abstracts at a European university.  You'll find a wealth of information covering the conventional and unconventional in medicine and health: hospitals, dentistry, women's health, heart health, cancer, diabetes, plastic surgery, mental health, foot care, even ``Rogaine Online'' _ and that's just a sampling.  Understanding of the topic is often enhanced by superior graphics. If you want to check into herbal medicine, for instance, it's a great help to ``see'' the herbs you're reading about. Try the herbal photo gallery at Herbal Hall (http://www.crl.com/(T)robbee/herbal.html), as well as a menu of other selections from ``Longevity Herbs-Adaptogens-Nutritives'' to ``Herbal-Medical Dictionary.''  Or you could start at the Alternative Medicine Homepage (http://www.pitt.edu/(T)cbw/altm.html), which describes itself as ``a jumpstation for sources of information on unconventional, unorthodox, unproven or alternative, innovative, integrative therapies.''  From there, you're a mouse-click away from a pool of newsletters, access to mailing lists and commercial databases, bulletin boards and files for such selections as Kombucha (the medicinal mushroom), music therapy, massage, chiropractic and acupuncture.  Want to get the latest on food guides for ovo-lacto vegetarians? Check out the Vegetarian Society and its related Web pages for everything you ever wanted to know about vegetarianism.  If there's a nip or tuck in your future, set your Web-searching tool for ``plastic surgery'' and browse through plastic surgery-focused home pages, such as the University of California Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery page, a list of plastic surgery medical journals called Plink or hundreds of other publications, each outfitted with hypertext links of its own.  You'll find a dazzling array, including information-jammed text files, charts, graphs, drawings, diagrams, photos and, in some cases, even sound-bytes and movies on nearly every subject you can imagine.  The World Wide web is a home for ``hundreds of resources from schools, hospitals, health-care professionals, informed amateurs, former patients and charlatans,'' says Abbot Chambers, editor of the Whole Internet Catalog (http://gnn.com/wic/index.html), which is online.  ``In short, it's a mirror of everything going on in society at large.''  Following is a selection of home pages on health topics; use these as a jumping-off point for hundreds of related pages  _ Women's health resources: Click onto the Women's Medical Health Page (http://www.best.com/(T)sirlou/sheimp.html) spotlights recent publications and medical issues, such as RU486 (abortion-pill) alternatives.  _ Back pain: Check out the Cleveland Clinic Department of Neurological Surgery (http://www.neus.ccf.org/). It provides ``Frequently Asked Questions'' (FAQ) files about neurology and educational material on disorders of the brain, spinal cord and peripheral nervous system.  It also includes a description of the facility's services and personnel, and it lists links to other resources.  _ Heart health: Click onto the University of California at Irvine (UCI) Heart Disease Prevention Program's site (http://www.reg.uci.edu/UCI/CARDIOLOGY/PREVENTIVE/). UCI offers an extensive program, including information about risk factors and updates on research, especially ongoing studies at UCI.  At the American College of Cardiology (ACC) Web site (http://www.acc.org), visitors will find information about the ACC, clinical practice publications, ACC educational programs, computer applications and related topics.  _ Cancer: CancerGuide, Steve Dunn's Cancer Information Page (http://cancerguide.org) is a guide created by a cancer survivor ``for patients who want to understand more about the disease and their treatment options.''  It offers information on researching medical literature, including accessing medline, the world's most powerful medical database; updates on clinical trials; data on specific cancers, rare cancers and bone marrow transplants and alternative therapies, such as bovine cartilage.  _ Customized advice about health concerns: Try Go Ask Alice (http://www.columbia.edu/cu/healthwise/alice.html), an interactive health service where online visitors post questions anonymously on any health topic _ from fitness to alcohol to sexual health.  _ Depression: Depression FAQ (http://avocado.pc.helsinki.fi/81/%7Ejanne/asdfaq/) Chambers calls ``a fine example of the sort of mutually supportive documents available on the Web.''  It provides a depression primer, FAQ files on depression's causes, treatments and medications and tips on finding appropriate doctors.  _ Miscellaneous: Rogaine online is at (http://www2.nfic.com/Rogaine/) or (http://www2.igroup.com/Rogaine/index.html). Both addresses provide the same page and same information.  The Vegetarian Society (http://catless.ncl.ac.uk/veg/) offers links to the major vegetarian sites as well as information about vegetarianism and related topics.  Please note: many of these website addresses are subject to change. (Peggy Noonan is an Edgewater, Colo.-based free-lance writer.) ------------------------------------------------- </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960624.0417 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-PROTECTING-YOUR-LAWN-PAGEUP-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> PROTECTING YOUR TURF: TOP LAWN CARE By ROBERT M. KRUGHOFF c.1996 The Washingtonian (Distributed by New York Times Syndicate.)  There's only one thing worse than a lawn that seems to need mowing every time you look _ one that doesn't.  Most homeowners want their lawns to be green and lush. But not many people look forward to weekends of spreading fertilizer, eradicating weeds or replacing patches of brown.
