Fortunately, lawn-care firms can spare you this labor and produce a lawn that will make your neighbors green with envy.  Washington Consumers' Checkbook, a nonprofit magazine, found that costs for lawn care can vary dramatically. Just in the Washington, D.C., area, prices for the same work on one lawn ranged from $417 to $1,292.  The best way to improve your chances of getting a good price and good service is to invite several firms to inspect your lawn and propose prices.  Although most firms don't require you to be there during an inspection, try to meet with a firm's representative so you can size up the company and get answers to questions. You can help the firm satisfy you by explaining to its representative:  _ how tolerant you are of weeds, thin spots and other lawn problems.  _ what you envision the result of the firm's work to be. _ how long you are willing to wait for the lawn to reach an acceptable condition.  _ how much responsibility you are willing to take on yourself.  _ how strong your concerns are regarding the use of chemical fertilizers and pesticides and what precautions you expect. THE DIRT ON LAWN-CARE COMPANIES  The experiences of homeowners surveyed by Checkbook suggest that some sales representatives know little or nothing about lawns.  For one lawn, for example, Checkbook got written ``lawn analyses'' and price quotes from six firms.  _ Two firms saw evidence of leaf-spot disease, three firms found red-thread disease, one firm saw dollar-spot disease and two firms did not find any disease.  _ Two firms saw grubs, while four firms did not see any insect problems.  _ Three firms spotted crabgrass, while three did not.  _ Three firms spotted ground ivy, while three did not.  _ Three firms recommended aeration, while the other three did not.  If a firm's representative is not savvy enough to make informed judgments, the firm may be forced to follow fixed routines _ providing roughly the same treatment for every lawn. That means broadly applying pesticides and other controls rather than treating specific problems.  If you want a more tailored program, you'll want a firm with a knowledgeable staff. Identifying such a firm is not easy, but you might get insight several ways:  _ by walking your property with each firm's sales representative, listening to his or her observations and asking questions.  _ by calling your area's Cooperative Extension Service office and discussing the firms' recommendations.  _ by asking _ after having hired a firm _ that a brief explanation be left for you after each treatment, explaining what was done to which parts of your lawn and why. THE FINE PRINT  As you gather bids, you'll want to make sure each firm is quoting at least a year's worth of service, because it often takes at least that long to get good results.  Ask each company what guarantees it offers. Usually a firm promises to refund money for a treatment, or to reapply a treatment, if a customer is not satisfied.  A few firms will agree, in writing, to refund a customer's money for the entire year if the customer is not satisfied with the result.  A number of others will agree, in writing, to continue service at no cost until the customer is satisfied.  If all the firms propose prices above what you are willing to pay, ask bidders how they can cut back service to trim costs _ and what effects those cuts might have on your lawn.  Autumn fertilization and seeding, if needed, are generally regarded as the most necessary treatments. NATURAL VERSUS ORGANIC  In the past few years, lawn-care firms have offered ``natural'' or ``organic'' programs to limit environmental risks.  Although the labels are used rather loosely, most natural or organic programs simply call for fertilizing several times a year with a non-synthetic fertilizer and aerating and seeding once or twice a year.  Coupled with proper mowing and watering, such a simple program often can create a lawn as attractive as one that receives conventional chemical treatments.  Some firms offer more extensive organic treatments to kill weeds and pests, including insecticidal oils and soaps and other chemicals that are less toxic than traditional herbicides and pesticides. SECRETS OF GOOD MOWING  While a lawn-care company can provide a variety of services to improve your lawn, most leave important tasks to you, including mowing and watering. But a good firm will advise you on how to do your part.  The key to mowing is not to mow too short. Most grasses should not be cut below a height of 3 inches, although zoysia grass should be cut to about an inch.  A lawn should be mowed frequently enough that no more than one-third of the leaf is cut off at once. Mower blades should be sharp to avoid tearing the cut ends of grass, which can make them brown and vulnerable to pest attack.  Grass should be mowed when it is dry. Clippings should be left on the lawn so they can decompose and return nutrients to the soil.  Watering is also important. Grass should be watered just when the leaves are approaching the point of wilting. You'll know that your grass has reached this point if you leave footprints when you walk on it.  To keep grass green during the summer, try to make sure it gets about 1 inch of water a week: a rain gauge or a tin can can help you figure out how much you'll have to supplement rainfall.  Watering should be thorough, so that moisture penetrates at least 3 inches into the soil. Until you get a sense of how much watering your lawn needs, you can check how deep the water penetrates by digging out (and then returning) a plug of sod with a spade.  The best time to water is early in the morning. In hot weather, it's best not to water at night because that may contribute to disease. But the risk of disease is low in a well-tended lawn, and it's better to water at night than not at all.  If you see problems, call your lawn-care company to describe what you've seen. Remember that in long dry periods, brown areas may just mean that the grass has gone into a dormant stage to save its moisture and energy. (Robert M. Krughoff is publisher of ``Washington Consumers' Checkbook.'') ------------------------------------------------- </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960624.0418 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-HOW-TO-PUSH-YOUR-LUCK-PAGEUP-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> LUCK: WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW TO MAKE IT GO YOUR WAY Includes a 200-word sidebar. By NICHOLAS RESCHER c.1996 USAir Magazine (Distributed by New York Times Syndicate.)  One person wins the lottery, the other falls victim to a drive-by shooting. Some stumble on a treasure trove, others succumb to a roving flu germ. Luck, good and bad, is at work everywhere in the world about us.  Luck comes our way when good or bad things happen unpredictably, in ways that we cannot foresee, let alone control.  Luck has nothing to do with success that comes the old fashioned way _ through hard work or carefully developed skill. But if you clinch a deal just because you happened along in time to help the firm's biggest client fix his flat tire, that's sheer luck.  Luck pivots on the element of chance. That sets it apart from good fortune, which is a matter of how one is situated in the world. The person who is born heir to an enormous enterprise or who possesses a vast reservoir of natural talent is fortunate but not lucky; the element of chance is absent.  Sometimes, of course, the two factors cooperate: The movie starlet is fortunate to be a talented actress and lucky to be ``discovered.''  Is there anything that lucky people have in common? The one way in which those who have luck seem to differ from those who don't is in their tendency to expose themselves to potentially lucky circumstances.  Only someone who holds a lottery ticket can be a lucky winner; only the person who runs the risk of possible failure can achieve success through luck's gift.  Luck, be it good or bad, will accordingly play a larger role _ statistically speaking _ in the lives of risk takers than in those of the world's Casper Milquetoasts.  Might someone become successful through luck alone? The odds of that are unlikely. Usually, the most that luck brings is an opportunity, or a favorable conjuncture of events. The individual must be in a position to capitalize on that opportunity.  A stroke of luck might make someone enormously wealthy, but the concept of success suggests engaging in an enterprise that yields a chain of positive consequences _ good results achieved systematically in some ongoing line of endeavor.  That such results could be realized through chance alone is improbable. Think of your favorite candidate for the role of ``incredibly lucky person,'' someone whose career and course of life has been punctuated by great strokes of luck. Almost inevitably you will find that those gifts of luck are coupled with an extraordinary talent for exploiting them.  Luck seems to be particularly evident when matters go especially well or ill despite the probabilities. Consider what the world would be like if this were not so _ if the talented always succeeded and the inept invariably came to ruin.  Luck is a great equalizer. Exempt from reason, it helps make the playing field of life more level. It creates a situation in which everyone has a chance. Even those who are handsome, rich, naturally well-endowed and well-equipped with the world's goods may suffer the ravages of hard luck.  And the world's victims, handicapped by the lack of life's good things, may have their bleak condition alleviated by spurts of good luck.  How can one comfort someone who has sustained major misfortune through bad luck? Some people find it helpful to believe that all mischance is only apparently so _ that it's part of a great plan in which everything happens for the best.  But for those who believe in a more random universe, comfort may be found in the very idea that chance is blind. One simply accepts that ill luck is undeserved, and that its victims have not brought it on themselves.  The prospect of occasional bad luck is there for us all. The range of what we cannot foresee is so extensive that luck is bound to be an important reality for everyone.  And even if we could eliminate luck altogether, would we want to? Doing so would impoverish our lives. In a predictable world, where all actions could be read off from the register of the Recording Angel before the fact, there would remain no room for human freedom.  But if luck can't be eliminated, can it at least be controlled or manipulated? In one sense the answer is clearly no. By the time luck enters the scene it is usually too late for intervention.  What can be controlled or manipulated, however, is the extent to which matters are left to chance. Planning, preparation, safety measures and insurance are all classic examples of safeguards we take to protect ourselves against the potential impact of bad luck.  It must also be acknowledged that sometimes even superstition _ the feeling that luck is on one's side _ can make a difference.  In circumstances where one's mental attitude counts, a feeling of confidence can affect performance. When, for example, a salesman is dealing with a difficult customer, or a tennis player with a tough opponent, the heartening feeling that today is one's lucky day _ that on this occasion success will come one's way, even against the odds _ can affect one's prospects.  But in genuine games of chance, such as roulette or the lottery, that notion can be an invitation to frustration. Luck doesn't take sides.  The attribute that Napoleon is said to have prized in his marshals was their apparent good luck. But chance alone did not throw success in battle into their waiting arms. Preparedness and diligence do not bring luck into being, but they help us position ourselves to take advantage of favorable moments.  It was, if memory serves, the golfer Lee Trevino who said, ``The harder I work, the luckier I get.'' As such precepts suggest, luck management is mostly a matter of common sense.  How could it be otherwise? Just exactly because luck is so prominent and pervasive a factor in human affairs, we have an enormous amount of accumulated experience on the issue. But whether or not we actually profit from that wisdom is something else altogether.  Luck may not play favorites, but it certainly does not discriminate against those who use their heads. -0- SIDEBAR: FIVE WAYS TO INCREASE YOUR LUCK  Luck management draws on principles of proverbial wisdom; in other words, on common sense.  1. Invite good luck. To maximize your exposure to good luck, capitalize on opportunities that put you in situations where favorable developments can occur.  2. Play the odds. Wherever possible, keep the odds on your side by managing risks in terms of determinable probabilities, thereby reducing the extent to which you rely on luck alone.  3. Avoid undue risks. Another cardinal rule of prudence is to minimize your exposure to bad luck. Don't take undue or unnecessary chances.  4. Plan for contingencies. Insurance _ literally, an insurance policy, or figuratively, a disaster or contingency plan _ is another tried-and-true resource for managing unpredictability. It provides protection and buffering against the inevitable occurrence of unlucky outcomes.  5. Extend your knowledge. Gather needed information and act on that knowledge, instead of simply trusting luck. By testing the market before introducing a product line you will not leave its success or failure to chance. (Nicholas Rescher is a professor of philosophy at the University of Pittsburgh and a past president of the American Philosophical Association. He is the author of ``Luck'' (Farrar Straus Giroux, 1995).) ------------------------------------------------- </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960624.0419 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-OPPOSITES-KEEP-THEIR-MARRIAGES-HAPPY-PAGEUP-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> WHEN OPPOSITES ATTRACT AND THEN DETRACT: HOW CAN A MARRIAGE STAY HAPPY? Includes a 200-word sidebar By SHERRY SUIB COHEN c.1996 Family Circle North American rights only. (Distributed by New York Times Syndicate.)  There's something captivating about an opposite. Passion is aroused by a jolt of differences: It's exciting.  The opposite natures of couples can lend a marriage its most exciting challenges _ and balance. The very best marriages thrive on growth and change. But what if your differences become annoyances? Or worse, obstacles to your marriage?  What follows are four combinations of disparate individuals (all names have been changed) who are married to each other. If you find yourself in one or more categories, read on for tips on transforming your differences into strengths. THE INTROVERT &AMP; EXTROVERT: OPPOSITE TYPES  ``Steve was intensely private,'' says Ann from Florida. ``At first, it seemed intriguing and romantic.''  But after six months of marriage, ``the silence got dull. We're so different socially. I love people; his inspiration comes from empty rooms. Are we in trouble?''  ``We're talking about issues of safety here,'' says Rebecca Cutter, a Portland, Ore., psychotherapist and author of ``When Opposites Attract (Plume/Penguin, 1995).  Understanding is the key. The extrovert must recognize why her spouse won't choose to be social (he feels unsafe), and minimize the perceived danger for him. She should never put him in the spotlight without his prior knowledge (surprise parties are a definite no).  When the introvert trusts his mate, Cutter says, he'll risk a little more social activity knowing she won't do anything to hurt him (like desert him in a crowded room).  By the same token, the introvert must maximize the variety in the partners' lives or risk deadening the liveliness of the marriage.  ``Invigorating changes _ more travel, for example _ keep the relationship vital,'' Cutter says.  Another approach comes from Sybil Evans, president of Sybil Evans Associates, a New York organization specializing in conflict resolution.  ``We look for an `integrated solution' that satisfies both,'' Evans says, ``instead of the traditional `compromise' where neither ends up happy.''  For example, a traditional compromise might consist of Steve's reluctantly agreeing to a large party one week if Ann says yes to staying home the next. But rest assured, Evans says, that even though it's a compromise, he'll hate the party, and she'll feel like a prisoner at home. Both may become bitter and blame each other.  But here's the integrated approach: hosting a quiet, two-couple dinner instead of attending a large affair. The intimate party will satisfy Ann's need to interact with others, and it will meet her husband's need to limit socializing to a few people rather than having to painfully cruise a crowd. THE FISHERMAN &AMP; THE READER: OPPOSITE INTERESTS  ``Nancy was a client of mine,'' Evans says. ``At first, the city-lover in her was drawn to the outdoorsy him. But just because the ocean interested him didn't mean she wanted to do battle with 6-foot waves.''  The relationship worked all right initially _ when he went off to do things with worms and sharks, she explored the flea markets or simply stayed home with a novel.  Then Nancy noticed that there was something wrong with her husband's fish stories.  ``He'd come home with these wonderful tales about seeing whales and catching giant tuna,'' she told Evans, ``but I realized, I was just hearing the stories. I wasn't in them.''  At Evans's suggestion, Nancy came up with a plan. She goes on the boat a lot now but never without a book. Nancy enjoys reading during the more mundane parts, but she's also there to marvel when they see a giant turtle.  And when it's her turn to curl up with a book, he practices his fishing knots next to her on the same couch.  Two caveats: Blending interests only works when both partners share in the blending. And although it's great when it happens, partners with opposite interests can't always blend them, Evans warns. THE OPTIMIST &AMP; THE PESSIMIST: OPPOSITE OUTLOOKS  Jane, a Boston lawyer, was enticed, she says, by Randy's ``happy face and sunny outlook.'' And Jane, says Randy, was ``the most interesting, grounded woman'' he ever met.  When they married six years ago, they began to live the way they'd been brought up: Randy, a reporter, focuses not on problems but on finding solutions, and he believes that he and Jane can always turn roadblocks into opportunities. When he lost his job recently, he wasn't crushed _ he was confident that he'd find another.  Jane is steady and intelligent, but worry and distrust are her middle names. She often thinks Randy's being childish. In a shrinking economy she's sure he won't find another job. The two are wearing each other down. Is there any hope?  Cutter offers two coping tricks to help achieve a balance between negativity and positivity: ``When Randy Optimist is having a really difficult time with Janie Pessimist, he might try picturing her when she was 5,'' Cutter suggests.  Seeing your partner as a vulnerable child, Cutter says, helps you understand and respect her way of looking at life. It makes her an endearing _ instead of a cranky _ character.  If two opposite personalities can learn to talk peacefully and try to understand, then sometimes draw from each other's reverse outlook, a remarkable balance certainly can be achieved, Evans says.  Randy and Jane might try working out a ``best-case'' and a ``worst-case'' scenario for any given threat. The idea is to temper his enthusiasm while uplifting her gloominess. Working together, they will see that growth and strength lie in emotional moderation. THE SPENDER &AMP; THE SAVER: OPPOSITE IMPULSES  After 13 years of a difficult marriage, Sara from Colorado is doubtful that either she or Michael have many strengths the other needs _ or wants.  When they met, she was drawn to his financial stability and his quiet reticence. Like a moth to flame, he flew to the way she made him laugh.  Today she wouldn't give 5 cents for his quiet, and he doesn't find her so funny anymore.  Sara is a generous spirit. Her strongest impulse is to spend her money and to share her dreams and thoughts with all her friends, not just Michael.  She has a full-time job, and her checking and savings accounts are in both their names.  Conversely, Michael's deepest impulse is to hoard. His bank account is in his name alone: ``What's mine is mine, what's hers is ours because I earn more'' is the way he looks at finances. He also shares very little emotionally.  It's not too late for this couple to see that they have reconcilable differences, says Dr. Harville Hendrix, co-author of ``The Couples Companion'' (Pocket, 1994). And with work, they can weave gold from chaff.  ``They should recognize that both too much giving and too much hoarding are defenses,'' Hendrix says. ``The generous spirit and the miserly mate must understand each other's motivations.''  Giving, Hendrix says, is, among other things, a subtle attempt to get others to love you. Most ultragenerous spirits are trying very hard to build a wall against loneliness, which would make them too vulnerable. They think if they give things of value away _ and that includes emotions _ people will be devoted to them and that will be a defense against being alone.  The miserly mate is also trying to make something happen: He wants to feel secure, and he fears he hasn't enough resources or emotions to share. If he lets down his guard, tells his secrets or spends his money, he'll be exposed and vulnerable.  What to do? The answer, like most good solutions, is disarmingly simple. Hendrix says that ``each must understand that the other's difference is precisely what's missing in themselves and then try to develop in themselves some of what they most object to in their partners.''  The miser must try to share more and protect less. He might start, Evans says, with joint banking accounts to promote trust in the marriage (both might still keep small separate accounts so each still has autonomy, and neither has to ask ``permission'' to spend money).  The emotional hoarder must also attempt to give his partner more access to his inner world _ even if it doesn't immediately feel safe. When it becomes a habit, it will start to feel safe.  The partner who gives everything away needs to put limits on her largesse, needs to incorporate a bit of her mate's hoarding behavior. She has to understand that keeping some things to herself doesn't diminish but enhances her desirability to others, Hendrix says. -0- SIDEBAR: TURNING YOUR DIFFERENCES INTO STRENGTHS  These conflict-resolution methods will help keep you and your spouse close.  _ Check assumptions before leaping to conclusions. Agree to stop for a moment at an ``outlook impasse'' and entertain the possibility that this time the other's outlook may be right.  For example, she notices her wallet is gone and assumes it's stolen. He says she probably left it at home. Each must listen to each other's reasons for their conclusions _ then figure out together the most logical one.  No sarcasm is allowed.  _ Role play. Every few weeks, agree to creep into each other's skin for a day. He will try not to be Pollyanna, and she will not dwell on wort-case scenarios.  At any given crisis during the day, each must promise to think, ``What would my spouse do?'' Then each will do it in the other's way.  This approach gives spouses permission to step back and take another route other than the programmed one. It works.  _ Get funny. Try to look at your spouse's outlooks in a humorous way and don't take things too seriously. Laughing at yourself is a lovable act, and lovable acts cement relationships. (Sherry Suib Cohen is a New York city-based free-lance writer.) ------------------------------------------------- </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960624.0420 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-HEALTH-NEWS-ON-THE-WEB-PAGEUP-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> TAPPING INTO THE WORLD OF WEB INFORMATION CAN KEEP YOU HEALTHY (To publish this ``separate buy'' article it must be purchased -- the rate is not prohibitive -- from one of these New York Times Syndicate sales representatives: (--U.S., Canada and the Pacific: CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City, 816-822-8448 or fax her at 816-822-1444. (--Europe and Asia: KARL HORWITZ in Paris at 47-42-17-11; fax, 47-42-80-44 or 47-42-18-81; telex, 282-942. (--Mexico, Central America, South America: PAUL FINCH in Los Angeles, 310-996-0075; fax, 310-996-0089. (Distributed by New York Times Syndicate) By PEGGY NOONAN c.1996 Longevity (Distributed by New York Times Syndicate.) EDITORS: Please note ``(T)'' in the computer addresses below equates to a tilde sign, which cannot be transmitted into newspaper computer systems).  Within the reaches of the information superhighway lies the World Wide Web, a vast subsystem that's even faster and easier to access than the Internet.  Since its creation in 1989, the Web has exploded into hundreds of thousands of home pages, or Web sites. The possibilities for researching a particular health topic boggle the mind.  No matter which home page you start with, by following hypertext clues (text that's colored to lead you to other sites at the click of a mouse), you can end up browsing everything from the National Institutes of Health to research abstracts at a European university.  You'll find a wealth of information covering the conventional and unconventional in medicine and health: hospitals, dentistry, women's health, heart health, cancer, diabetes, plastic surgery, mental health, foot care, even ``Rogaine Online'' _ and that's just a sampling.  Understanding of the topic is often enhanced by superior graphics. If you want to check into herbal medicine, for instance, it's a great help to ``see'' the herbs you're reading about. Try the herbal photo gallery at Herbal Hall (http://www.crl.com/(T)robbee/herbal.html), as well as a menu of other selections from ``Longevity Herbs-Adaptogens-Nutritives'' to ``Herbal-Medical Dictionary.''  Or you could start at the Alternative Medicine Homepage (http://www.pitt.edu/(T)cbw/altm.html), which describes itself as ``a jumpstation for sources of information on unconventional, unorthodox, unproven or alternative, innovative, integrative therapies.''  From there, you're a mouse-click away from a pool of newsletters, access to mailing lists and commercial databases, bulletin boards and files for such selections as Kombucha (the medicinal mushroom), music therapy, massage, chiropractic and acupuncture.  Want to get the latest on food guides for ovo-lacto vegetarians? Check out the Vegetarian Society and its related Web pages for everything you ever wanted to know about vegetarianism.  If there's a nip or tuck in your future, set your Web-searching tool for ``plastic surgery'' and browse through plastic surgery-focused home pages, such as the University of California Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery page, a list of plastic surgery medical journals called Plink or hundreds of other publications, each outfitted with hypertext links of its own.  You'll find a dazzling array, including information-jammed text files, charts, graphs, drawings, diagrams, photos and, in some cases, even sound-bytes and movies on nearly every subject you can imagine.  The World Wide web is a home for ``hundreds of resources from schools, hospitals, health-care professionals, informed amateurs, former patients and charlatans,'' says Abbot Chambers, editor of the Whole Internet Catalog (http://gnn.com/wic/index.html), which is online.  ``In short, it's a mirror of everything going on in society at large.''  Following is a selection of home pages on health topics; use these as a jumping-off point for hundreds of related pages  _ Women's health resources: Click onto the Women's Medical Health Page (http://www.best.com/(T)sirlou/sheimp.html) spotlights recent publications and medical issues, such as RU486 (abortion-pill) alternatives.  _ Back pain: Check out the Cleveland Clinic Department of Neurological Surgery (http://www.neus.ccf.org/). It provides ``Frequently Asked Questions'' (FAQ) files about neurology and educational material on disorders of the brain, spinal cord and peripheral nervous system.  It also includes a description of the facility's services and personnel, and it lists links to other resources.  _ Heart health: Click onto the University of California at Irvine (UCI) Heart Disease Prevention Program's site (http://www.reg.uci.edu/UCI/CARDIOLOGY/PREVENTIVE/). UCI offers an extensive program, including information about risk factors and updates on research, especially ongoing studies at UCI.  At the American College of Cardiology (ACC) Web site (http://www.acc.org), visitors will find information about the ACC, clinical practice publications, ACC educational programs, computer applications and related topics.  _ Cancer: CancerGuide, Steve Dunn's Cancer Information Page (http://cancerguide.org) is a guide created by a cancer survivor ``for patients who want to understand more about the disease and their treatment options.''  It offers information on researching medical literature, including accessing medline, the world's most powerful medical database; updates on clinical trials; data on specific cancers, rare cancers and bone marrow transplants and alternative therapies, such as bovine cartilage.  _ Customized advice about health concerns: Try Go Ask Alice (http://www.columbia.edu/cu/healthwise/alice.html), an interactive health service where online visitors post questions anonymously on any health topic _ from fitness to alcohol to sexual health.  _ Depression: Depression FAQ (http://avocado.pc.helsinki.fi/81/%7Ejanne/asdfaq/) Chambers calls ``a fine example of the sort of mutually supportive documents available on the Web.''  It provides a depression primer, FAQ files on depression's causes, treatments and medications and tips on finding appropriate doctors.  _ Miscellaneous: Rogaine online is at (http://www2.nfic.com/Rogaine/) or (http://www2.igroup.com/Rogaine/index.html). Both addresses provide the same page and same information.  The Vegetarian Society (http://catless.ncl.ac.uk/veg/) offers links to the major vegetarian sites as well as information about vegetarianism and related topics.  Please note: many of these website addresses are subject to change. (Peggy Noonan is an Edgewater, Colo.-based free-lance writer.) -------------------------------------------------  (To publish this ``separate buy'' article it must be purchased -- the rate is not prohibitive -- from one of these New York Times Syndicate sales representatives:  (--Europe and Asia: KARL HORWITZ in Paris at 47-42-17-11; fax, 47-42-80-44 or 47-42-18-81; telex, 282-942.  (--Mexico, Central America, South America: PAUL FINCH in Los Angeles, 310-996-0075; fax, 310-996-0089.  (--U.S., Canada and the Pacific: CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City, 816-822-8448 or fax her at 816-822-1444. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960624.0421 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-OPPOSITES-KEEP-THEIR-MARRIAGES-HAPPY-PAGEUP-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> WHEN OPPOSITES ATTRACT AND THEN DETRACT: HOW CAN A MARRIAGE STAY HAPPY? (To publish this ``separate buy'' article it must be purchased -- the rate is not prohibitive -- from one of these New York Times Syndicate sales representatives:  (--U.S., Canada and the Pacific: CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City, 816-822-8448 or fax her at 816-822-1444.  (--Europe and Asia: KARL HORWITZ in Paris at 47-42-17-11; fax, 47-42-80-44 or 47-42-18-81; telex, 282-942.  (--Mexico, Central America, South America: PAUL FINCH in Los Angeles, 310-996-0075; fax, 310-996-0089. (Distributed by New York Times Syndicate) Includes a 200-word sidebar By SHERRY SUIB COHEN c.1996 Family Circle North American rights only. (Distributed by New York Times Syndicate.)  There's something captivating about an opposite. Passion is aroused by a jolt of differences: It's exciting.  The opposite natures of couples can lend a marriage its most exciting challenges _ and balance. The very best marriages thrive on growth and change. But what if your differences become annoyances? Or worse, obstacles to your marriage?  What follows are four combinations of disparate individuals (all names have been changed) who are married to each other. If you find yourself in one or more categories, read on for tips on transforming your differences into strengths. THE INTROVERT &AMP; EXTROVERT: OPPOSITE TYPES  ``Steve was intensely private,'' says Ann from Florida. ``At first, it seemed intriguing and romantic.''  But after six months of marriage, ``the silence got dull. We're so different socially. I love people; his inspiration comes from empty rooms. Are we in trouble?''  ``We're talking about issues of safety here,'' says Rebecca Cutter, a Portland, Ore., psychotherapist and author of ``When Opposites Attract (Plume/Penguin, 1995).  Understanding is the key. The extrovert must recognize why her spouse won't choose to be social (he feels unsafe), and minimize the perceived danger for him. She should never put him in the spotlight without his prior knowledge (surprise parties are a definite no).  When the introvert trusts his mate, Cutter says, he'll risk a little more social activity knowing she won't do anything to hurt him (like desert him in a crowded room).  By the same token, the introvert must maximize the variety in the partners' lives or risk deadening the liveliness of the marriage.  ``Invigorating changes _ more travel, for example _ keep the relationship vital,'' Cutter says.  Another approach comes from Sybil Evans, president of Sybil Evans Associates, a New York organization specializing in conflict resolution.  ``We look for an `integrated solution' that satisfies both,'' Evans says, ``instead of the traditional `compromise' where neither ends up happy.''  For example, a traditional compromise might consist of Steve's reluctantly agreeing to a large party one week if Ann says yes to staying home the next. But rest assured, Evans says, that even though it's a compromise, he'll hate the party, and she'll feel like a prisoner at home. Both may become bitter and blame each other.  But here's the integrated approach: hosting a quiet, two-couple dinner instead of attending a large affair. The intimate party will satisfy Ann's need to interact with others, and it will meet her husband's need to limit socializing to a few people rather than having to painfully cruise a crowd. THE FISHERMAN &AMP; THE READER: OPPOSITE INTERESTS  ``Nancy was a client of mine,'' Evans says. ``At first, the city-lover in her was drawn to the outdoorsy him. But just because the ocean interested him didn't mean she wanted to do battle with 6-foot waves.''  The relationship worked all right initially _ when he went off to do things with worms and sharks, she explored the flea markets or simply stayed home with a novel.  Then Nancy noticed that there was something wrong with her husband's fish stories.  ``He'd come home with these wonderful tales about seeing whales and catching giant tuna,'' she told Evans, ``but I realized, I was just hearing the stories. I wasn't in them.''  At Evans's suggestion, Nancy came up with a plan. She goes on the boat a lot now but never without a book. Nancy enjoys reading during the more mundane parts, but she's also there to marvel when they see a giant turtle.  And when it's her turn to curl up with a book, he practices his fishing knots next to her on the same couch.  Two caveats: Blending interests only works when both partners share in the blending. And although it's great when it happens, partners with opposite interests can't always blend them, Evans warns. THE OPTIMIST &AMP; THE PESSIMIST: OPPOSITE OUTLOOKS  Jane, a Boston lawyer, was enticed, she says, by Randy's ``happy face and sunny outlook.'' And Jane, says Randy, was ``the most interesting, grounded woman'' he ever met.  When they married six years ago, they began to live the way they'd been brought up: Randy, a reporter, focuses not on problems but on finding solutions, and he believes that he and Jane can always turn roadblocks into opportunities. When he lost his job recently, he wasn't crushed _ he was confident that he'd find another.  Jane is steady and intelligent, but worry and distrust are her middle names. She often thinks Randy's being childish. In a shrinking economy she's sure he won't find another job. The two are wearing each other down. Is there any hope?  Cutter offers two coping tricks to help achieve a balance between negativity and positivity: ``When Randy Optimist is having a really difficult time with Janie Pessimist, he might try picturing her when she was 5,'' Cutter suggests.  Seeing your partner as a vulnerable child, Cutter says, helps you understand and respect her way of looking at life. It makes her an endearing _ instead of a cranky _ character.  If two opposite personalities can learn to talk peacefully and try to understand, then sometimes draw from each other's reverse outlook, a remarkable balance certainly can be achieved, Evans says.  Randy and Jane might try working out a ``best-case'' and a ``worst-case'' scenario for any given threat. The idea is to temper his enthusiasm while uplifting her gloominess. Working together, they will see that growth and strength lie in emotional moderation. THE SPENDER &AMP; THE SAVER: OPPOSITE IMPULSES  After 13 years of a difficult marriage, Sara from Colorado is doubtful that either she or Michael have many strengths the other needs _ or wants.  When they met, she was drawn to his financial stability and his quiet reticence. Like a moth to flame, he flew to the way she made him laugh.  Today she wouldn't give 5 cents for his quiet, and he doesn't find her so funny anymore.  Sara is a generous spirit. Her strongest impulse is to spend her money and to share her dreams and thoughts with all her friends, not just Michael.  She has a full-time job, and her checking and savings accounts are in both their names.  Conversely, Michael's deepest impulse is to hoard. His bank account is in his name alone: ``What's mine is mine, what's hers is ours because I earn more'' is the way he looks at finances. He also shares very little emotionally.  It's not too late for this couple to see that they have reconcilable differences, says Dr. Harville Hendrix, co-author of ``The Couples Companion'' (Pocket, 1994). And with work, they can weave gold from chaff.  ``They should recognize that both too much giving and too much hoarding are defenses,'' Hendrix says. ``The generous spirit and the miserly mate must understand each other's motivations.''  Giving, Hendrix says, is, among other things, a subtle attempt to get others to love you. Most ultragenerous spirits are trying very hard to build a wall against loneliness, which would make them too vulnerable. They think if they give things of value away _ and that includes emotions _ people will be devoted to them and that will be a defense against being alone.  The miserly mate is also trying to make something happen: He wants to feel secure, and he fears he hasn't enough resources or emotions to share. If he lets down his guard, tells his secrets or spends his money, he'll be exposed and vulnerable.  What to do? The answer, like most good solutions, is disarmingly simple. Hendrix says that ``each must understand that the other's difference is precisely what's missing in themselves and then try to develop in themselves some of what they most object to in their partners.''  The miser must try to share more and protect less. He might start, Evans says, with joint banking accounts to promote trust in the marriage (both might still keep small separate accounts so each still has autonomy, and neither has to ask ``permission'' to spend money).  The emotional hoarder must also attempt to give his partner more access to his inner world _ even if it doesn't immediately feel safe. When it becomes a habit, it will start to feel safe.  The partner who gives everything away needs to put limits on her largesse, needs to incorporate a bit of her mate's hoarding behavior. She has to understand that keeping some things to herself doesn't diminish but enhances her desirability to others, Hendrix says. -0- SIDEBAR: TURNING YOUR DIFFERENCES INTO STRENGTHS  These conflict-resolution methods will help keep you and your spouse close.  _ Check assumptions before leaping to conclusions. Agree to stop for a moment at an ``outlook impasse'' and entertain the possibility that this time the other's outlook may be right.  For example, she notices her wallet is gone and assumes it's stolen. He says she probably left it at home. Each must listen to each other's reasons for their conclusions _ then figure out together the most logical one.  No sarcasm is allowed.  _ Role play. Every few weeks, agree to creep into each other's skin for a day. He will try not to be Pollyanna, and she will not dwell on wort-case scenarios.  At any given crisis during the day, each must promise to think, ``What would my spouse do?'' Then each will do it in the other's way.  This approach gives spouses permission to step back and take another route other than the programmed one. It works.  _ Get funny. Try to look at your spouse's outlooks in a humorous way and don't take things too seriously. Laughing at yourself is a lovable act, and lovable acts cement relationships. (Sherry Suib Cohen is a New York city-based free-lance writer.) -------------------------------------------------  (To publish this ``separate buy'' article it must be purchased -- the rate is not prohibitive -- from one of these New York Times Syndicate sales representatives:  (--Europe and Asia: KARL HORWITZ in Paris at 47-42-17-11; fax, 47-42-80-44 or 47-42-18-81; telex, 282-942.  (--Mexico, Central America, South America: PAUL FINCH in Los Angeles, 310-996-0075; fax, 310-996-0089.  (--U.S., Canada and the Pacific: CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City, 816-822-8448 or fax her at 816-822-1444. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960624.0422 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-WILL-SMITH-IN-`INDEPENDENCE-DAY'-PAGEUP-ART-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> WILL SMITH CELEBRATES ``INDEPENDENCE DAY'' (This ``separate buy'' article is from this week's PageUp Lifestyle and Entertainment Package.) (To publish this article, it must be purchased _ the rate is not prohibitive _ from New York Times Syndicate sales representative CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City at 1-800-444-0267 or 816-822-8448, or by fax her at 816-822-1444.) (She also has information on how to subscribe to PageUp, a weekly package of eight intriguing articles with color art.) Includes a color slide of Will Smith in a scene from ``Independence Day.'' By CINDY PEARLMAN World rights except Chicago (Distributed by New York Times Special Features)  What is it about Will Smith and aliens?  He battles extraterrestrial invaders in his role as a cocky, gifted Marine fighter pilot in ``Independence Day,'' opening July 3.  But while awaiting release of that film, which might be the summer's biggest hit, Smith is in a muggy New York City, on the set of ``Men in Black'' _ and he's chasing aliens again.  ``Men in Black,'' co-starring Tommy Lee Jones, is based on a popular comic book. It casts Smith as a New York City police officer recruited by the Men in Black, an elite force who combat aliens living among us.  ``I must have been crowned the alien man,'' Smith says with a laugh. ``The next thing you'll hear is that I've signed up for `Alien 4' with Sigourney Weaver. The poster will read, `Will Smith IS the Alien.'''  Alien-fighting is a strange business.  ``Tommy Lee Jones is my partner,'' explains Smith over the phone from his trailer on the set. ``This morning, Tommy Lee blew this guy's head off in front of me. I was about to arrest Tommy Lee for murder. All of a sudden his victim's head grew back.  ``It's pretty creepy stuff.''  Filming the $70-million ``Independence Day'' was less bizarre, he says. In fact, it was downright boring.  ``When I would look in the sky, I didn't see the aliens. They were put in later with a computer,'' Smith says. ``So I'd be standing there looking at nothing but clouds and then I would have to freak out.''  Even the air combat scenes were exercises in imagination.  ``There were no other jets or little green guys flying them,'' he says. ``I was just sitting there in this easy chair throwing my body around and yelling, `Explosion!' or `There must be 12,000 aliens in that spaceship!'  ``Anyone could do it at home.''  Given his apparent specialization in alien movies, what does Smith think about real-life ETs?  ``I just think it is arrogant for us to believe we are the only life force (in the universe),'' he answers. ``How can we think we're it?  ``I have to say that my dreams are getting a little weird. I'm getting beamed to a lot of places. Weird little people show up. I think, `Will, you have to get a hobby or something.' I just can't stop thinking about aliens.  ``Everywhere I go, it's the same thing. I'm in a restaurant and the waitress will say, `Will, do you want fries with that and do you believe in aliens?' People seem very excited about it.''  After six years as television's ``Fresh Prince of Bel Air,'' Smith is excited about a movie career that has taken off. Offers are pouring in, including a sequel to ``Bad Boys'' (1995), his hit action film that cracked the $100 million mark.  ``It's funny. This June marks my 10th anniversary in show business,'' the 28-year-old says. ``In many ways it seems like I just started. Then I have days where everything just seems to be happening too quickly.''  Smith was born in Philadelphia, where he grew up with two sisters and a brother. His mother worked with the school board, his father at an ice company.  Despite his raffish charm and quick wit, Smith was not the class clown as a boy, he says.  ``I was a little shy, especially with women. I was interested in computer engineering. Math was my best subject, and I thought I'd have a nice little 9-to-5 job someday.''  It was his hobby that derailed those plans: In his spare time, Smith liked to rap.  ``It was just something to do,'' he recalls. ``I started rapping at age 12, but I never had big plans to cut a record or anything.''  In 1986, Smith and Jeff Townes formed a group, D.J. Jazzy Jeff and The Fresh Prince. During his senior year of high school, a talent scout from Jive records heard their music. One month before high-school graduation, Jive released the duo's first record, ``Girls Ain't Nothing But Trouble.''  The group earned a 1988 Grammy Award for best rap performance for ``Parents Just Don't Understand,'' the hit single from their second album, ``He's the DJ, I'm the Rapper.'' They also won a Grammy for the single ``Summertime,'' from their fourth album, ``Homebase,'' which was released in 1991 and went platinum.  When producing legend Quincy Jones heard their music and called Smith to offer him the lead role in ``Fresh Prince of Belair,'' the rapper didn't have to think twice.  ``At the time, I thought, `Why not? I'm just so very good. I'm talented, I should have a TV series.' I'm so cocky!'' he says.  ``After six years on `Fresh Prince,' I'm gonna miss it a little bit,'' Smith admits. ``I do keep in touch with everyone. Our job was to have fun on that set and there are wonderful memories. You just can't spend your life looking back.''  Throughout the run of the series, Smith had used his hiatuses for film roles in such features as ``Where the Day Takes You'' (1992), ``Six Degrees of Separation'' (1993) and ``Made in America'' (1993). Now, with the series having ended, he can be a movie machine if he likes.  ``All these offers roll in,'' he says. ``It's hard to know what to do or who to trust to steer me in the right direction.  ``I trust me. That's the only person you can really trust in this business. People in this business just want to make money off you, and usually it's not in your best interests. I'm excited about a movie career, but cautious too.''  In an effort to revive his musical career, he plans to spend more time in New York, which wasn't possible during the run of ``Fresh Prince.''  ``There is just no creative inspiration in Los Angeles. It pulls my creativity down,'' Smith says. ``There's a huge difference between New York and Los Angeles in the way rap music is performed. In New York, I feel there is more hope in the music and more comedy. That's what I like.''  The end of the series will also give him more time to spend with his son, Willard C. Smith III, nicknamed ``Trey.'' Smith is divorced from his son's mother and is currently dating actress Jada Pinkett, who stars this summer in ``The Nutty Professor.''  Feeling a little played out, Smith says he will take the rest of the summer off after ``Men in Black'' wraps.  ``Jada and I talk about doing something together. We've got to strengthen the relationship first. You must get yourselves together first, before you put a movie in the mix. Otherwise you just get too stressed out.''  Not that Smith isn't enjoying his success.  ``I'm not shy with girls anymore,'' he says. ``Seriously, for the first time in my life, I feel that women like me. There was always the other guy. I was always told, `Will is fun and he makes me laugh.' I was always the best friend and it stunk. Now women like me better.''  And why not? You never know when you may need to chase away some aliens, and Will Smith is a good man to have around for that sort of thing.  But not to hear him tell it. This Independence Day, his plans don't involve any world-saving.  ``I'll be at the barbecue,'' he says. ``I'm the grill man. The only thing I'll be saving is the hamburgers from falling into the flames.'' c.1996 Cindy Pearlman  (Cindy Pearlman is a Chicago-based free-lance writer.) (To publish this article, it must be purchased _ the rate is not prohibitive _ from New York Times Syndicate sales representative CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City at 1-800-444-0267 or 816-822-8448, or by fax her at 816-822-1444.) (She also has information on how to subscribe to PageUp, a weekly package of eight intriguing articles with color art.) ------------------------------------------------- </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960624.0423 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-HOOTIE-AND-THE-BLOWFISH-PAGEUP-ART-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> ATTN MIDWEST: IL./MICH./MO./OHIO/TENN./WIS. HOOTING AND HOLLERING: ON THE ROAD WITH HOOTIE AND THE BLOWFISH (This ``separate buy'' article is from this week's PageUp Lifestyle and Entertainment Package.) (To publish this article, it must be purchased _ the rate is not prohibitive _ from New York Times Syndicate sales representative CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City at 1-800-444-0267 or 816-822-8448, or by fax her at 816-822-1444.) (She also has information on how to subscribe to PageUp, a weekly package of eight intriguing articles with color art.) Includes a color slide of the band Hootie and the Blowfish and a sidebar listing the band's July tour dates in the Midwest. By JEANNE WOLF (Distributed by New York Times Special Features)  No tuxedos for Hootie and the Blowfish, not even when they appeared on the Grammys or sang for royalty in Monaco.  ``We're just not a tux band,'' lead singer Darius Rucker explains. ``We've borrowed tuxes for some shows because it was a respect thing, but that's not us.''  No problem for this astoundingly successful band. They can wear and sing whatever they want in the wake of their record-setting first album. More than 13 million copies of ``Cracked Rear View'' (1994) were sold, and the record was still on the charts when they went back to the studio to record their much-awaited follow-up album, ``Fairweather Johnson.''  It's no coincidence that this very American group headed off on a European tour shortly after the new album came out in May.  ``We wanted to get away from all the hype and everything,'' Rucker says bluntly, ``'cause, you know, hype sucks.''  The band has encountered plenty of hype _ unsurprisingly so, given that theirs was the second-best-selling debut album in recording history, trailing only Boston's 1976 first effort.  But with the hype came intimidatingly high expectations for their second album, along with fears of the dreaded ``sophomore jinx'' which has made many artists' second albums into disappointments. Many predicted that these South Carolina college buddies, more used to playing minor clubs and small gigs all over the South, would crumble under the pressure.  But Rucker says that when they hit the studio they were fearless.  ``We had a lot of ideas and we weren't worried about it. We were just ready to do another album and we weren't scared at all.''  The group also was ready for flak from critics, who have never really been kind to them.  ``We worried about the critics at first, but not any more,'' Rucker says. ``We figured out that the media didn't sell our record. First it was the music and then it was the radio and then people just seemed to like it.''  ``We had pressure on ourselves, but from a different angle,'' agrees bassist Dean Felber. ``We're a live band and we wanted to tour, and in order to do that we needed new songs. And we were kind of worn out on the old stuff.  ``All of the pressure we put on ourselves is easier pressure to handle than when it's outside sources pushing you in a certain direction. We got to pick our own course.''  Felber says the group was braced for inevitable, probably unfavorable comparisons to its first album.  ``You can't expect something like that twice,'' he says. ``We didn't expect it the first time, you know _ it was kind of a gift. It was timing or whatever.''  He shrugs.  ``To create that twice in a row ... I don't know if that could be done.''  Guitarist Mark Bryan says that they were eager to try some new ideas.  ``I'm proud that we're still growing. I'm proud of our songwriting abilities, which are maturing,'' he says. ``I enjoy the songs from `Fairweather Johnson' the way I enjoyed the songs from `Cracked Rear View' when we first wrote them.  ``Most of all, I enjoy everyone getting together and playing. We can still have fun together and also make our music better.''  ``Fairweather Johnson'' has been in the top five since its debut. Now, as the group hits the road, Bryan looks forward to the chance to bring the new songs to live audiences.  ``We are trying as hard as we can to be anti-hype,'' he says. ``It's much more fun to just worry about your music and just play and not read about yourself every day.''  All the band members stress the group's commitment to live performances and present themselves as anti-stars _ working-guy musicians devoid of star glitter.  ``A six-week European tour, and two nights before I'm like, `OK, I gotta pack,''' Felber says. He claims that his secret to traveling comfort is to bring only two weeks' worth of clothing and do laundry every two weeks.  Bryan tries to see as much as he can in each new city they visit. He also calls home every day.  ``I try to talk to my wife every night,'' he says. ``It's important to keep yourself involved in your life back home.''  Drummer Jim ``Soni'' Sonefeld sums up his slant on the European experience:  ``It's pretty here but I can't afford a hamburger _ $38 for a burger! That's wild!''  ``We are not used to these four-star hotels,'' Felber says with a smile. ``You gotta understand, the nicest place in town in a lot of the cities we play is just an ordinary motel. I keep kidding that we don't really belong in this kind of luxury.''  And how do these hot young rockers spent their time on the road? Do they trash hotel rooms, party into the night or cruise the night scene?  No, because it might interfere with their real passion: This may be the world's only rock band which also makes up a foursome for golf.  ``Everyone asks us if success spoiled us,'' Sonefeld says. ``About golf, I can say yes! We get to play some of the nicest courses in the country and sometimes in the world.  ``We know there are people that are much more deserving who would die to play on these courses and they can't. We've been playing them for free, and we stink. We've been spoiled in that world.''  Another unusual aspect of this band is that, at least from an outsider's perspective, they reveal few signs of artistic or personal conflicts. To all appearances, all four Blowfish get along amazingly well, exchanging good-natured barbs and clearly enjoying what they do. Their only real conflicts arise from business discussions:  ``The biggest chafe these days is just trying to separate business from our music, 'cause business has become a big part of it,'' Sonefeld says. ``There's a lot of responsibility that comes with success and you've got to sit there and sort it out.  ``Though counting money isn't the biggest problem in the world to have, it can chafe people the wrong way when you're tired and you've just finished a big concert and the last thing you want to discuss is payroll taxes and investments.  ``We are all truly grateful, but we're in this for the music,'' he continues. ``And when you have to get into all these business details it can be a bit of a pain in the (butt), and tempers run a little short.''  He grins.  ``It's not a joking matter, (but) we're such lighthearted people and we still want to joke sometimes. I admit I'm the worst at it.''  Onstage, though, any lingering annoyance disappears, Sonefeld says.  ``It's not about money. It's not about anything in the world other than playing the music. That's the reason we all got together in the first place. It's what brings you back to the first time you ever had a gig together, you know. You've got your instrument, you've got your microphone and the crowd gets going. It's great!''  So great, in fact, that the musicians occasionally can't believe it, Rucker says. They are a long way from taking it for granted.  ``We were sitting around last night just having a beer,'' Rucker says, ``and thinking, `This is all part of the fantasy.'  ``And it's like I never want to wake up. Because I swear this is a dream, and one day my alarm's gonna go off and I'm going to be waking up in Charleston, S.C. and heading to the Music Forum to play a show.'' c.1996 Pentacom Productions  (Jeanne Wolf, who is based in Hollywood, reports on the entertainment industry for television, radio and print outlets.)  -0- SIDEBAR: HOOTIE AND THE BLOWFISH ON TOUR  This summer's tour will bring Hootie and the Blowfish to sites throughout the United States, including the following July dates: July 7, Mears, Mich.; July 8, Nobelsville, Mich.; July 9, St. Louis, Mo.; July 10, Kansas City, Kan.; July 12, Tinley Park, Ill.; July 13, East Troy, Wis.; July 14, Columbus, Ohio; July 16-17, Clarkston, Mich.; July 18, Cleveland, Ohio; July 21, Nashville, Tenn.; July 23, Cincinnati, Ohio; July 26, Burgettstown, Penn.; July 27-28, Bristow, Va.; July 30-31, New York City. The tour continues through September 22.
