(--Europe and Asia: KARL HORWITZ in Paris at 47-42-17-11; fax, 47-42-80-44 or 47-42-18-81; telex, 282-942. (--Mexico, Central America, South America: PAUL FINCH in Los Angeles, 310-996-0075; fax, 310-996-0089. (Distributed by New York Times Syndicate) By PEGGY NOONAN c.1996 Longevity (Distributed by New York Times Syndicate.) EDITORS: Please note ``(T)'' in the computer addresses below equates to a tilde sign, which cannot be transmitted into newspaper computer systems).  Within the reaches of the information superhighway lies the World Wide Web, a vast subsystem that's even faster and easier to access than the Internet.  Since its creation in 1989, the Web has exploded into hundreds of thousands of home pages, or Web sites. The possibilities for researching a particular health topic boggle the mind.  No matter which home page you start with, by following hypertext clues (text that's colored to lead you to other sites at the click of a mouse), you can end up browsing everything from the National Institutes of Health to research abstracts at a European university.  You'll find a wealth of information covering the conventional and unconventional in medicine and health: hospitals, dentistry, women's health, heart health, cancer, diabetes, plastic surgery, mental health, foot care, even ``Rogaine Online'' _ and that's just a sampling.  Understanding of the topic is often enhanced by superior graphics. If you want to check into herbal medicine, for instance, it's a great help to ``see'' the herbs you're reading about. Try the herbal photo gallery at Herbal Hall (http://www.crl.com/(T)robbee/herbal.html), as well as a menu of other selections from ``Longevity Herbs-Adaptogens-Nutritives'' to ``Herbal-Medical Dictionary.''  Or you could start at the Alternative Medicine Homepage (http://www.pitt.edu/(T)cbw/altm.html), which describes itself as ``a jumpstation for sources of information on unconventional, unorthodox, unproven or alternative, innovative, integrative therapies.''  From there, you're a mouse-click away from a pool of newsletters, access to mailing lists and commercial databases, bulletin boards and files for such selections as Kombucha (the medicinal mushroom), music therapy, massage, chiropractic and acupuncture.  Want to get the latest on food guides for ovo-lacto vegetarians? Check out the Vegetarian Society and its related Web pages for everything you ever wanted to know about vegetarianism.  If there's a nip or tuck in your future, set your Web-searching tool for ``plastic surgery'' and browse through plastic surgery-focused home pages, such as the University of California Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery page, a list of plastic surgery medical journals called Plink or hundreds of other publications, each outfitted with hypertext links of its own.  You'll find a dazzling array, including information-jammed text files, charts, graphs, drawings, diagrams, photos and, in some cases, even sound-bytes and movies on nearly every subject you can imagine.  The World Wide web is a home for ``hundreds of resources from schools, hospitals, health-care professionals, informed amateurs, former patients and charlatans,'' says Abbot Chambers, editor of the Whole Internet Catalog (http://gnn.com/wic/index.html), which is online.  ``In short, it's a mirror of everything going on in society at large.''  Following is a selection of home pages on health topics; use these as a jumping-off point for hundreds of related pages  _ Women's health resources: Click onto the Women's Medical Health Page (http://www.best.com/(T)sirlou/sheimp.html) spotlights recent publications and medical issues, such as RU486 (abortion-pill) alternatives.  _ Back pain: Check out the Cleveland Clinic Department of Neurological Surgery (http://www.neus.ccf.org/). It provides ``Frequently Asked Questions'' (FAQ) files about neurology and educational material on disorders of the brain, spinal cord and peripheral nervous system.  It also includes a description of the facility's services and personnel, and it lists links to other resources.  _ Heart health: Click onto the University of California at Irvine (UCI) Heart Disease Prevention Program's site (http://www.reg.uci.edu/UCI/CARDIOLOGY/PREVENTIVE/). UCI offers an extensive program, including information about risk factors and updates on research, especially ongoing studies at UCI.  At the American College of Cardiology (ACC) Web site (http://www.acc.org), visitors will find information about the ACC, clinical practice publications, ACC educational programs, computer applications and related topics.  _ Cancer: CancerGuide, Steve Dunn's Cancer Information Page (http://cancerguide.org) is a guide created by a cancer survivor ``for patients who want to understand more about the disease and their treatment options.''  It offers information on researching medical literature, including accessing medline, the world's most powerful medical database; updates on clinical trials; data on specific cancers, rare cancers and bone marrow transplants and alternative therapies, such as bovine cartilage.  _ Customized advice about health concerns: Try Go Ask Alice (http://www.columbia.edu/cu/healthwise/alice.html), an interactive health service where online visitors post questions anonymously on any health topic _ from fitness to alcohol to sexual health.  _ Depression: Depression FAQ (http://avocado.pc.helsinki.fi/81/%7Ejanne/asdfaq/) Chambers calls ``a fine example of the sort of mutually supportive documents available on the Web.''  It provides a depression primer, FAQ files on depression's causes, treatments and medications and tips on finding appropriate doctors.  _ Miscellaneous: Rogaine online is at (http://www2.nfic.com/Rogaine/) or (http://www2.igroup.com/Rogaine/index.html). Both addresses provide the same page and same information.  The Vegetarian Society (http://catless.ncl.ac.uk/veg/) offers links to the major vegetarian sites as well as information about vegetarianism and related topics.  Please note: many of these website addresses are subject to change. (Peggy Noonan is an Edgewater, Colo.-based free-lance writer.) -------------------------------------------------  (To publish this ``separate buy'' article it must be purchased -- the rate is not prohibitive -- from one of these New York Times Syndicate sales representatives:  (--Europe and Asia: KARL HORWITZ in Paris at 47-42-17-11; fax, 47-42-80-44 or 47-42-18-81; telex, 282-942.  (--Mexico, Central America, South America: PAUL FINCH in Los Angeles, 310-996-0075; fax, 310-996-0089.  (--U.S., Canada and the Pacific: CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City, 816-822-8448 or fax her at 816-822-1444. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960624.0425 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-OPPOSITES-KEEP-THEIR-MARRIAGES-HAPPY-PAGEUP-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> WHEN OPPOSITES ATTRACT AND THEN DETRACT: HOW CAN A MARRIAGE STAY HAPPY? (To publish this ``separate buy'' article it must be purchased -- the rate is not prohibitive -- from one of these New York Times Syndicate sales representatives:  (--U.S., Canada and the Pacific: CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City, 816-822-8448 or fax her at 816-822-1444.  (--Europe and Asia: KARL HORWITZ in Paris at 47-42-17-11; fax, 47-42-80-44 or 47-42-18-81; telex, 282-942.  (--Mexico, Central America, South America: PAUL FINCH in Los Angeles, 310-996-0075; fax, 310-996-0089. (Distributed by New York Times Syndicate) Includes a 200-word sidebar By SHERRY SUIB COHEN c.1996 Family Circle North American rights only. (Distributed by New York Times Syndicate.)  There's something captivating about an opposite. Passion is aroused by a jolt of differences: It's exciting.  The opposite natures of couples can lend a marriage its most exciting challenges _ and balance. The very best marriages thrive on growth and change. But what if your differences become annoyances? Or worse, obstacles to your marriage?  What follows are four combinations of disparate individuals (all names have been changed) who are married to each other. If you find yourself in one or more categories, read on for tips on transforming your differences into strengths. THE INTROVERT &AMP; EXTROVERT: OPPOSITE TYPES  ``Steve was intensely private,'' says Ann from Florida. ``At first, it seemed intriguing and romantic.''  But after six months of marriage, ``the silence got dull. We're so different socially. I love people; his inspiration comes from empty rooms. Are we in trouble?''  ``We're talking about issues of safety here,'' says Rebecca Cutter, a Portland, Ore., psychotherapist and author of ``When Opposites Attract (Plume/Penguin, 1995).  Understanding is the key. The extrovert must recognize why her spouse won't choose to be social (he feels unsafe), and minimize the perceived danger for him. She should never put him in the spotlight without his prior knowledge (surprise parties are a definite no).  When the introvert trusts his mate, Cutter says, he'll risk a little more social activity knowing she won't do anything to hurt him (like desert him in a crowded room).  By the same token, the introvert must maximize the variety in the partners' lives or risk deadening the liveliness of the marriage.  ``Invigorating changes _ more travel, for example _ keep the relationship vital,'' Cutter says.  Another approach comes from Sybil Evans, president of Sybil Evans Associates, a New York organization specializing in conflict resolution.  ``We look for an `integrated solution' that satisfies both,'' Evans says, ``instead of the traditional `compromise' where neither ends up happy.''  For example, a traditional compromise might consist of Steve's reluctantly agreeing to a large party one week if Ann says yes to staying home the next. But rest assured, Evans says, that even though it's a compromise, he'll hate the party, and she'll feel like a prisoner at home. Both may become bitter and blame each other.  But here's the integrated approach: hosting a quiet, two-couple dinner instead of attending a large affair. The intimate party will satisfy Ann's need to interact with others, and it will meet her husband's need to limit socializing to a few people rather than having to painfully cruise a crowd. THE FISHERMAN &AMP; THE READER: OPPOSITE INTERESTS  ``Nancy was a client of mine,'' Evans says. ``At first, the city-lover in her was drawn to the outdoorsy him. But just because the ocean interested him didn't mean she wanted to do battle with 6-foot waves.''  The relationship worked all right initially _ when he went off to do things with worms and sharks, she explored the flea markets or simply stayed home with a novel.  Then Nancy noticed that there was something wrong with her husband's fish stories.  ``He'd come home with these wonderful tales about seeing whales and catching giant tuna,'' she told Evans, ``but I realized, I was just hearing the stories. I wasn't in them.''  At Evans's suggestion, Nancy came up with a plan. She goes on the boat a lot now but never without a book. Nancy enjoys reading during the more mundane parts, but she's also there to marvel when they see a giant turtle.  And when it's her turn to curl up with a book, he practices his fishing knots next to her on the same couch.  Two caveats: Blending interests only works when both partners share in the blending. And although it's great when it happens, partners with opposite interests can't always blend them, Evans warns. THE OPTIMIST &AMP; THE PESSIMIST: OPPOSITE OUTLOOKS  Jane, a Boston lawyer, was enticed, she says, by Randy's ``happy face and sunny outlook.'' And Jane, says Randy, was ``the most interesting, grounded woman'' he ever met.  When they married six years ago, they began to live the way they'd been brought up: Randy, a reporter, focuses not on problems but on finding solutions, and he believes that he and Jane can always turn roadblocks into opportunities. When he lost his job recently, he wasn't crushed _ he was confident that he'd find another.  Jane is steady and intelligent, but worry and distrust are her middle names. She often thinks Randy's being childish. In a shrinking economy she's sure he won't find another job. The two are wearing each other down. Is there any hope?  Cutter offers two coping tricks to help achieve a balance between negativity and positivity: ``When Randy Optimist is having a really difficult time with Janie Pessimist, he might try picturing her when she was 5,'' Cutter suggests.  Seeing your partner as a vulnerable child, Cutter says, helps you understand and respect her way of looking at life. It makes her an endearing _ instead of a cranky _ character.  If two opposite personalities can learn to talk peacefully and try to understand, then sometimes draw from each other's reverse outlook, a remarkable balance certainly can be achieved, Evans says.  Randy and Jane might try working out a ``best-case'' and a ``worst-case'' scenario for any given threat. The idea is to temper his enthusiasm while uplifting her gloominess. Working together, they will see that growth and strength lie in emotional moderation. THE SPENDER &AMP; THE SAVER: OPPOSITE IMPULSES  After 13 years of a difficult marriage, Sara from Colorado is doubtful that either she or Michael have many strengths the other needs _ or wants.  When they met, she was drawn to his financial stability and his quiet reticence. Like a moth to flame, he flew to the way she made him laugh.  Today she wouldn't give 5 cents for his quiet, and he doesn't find her so funny anymore.  Sara is a generous spirit. Her strongest impulse is to spend her money and to share her dreams and thoughts with all her friends, not just Michael.  She has a full-time job, and her checking and savings accounts are in both their names.  Conversely, Michael's deepest impulse is to hoard. His bank account is in his name alone: ``What's mine is mine, what's hers is ours because I earn more'' is the way he looks at finances. He also shares very little emotionally.  It's not too late for this couple to see that they have reconcilable differences, says Dr. Harville Hendrix, co-author of ``The Couples Companion'' (Pocket, 1994). And with work, they can weave gold from chaff.  ``They should recognize that both too much giving and too much hoarding are defenses,'' Hendrix says. ``The generous spirit and the miserly mate must understand each other's motivations.''  Giving, Hendrix says, is, among other things, a subtle attempt to get others to love you. Most ultragenerous spirits are trying very hard to build a wall against loneliness, which would make them too vulnerable. They think if they give things of value away _ and that includes emotions _ people will be devoted to them and that will be a defense against being alone.  The miserly mate is also trying to make something happen: He wants to feel secure, and he fears he hasn't enough resources or emotions to share. If he lets down his guard, tells his secrets or spends his money, he'll be exposed and vulnerable.  What to do? The answer, like most good solutions, is disarmingly simple. Hendrix says that ``each must understand that the other's difference is precisely what's missing in themselves and then try to develop in themselves some of what they most object to in their partners.''  The miser must try to share more and protect less. He might start, Evans says, with joint banking accounts to promote trust in the marriage (both might still keep small separate accounts so each still has autonomy, and neither has to ask ``permission'' to spend money).  The emotional hoarder must also attempt to give his partner more access to his inner world _ even if it doesn't immediately feel safe. When it becomes a habit, it will start to feel safe.  The partner who gives everything away needs to put limits on her largesse, needs to incorporate a bit of her mate's hoarding behavior. She has to understand that keeping some things to herself doesn't diminish but enhances her desirability to others, Hendrix says. -0- SIDEBAR: TURNING YOUR DIFFERENCES INTO STRENGTHS  These conflict-resolution methods will help keep you and your spouse close.  _ Check assumptions before leaping to conclusions. Agree to stop for a moment at an ``outlook impasse'' and entertain the possibility that this time the other's outlook may be right.  For example, she notices her wallet is gone and assumes it's stolen. He says she probably left it at home. Each must listen to each other's reasons for their conclusions _ then figure out together the most logical one.  No sarcasm is allowed.  _ Role play. Every few weeks, agree to creep into each other's skin for a day. He will try not to be Pollyanna, and she will not dwell on wort-case scenarios.  At any given crisis during the day, each must promise to think, ``What would my spouse do?'' Then each will do it in the other's way.  This approach gives spouses permission to step back and take another route other than the programmed one. It works.  _ Get funny. Try to look at your spouse's outlooks in a humorous way and don't take things too seriously. Laughing at yourself is a lovable act, and lovable acts cement relationships. (Sherry Suib Cohen is a New York city-based free-lance writer.) -------------------------------------------------  (To publish this ``separate buy'' article it must be purchased -- the rate is not prohibitive -- from one of these New York Times Syndicate sales representatives:  (--Europe and Asia: KARL HORWITZ in Paris at 47-42-17-11; fax, 47-42-80-44 or 47-42-18-81; telex, 282-942.  (--Mexico, Central America, South America: PAUL FINCH in Los Angeles, 310-996-0075; fax, 310-996-0089.  (--U.S., Canada and the Pacific: CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City, 816-822-8448 or fax her at 816-822-1444. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960624.0426 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-WILL-SMITH-IN-`INDEPENDENCE-DAY'-PAGEUP-ART-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> WILL SMITH CELEBRATES ``INDEPENDENCE DAY'' (This ``separate buy'' article is from this week's PageUp Lifestyle and Entertainment Package.) (To publish this article, it must be purchased _ the rate is not prohibitive _ from New York Times Syndicate sales representative CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City at 1-800-444-0267 or 816-822-8448, or by fax her at 816-822-1444.) (She also has information on how to subscribe to PageUp, a weekly package of eight intriguing articles with color art.) Includes a color slide of Will Smith in a scene from ``Independence Day.'' By CINDY PEARLMAN World rights except Chicago (Distributed by New York Times Special Features)  What is it about Will Smith and aliens?  He battles extraterrestrial invaders in his role as a cocky, gifted Marine fighter pilot in ``Independence Day,'' opening July 3.  But while awaiting release of that film, which might be the summer's biggest hit, Smith is in a muggy New York City, on the set of ``Men in Black'' _ and he's chasing aliens again.  ``Men in Black,'' co-starring Tommy Lee Jones, is based on a popular comic book. It casts Smith as a New York City police officer recruited by the Men in Black, an elite force who combat aliens living among us.  ``I must have been crowned the alien man,'' Smith says with a laugh. ``The next thing you'll hear is that I've signed up for `Alien 4' with Sigourney Weaver. The poster will read, `Will Smith IS the Alien.'''  Alien-fighting is a strange business.  ``Tommy Lee Jones is my partner,'' explains Smith over the phone from his trailer on the set. ``This morning, Tommy Lee blew this guy's head off in front of me. I was about to arrest Tommy Lee for murder. All of a sudden his victim's head grew back.  ``It's pretty creepy stuff.''  Filming the $70-million ``Independence Day'' was less bizarre, he says. In fact, it was downright boring.  ``When I would look in the sky, I didn't see the aliens. They were put in later with a computer,'' Smith says. ``So I'd be standing there looking at nothing but clouds and then I would have to freak out.''  Even the air combat scenes were exercises in imagination.  ``There were no other jets or little green guys flying them,'' he says. ``I was just sitting there in this easy chair throwing my body around and yelling, `Explosion!' or `There must be 12,000 aliens in that spaceship!'  ``Anyone could do it at home.''  Given his apparent specialization in alien movies, what does Smith think about real-life ETs?  ``I just think it is arrogant for us to believe we are the only life force (in the universe),'' he answers. ``How can we think we're it?  ``I have to say that my dreams are getting a little weird. I'm getting beamed to a lot of places. Weird little people show up. I think, `Will, you have to get a hobby or something.' I just can't stop thinking about aliens.  ``Everywhere I go, it's the same thing. I'm in a restaurant and the waitress will say, `Will, do you want fries with that and do you believe in aliens?' People seem very excited about it.''  After six years as television's ``Fresh Prince of Bel Air,'' Smith is excited about a movie career that has taken off. Offers are pouring in, including a sequel to ``Bad Boys'' (1995), his hit action film that cracked the $100 million mark.  ``It's funny. This June marks my 10th anniversary in show business,'' the 28-year-old says. ``In many ways it seems like I just started. Then I have days where everything just seems to be happening too quickly.''  Smith was born in Philadelphia, where he grew up with two sisters and a brother. His mother worked with the school board, his father at an ice company.  Despite his raffish charm and quick wit, Smith was not the class clown as a boy, he says.  ``I was a little shy, especially with women. I was interested in computer engineering. Math was my best subject, and I thought I'd have a nice little 9-to-5 job someday.''  It was his hobby that derailed those plans: In his spare time, Smith liked to rap.  ``It was just something to do,'' he recalls. ``I started rapping at age 12, but I never had big plans to cut a record or anything.''  In 1986, Smith and Jeff Townes formed a group, D.J. Jazzy Jeff and The Fresh Prince. During his senior year of high school, a talent scout from Jive records heard their music. One month before high-school graduation, Jive released the duo's first record, ``Girls Ain't Nothing But Trouble.''  The group earned a 1988 Grammy Award for best rap performance for ``Parents Just Don't Understand,'' the hit single from their second album, ``He's the DJ, I'm the Rapper.'' They also won a Grammy for the single ``Summertime,'' from their fourth album, ``Homebase,'' which was released in 1991 and went platinum.  When producing legend Quincy Jones heard their music and called Smith to offer him the lead role in ``Fresh Prince of Belair,'' the rapper didn't have to think twice.  ``At the time, I thought, `Why not? I'm just so very good. I'm talented, I should have a TV series.' I'm so cocky!'' he says.  ``After six years on `Fresh Prince,' I'm gonna miss it a little bit,'' Smith admits. ``I do keep in touch with everyone. Our job was to have fun on that set and there are wonderful memories. You just can't spend your life looking back.''  Throughout the run of the series, Smith had used his hiatuses for film roles in such features as ``Where the Day Takes You'' (1992), ``Six Degrees of Separation'' (1993) and ``Made in America'' (1993). Now, with the series having ended, he can be a movie machine if he likes.  ``All these offers roll in,'' he says. ``It's hard to know what to do or who to trust to steer me in the right direction.  ``I trust me. That's the only person you can really trust in this business. People in this business just want to make money off you, and usually it's not in your best interests. I'm excited about a movie career, but cautious too.''  In an effort to revive his musical career, he plans to spend more time in New York, which wasn't possible during the run of ``Fresh Prince.''  ``There is just no creative inspiration in Los Angeles. It pulls my creativity down,'' Smith says. ``There's a huge difference between New York and Los Angeles in the way rap music is performed. In New York, I feel there is more hope in the music and more comedy. That's what I like.''  The end of the series will also give him more time to spend with his son, Willard C. Smith III, nicknamed ``Trey.'' Smith is divorced from his son's mother and is currently dating actress Jada Pinkett, who stars this summer in ``The Nutty Professor.''  Feeling a little played out, Smith says he will take the rest of the summer off after ``Men in Black'' wraps.  ``Jada and I talk about doing something together. We've got to strengthen the relationship first. You must get yourselves together first, before you put a movie in the mix. Otherwise you just get too stressed out.''  Not that Smith isn't enjoying his success.  ``I'm not shy with girls anymore,'' he says. ``Seriously, for the first time in my life, I feel that women like me. There was always the other guy. I was always told, `Will is fun and he makes me laugh.' I was always the best friend and it stunk. Now women like me better.''  And why not? You never know when you may need to chase away some aliens, and Will Smith is a good man to have around for that sort of thing.  But not to hear him tell it. This Independence Day, his plans don't involve any world-saving.  ``I'll be at the barbecue,'' he says. ``I'm the grill man. The only thing I'll be saving is the hamburgers from falling into the flames.'' c.1996 Cindy Pearlman  (Cindy Pearlman is a Chicago-based free-lance writer.) (To publish this article, it must be purchased _ the rate is not prohibitive _ from New York Times Syndicate sales representative CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City at 1-800-444-0267 or 816-822-8448, or by fax her at 816-822-1444.) (She also has information on how to subscribe to PageUp, a weekly package of eight intriguing articles with color art.) ------------------------------------------------- </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960624.0427 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-HOOTIE-AND-THE-BLOWFISH-PAGEUP-ART-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> ATTN MIDWEST: IL./MICH./MO./OHIO/TENN./WIS. HOOTING AND HOLLERING: ON THE ROAD WITH HOOTIE AND THE BLOWFISH (This ``separate buy'' article is from this week's PageUp Lifestyle and Entertainment Package.) (To publish this article, it must be purchased _ the rate is not prohibitive _ from New York Times Syndicate sales representative CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City at 1-800-444-0267 or 816-822-8448, or by fax her at 816-822-1444.) (She also has information on how to subscribe to PageUp, a weekly package of eight intriguing articles with color art.) Includes a color slide of the band Hootie and the Blowfish and a sidebar listing the band's July tour dates in the Midwest. By JEANNE WOLF (Distributed by New York Times Special Features)  No tuxedos for Hootie and the Blowfish, not even when they appeared on the Grammys or sang for royalty in Monaco.  ``We're just not a tux band,'' lead singer Darius Rucker explains. ``We've borrowed tuxes for some shows because it was a respect thing, but that's not us.''  No problem for this astoundingly successful band. They can wear and sing whatever they want in the wake of their record-setting first album. More than 13 million copies of ``Cracked Rear View'' (1994) were sold, and the record was still on the charts when they went back to the studio to record their much-awaited follow-up album, ``Fairweather Johnson.''  It's no coincidence that this very American group headed off on a European tour shortly after the new album came out in May.  ``We wanted to get away from all the hype and everything,'' Rucker says bluntly, ``'cause, you know, hype sucks.''  The band has encountered plenty of hype _ unsurprisingly so, given that theirs was the second-best-selling debut album in recording history, trailing only Boston's 1976 first effort.  But with the hype came intimidatingly high expectations for their second album, along with fears of the dreaded ``sophomore jinx'' which has made many artists' second albums into disappointments. Many predicted that these South Carolina college buddies, more used to playing minor clubs and small gigs all over the South, would crumble under the pressure.  But Rucker says that when they hit the studio they were fearless.  ``We had a lot of ideas and we weren't worried about it. We were just ready to do another album and we weren't scared at all.''  The group also was ready for flak from critics, who have never really been kind to them.  ``We worried about the critics at first, but not any more,'' Rucker says. ``We figured out that the media didn't sell our record. First it was the music and then it was the radio and then people just seemed to like it.''  ``We had pressure on ourselves, but from a different angle,'' agrees bassist Dean Felber. ``We're a live band and we wanted to tour, and in order to do that we needed new songs. And we were kind of worn out on the old stuff.  ``All of the pressure we put on ourselves is easier pressure to handle than when it's outside sources pushing you in a certain direction. We got to pick our own course.''  Felber says the group was braced for inevitable, probably unfavorable comparisons to its first album.  ``You can't expect something like that twice,'' he says. ``We didn't expect it the first time, you know _ it was kind of a gift. It was timing or whatever.''  He shrugs.  ``To create that twice in a row ... I don't know if that could be done.''  Guitarist Mark Bryan says that they were eager to try some new ideas.  ``I'm proud that we're still growing. I'm proud of our songwriting abilities, which are maturing,'' he says. ``I enjoy the songs from `Fairweather Johnson' the way I enjoyed the songs from `Cracked Rear View' when we first wrote them.  ``Most of all, I enjoy everyone getting together and playing. We can still have fun together and also make our music better.''  ``Fairweather Johnson'' has been in the top five since its debut. Now, as the group hits the road, Bryan looks forward to the chance to bring the new songs to live audiences.  ``We are trying as hard as we can to be anti-hype,'' he says. ``It's much more fun to just worry about your music and just play and not read about yourself every day.''  All the band members stress the group's commitment to live performances and present themselves as anti-stars _ working-guy musicians devoid of star glitter.  ``A six-week European tour, and two nights before I'm like, `OK, I gotta pack,''' Felber says. He claims that his secret to traveling comfort is to bring only two weeks' worth of clothing and do laundry every two weeks.  Bryan tries to see as much as he can in each new city they visit. He also calls home every day.  ``I try to talk to my wife every night,'' he says. ``It's important to keep yourself involved in your life back home.''  Drummer Jim ``Soni'' Sonefeld sums up his slant on the European experience:  ``It's pretty here but I can't afford a hamburger _ $38 for a burger! That's wild!''  ``We are not used to these four-star hotels,'' Felber says with a smile. ``You gotta understand, the nicest place in town in a lot of the cities we play is just an ordinary motel. I keep kidding that we don't really belong in this kind of luxury.''  And how do these hot young rockers spent their time on the road? Do they trash hotel rooms, party into the night or cruise the night scene?  No, because it might interfere with their real passion: This may be the world's only rock band which also makes up a foursome for golf.  ``Everyone asks us if success spoiled us,'' Sonefeld says. ``About golf, I can say yes! We get to play some of the nicest courses in the country and sometimes in the world.  ``We know there are people that are much more deserving who would die to play on these courses and they can't. We've been playing them for free, and we stink. We've been spoiled in that world.''  Another unusual aspect of this band is that, at least from an outsider's perspective, they reveal few signs of artistic or personal conflicts. To all appearances, all four Blowfish get along amazingly well, exchanging good-natured barbs and clearly enjoying what they do. Their only real conflicts arise from business discussions:  ``The biggest chafe these days is just trying to separate business from our music, 'cause business has become a big part of it,'' Sonefeld says. ``There's a lot of responsibility that comes with success and you've got to sit there and sort it out.  ``Though counting money isn't the biggest problem in the world to have, it can chafe people the wrong way when you're tired and you've just finished a big concert and the last thing you want to discuss is payroll taxes and investments.  ``We are all truly grateful, but we're in this for the music,'' he continues. ``And when you have to get into all these business details it can be a bit of a pain in the (butt), and tempers run a little short.''  He grins.  ``It's not a joking matter, (but) we're such lighthearted people and we still want to joke sometimes. I admit I'm the worst at it.''  Onstage, though, any lingering annoyance disappears, Sonefeld says.  ``It's not about money. It's not about anything in the world other than playing the music. That's the reason we all got together in the first place. It's what brings you back to the first time you ever had a gig together, you know. You've got your instrument, you've got your microphone and the crowd gets going. It's great!''  So great, in fact, that the musicians occasionally can't believe it, Rucker says. They are a long way from taking it for granted.  ``We were sitting around last night just having a beer,'' Rucker says, ``and thinking, `This is all part of the fantasy.'  ``And it's like I never want to wake up. Because I swear this is a dream, and one day my alarm's gonna go off and I'm going to be waking up in Charleston, S.C. and heading to the Music Forum to play a show.'' c.1996 Pentacom Productions  (Jeanne Wolf, who is based in Hollywood, reports on the entertainment industry for television, radio and print outlets.)  -0- SIDEBAR: HOOTIE AND THE BLOWFISH ON TOUR  This summer's tour will bring Hootie and the Blowfish to sites throughout the United States, including the following July dates: July 7, Mears, Mich.; July 8, Nobelsville, Mich.; July 9, St. Louis, Mo.; July 10, Kansas City, Kan.; July 12, Tinley Park, Ill.; July 13, East Troy, Wis.; July 14, Columbus, Ohio; July 16-17, Clarkston, Mich.; July 18, Cleveland, Ohio; July 21, Nashville, Tenn.; July 23, Cincinnati, Ohio; July 26, Burgettstown, Penn.; July 27-28, Bristow, Va.; July 30-31, New York City. The tour continues through September 22. (She also has information on how to subscribe to PageUp, a weekly package of eight intriguing articles with color art.) ------------------------------------------------- </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960624.0428 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-HEALTH-NEWS-ON-THE-WEB-PAGEUP-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> TAPPING INTO THE WORLD OF WEB INFORMATION CAN KEEP YOU HEALTHY (To publish this ``separate buy'' article it must be purchased -- the rate is not prohibitive -- from one of these New York Times Syndicate sales representatives: (--U.S., Canada and the Pacific: CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City, 816-822-8448 or fax her at 816-822-1444. (--Europe and Asia: KARL HORWITZ in Paris at 47-42-17-11; fax, 47-42-80-44 or 47-42-18-81; telex, 282-942. (--Mexico, Central America, South America: PAUL FINCH in Los Angeles, 310-996-0075; fax, 310-996-0089. (Distributed by New York Times Syndicate) By PEGGY NOONAN c.1996 Longevity (Distributed by New York Times Syndicate.) EDITORS: Please note ``(T)'' in the computer addresses below equates to a tilde sign, which cannot be transmitted into newspaper computer systems).  Within the reaches of the information superhighway lies the World Wide Web, a vast subsystem that's even faster and easier to access than the Internet.  Since its creation in 1989, the Web has exploded into hundreds of thousands of home pages, or Web sites. The possibilities for researching a particular health topic boggle the mind.  No matter which home page you start with, by following hypertext clues (text that's colored to lead you to other sites at the click of a mouse), you can end up browsing everything from the National Institutes of Health to research abstracts at a European university.  You'll find a wealth of information covering the conventional and unconventional in medicine and health: hospitals, dentistry, women's health, heart health, cancer, diabetes, plastic surgery, mental health, foot care, even ``Rogaine Online'' _ and that's just a sampling.  Understanding of the topic is often enhanced by superior graphics. If you want to check into herbal medicine, for instance, it's a great help to ``see'' the herbs you're reading about. Try the herbal photo gallery at Herbal Hall (http://www.crl.com/(T)robbee/herbal.html), as well as a menu of other selections from ``Longevity Herbs-Adaptogens-Nutritives'' to ``Herbal-Medical Dictionary.''  Or you could start at the Alternative Medicine Homepage (http://www.pitt.edu/(T)cbw/altm.html), which describes itself as ``a jumpstation for sources of information on unconventional, unorthodox, unproven or alternative, innovative, integrative therapies.''  From there, you're a mouse-click away from a pool of newsletters, access to mailing lists and commercial databases, bulletin boards and files for such selections as Kombucha (the medicinal mushroom), music therapy, massage, chiropractic and acupuncture.  Want to get the latest on food guides for ovo-lacto vegetarians? Check out the Vegetarian Society and its related Web pages for everything you ever wanted to know about vegetarianism.  If there's a nip or tuck in your future, set your Web-searching tool for ``plastic surgery'' and browse through plastic surgery-focused home pages, such as the University of California Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery page, a list of plastic surgery medical journals called Plink or hundreds of other publications, each outfitted with hypertext links of its own.  You'll find a dazzling array, including information-jammed text files, charts, graphs, drawings, diagrams, photos and, in some cases, even sound-bytes and movies on nearly every subject you can imagine.  The World Wide web is a home for ``hundreds of resources from schools, hospitals, health-care professionals, informed amateurs, former patients and charlatans,'' says Abbot Chambers, editor of the Whole Internet Catalog (http://gnn.com/wic/index.html), which is online.  ``In short, it's a mirror of everything going on in society at large.''  Following is a selection of home pages on health topics; use these as a jumping-off point for hundreds of related pages  _ Women's health resources: Click onto the Women's Medical Health Page (http://www.best.com/(T)sirlou/sheimp.html) spotlights recent publications and medical issues, such as RU486 (abortion-pill) alternatives.  _ Back pain: Check out the Cleveland Clinic Department of Neurological Surgery (http://www.neus.ccf.org/). It provides ``Frequently Asked Questions'' (FAQ) files about neurology and educational material on disorders of the brain, spinal cord and peripheral nervous system.  It also includes a description of the facility's services and personnel, and it lists links to other resources.  _ Heart health: Click onto the University of California at Irvine (UCI) Heart Disease Prevention Program's site (http://www.reg.uci.edu/UCI/CARDIOLOGY/PREVENTIVE/). UCI offers an extensive program, including information about risk factors and updates on research, especially ongoing studies at UCI.  At the American College of Cardiology (ACC) Web site (http://www.acc.org), visitors will find information about the ACC, clinical practice publications, ACC educational programs, computer applications and related topics.  _ Cancer: CancerGuide, Steve Dunn's Cancer Information Page (http://cancerguide.org) is a guide created by a cancer survivor ``for patients who want to understand more about the disease and their treatment options.''  It offers information on researching medical literature, including accessing medline, the world's most powerful medical database; updates on clinical trials; data on specific cancers, rare cancers and bone marrow transplants and alternative therapies, such as bovine cartilage.  _ Customized advice about health concerns: Try Go Ask Alice (http://www.columbia.edu/cu/healthwise/alice.html), an interactive health service where online visitors post questions anonymously on any health topic _ from fitness to alcohol to sexual health.  _ Depression: Depression FAQ (http://avocado.pc.helsinki.fi/81/%7Ejanne/asdfaq/) Chambers calls ``a fine example of the sort of mutually supportive documents available on the Web.''  It provides a depression primer, FAQ files on depression's causes, treatments and medications and tips on finding appropriate doctors.  _ Miscellaneous: Rogaine online is at (http://www2.nfic.com/Rogaine/) or (http://www2.igroup.com/Rogaine/index.html). Both addresses provide the same page and same information.  The Vegetarian Society (http://catless.ncl.ac.uk/veg/) offers links to the major vegetarian sites as well as information about vegetarianism and related topics.  Please note: many of these website addresses are subject to change. (Peggy Noonan is an Edgewater, Colo.-based free-lance writer.) -------------------------------------------------  (To publish this ``separate buy'' article it must be purchased -- the rate is not prohibitive -- from one of these New York Times Syndicate sales representatives:  (--Europe and Asia: KARL HORWITZ in Paris at 47-42-17-11; fax, 47-42-80-44 or 47-42-18-81; telex, 282-942.  (--Mexico, Central America, South America: PAUL FINCH in Los Angeles, 310-996-0075; fax, 310-996-0089.  (--U.S., Canada and the Pacific: CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City, 816-822-8448 or fax her at 816-822-1444. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960624.0429 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-OPPOSITES-KEEP-THEIR-MARRIAGES-HAPPY-PAGEUP-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> WHEN OPPOSITES ATTRACT AND THEN DETRACT: HOW CAN A MARRIAGE STAY HAPPY? (To publish this ``separate buy'' article it must be purchased -- the rate is not prohibitive -- from one of these New York Times Syndicate sales representatives:  (--U.S., Canada and the Pacific: CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City, 816-822-8448 or fax her at 816-822-1444.  (--Europe and Asia: KARL HORWITZ in Paris at 47-42-17-11; fax, 47-42-80-44 or 47-42-18-81; telex, 282-942.  (--Mexico, Central America, South America: PAUL FINCH in Los Angeles, 310-996-0075; fax, 310-996-0089. (Distributed by New York Times Syndicate) Includes a 200-word sidebar By SHERRY SUIB COHEN c.1996 Family Circle North American rights only. (Distributed by New York Times Syndicate.)  There's something captivating about an opposite. Passion is aroused by a jolt of differences: It's exciting.  The opposite natures of couples can lend a marriage its most exciting challenges _ and balance. The very best marriages thrive on growth and change. But what if your differences become annoyances? Or worse, obstacles to your marriage?  What follows are four combinations of disparate individuals (all names have been changed) who are married to each other. If you find yourself in one or more categories, read on for tips on transforming your differences into strengths. THE INTROVERT &AMP; EXTROVERT: OPPOSITE TYPES  ``Steve was intensely private,'' says Ann from Florida. ``At first, it seemed intriguing and romantic.''  But after six months of marriage, ``the silence got dull. We're so different socially. I love people; his inspiration comes from empty rooms. Are we in trouble?''  ``We're talking about issues of safety here,'' says Rebecca Cutter, a Portland, Ore., psychotherapist and author of ``When Opposites Attract (Plume/Penguin, 1995).  Understanding is the key. The extrovert must recognize why her spouse won't choose to be social (he feels unsafe), and minimize the perceived danger for him. She should never put him in the spotlight without his prior knowledge (surprise parties are a definite no).  When the introvert trusts his mate, Cutter says, he'll risk a little more social activity knowing she won't do anything to hurt him (like desert him in a crowded room).  By the same token, the introvert must maximize the variety in the partners' lives or risk deadening the liveliness of the marriage.  ``Invigorating changes _ more travel, for example _ keep the relationship vital,'' Cutter says.  Another approach comes from Sybil Evans, president of Sybil Evans Associates, a New York organization specializing in conflict resolution.  ``We look for an `integrated solution' that satisfies both,'' Evans says, ``instead of the traditional `compromise' where neither ends up happy.''  For example, a traditional compromise might consist of Steve's reluctantly agreeing to a large party one week if Ann says yes to staying home the next. But rest assured, Evans says, that even though it's a compromise, he'll hate the party, and she'll feel like a prisoner at home. Both may become bitter and blame each other.  But here's the integrated approach: hosting a quiet, two-couple dinner instead of attending a large affair. The intimate party will satisfy Ann's need to interact with others, and it will meet her husband's need to limit socializing to a few people rather than having to painfully cruise a crowd. THE FISHERMAN &AMP; THE READER: OPPOSITE INTERESTS  ``Nancy was a client of mine,'' Evans says. ``At first, the city-lover in her was drawn to the outdoorsy him. But just because the ocean interested him didn't mean she wanted to do battle with 6-foot waves.''  The relationship worked all right initially _ when he went off to do things with worms and sharks, she explored the flea markets or simply stayed home with a novel.  Then Nancy noticed that there was something wrong with her husband's fish stories.  ``He'd come home with these wonderful tales about seeing whales and catching giant tuna,'' she told Evans, ``but I realized, I was just hearing the stories. I wasn't in them.''  At Evans's suggestion, Nancy came up with a plan. She goes on the boat a lot now but never without a book. Nancy enjoys reading during the more mundane parts, but she's also there to marvel when they see a giant turtle.  And when it's her turn to curl up with a book, he practices his fishing knots next to her on the same couch.  Two caveats: Blending interests only works when both partners share in the blending. And although it's great when it happens, partners with opposite interests can't always blend them, Evans warns. THE OPTIMIST &AMP; THE PESSIMIST: OPPOSITE OUTLOOKS  Jane, a Boston lawyer, was enticed, she says, by Randy's ``happy face and sunny outlook.'' And Jane, says Randy, was ``the most interesting, grounded woman'' he ever met.  When they married six years ago, they began to live the way they'd been brought up: Randy, a reporter, focuses not on problems but on finding solutions, and he believes that he and Jane can always turn roadblocks into opportunities. When he lost his job recently, he wasn't crushed _ he was confident that he'd find another.  Jane is steady and intelligent, but worry and distrust are her middle names. She often thinks Randy's being childish. In a shrinking economy she's sure he won't find another job. The two are wearing each other down. Is there any hope?  Cutter offers two coping tricks to help achieve a balance between negativity and positivity: ``When Randy Optimist is having a really difficult time with Janie Pessimist, he might try picturing her when she was 5,'' Cutter suggests.  Seeing your partner as a vulnerable child, Cutter says, helps you understand and respect her way of looking at life. It makes her an endearing _ instead of a cranky _ character.  If two opposite personalities can learn to talk peacefully and try to understand, then sometimes draw from each other's reverse outlook, a remarkable balance certainly can be achieved, Evans says.  Randy and Jane might try working out a ``best-case'' and a ``worst-case'' scenario for any given threat. The idea is to temper his enthusiasm while uplifting her gloominess. Working together, they will see that growth and strength lie in emotional moderation. THE SPENDER &AMP; THE SAVER: OPPOSITE IMPULSES  After 13 years of a difficult marriage, Sara from Colorado is doubtful that either she or Michael have many strengths the other needs _ or wants.  When they met, she was drawn to his financial stability and his quiet reticence. Like a moth to flame, he flew to the way she made him laugh.  Today she wouldn't give 5 cents for his quiet, and he doesn't find her so funny anymore.  Sara is a generous spirit. Her strongest impulse is to spend her money and to share her dreams and thoughts with all her friends, not just Michael.  She has a full-time job, and her checking and savings accounts are in both their names.  Conversely, Michael's deepest impulse is to hoard. His bank account is in his name alone: ``What's mine is mine, what's hers is ours because I earn more'' is the way he looks at finances. He also shares very little emotionally.  It's not too late for this couple to see that they have reconcilable differences, says Dr. Harville Hendrix, co-author of ``The Couples Companion'' (Pocket, 1994). And with work, they can weave gold from chaff.  ``They should recognize that both too much giving and too much hoarding are defenses,'' Hendrix says. ``The generous spirit and the miserly mate must understand each other's motivations.''  Giving, Hendrix says, is, among other things, a subtle attempt to get others to love you. Most ultragenerous spirits are trying very hard to build a wall against loneliness, which would make them too vulnerable. They think if they give things of value away _ and that includes emotions _ people will be devoted to them and that will be a defense against being alone.  The miserly mate is also trying to make something happen: He wants to feel secure, and he fears he hasn't enough resources or emotions to share. If he lets down his guard, tells his secrets or spends his money, he'll be exposed and vulnerable.  What to do? The answer, like most good solutions, is disarmingly simple. Hendrix says that ``each must understand that the other's difference is precisely what's missing in themselves and then try to develop in themselves some of what they most object to in their partners.''  The miser must try to share more and protect less. He might start, Evans says, with joint banking accounts to promote trust in the marriage (both might still keep small separate accounts so each still has autonomy, and neither has to ask ``permission'' to spend money).  The emotional hoarder must also attempt to give his partner more access to his inner world _ even if it doesn't immediately feel safe. When it becomes a habit, it will start to feel safe.  The partner who gives everything away needs to put limits on her largesse, needs to incorporate a bit of her mate's hoarding behavior. She has to understand that keeping some things to herself doesn't diminish but enhances her desirability to others, Hendrix says. -0- SIDEBAR: TURNING YOUR DIFFERENCES INTO STRENGTHS  These conflict-resolution methods will help keep you and your spouse close.  _ Check assumptions before leaping to conclusions. Agree to stop for a moment at an ``outlook impasse'' and entertain the possibility that this time the other's outlook may be right.  For example, she notices her wallet is gone and assumes it's stolen. He says she probably left it at home. Each must listen to each other's reasons for their conclusions _ then figure out together the most logical one.  No sarcasm is allowed.  _ Role play. Every few weeks, agree to creep into each other's skin for a day. He will try not to be Pollyanna, and she will not dwell on wort-case scenarios.  At any given crisis during the day, each must promise to think, ``What would my spouse do?'' Then each will do it in the other's way.  This approach gives spouses permission to step back and take another route other than the programmed one. It works.  _ Get funny. Try to look at your spouse's outlooks in a humorous way and don't take things too seriously. Laughing at yourself is a lovable act, and lovable acts cement relationships. (Sherry Suib Cohen is a New York city-based free-lance writer.) -------------------------------------------------  (To publish this ``separate buy'' article it must be purchased -- the rate is not prohibitive -- from one of these New York Times Syndicate sales representatives:  (--Europe and Asia: KARL HORWITZ in Paris at 47-42-17-11; fax, 47-42-80-44 or 47-42-18-81; telex, 282-942.  (--Mexico, Central America, South America: PAUL FINCH in Los Angeles, 310-996-0075; fax, 310-996-0089.  (--U.S., Canada and the Pacific: CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City, 816-822-8448 or fax her at 816-822-1444. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960624.0430 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-WILL-SMITH-IN-`INDEPENDENCE-DAY'-PAGEUP-ART-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> WILL SMITH CELEBRATES ``INDEPENDENCE DAY'' (This ``separate buy'' article is from this week's PageUp Lifestyle and Entertainment Package.) (To publish this article, it must be purchased _ the rate is not prohibitive _ from New York Times Syndicate sales representative CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City at 1-800-444-0267 or 816-822-8448, or by fax her at 816-822-1444.) (She also has information on how to subscribe to PageUp, a weekly package of eight intriguing articles with color art.) Includes a color slide of Will Smith in a scene from ``Independence Day.'' By CINDY PEARLMAN World rights except Chicago (Distributed by New York Times Special Features)  What is it about Will Smith and aliens?  He battles extraterrestrial invaders in his role as a cocky, gifted Marine fighter pilot in ``Independence Day,'' opening July 3.  But while awaiting release of that film, which might be the summer's biggest hit, Smith is in a muggy New York City, on the set of ``Men in Black'' _ and he's chasing aliens again.  ``Men in Black,'' co-starring Tommy Lee Jones, is based on a popular comic book. It casts Smith as a New York City police officer recruited by the Men in Black, an elite force who combat aliens living among us.  ``I must have been crowned the alien man,'' Smith says with a laugh. ``The next thing you'll hear is that I've signed up for `Alien 4' with Sigourney Weaver. The poster will read, `Will Smith IS the Alien.'''  Alien-fighting is a strange business.  ``Tommy Lee Jones is my partner,'' explains Smith over the phone from his trailer on the set. ``This morning, Tommy Lee blew this guy's head off in front of me. I was about to arrest Tommy Lee for murder. All of a sudden his victim's head grew back.  ``It's pretty creepy stuff.''  Filming the $70-million ``Independence Day'' was less bizarre, he says. In fact, it was downright boring.  ``When I would look in the sky, I didn't see the aliens. They were put in later with a computer,'' Smith says. ``So I'd be standing there looking at nothing but clouds and then I would have to freak out.''  Even the air combat scenes were exercises in imagination.  ``There were no other jets or little green guys flying them,'' he says. ``I was just sitting there in this easy chair throwing my body around and yelling, `Explosion!' or `There must be 12,000 aliens in that spaceship!'  ``Anyone could do it at home.''  Given his apparent specialization in alien movies, what does Smith think about real-life ETs?  ``I just think it is arrogant for us to believe we are the only life force (in the universe),'' he answers. ``How can we think we're it?  ``I have to say that my dreams are getting a little weird. I'm getting beamed to a lot of places. Weird little people show up. I think, `Will, you have to get a hobby or something.' I just can't stop thinking about aliens.  ``Everywhere I go, it's the same thing. I'm in a restaurant and the waitress will say, `Will, do you want fries with that and do you believe in aliens?' People seem very excited about it.''  After six years as television's ``Fresh Prince of Bel Air,'' Smith is excited about a movie career that has taken off. Offers are pouring in, including a sequel to ``Bad Boys'' (1995), his hit action film that cracked the $100 million mark.  ``It's funny. This June marks my 10th anniversary in show business,'' the 28-year-old says. ``In many ways it seems like I just started. Then I have days where everything just seems to be happening too quickly.''  Smith was born in Philadelphia, where he grew up with two sisters and a brother. His mother worked with the school board, his father at an ice company.  Despite his raffish charm and quick wit, Smith was not the class clown as a boy, he says.  ``I was a little shy, especially with women. I was interested in computer engineering. Math was my best subject, and I thought I'd have a nice little 9-to-5 job someday.''  It was his hobby that derailed those plans: In his spare time, Smith liked to rap.  ``It was just something to do,'' he recalls. ``I started rapping at age 12, but I never had big plans to cut a record or anything.''  In 1986, Smith and Jeff Townes formed a group, D.J. Jazzy Jeff and The Fresh Prince. During his senior year of high school, a talent scout from Jive records heard their music. One month before high-school graduation, Jive released the duo's first record, ``Girls Ain't Nothing But Trouble.''  The group earned a 1988 Grammy Award for best rap performance for ``Parents Just Don't Understand,'' the hit single from their second album, ``He's the DJ, I'm the Rapper.'' They also won a Grammy for the single ``Summertime,'' from their fourth album, ``Homebase,'' which was released in 1991 and went platinum.  When producing legend Quincy Jones heard their music and called Smith to offer him the lead role in ``Fresh Prince of Belair,'' the rapper didn't have to think twice.  ``At the time, I thought, `Why not? I'm just so very good. I'm talented, I should have a TV series.' I'm so cocky!'' he says.  ``After six years on `Fresh Prince,' I'm gonna miss it a little bit,'' Smith admits. ``I do keep in touch with everyone. Our job was to have fun on that set and there are wonderful memories. You just can't spend your life looking back.''  Throughout the run of the series, Smith had used his hiatuses for film roles in such features as ``Where the Day Takes You'' (1992), ``Six Degrees of Separation'' (1993) and ``Made in America'' (1993). Now, with the series having ended, he can be a movie machine if he likes.  ``All these offers roll in,'' he says. ``It's hard to know what to do or who to trust to steer me in the right direction.  ``I trust me. That's the only person you can really trust in this business. People in this business just want to make money off you, and usually it's not in your best interests. I'm excited about a movie career, but cautious too.''  In an effort to revive his musical career, he plans to spend more time in New York, which wasn't possible during the run of ``Fresh Prince.''  ``There is just no creative inspiration in Los Angeles. It pulls my creativity down,'' Smith says. ``There's a huge difference between New York and Los Angeles in the way rap music is performed. In New York, I feel there is more hope in the music and more comedy. That's what I like.''  The end of the series will also give him more time to spend with his son, Willard C. Smith III, nicknamed ``Trey.'' Smith is divorced from his son's mother and is currently dating actress Jada Pinkett, who stars this summer in ``The Nutty Professor.''  Feeling a little played out, Smith says he will take the rest of the summer off after ``Men in Black'' wraps.  ``Jada and I talk about doing something together. We've got to strengthen the relationship first. You must get yourselves together first, before you put a movie in the mix. Otherwise you just get too stressed out.''  Not that Smith isn't enjoying his success.  ``I'm not shy with girls anymore,'' he says. ``Seriously, for the first time in my life, I feel that women like me. There was always the other guy. I was always told, `Will is fun and he makes me laugh.' I was always the best friend and it stunk. Now women like me better.''  And why not? You never know when you may need to chase away some aliens, and Will Smith is a good man to have around for that sort of thing.  But not to hear him tell it. This Independence Day, his plans don't involve any world-saving.  ``I'll be at the barbecue,'' he says. ``I'm the grill man. The only thing I'll be saving is the hamburgers from falling into the flames.'' c.1996 Cindy Pearlman  (Cindy Pearlman is a Chicago-based free-lance writer.) (She also has information on how to subscribe to PageUp, a weekly package of eight intriguing articles with color art.) ------------------------------------------------- </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_19960624.0431 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-HOOTIE-AND-THE-BLOWFISH-PAGEUP-ART-NYTSF) </DATELINE> <TEXT> ATTN MIDWEST: IL./MICH./MO./OHIO/TENN./WIS. HOOTING AND HOLLERING: ON THE ROAD WITH HOOTIE AND THE BLOWFISH (This ``separate buy'' article is from this week's PageUp Lifestyle and Entertainment Package.) (To publish this article, it must be purchased _ the rate is not prohibitive _ from New York Times Syndicate sales representative CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City at 1-800-444-0267 or 816-822-8448, or by fax her at 816-822-1444.) (She also has information on how to subscribe to PageUp, a weekly package of eight intriguing articles with color art.) Includes a color slide of the band Hootie and the Blowfish and a sidebar listing the band's July tour dates in the Midwest. By JEANNE WOLF (Distributed by New York Times Special Features)  No tuxedos for Hootie and the Blowfish, not even when they appeared on the Grammys or sang for royalty in Monaco.  ``We're just not a tux band,'' lead singer Darius Rucker explains. ``We've borrowed tuxes for some shows because it was a respect thing, but that's not us.''  No problem for this astoundingly successful band. They can wear and sing whatever they want in the wake of their record-setting first album. More than 13 million copies of ``Cracked Rear View'' (1994) were sold, and the record was still on the charts when they went back to the studio to record their much-awaited follow-up album, ``Fairweather Johnson.''  It's no coincidence that this very American group headed off on a European tour shortly after the new album came out in May.  ``We wanted to get away from all the hype and everything,'' Rucker says bluntly, ``'cause, you know, hype sucks.''  The band has encountered plenty of hype _ unsurprisingly so, given that theirs was the second-best-selling debut album in recording history, trailing only Boston's 1976 first effort.  But with the hype came intimidatingly high expectations for their second album, along with fears of the dreaded ``sophomore jinx'' which has made many artists' second albums into disappointments. Many predicted that these South Carolina college buddies, more used to playing minor clubs and small gigs all over the South, would crumble under the pressure.  But Rucker says that when they hit the studio they were fearless.  ``We had a lot of ideas and we weren't worried about it. We were just ready to do another album and we weren't scared at all.''  The group also was ready for flak from critics, who have never really been kind to them.  ``We worried about the critics at first, but not any more,'' Rucker says. ``We figured out that the media didn't sell our record. First it was the music and then it was the radio and then people just seemed to like it.''  ``We had pressure on ourselves, but from a different angle,'' agrees bassist Dean Felber. ``We're a live band and we wanted to tour, and in order to do that we needed new songs. And we were kind of worn out on the old stuff.  ``All of the pressure we put on ourselves is easier pressure to handle than when it's outside sources pushing you in a certain direction. We got to pick our own course.''  Felber says the group was braced for inevitable, probably unfavorable comparisons to its first album.  ``You can't expect something like that twice,'' he says. ``We didn't expect it the first time, you know _ it was kind of a gift. It was timing or whatever.''  He shrugs.  ``To create that twice in a row ... I don't know if that could be done.''  Guitarist Mark Bryan says that they were eager to try some new ideas.  ``I'm proud that we're still growing. I'm proud of our songwriting abilities, which are maturing,'' he says. ``I enjoy the songs from `Fairweather Johnson' the way I enjoyed the songs from `Cracked Rear View' when we first wrote them.  ``Most of all, I enjoy everyone getting together and playing. We can still have fun together and also make our music better.''  ``Fairweather Johnson'' has been in the top five since its debut. Now, as the group hits the road, Bryan looks forward to the chance to bring the new songs to live audiences.  ``We are trying as hard as we can to be anti-hype,'' he says. ``It's much more fun to just worry about your music and just play and not read about yourself every day.''  All the band members stress the group's commitment to live performances and present themselves as anti-stars _ working-guy musicians devoid of star glitter.  ``A six-week European tour, and two nights before I'm like, `OK, I gotta pack,''' Felber says. He claims that his secret to traveling comfort is to bring only two weeks' worth of clothing and do laundry every two weeks.  Bryan tries to see as much as he can in each new city they visit. He also calls home every day.  ``I try to talk to my wife every night,'' he says. ``It's important to keep yourself involved in your life back home.''  Drummer Jim ``Soni'' Sonefeld sums up his slant on the European experience:  ``It's pretty here but I can't afford a hamburger _ $38 for a burger! That's wild!''  ``We are not used to these four-star hotels,'' Felber says with a smile. ``You gotta understand, the nicest place in town in a lot of the cities we play is just an ordinary motel. I keep kidding that we don't really belong in this kind of luxury.''  And how do these hot young rockers spent their time on the road? Do they trash hotel rooms, party into the night or cruise the night scene?  No, because it might interfere with their real passion: This may be the world's only rock band which also makes up a foursome for golf.  ``Everyone asks us if success spoiled us,'' Sonefeld says. ``About golf, I can say yes! We get to play some of the nicest courses in the country and sometimes in the world.  ``We know there are people that are much more deserving who would die to play on these courses and they can't. We've been playing them for free, and we stink. We've been spoiled in that world.''  Another unusual aspect of this band is that, at least from an outsider's perspective, they reveal few signs of artistic or personal conflicts. To all appearances, all four Blowfish get along amazingly well, exchanging good-natured barbs and clearly enjoying what they do. Their only real conflicts arise from business discussions:  ``The biggest chafe these days is just trying to separate business from our music, 'cause business has become a big part of it,'' Sonefeld says. ``There's a lot of responsibility that comes with success and you've got to sit there and sort it out.  ``Though counting money isn't the biggest problem in the world to have, it can chafe people the wrong way when you're tired and you've just finished a big concert and the last thing you want to discuss is payroll taxes and investments.  ``We are all truly grateful, but we're in this for the music,'' he continues. ``And when you have to get into all these business details it can be a bit of a pain in the (butt), and tempers run a little short.''  He grins.  ``It's not a joking matter, (but) we're such lighthearted people and we still want to joke sometimes. I admit I'm the worst at it.''  Onstage, though, any lingering annoyance disappears, Sonefeld says.  ``It's not about money. It's not about anything in the world other than playing the music. That's the reason we all got together in the first place. It's what brings you back to the first time you ever had a gig together, you know. You've got your instrument, you've got your microphone and the crowd gets going. It's great!''  So great, in fact, that the musicians occasionally can't believe it, Rucker says. They are a long way from taking it for granted.  ``We were sitting around last night just having a beer,'' Rucker says, ``and thinking, `This is all part of the fantasy.'  ``And it's like I never want to wake up. Because I swear this is a dream, and one day my alarm's gonna go off and I'm going to be waking up in Charleston, S.C. and heading to the Music Forum to play a show.'' c.1996 Pentacom Productions  (Jeanne Wolf, who is based in Hollywood, reports on the entertainment industry for television, radio and print outlets.)  -0- SIDEBAR: HOOTIE AND THE BLOWFISH ON TOUR  This summer's tour will bring Hootie and the Blowfish to sites throughout the United States, including the following July dates: July 7, Mears, Mich.; July 8, Nobelsville, Mich.; July 9, St. Louis, Mo.; July 10, Kansas City, Kan.; July 12, Tinley Park, Ill.; July 13, East Troy, Wis.; July 14, Columbus, Ohio; July 16-17, Clarkston, Mich.; July 18, Cleveland, Ohio; July 21, Nashville, Tenn.; July 23, Cincinnati, Ohio; July 26, Burgettstown, Penn.; July 27-28, Bristow, Va.; July 30-31, New York City. The tour continues through September 22. If you have any questions, please call Paul Wagner, Jim Peipert or Brian Wilson on the Star-Telegram's National/Foreign Desk at (817) 390-7785.  FROST-HOUSE  WASHINGTON _ A smiling President Clinton looked over the audience at a New York fund-raiser early this year and joked about the dogged determination Rep. Martin Frost brought to his job as chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. ``When Martin Frost was up here announcing that this was the most successful event by the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee ever held outside Washington, I thought, `My God, even people in New York can't tell him no. Anything to get him off the phone,''' Clinton quipped. While Clinton got a few laughs from campaign contributors dining at the posh St. Regis Hotel, he also acknowledged that the work of the Dallas lawmaker since December 1994 to reclaim Congress for the Democrats has been no joke. By MICHAEL D. TOWLE. Story will move in ``p'' political category.  OSTRICHES-COMEBACK  MANSFIELD, Texas _ Ostrich, once the prey of fly-by-night investment schemes, is finally gaining the attention of slaughterhouses and white tablecloth restaurants. Prices for the flightless fowl plummeted as much as 90 percent nearly two years ago as a speculative ``breeders'' market fizzled. But patient ranchers, noting greater market acceptance, say the ostrich is becoming a viable alternative to other meat and poultry. By BARRY SHLACHTER. Story will move in ``a'' general news category.  HORSEBACK VISIT  DUNCANVILLE, Texas _ Some proud grandparents hop in the car or take the first flight to see the family's latest addition. Bob Mathis of Duncanville is taking his good time. On Friday, the 64-year-old will tie down his bedroll and saddlebags, then mount his favorite horse, an Arabian stallion named Checkmate. Together, they will ride 412 miles south toward Corpus Christi and his newborn grandson, whom he expects to see after 16 days on the trail _ alongside country roads and highways. By BARRY SHLACHTER. Story will move in ``a'' general news category.  ONE TON-RECORD COMPANY  DALLAS _ Take a look around the downtown Dallas office of One Ton Records and you'll see a ton of things: posters and fliers hyping North Texas bands such as the Toadies, Brutal Juice, Caulk and Baboon; a rehearsal area where various local bands jam; an office zone where TVs flicker and computers chirp; and a comfy living space where a quintet of cats wanders around, meowing and looking for affection. Hovering above it all is 26-year-old Aden Holt, who, one second, is helping his girlfriend, Lara Decker, answer the phone that never seems to stop ringing, and the next is fooling with his computer, and the next is finishing an upcoming concert flier. For the past two years, this has pretty much been Holt's daily routine. He used to have a day job as a graphics designer but he quit to pour all he could into building One Ton, which is more than just a record label. By MALCOLM MAYHEW. Story will move in ``e'' entertainment category.  ROBERT EARL KEEN  UNDATED _ Life itself has gotten a lot faster for Robert Earl Keen over the past year or so, as the Bandera, Texas-based singer-songwriter's cultlike fame has spread. ``It doesn't seem to slow down. We're out about two or three days a week, then about every six weeks we'll go out for 10 days or so,'' Keen says. ``We had a tour to California and the East Coast, but we had to cancel it all. It was just too much.'' By SHIRLEY JINKINS. Story will move in ``e'' entertainment category.  BIZ-BOOKS  UNDATED _ In their new book, John Micklethwait and Adrian Wooldridge, two editors at The Economist, take a hard look at the good and destructive forces behind management theorists in today's companies. By TERESA McUSIC. (NYLite items can be published if desired; please credit the contributor. Contribute to NYLite and get a NYT rolling-writer style pen.)  NYLite items can be published if desired; please credit the contributor.)  MUG OF THE WEEK !!!!!!  We will now be awarding a mug every Friday for the best joke, story, anecdote, whatever, of the week. (C'mon, admit it, you're excited!) Send by fax (212-556-3535) or via e-mail:  Dr. NYlite can now be reached by e-mail: nylite(at)nytimes.com (use ``at'' sign sted (at)).  TRANSSEXUAL SUBTERFUGE  A guy walks into the lounge at work the day after Christmas and his coworkers ask: `Hey Johnny, what'd your wife get ya for Christmas?'  Johnny: `Women's underwear'  Coworkers: `Since when do you wear women's underwear?'  Johnny: `Since my wife found some in my glove compartment last year.'  _ Monica Mendoza  QUOTABLES FROM NBC'S `THE TONIGHT SHOW WITH JAY LENO'  The following are quotes from Jay Leno's monologue for the week of December 23, 1996:  ``Here we are day after Christmas. How many men still have some shopping left to do?''  ``Here's another question for you. You know that Tickle Me Elmo doll you bought for Christmas? Still think it's worth $1200 now?''  ``Yesterday on the news they showed footage of President Clinton shopping at a jewelry store in Washington. I understand he bought some really expensive gifts for his loved ones. Those Indonesian businessmen, they are tough to shop for.''  ``The President's staff got him an exercise bike for Christmas. They said in the paper today the bike was specially designed for President Clinton. That means it only backpedals.''  ``Yesterday a group of men in Washington, D.C., re-enacted George Washington's crossing of the Delaware River. Back then it was freezing cold, of course there was no food, and they didn't know if they'd make it alive. So in a sense, this was the very first Carnival Cruise.''  ``Unbelievable bad weather all across the country. Snow was so deep in Michigan this week Dr. Kevorkian had to revive a couple of dead passengers to help push his suicide van out of the snow.''  ``Here's a shocker. The head coach of the New York Jets resigned today. What a surprise!''  ``According to a new sports survey, the most-used name for college football teams is `Tigers.' Anybody know the least-used name for college football? `Graduates.'''  ``This week TV executives gave final approval to a ratings system that rates programs for sexual content and violence. The shows are gonna be rated with a little symbol in the corner of the screen within 15 seconds after the show begins. Fifteen seconds? By that time every character on `Melrose Place' has slept with every other character.''  ``Do you know what Michael Jackson calls the Tickle Me Elmo doll? Bait!''  ``RuPaul told Interview magazine it takes him an hour and a half to turn himself into a woman. So guys, next time you ask a woman out and she says, `Oh it's gonna take me about an hour and a half to get ready,' you could be in for a big surprise.''  OPENING REMARKS FROM THE ``LATE SHOW with DAVID LETTERMAN''  ON THE CBS TELEVISION NETWORK  (Monday, Dec. 23-Friday, Dec. 27)  ``I have an announcement from the New York City Department of Sanitation. If you want your Christmas tree picked up, here's what you do. Take all of the ornaments, take all of the festive trimming, all of the garlands, all of the tinsel, all of the multicolored lights --take all of that stuff off the Christmas tree. Then you take it outside onto the curb and you place it right next to last year's Christmas tree.''  ``Big Christmas down in Washington, D.C. I don't know what's going on, but President Clinton buys Hillary for Christmas a book about baseball. Isn't that odd? And here's the strange part about it -- for Joe Torre, he bought a black lace teddy.''  ``Mayor Giuliani is very excited about something because...New York City has a chance at finishing 1996 with fewer than a thousand homicides. Ladies and gentlemen, here's my promise to you: if, at 11:30 New Year's Eve, we have 999, I will personally go down to Times Square and whack Dick Clark.''  ``Ladies and gentlemen, here's good news for frequent flyers. United Airlines, for the second year in a row, was voted Best Airline Food.' That's right, Best Airline Food.' And, I thought, man, what a wonderful honor! That's like being named M.V.P. on the Jets.''  ``Let me remind you of one thing, especially here in New York City. If you have clothing you're not going to use, if you have canned goods you're not going to use, make sure that those go to somebody less fortunate than you are and, especially here in New York City, specify either Rich Kotite of the Jets or Dan Reeves of the Giants before you send it out.''  ``The Jets , God bless em, finished their 1996 season -- let me see if I have the record right here --the Jets finished their season 1-and-15. And, you know, Friday before the last game of the season, their coach Rich Kotite called a press conference and he announced to the assembled New York media, he said, I have not been fired. I am not quitting. I am stepping down.' Hard to believe this guy had difficulty communicating with his players, isn't it?''  ``The big story coming out of Los Angeles -- you probably read about this last week -- a supermarket cashier now claims to be pregnant with Christopher Darden's child. Isn't that amazing! Well, Chris, if you're watching, pal, maybe you should have spent a little more time trying to nail O.J.''  GOOD DAY, WIRE WANDERERS!!!!!  Offer not available in any store!
