TRANSSEXUAL SUBTERFUGE  A guy walks into the lounge at work the day after Christmas and his coworkers ask: `Hey Johnny, what'd your wife get ya for Christmas?'  Johnny: `Women's underwear'  Coworkers: `Since when do you wear women's underwear?'  Johnny: `Since my wife found some in my glove compartment last year.'  _ Monica Mendoza  QUOTABLES FROM NBC'S `THE TONIGHT SHOW WITH JAY LENO'  The following are quotes from Jay Leno's monologue for the week of December 23, 1996:  ``Here we are day after Christmas. How many men still have some shopping left to do?''  ``Here's another question for you. You know that Tickle Me Elmo doll you bought for Christmas? Still think it's worth $1200 now?''  ``Yesterday on the news they showed footage of President Clinton shopping at a jewelry store in Washington. I understand he bought some really expensive gifts for his loved ones. Those Indonesian businessmen, they are tough to shop for.''  ``The President's staff got him an exercise bike for Christmas. They said in the paper today the bike was specially designed for President Clinton. That means it only backpedals.''  ``Yesterday a group of men in Washington, D.C., re-enacted George Washington's crossing of the Delaware River. Back then it was freezing cold, of course there was no food, and they didn't know if they'd make it alive. So in a sense, this was the very first Carnival Cruise.''  ``Unbelievable bad weather all across the country. Snow was so deep in Michigan this week Dr. Kevorkian had to revive a couple of dead passengers to help push his suicide van out of the snow.''  ``Here's a shocker. The head coach of the New York Jets resigned today. What a surprise!''  ``According to a new sports survey, the most-used name for college football teams is `Tigers.' Anybody know the least-used name for college football? `Graduates.'''  ``This week TV executives gave final approval to a ratings system that rates programs for sexual content and violence. The shows are gonna be rated with a little symbol in the corner of the screen within 15 seconds after the show begins. Fifteen seconds? By that time every character on `Melrose Place' has slept with every other character.''  ``Do you know what Michael Jackson calls the Tickle Me Elmo doll? Bait!''  ``RuPaul told Interview magazine it takes him an hour and a half to turn himself into a woman. So guys, next time you ask a woman out and she says, `Oh it's gonna take me about an hour and a half to get ready,' you could be in for a big surprise.''  OPENING REMARKS FROM THE ``LATE SHOW with DAVID LETTERMAN''  ON THE CBS TELEVISION NETWORK  (Monday, Dec. 23-Friday, Dec. 27)  ``I have an announcement from the New York City Department of Sanitation. If you want your Christmas tree picked up, here's what you do. Take all of the ornaments, take all of the festive trimming, all of the garlands, all of the tinsel, all of the multicolored lights --take all of that stuff off the Christmas tree. Then you take it outside onto the curb and you place it right next to last year's Christmas tree.''  ``Big Christmas down in Washington, D.C. I don't know what's going on, but President Clinton buys Hillary for Christmas a book about baseball. Isn't that odd? And here's the strange part about it -- for Joe Torre, he bought a black lace teddy.''  ``Mayor Giuliani is very excited about something because...New York City has a chance at finishing 1996 with fewer than a thousand homicides. Ladies and gentlemen, here's my promise to you: if, at 11:30 New Year's Eve, we have 999, I will personally go down to Times Square and whack Dick Clark.''  ``Ladies and gentlemen, here's good news for frequent flyers. United Airlines, for the second year in a row, was voted Best Airline Food.' That's right, Best Airline Food.' And, I thought, man, what a wonderful honor! That's like being named M.V.P. on the Jets.''  ``Let me remind you of one thing, especially here in New York City. If you have clothing you're not going to use, if you have canned goods you're not going to use, make sure that those go to somebody less fortunate than you are and, especially here in New York City, specify either Rich Kotite of the Jets or Dan Reeves of the Giants before you send it out.''  ``The Jets , God bless em, finished their 1996 season -- let me see if I have the record right here --the Jets finished their season 1-and-15. And, you know, Friday before the last game of the season, their coach Rich Kotite called a press conference and he announced to the assembled New York media, he said, I have not been fired. I am not quitting. I am stepping down.' Hard to believe this guy had difficulty communicating with his players, isn't it?''  ``The big story coming out of Los Angeles -- you probably read about this last week -- a supermarket cashier now claims to be pregnant with Christopher Darden's child. Isn't that amazing! Well, Chris, if you're watching, pal, maybe you should have spent a little more time trying to nail O.J.''  GOOD DAY, WIRE WANDERERS!!!!!  Offer not available in any store! Still think it's worth $1200 now?''  ``Yesterday on the news they showed footage of President Clinton shopping at a jewelry store in Washington. I understand he bought some really expensive gifts for his loved ones. Those Indonesian businessmen, they are tough to shop for.''  ``The President's staff got him an exercise bike for Christmas. They said in the paper today the bike was specially designed for President Clinton. That means it only backpedals.''  ``Yesterday a group of men in Washington, D.C., re-enacted George Washington's crossing of the Delaware River. Bait!''  ``RuPaul told Interview magazine it takes him an hour and a half to turn himself into a woman. OPENING REMARKS FROM THE ``LATE SHOW with DAVID LETTERMAN''  ON THE CBS TELEVISION NETWORK  (Monday, Dec. 23-Friday, Dec. 27)  ``I have an announcement from the New York City Department of Sanitation. If you want your Christmas tree picked up, here's what you do. Take all of the ornaments, take all of the festive trimming, all of the garlands, all of the tinsel, all of the multicolored lights --take all of that stuff off the Christmas tree. Then you take it outside onto the curb and you place it right next to last year's Christmas tree.''  ``Big Christmas down in Washington, D.C. I don't know what's going on, but President Clinton buys Hillary for Christmas a book about baseball. Isn't that odd? And here's the strange part about it -- for Joe Torre, he bought a black lace teddy.''  ``Mayor Giuliani is very excited about something because...New York City has a chance at finishing 1996 with fewer than a thousand homicides. Ladies and gentlemen, here's my promise to you: if, at 11:30 New Year's Eve, we have 999, I will personally go down to Times Square and whack Dick Clark.''  ``Ladies and gentlemen, here's good news for frequent flyers. United Airlines, for the second year in a row, was voted Best Airline Food.' That's right, Best Airline Food.' And, I thought, man, what a wonderful honor! That's like being named M.V.P. on the Jets.''  ``Let me remind you of one thing, especially here in New York City. If you have clothing you're not going to use, if you have canned goods you're not going to use, make sure that those go to somebody less fortunate than you are and, especially here in New York City, specify either Rich Kotite of the Jets or Dan Reeves of the Giants before you send it out.''  ``The Jets , God bless em, finished their 1996 season -- let me see if I have the record right here --the Jets finished their season 1-and-15. And, you know, Friday before the last game of the season, their coach Rich Kotite called a press conference and he announced to the assembled New York media, he said, I have not been fired. I am not quitting. I am stepping down.' Hard to believe this guy had difficulty communicating with his players, isn't it?''  ``The big story coming out of Los Angeles -- you probably read about this last week -- a supermarket cashier now claims to be pregnant with Christopher Darden's child. Isn't that amazing! Well, Chris, if you're watching, pal, maybe you should have spent a little more time trying to nail O.J.''  GOOD DAY, WIRE WANDERERS!!!!!  Offer not available in any store! If you want your Christmas tree picked up, here's what you do. Take all of the ornaments, take all of the festive trimming, all of the garlands, all of the tinsel, all of the multicolored lights --take all of that stuff off the Christmas tree. Then you take it outside onto the curb and you place it right next to last year's Christmas tree.''  ``Big Christmas down in Washington, D.C. I don't know what's going on, but President Clinton buys Hillary for Christmas a book about baseball. Isn't that odd? And here's the strange part about it -- for Joe Torre, he bought a black lace teddy.''  ``Mayor Giuliani is very excited about something because...New York City has a chance at finishing 1996 with fewer than a thousand homicides. Ladies and gentlemen, here's my promise to you: if, at 11:30 New Year's Eve, we have 999, I will personally go down to Times Square and whack Dick Clark.''  ``Ladies and gentlemen, here's good news for frequent flyers. United Airlines, for the second year in a row, was voted Best Airline Food.' That's right, Best Airline Food.' And, I thought, man, what a wonderful honor! That's like being named M.V.P. on the Jets.''  ``Let me remind you of one thing, especially here in New York City. If you have clothing you're not going to use, if you have canned goods you're not going to use, make sure that those go to somebody less fortunate than you are and, especially here in New York City, specify either Rich Kotite of the Jets or Dan Reeves of the Giants before you send it out.''  ``The Jets , God bless em, finished their 1996 season -- let me see if I have the record right here --the Jets finished their season 1-and-15. And, you know, Friday before the last game of the season, their coach Rich Kotite called a press conference and he announced to the assembled New York media, he said, I have not been fired. I am not quitting. I am stepping down.' Hard to believe this guy had difficulty communicating with his players, isn't it?''  ``The big story coming out of Los Angeles -- you probably read about this last week -- a supermarket cashier now claims to be pregnant with Christopher Darden's child. Isn't that amazing! Well, Chris, if you're watching, pal, maybe you should have spent a little more time trying to nail O.J.''  GOOD DAY, WIRE WANDERERS!!!!!  Offer not available in any store! NYLite items can be published if desired; please credit the contributor.)  MUG OF THE WEEK !!!!!!  We will now be awarding a mug every Friday for the best joke, story, anecdote, whatever, of the week. (C'mon, admit it, you're excited!) Send by fax (212-556-3535) or via e-mail:  Dr. NYlite can now be reached by e-mail: nylite(at)nytimes.com (use ``at'' sign sted (at)).  TRANSSEXUAL SUBTERFUGE  A guy walks into the lounge at work the day after Christmas and his coworkers ask: `Hey Johnny, what'd your wife get ya for Christmas?'  Johnny: `Women's underwear'  Coworkers: `Since when do you wear women's underwear?'  Johnny: `Since my wife found some in my glove compartment last year.'  _ Monica Mendoza  QUOTABLES FROM NBC'S `THE TONIGHT SHOW WITH JAY LENO'  The following are quotes from Jay Leno's monologue for the week of December 23, 1996:  ``Here we are day after Christmas. How many men still have some shopping left to do?''  ``Here's another question for you. You know that Tickle Me Elmo doll you bought for Christmas? Still think it's worth $1200 now?''  ``Yesterday on the news they showed footage of President Clinton shopping at a jewelry store in Washington. I understand he bought some really expensive gifts for his loved ones. Those Indonesian businessmen, they are tough to shop for.''  ``The President's staff got him an exercise bike for Christmas. They said in the paper today the bike was specially designed for President Clinton. That means it only backpedals.''  ``Yesterday a group of men in Washington, D.C., re-enacted George Washington's crossing of the Delaware River. Back then it was freezing cold, of course there was no food, and they didn't know if they'd make it alive. So in a sense, this was the very first Carnival Cruise.''  ``Unbelievable bad weather all across the country. Snow was so deep in Michigan this week Dr. Kevorkian had to revive a couple of dead passengers to help push his suicide van out of the snow.''  ``Here's a shocker. The head coach of the New York Jets resigned today. What a surprise!''  ``According to a new sports survey, the most-used name for college football teams is `Tigers.' Anybody know the least-used name for college football? `Graduates.'''  ``This week TV executives gave final approval to a ratings system that rates programs for sexual content and violence. The shows are gonna be rated with a little symbol in the corner of the screen within 15 seconds after the show begins. Fifteen seconds? By that time every character on `Melrose Place' has slept with every other character.''  ``Do you know what Michael Jackson calls the Tickle Me Elmo doll? Bait!''  ``RuPaul told Interview magazine it takes him an hour and a half to turn himself into a woman. So guys, next time you ask a woman out and she says, `Oh it's gonna take me about an hour and a half to get ready,' you could be in for a big surprise.''  OPENING REMARKS FROM THE ``LATE SHOW with DAVID LETTERMAN''  ON THE CBS TELEVISION NETWORK  (Monday, Dec. 23-Friday, Dec. 27)  ``I have an announcement from the New York City Department of Sanitation. If you want your Christmas tree picked up, here's what you do. Take all of the ornaments, take all of the festive trimming, all of the garlands, all of the tinsel, all of the multicolored lights --take all of that stuff off the Christmas tree. Then you take it outside onto the curb and you place it right next to last year's Christmas tree.''  ``Big Christmas down in Washington, D.C. I don't know what's going on, but President Clinton buys Hillary for Christmas a book about baseball. Isn't that odd? And here's the strange part about it -- for Joe Torre, he bought a black lace teddy.''  ``Mayor Giuliani is very excited about something because...New York City has a chance at finishing 1996 with fewer than a thousand homicides. Ladies and gentlemen, here's my promise to you: if, at 11:30 New Year's Eve, we have 999, I will personally go down to Times Square and whack Dick Clark.''  ``Ladies and gentlemen, here's good news for frequent flyers. United Airlines, for the second year in a row, was voted Best Airline Food.' That's right, Best Airline Food.' And, I thought, man, what a wonderful honor! That's like being named M.V.P. on the Jets.''  ``Let me remind you of one thing, especially here in New York City. If you have clothing you're not going to use, if you have canned goods you're not going to use, make sure that those go to somebody less fortunate than you are and, especially here in New York City, specify either Rich Kotite of the Jets or Dan Reeves of the Giants before you send it out.''  ``The Jets , God bless em, finished their 1996 season -- let me see if I have the record right here --the Jets finished their season 1-and-15. And, you know, Friday before the last game of the season, their coach Rich Kotite called a press conference and he announced to the assembled New York media, he said, I have not been fired. I am not quitting. I am stepping down.' Hard to believe this guy had difficulty communicating with his players, isn't it?''  ``The big story coming out of Los Angeles -- you probably read about this last week -- a supermarket cashier now claims to be pregnant with Christopher Darden's child. Isn't that amazing! Well, Chris, if you're watching, pal, maybe you should have spent a little more time trying to nail O.J.''  GOOD DAY, WIRE WANDERERS!!!!!  Offer not available in any store! MOVING TO BOTH LIFESTYLE (L) AND BUSINESS (F) QUEUES  Sports  SNOW-GEESE _ AUSTIN, Texas _ Alfred Hitchcock was right. Birds are breeding out of control, destroying land and threatening millions of lives. But the switch is that these birds _ snow geese _ are ruining their own breeding grounds, and the lives in danger are their own and their offspring's. The question facing an international coalition of wildlife managers is whether to use extreme and heretofore illegal means to kill off large numbers of the geese in order to save larger numbers in the future. (s)  Commentary  GEEWAX-COLUMN _ undated _ Credit cards are too easy to get, too easy to misuse. MOVING TO BOTH COMMENTARY (K) AND BUSINESS (F) QUEUES  EZZARD-COLUMN _ undated _ Assuming the worst about the poor. (k)  MINTER-COLUMN _ FAYETTE COUNTY, Ga. _ Something pretty special must be in British gardens. (k)  LANE-COLUMN _ undated _ The rock critic was by my office and he was wearing a tie. I take note of anyone who drops by wearing a tie and an earring, one each. It was, I thought, a cool tie, as befits a person who is paid, in part, to aid readers in their individual quests for coolness. But here's the thing: it was a knit tie with a squared-off end. It was, to be sure, an '80s tie. (k)  SCHUETT-COLUMN _ undated _ GIBSONBURG, Ohio _ My morning paper is full of important stuff. On the front page alone, there's coverage of President Clinton blocking an airline strike, the latest installment of Chrysler's ongoing tap-dance routine: does Jeep stay in Toledo? and a heartwarming story of three teens who risked their lives to rescue a trucker trapped beneath his gasoline-soaked rig. There was also a story headlined: Symmetry gives men sex appeal. Guess which one I read first? (k)  For answers or resends, call the Cox News Service at 202-331-0900. (NYT26) NEW YORK -- April 19, 2001 -- PRODUCERS-THEATER-REVIEW-3 -- ``The Producers,'' the comic veteran Mel Brooks' stage adaptation of his own cult movie from 1968, is as full of gags, gadgets and gimmicks as an old vaudevillian's trunk. ``The Producers,'' is a big Broadway book musical that is so ecstatically drunk on its powers to entertain that it leaves you delirious, too. Nathan Lane, left, and Matthew Broderick in ``The Producers'' at the St. James Theater in New York. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)  (NYT25) QUEBEC -- April 19, 2001 -- AMERICAS-SUMMIT -- A member of the Quebec provincial security personnel monitors the perimeter surrounding the Summit of the Americas in Quebec City as contruction workers pull fenced gates into place Thursday. Fears of violent demonstrations intended to undermine the talks--similar to street clashes that derailed World Trade Organization negotiations in Seattle in December 1999--have caused officials to build a wall of concrete and wire fencing around Quebec City. (Robert J. The wildfire that was started as a controlled burn in a county reserve spread to 4,500 acres, burned one home and forced the evacuation of the residential neighborhood of North Port, Fla. Like children who make toys and games from pots and pans, popsicle sticks and bottle tops, artists reconfigure unlikely materials for unexpected purposes. Today they rearrange industrial goods and convert technologies to aesthetic ends, and the technological bit is becoming a contemporary specialty. Jenny Holzer appropriated the scoreboard at Candlestick Park for one of her works in her ``Truisms 1977-1979'' series. (Regional Performing Arts Center, Philadelphia/The New York Times)  (NYT7) NEW YORK -- April 19, 2001 -- ART-NOTES -- For yet another auction season at Sotheby's, a work by the 1980s art star Jeff Koons is likely to eclipse much of the contemporary art coming up for sale. ``Michael Jackson and Bubbles,'' a 1988 porcelain sculpture of the pop star with his chimpanzee, decorated with gold metallic paint, is on view behind glass at Sotheby's New York headquarters. (Sotheby's/The New York Times)  (NYT6) WASHINGTON -- April 19, 2001 -- BUSH-HOLOCAUST -- President George W. Bush and Irving Greenberg, chairman of the United States Holocaust Memorial Council, look on as a candle is lit in memory of Holocaust victims, Thursday at the U.S. Capitol. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)  (NYT5) WASHINGTON -- April 19, 2001 -- BUSH-ENVIRON -- President Bush announced Thursday that he will sign and ask the Senate to ratify a Clinton-era treaty calling for the worldwide phaseout of a dozen highly toxic chemicals known as POPs. ``The risks are great and the need for action is clear,'' Bush said in a Rose Garden ceremony flanked by Secretary of State Colin Powell and Christie Whitman, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. Bush with Powell and Whitman head to the ceremony, Thursday. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)  (NYT4) NEW YORK -- April 19, 2001 -- PRODUCERS-THEATER-REVIEW-2 -- ``The Producers,'' the comic veteran Mel Brooks' stage adaptation of his own cult movie from 1968, is as full of gags, gadgets and gimmicks as an old vaudevillian's trunk. Everybody who sees the musical which opened on Thursday, will be hard-pressed to choose their favorite part. Nathan Lane, right, and Matthew Broderick in ``The Producers'' at the St. James Theater in New York. , they contend,	 Many economists and government officials say it is highly unlikely that the market for Japanese government bonds can collapse _ an event that would send yields soaring and could jolt markets throughout the world. Unfortunately, she said, in a place with virtually no industry, she had only two choices: a low-paying government job or a well-paying oil-industry job that would keep her away for weeks at a time on a rig full of men. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, he said,	 Satcher's spokesman, Damon Thompson, initially disputed that a call to action was ever to be released. Rather, he said, the surgeon general had convened the retreats as ``listening sessions'' to determine whether he could find common ground between two camps that have polarized the debate over sex education: supporters of comprehensive sex education, and those who would teach abstinence until marriage as the only alternative. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz

, they said,	 A stand from the surgeon general, they said, would review the research linking access to information about protection with behaviors that reduce risk. It would provide neutral, authoritative support for frank discussions about sex and for improving access to contraception. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz

If you have questions about stories, call 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927. For questions about photos, call 888-603-1036 or 212-556-4204.  ENTERTAINMENT &AMP; ARTS  (moving in `e' category)  COVER STORIES  FILM-MUSIC (Undated) _ For two years in a row, the Academy Award for best film score has gone to a classical composer: first John Corigliano for ``The Red Violin,'' then Tan Dun for ``Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.'' While cynics claim that this is the film industry's way of advertising its high-art pretensions, Hollywood may really be ahead of New York in acknowledging that the opposition between film music and concert music is a phantom of the last century. Today the two styles constantly interact. By David Schiff.  ART-TECHNOLOGY (Undated) _ Artists are engines of invention. Like children who make toys and games from pots and pans, popsicle sticks and bottle tops, artists reconfigure unlikely materials for unexpected purposes. Today they rearrange industrial goods and convert technologies to aesthetic ends, and the technological bit is becoming a contemporary specialty. In the early 20th century, art raised industrial materials to the status of a cause. In the 1960s, technology itself became the cause. Artistic appropriation of technology and collaboration with it has flourished ever since. By Vicki Goldberg.  With photo.  FILM  FILM-UMA-THURMAN (Undated) _ there are fair number of pretty faces in Hollywood, if you are not too fussy about their acting or diction and do not object to ``a clone-type of beauty,'' as the director James Ivory has put it. But for the demanding part of Charlotte Stant in their adaptation of ``The Golden Bowl,'' arguably the most challenging of Henry James' novels, Ivory and his producing partner, Ismail Merchant, were convinced that nothing less than a goddess would do. ``There was only one person who came to mind,'' said Ivory, ``who was our first choice from the very beginning, who was full of that kind of vitality and life, with a beauty that is very individual and completely beguiling, and that was Uma.'' By Jennet Conant.  With photo.  THEATER  THEATER-NYRO (New York) _ When Diane Paulus was approached with the idea of directing a musical based on the songs of Laura Nyro, she had absolutely no idea who Laura Nyro was. Nyro's renown as a performer and songwriter is for the most part confined to Paulus' baby-boomer elders, many of whom found in Nyro's emotional, often spiritual albums a passionate expression of their own bliss and anguish. By Peter Marks.  With photo.  MUSIC  MUSIC-OPERA-BORODINA (New York) _ Mezzo-soprano Olga Borodina might want to give up the sublets she has been living in since coming to New York from St. Petersburg and invest in Manhattan real estate. This season alone, she sang eight Met performances of ``Carmen,'' four of ``Aida'' and two of ``Samson et Dalila.'' On April 29, she will join James Levine and the Met Orchestra and Chorus in the Verdi Requiem at Carnegie Hall. And on May 4, she and Levine will return to Carnegie Hall for a recital of songs by Tchaikovsky, Rachmaninoff, Mahler and Falla. Cori Ellison talks with the Russian opera star.  With photo.  MUSIC-COUNTRY (Undated) _ Country music these days is defined more by what it lacks than by what it is: it's '70s rock without the sexual knowingness; singer-songwriter narratives without the desperate confessions; friendly, slickly packaged Southernness with none of the region's literary flair or ungovernable eccentricities. By Anthony DeCurtis.  TELEVISION  TV-MANHEIM (Los Angeles) _ Camryn Manheim is the star and an executive producer of a new film for ABC, ``Kiss My Act,'' which is, in its own way, revolutionary. It's one of the rare television or feature films in which the fat girl actually gets the good-looking guy. ``It happens in real life but never in television and movies,'' she said. ``Face it: more women look like me than Julia Roberts. Why can't the fat girl end up with the handsome prince?'' By Bernard Weinraub.  ART/ARCHITECTURE  ART-U.S.-FOLKART (Boston) _ The gallery evokes a New England Eden. A wall painted to look like the side of a barn is stocked with a herd of copper weather vanes, a flock of decoys floats on a Mylar pool, a watercolor giraffe nibbles on his border of stenciled leaves. A carved wooden lion with fierce eyebrows growls. And a carousel greyhound in a red and gold harness leans, ears flattened, into an imaginary wind. The installation forms part of ``American Folk,'' a beguiling exhibition that runs through Aug. 5 at the Museum of Fine Arts here. The show is the first devoted to the museum's important and growing collection of American folk art. By Deborah Weisgall.  With photo.  ART-SUPERFLAT (Hollywood) _ ``Superflat'' is the inaugural exhibition at the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art's newest gallery, a multimedia mix of high and low culture invited viewers to ponder what a life-size sculpture of a fighter plane made from 15,000 photographs of a plastic model taped on bubble wrap might have in common with giant carp swimming up New York waterfalls or with a cartoon caterpillar baring aroused female genitals. By Ariel Swartley.  BESTSELLERS, CHILDREN'S-BESTSELLERS and PAPERBACKS have all moved.  TRAVEL  (Coded `t')  COVER STORIES  TRAVEL-GORILLAS (Undated) _ In Rwanda, the intrepid can buy an expensive semiprivate audience with a small band of mountain gorillas. By Ian Fisher.  INSIDE THE SECTION  TRAVEL-PARIS-These days in Paris the choice of cuisines, flavors and styles is greater than ever. By Patricia Wells.  TRAVEL-BAHAMAS (Undated) _ On Elbow Cay in the Bahamas, it's easy to relax if you've got a golf cart (the preferred means of transport) and the right frame of mind. By Amy Harmon.  REGULAR FEATURES  PRACTICAL-TRAVELER (Undated) _ Courses in vacation settings are proliferating. Many are on the fluffier side, covering such topics as the history of swing bands. But there are classes with more substance for those who want them, and some designed to bridge generations. By Betsy Wade.  TRAVEL-Q&AMP;A (Undated) _ Travel questions and answers on tourist amenities in Siberia, where to study Portuguese and a Gypsy jazz festival in France.  TRAVEL-BRIEFS (Undated) _ The railway station in Scotland that was used for 100 years by members of the royal family on their way to their Scottish home, Balmoral Castle, has been restored and turned into a tourist attraction.  TRAVEL-AIR-CANADA (Undated) _ With the onset of spring, Americans look north again to Canada, a nation that is expected to surpass Britain this year as the most popular destination for air travelers from the United States. This summer, returning visitors will discover that over the last year Canadian skies have quietly undergone an air-travel revolution _ not entirely for the better. By James Brooke.  BUSINESS/FINANCE  (Coded `f')  ON THE SECTION FRONT  COCACOLA-AFRICA (Bom Jesus, Angola) _ This is a corner of the world unlike almost any other where Coca-Cola, the world's leading soft-drink purveyor, operates. Yet Coca-Cola is here, re-establishing itself in a country it quit 26 years ago. By Henri E. Cauvin.  With photo and graphic.  TELECOM (Undated) _ After five years of break-neck expansion, the telecommunications industry is deep in debt, a state of seeming overcapacity and a commoditized product _ thanks to unintended consequences of the '96 telecom act. Now, the industry must regroup, consolidate. By Seth Schiesel.  With photo and graphic.  MARKET-WATCH (New York) _ Weekly Wall Street commentary. By Gretchen Morgenson.  With graphic.  INSIDE THE SECTION:  IDEAS-COM (Undated) _ Ideas.com, one of the web companies founded to match companies that need ideas with people that have them, is about to have some success. By Deborah Kong.  With photo.  FIVE-QUESTIONS-WACHTER (Undated) _ Laurie Wachter, vice president in charge of the Consumer Insights Group at IRI, answers questions about the marketing implications of the 2000 census. By Julie Flaherty.  BIZ-BOOKS (Undated) _ In ``Creative Destruction,'' by Richard Foster and Sarah Kaplan, two McKinsey consultants seek to shatter what they call the myth that powerful ``built to last'' companies can excel indefinitely. Reviewed by Fred Andrews.  INVESTING  INVEST-MUTFUNDS (Undated) _ Some funds are unconcerned about whether the market goes up or down, relying strictly on how well they pick stocks. A look at how is this approach working? By Danny Hakim.  With graphic.  INVEST-INSIGHT-Q&AMP;A (Undated) _ Marc Cohen, a tobacco analyst at Goldman Sachs &AMP; Co., talks about the challenges and opportunities confronting Big Tobacco. By Kenneth N. Gilpin.  INVEST-TILLINGHAST-FIDELITY (Undated) _ Investment Q&AMP;A with Joel Tillinghast, manager of Fidelity Low Priced Stock fund. By Danny Hakim.  With graphic.  INVEST-CENDANT (Undated) _ Cendant, the troubled insurer, seems to be making headway under new, lavishly-paid management. But big hurdles remain. By Dan Colarusso.  FINANCIAL COMMENTARY  STRATEGIES-COLUMN (Undated) _ Tortoises of investing, take heart. One of your standard-bearers, Charles Allmon, has come on so strongly over the last year and a half that he now is within shouting distance of leading the pack. By Mark Hulbert.  With graphic.  MIDSTREAM-COLUMN (Undated) _ Like every other generation that has tried to raise a family, save for college and retirement and still go out to dinner once in awhile, baby boomers are sensitive about taxes.By James Schembari.  AUTOS  ABOUTCARS-KOREAN (Undated) _ Reviews of the Hyundai XG300 and the Kia Optima. By Peter Passell.  STYLE  (Coded `l')  GREATEST-GENERATION (Undated) _ ``Pearl Harbor,'' a $135 million production starring Ben Affleck, opens on Memorial Day. ``Flags of Our Fathers,'' a star-spangled tribute by the son of one of the Iwo Jima flag-raisers, is a best seller. Tom Brokaw's ``greatest generation'' cottage industry continues with ``An Album of Memories,'' out next week. And George W. Bush has installed a bust of Dwight D. Eisenhower in the Oval Office. Like the Allied forces on D-Day, waves of World War II worship keep on coming. Were the men and women of World War II really the greatest generation? By Rick Marin.  With photo.  RHODE-ISLAND (Undated) _ Rhode Island's biggest tourist attraction is not so much its glittering coastline, but its seedy, gothic heart _ an element less accurately portrayed in Edith Wharton's high-brow novels than by the Farrelly brothers (``Dumb and Dumber'') and Barbet Schroeder (``Reversal of Fortune''). ``What's intriguing about Rhode Island is this undercurrent of petty crime, and what makes it delicious is that it's set against this incredible beauty,'' said Maria Flook, whose darkly comic novel ``Open Water'' (Pantheon, 1994) was a Rhode Island postcard, an opera of small cons and dashed hopes. By Penelope Green.  RAMONE-REMEMBERED (Undated) _ Joey Ramone, the gawky, geeky, lovable-loser singer of the Ramones, died last Sunday of lymphatic cancer, never to be underestimated again. His real name was Jeffrey Hyman; he was 49. As the music world celebrates the 25th anniversary of punk, the band's imprint _ its goofy fury and delinquent humor _ echoes not just in the music of latter-day punks like Green Day and Blink 182, but in the strain of self-aware, loser comedy that has become the dominant adolescent rattle: ``The Simpsons'' and ``South Park,'' pro wrestling and MTV's blithely moronic ``Jackass.'' By John Leland.  WIFEBEATER-FASHION (Undated) _ `Wifebeater,' the street name for the sleeveless t-shirt, has entered the fashion lexicon. Those who use the term insist that it is not meant to demean women or condone domestic violence; instead, they say, it playfully refers to a stereotype, conjuring lumpen brutes ranging from Ralph Cramden to Tony Soprano. By Elizabeth Hayt. , he said,	 The initial evidence, he said, was observational. Scientists found a ``dose-response relationship'' between smoking and disease: The more a person smoked, the greater the likelihood of sickness. They found a temporal relationship: smoking preceded cancer. But still, the tobacco industry could claim that there was no proof. That did not change, Forrest said, until molecular biologists showed smoking caused genetic changes in the lung. Now, he said, the industry ``can no longer say `there is no connection, it's not proven.''' </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz

, she said,	 The current definition of a slave, according to Beth Herzfeld, of the London watchdog group Anti-Slavery International, is someone ``forced to work under physical or mental threat, and where the owner or employer controls the person completely _ where a person is bought or sold.'' There are also, she said, restrictions on freedom of movement, no pay or very little and no say over hours, holidays or rest. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, he said,	 You have to move forward in a parallel manner on different fronts, and then one of them sometimes produces the breakthrough,'' said Juan Somavia, director general of the International Labor Organization in Geneva, which is beginning a campaign to eliminate the worst forms of child labor, with initial programs in El Salvador, Nepal, Tanzania and West Africa. Most important, he said, is awareness-raising and community involvement. Legislation, labor courts and labor inspections are other forces for change. So are the companies that use child labor themselves, said Somavia, a former Chilean diplomat. ``A basic element for companies today is image,'' he said. ``That's a leverage.'' </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz

DRUMMOND AYRES JR. c.2001 New York Times News Service  The 2002 congressional elections are 18 months away, but already the White House is involved in the effort to tip the 50-50 balance in the Senate to the Republican side.  President Bush, Vice President Dick Cheney and the top White House political strategist, Karl Rove, are personally, even bluntly, injecting themselves into some races, pressuring candidates they consider weak to get out and urging reluctant but more promising runners (in the White House view) to get in.  Three weeks ago, Mayor Norm Coleman of St. Paul, Minn., felt the pressure. Coleman, who ran the Bush campaign in Minnesota last year, had been thinking about trying to unseat Minnesota's governor, Jesse Ventura, an independent, but the White House saw him as the best Republican bet to take on Sen. Paul Wellstone, a Democrat who some polls indicate is vulnerable.  Bush summoned Coleman for a little chat in the Rose Garden. Rove held a follow-up talk. Whereupon last weekend Coleman abandoned his hope to be governor and announced that he was ``putting the pieces together'' to take on Wellstone.  A couple of days later, the majority leader of the Minnesota House, Tim Pawlenty, felt the pressure.  Pawlenty was about to announce that he, too, intended to take on Wellstone. But then Cheney called, warning that a Pawlenty-Coleman primary fight might be too divisive. So rather than announce, Pawlenty renounced _ but not without lamenting as he departed that ``it makes you wonder about the integrity of the process.''  Meanwhile, next door in South Dakota, Rep. John Thune is beginning to feel the pressure. He wants to run for governor (the seat is open, with no serious Democratic opposition in sight), but the White House wants him to take on Sen. Tim Johnson, a Democrat who some Republican strategists think is vulnerable.  Bush had a talk with Thune in early March and then invited him and his wife, Kimberley, to the White House Thursday for a quiet dinner _ and more talk.  No word on how things went.  Looking Down the Road in a Trip to Louisiana  Speaking of the search for strong Senate candidates...  Bush is scheduled to make a swing through Louisiana this week to promote his congressional agenda, and if a new poll has it right, while he is there he might consider casting around a bit for someone to take on Sen. Mary Landrieu next year.  Landrieu, a moderate Democrat, won a first term in 1996 by fewer than 6,000 of the 1.7 million votes cast. And ever since, Republican strategists have regarded her as one of the most vulnerable Democrats in the Senate. In fact, one reason Bush is headed for Louisiana is to put pressure on her by lobbying for his tax and budget proposals while in her back yard.  But the new poll may give him pause, along with the once-confident Republican strategists.  The poll, conducted two weeks ago for a consortium of Louisiana television stations by Southern Media and Opinion Research of Baton Rouge, has Landrieu holding a 2-1 lead over each of the two Republicans who have indicated an interest in challenging her, Rep. John Cooksey, who hails from the 5th Congressional District in the state's northeast corner, and Suzanne Haik Terrell, the state's elections commissioner.  Landrieu called the poll ``pleasing,'' but noted that the campaign had hardly gotten under way.  Cooksey and Terrell did their best to find something pleasing in the numbers. Cooksey said he was encouraged by his level of support so early in the campaign. Terrell said she was flattered.  Perot's Battered Army Hangs On, and On  The Reform Party peaked in political power in the 1992 presidential election, when Ross Perot captured 19 percent of the vote. Since then, the trip has been all downhill.  It turned out that the party was not really a party. The party was Ross Perot, voluble billionaire, willing to spend millions to promote a populist, reformist agenda. Then he and the country lost interest.  But Russell Verney didn't lose interest.  Verney, Perot's political adviser, kept plugging away, hanging around Dallas, using the Perot name and sometimes a bit _ a pittance, really _ of the Perot money to somehow keep the wheezing organization on a lifeline. ``I believe in this'' was his mantra.  He hung on for nine long years, long enough to see the final remnant of the party implode at its 2000 nominating convention, long enough to see its nominee, Pat Buchanan, stumble across the finish line in November with 0.5 percent of the popular vote.  A few surviving Perotistas vow to continue the fight.  Verney is not among them.  Last week, he said he was negotiating to open a Dallas office for Judicial Watch, a conservative group that monitors legal affairs. Finally, he said, he will be leaving Perot's employ.  Forever and ever, amen?  ``I would never really leave Ross,'' he told The Fort Worth Star-Telegram. ``I love the man. He's my hero.'' </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010421.0140 type=story > <HEADLINE> SPORTS COLUMN: JORDAN SHOULD COME OUT OF RETIREMENT </HEADLINE> <DATELINE>  (BC-BKN-ARATON-COLUMN-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz

, he said,	 Turkey poults, young-of-the-year birds, were clearly in short supply last fall in New York. Glenn Cole, a biologist who retired last month from the Department of Environmental Conservation, said that in good years, the ratio of poults to adult hens in the fall is about 3 to 1; last fall that ratio was about 1 to 1, he said, many of the juveniles having been claimed by the inclement weather in early summer. A hen usually has 10 to 12 eggs in her nest. Newly hatched poults are subject to respiratory infections. When they are truly small, the hen can gather them under her and protect them from the elements, but soon there is not room for the entire brood. At six to eight weeks, turkeys are nearly as large as an adult ruffed grouse. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz

Word around Edmonton is that the Oilers have decided to exercise their right to switch places in the June draft with the Bruins. Figure the Oilers for No. 13 and the Bruins at No. 19. , they multiply,	 The growing process involves a biological trick. Incyte actually inserts its gene fragments into harmless bacteria. It is these gene-bearing bacteria that are stored in the freezers. When chilled, the bacteria don't grow. At the proper temperature, however, they multiply, creating more copies of the stored gene. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz

, he said,	 Loan sharking in New York's Latino neighborhoods appears to be flourishing despite local law-enforcement efforts. Dan Castleman, the chief of the Manhattan district attorney's investigations division, said loan-sharking prosecutions were traditionally spun off from inquiries into illegal gambling and were often associated with organized crime. Loan sharking in New York's newly arrived immigrant communities, he said, is a different phenomenon and is hard to pursue. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, he said,	 The loan sharks portray themselves as ordinary businessmen providing a service where their mainstream competitors fear to tread. Tony, the loan shark active in Washington Heights, says that he and his two partners have lent millions of dollars to mostly Dominican clients to help start area businesses. One of his biggest loans, he said, was $2.5 million to start a supermarket in Washington Heights. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, he said,	 Instead, he said that much like a bank, he and his partners secured collateral to seize if the loan failed _ often property that the borrower is trying to lease or buy. Tony said that was usually accomplished by holding the title of the property until the loan was repaid. Lewis can be reached by e-mail at dlewis(at)globe.com. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010423.0177 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-MOVIE-GUIDE-BOS) </DATELINE> <TEXT> MOVIES RECENTLY REVIEWED IN THE BOSTON GLOBE (For use by New York Times News Service clients) c.2001 The Boston Globe  !! ``Beautiful Creatures'' This film about brutish louts in Glasgow getting whacked by their abused women often plays like an exercise. That's partly because it seems to be speaking in somebody else's voice and not its own, partly because its stylizations become an end in themselves. Still, it's worth watching Rachel Weisz and Susan Lynch discover the joys of vengeance. (R)  !!! 1/2 ``The Claim'' Michael Winterbottom brilliantly transposes Thomas Hardy's novel of moral payback, ``The Mayor of Casterbridge,'' to the American West between the California Gold Rush and the building of the transcontinental railroad. The setting, a mining camp in the Sierra Nevadas, sometimes overwhelms the characters, including Peter Mullan's rich and powerful man corroded from within. But the visuals also conjure up a punishing yet breathtaking magnificence. (R)  ! ``Crocodile Dundee in Los Angeles'' A sequel whose time has come _ and gone. Paul Hogan's Croc journeys from the Australian Outback to La-La Land and looks dispiritingly at home there in this listless comedy that hasn't got enough energy or flavor even to seem bad. (PG)  !! ``Freddy Got Fingered'' Star, director, and co-writer Tom Green doesn't so much push the envelope as shred it. His gross-out comedy is crude and stupid, but also rudely funny as it rides a subtext of parental violence toward children. The id is alive and unwell in this gleeful demolishing of taboos that's calculated to offend. In an industry of largely abject cowardice, Green's fearlessness is invigorating. (R)  !! 1/2 ``The Low Down'' This ensemble comedy about North London types trying to figure out their next moves is carried mostly by Aidan Gillen's passive-aggressive slacker and Kate Ashfield as the woman who loves him. With its hand-held camerawork and workshop flavor, it plays like an improv, relying on charm to get it past its underdevelopment. (Unrated) </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010423.0178 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-WORKING-BRIEFS-BOS) </DATELINE> <TEXT> REICH STRESSES NEED FOR BALANCE (For use by New York Times News Service clients) By BRUCE BUTTERFIELD c.2001 The Boston Globe  Robert Reich worries that work threatens to be an all-consuming enterprise for an American family that is already trying to cope with the stress of too much time spent trying to balance the demands of home and office.  So much for the idea that technology was going to make everybody's life easier.  ``Forget it. Forget it,'' the former US labor secretary advised a group of 200 business and education leaders at the third annual Work Force Preparedness Summit in Natick, Mass. ``We were sold a bill of goods.''  Reich shook his head. And some of those in the audience agreed, it seemed, that the pace of life was getting a little too fast. But what to do, one asked?  ``Life is more than grades for college, getting a BA degree, and earning money,'' Reich told the group, many of them middle-aged parents with high demands on their children as well as themselves. ``Life is more than that.''  ``Some (of you) are having midlife crises now, just to find that out,'' he added.  The line drew big laughs. But everybody knew it was made of serious stuff.  Reich said the new global economy is producing undeniable benefits: greater wealth, flexibility in where work is done, and more innovation in how it's done. But its downside is pretty big, too, he noted. It includes longer work weeks, a drive for success that can often stifle creativity and individuality, and stresses on the family.  Much of this new pressure is being transferred to children as well, maintained Reich. They are pressured to have spotless academic records, overscheduled in activities parents believe will help their futures, pushed to win acceptance into top colleges. ``All the middle-class kids have to prove they are above average _ it's so ingrained in our society, it seems we can't change it,'' Reich said.  But it has to change, he added.  ``They have no time, no poetry, no realizations in their lives,'' he said. The result is that many young people may be quietly turning off.  ``That smell of resignation is what worries me,'' he added.  Reich said what worries him about parents is a different resignation _ one that has them convinced they have no choice but to run full tilt at work _ whether they are making huge incomes or struggling to pay the weekly bills.  ``It's robbing us of a lot of our lives outside of work,'' he said. ``the average middle-class family with children today is doing seven weeks more paid work (a year) than they did in l990.''  That, he added, doesn't include extra time spent at night checking and replying to e-mail on the home computer _ time taken away from family activities.  Reich said it was the dwindling time he had to spend with his own family, particularly his two sons, that led him to resign his Cabinet post in Washington and return to Massachusetts. He is currently a professor at Brandeis University, and the author of a new book, ``The Future of Success.''  All the extra work Americans do is not even benefiting most families in a significant financial way, he said. Reich told the group that only the top tier of middle-class families _ he put it at the top 5 percent _ have made substantial income gains in the last decade.  For middle-class families below that tier, he said, the median family income in Massachusetts adjusted for inflation rose barely at all, about $10,000 totally since l990.  Workers at the bottom did even worse. ``It is not easily reversed,'' he said, but it needs to be. ``We don't want to live in a two-tier economy.''  Firms don't see Net  as source of growth  Nearly 40 percent of small and midsize companies recently surveyed by the Conference Board expect to be acquired or form operating partnerships with major firms in order to survive and grow over the next five years. But the Internet does not factor greatly in the expectations of most.  ``Surprisingly, very few of the surveyed companies say the Internet will play a major role in their future growth,'' the Conference Board said. Indeed, Howard Muson, author of the survey for the Conference Board, said many companies ``are still scared to death of the Internet.''  The survey found only 10 percent of the companies identified the Internet as a key source in expected growth, with the majority concerned about the costs and complexities of Internet technology itself. Most companies said they expected growth from new customers, new products and services, and from acquisitions.  The Conference Board said is survey included 184 firms in a wide range of industries across the country.  Diverse industry base  a draw for top execs  So where do managers and executives go to find new jobs when they've been let go and want to get out of their hometowns?  Look no further than Chicago, San Diego, Denver, Austin, and Charlotte, N.C., according to a survey by Challenger, Gray &AMP; Christmas Inc., the international outplacement firm.  ``From a job seeker's point of view, these cities are perceived to have the most to offer in terms of employment,'' said John A. Challenger, chief executive of the Chicago firm. He said each city was cited for having a diverse industry base to help insulate the local economy during recessions and economic slowdowns.  But the so-called livability of the five cities was also cited. Noting his hometown is Chicago, Challenger said it was a top-pick city for relocating executives in part because it is seen ``as the most livable among large US cities.'' However, he gave no specific reasons for such a view.  San Diego was cited for its climate and ocean; Denver for the allure of the Rocky Mountains; and Austin and Charlotte were viewed as thriving yet still manageable new economy cities despite their rapid growth. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010423.0179 type=story > <HEADLINE> PLAYING BLUFF WITH SELLING ARMS TO TAIWAN </HEADLINE> <DATELINE>  (BC-GREENWAY-COLUMN-BOS) </DATELINE> <TEXT> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, he said,	 She kicked his can in three straight sets. Two years later he confided to me (true or not, we'll never know) that he went into that King match suffering from diarrhea and that, he said, ``if you study the tape of that match, I took one extra long timeout and left the court to change my shorts.'' </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, she said,	 But it's also an area many employers seem willing to overlook. One recent job hunter, laid off by Accessmagazine.com of Needham, Mass. in March, said she signed a noncompete agreement when she began work there last October, but no one mentioned it when she left. And in her first five interviews for another job, she said, no one asked whether she was bound by any such agreement. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, it appears,	 But the US government, it appears, has other intentions. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, they said,	 This, and several other clauses, gives the United States the power to lower the cost of ddI if it sees fit, according to legal specialists who have analyzed the agreement. The quickest way, they said, would be to allow foreign companies to make cheap generic versions of ddI. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, they note,	 But activists point out that the pills are still expensive for most Africans. And other Third World nations, they note, are not being offered similar deals. A case in point is Thailand. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, he said,	 To save cash in the long term, George McManigle, a Fallbrook grower whose 7.5 acres came with the property he purchased in September 1993, installed a solar system to heat his hot water and a more energy-efficient refigerator in the trailer used by his hired hand. He got rid of his own spare refrigerator. His goal, he said, is both to relieve his wallet and help alleviate the energy crisis that is now hitting other states. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, he said,	 The United States and other NATO countries, he said, are worried about suffering excessive casualties attempting to detain the heavily guarded Karadzic. They are also concerned about turning him into a martyr should he be killed in an arrest attempt. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, she has,	 The show is modeled after a typical newscast _ you know, with perfectly coifed anchors who read the headlines in a practiced, perky pitch. There's Victoria Sinclair at the top of the webcast. She opens with a story about the Israeli offensive in Palestine; the camera pulls back, and she unbuttons her shirt to reveal a silky, red bra. Next is a piece about rebels in Columbia; off goes the shirt. By the time she wraps up with an item about the anniversary of the Bay of Pigs, she has, shall we say, stripped the story right down to the bone. ``If they bomb us from above, we'll bomb them from below,'' she says, quoting a Cuban defense minister and flashing a prim, little smile. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, it seems,	 Even then, Bush was carefully avoiding using the word ``voucher,'' and his current stance puts even more distance between himself and the voucher proposals _ all, it seems, as a way to save the bulk of his education reform plan. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, they were,	 Robert Ellis Gordon, a novelist, ran writing workshops for nearly a decade inside Washington state prisons. His students included killers, armed robbers, and ``rapos'' (rapists). By Sandra Blakeslee.  SCI-TELLER-HBOMB (Undated) _ After a heart attack, Dr. Edward Teller sat down with a friend and a tape recorder and discussed the secret history of the hydrogen bomb. The first design, he said, ``was made by Dick Garwin.'' Teller, now 93, was not ceding the laurels for devising the bomb _ a glory he claims for himself. But he was rewriting how the rough idea became the world's most feared weapon. His tribute, made more than two decades ago but just now coming to light, adds a surprising twist to a dispute that has roiled historians and scientists for decades: Who should get credit for designing the H-bomb? A transcript of the conversation was made available to The Times. By William J. Broad. (2100 words)  With photos, NYT1,2.  SCI-BRAZIL-GENOMICS (Sao Paolo) _ The Research Support Foundation of the State of Sao Paulo is rapidly becoming a powerhouse in genomics and a model for scientific investigation in the third world. In July, a Brazilian consortium organized and financed by the foundation became the first anywhere to decode the genome of a plant pathogen, Xylella fastidiosa, an insect-borne bacteria that infests oranges. A few months later, the foundation, known as Fapesp, announced it had completed the genetic sequence of a second pest that plagues this country's thriving fruit export industry, Xanthomonas citri, or citrus canker. The twin successes not only established its international reputation but also led to collaborations with other important research agencies. By Larry Rohter. (1590 words)  With photo, NYT6.  SCI-HEART-TRAINING (Undated) _ Health clubs and cardiologists all over the country compute the maximum heart rate by subtracting a person's age from 220. Trouble is that formula doesn't work for at least 40 percent of the population, and that has ramifications for cardiac testing. Even the man who devised the formula says it's only an approximation that has taken on a life all its own. By Gina Kolata. (1750 words)  SCI-IONIC-LIQUIDS (Undated) _ Substances with chemical structures similar to table salt _ but look and flow like water _ may one day become environmentally friendly replacements for some of the noxious solvents used by industry. They're called ionic liquids, essentially salts with low melting temperatures. Although still years away from widespread industrial use, ionic liquids are attracting the interest of Exxon Mobil, BP Amoco and other companies. By Kenneth Chang. (890 words)  SCI-MESOSCALE-BIOLOGY (Undated) _ One submicropscopic area remains largely a mystery to experts: This is the region containing matter on a scale of 10 to 1,000 angstroms (an angstrom being one billionth of a meter) _ bigger than a simple molecule but smaller than a living cell. This is the realm in which the constituents of cells interact with one another. Now scientists are trying to penetrate that realm, known as the mesoscale. By Sandra Blakeslee. (1585 words)  SCI-DOG-BARKS (Undated) _ A small band of researchers around the world, trying to separate fact from speculation, are finding that dogs almost always bark for a reason, even if that reason isn't apparent to humans. Dog barks can be noisy, harmonic or a combination of the two, depending on their context and purpose. One study shows how different barks express different emotions, including loneliness, fear, distress, stress and pleasure, as well as a need for care among puppies _ and serve to alert other dogs, people or animals to changing external circumstances. By Mark Derr. (1100 words)  SCI-STEM-CELLS (Undated) _ Secretary Tommy Thompson of Health and Human Services tells the National Institutes of Health to hold off on considering grants for embryonic stem cell research, pending a legal review of the issue by HHS. By Nicholas Wade. (450 words)  SCI-WATCH (Undated) _ News and notes on science: Items on the genome of cheese, female elderly elephants and their role in the family, and toxic waste sites. By Henry Fountain. (680 words)  SCI-OMEGA3-DIET (Undated) _ A type of fat called Omega-3 and found mostly in fish is emerging as essential to good health. Lack of it may play a role in a number of modern maladies, including cardiac arrhythmia, irritable bowel syndrome and rheumatoid arthritis. Late last year the American Heart Association recommended that everyone include salmon or tuna in his diet at least twice a week, the first time the organization has departed from a general guideline to recommend a specific food. By Jim Robbins. (1200 words)  With photo, NYT5.  SCI-VENTILATION-HEALTH (Undated) _ As the population ages and medical technology gets better, the number of patients in the United States receiving long-term mechanical ventilation has been rising, from 6,000 in the mid-1980s to at least 12,000 and perhaps 20,000 or more today, experts on critical care say. The number of centers caring for these patients has also grown, from about 100 in 1990 to 240 today. Their care is expensive, and some tough decisions have to be made about financing it. By Sandeep Jauhar. (1465 words)  With photo, NYT4.  SCI-BRODY-HEALTH (Undated) _ Second of two Personal Health columns on getting sober. People who have mastered alcohol abstinence explain how they do it, and it isn't necessarily one day at a time. By Jane E. Brody.  SCI-BIKING-UP-EVEREST (Undated) _ This exercise group calls it Mount Everest. It's a four-hour stationary bike climb becoming increasingly popular at health clubs. A first-person account of what it involves. By Gina Kolata. (850 words)  With photo, NYT7.  SCI-VITAL-SIGNS (Undated) _ News and notes on health and fitness. By Eric Nagourney.  _ In a report that has implications for both commercial woodworkers and people who doing repairs at home, federal health authorities say they have found evidence that significant amounts of lead may remain in a piece of wood even after a solvent removes lead-based paint. (240 words)  _ Light therapy for seasonal affective disorder may benefit tissues as well as the eyes. (220 words)  _ Researchers at Duke and Veterans Affairs say they have evidence that many people who have trouble staying asleep may be better served by taking sleep training in which they learn to change their behavior. (265 words)  _ If you just can't get a certain song out of your head, it may not be because the tune is particularly catchy. It could be a brain aneurysm. Mayo Clinic reported on just such a case recently. The aneurysms were repaired and the music went away. (175 words)  _ Why is the rate of obesity going up in America? One explanation may be as simple as tearing open a bag of corn chips: snacking. (215 words)  SCI-Q&AMP;A (Undated) _ A science question answered: Is there any treatment for vitiligo, the loss of skin pigment that leaves white patches on the body, and, what causes it? By C. Claiborne Ray. (285 words)  Photos, where indicated, are being sent to NYT photo clients. Graphics, to NYT graphic clients. TO DOGS, IT'S ALL JUST TALK </HEADLINE> <DATELINE>  (BC-SCI-DOG-BARKS-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, she reported,	 The results, she reported, graphically portray how different barks express different emotions, including loneliness, fear, distress, stress and pleasure, as well as a need for care among puppies _ and serve to alert other dogs, people or animals to changing external circumstances. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, she said,	 Feddersen-Petersen made recordings for her work while the dogs were engaged in normal behavior, so she was able over repeated sessions to observe how dogs were barking in specific situations. After a while, she said, she began to be able to tell what a dog was doing by its bark. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, she noted,	 Like many canid vocalizations, these barks are often associated with physical cues, like a wrinkling of the brow, staring, raised hackles, pinned back ears, an upright or lowered tail and other submissive or threatening postures, Feddersen-Petersen said. But, she noted, in a wide range of breeds physical expression is limited because of the lack of a tail, floppy ears and other physical characteristics. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, she added,	 A few breeds, like the poodle and the American Staffordshire terrier, appear limited in their vocal repertory, she added, although none as severely as the barkless basenji. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, she said,	 Overall said researchers also needed to study the apparent capacity of dogs to apply barks to different contexts and objects. For example, she said, her Australian shepherd, Flash, has a separate bark for each species that visits the backyard _ fox, deer, woodchuck and the neighbor's cat. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, he said,	 The best fish oil formulas, he said, are made from small fish like anchovies or sardines because they are low on the food chain and do not accumulate toxins. Cod liver oil is not a good alternative, he said, because it contains too much vitamin A. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, it seems,	 His touch had deserted him, he had left interest rates too high for too long. The ``Greenspan put'' _ the idea that share prices would not fall far, because the Federal Reserve's chairman would cut rates to rescue them _ was in tatters. But not, it seems, where it really mattered: in the stock market itself. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz

, they said,	 This, and several other clauses, gives the United States the power to lower the cost of ddI if it sees fit, according to legal specialists who have analyzed the agreement. , they note,	 But activists point out that the pills are still expensive for most Africans. And other Third World nations, they note, are not being offered similar deals. A case in point is Thailand. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, he hopes,	 In fact Ovid is seeing another woman: his new patron, Julia, Augustus' granddaughter, who will give him access, he hopes, to the emperor himself. , he said,	 Lauer pays no attention to 220 minus age formula when he gives treadmill tests. , he said,	 The danger, he said, is that when doctors use that formula to decide when to end a treadmill test, some patients may be stopping too soon and others may seem to have a heart problem because they never can get to what is supposed to be their maximum rate. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz

For Immediate Release  The Boston Globe plans to move the following FEATURE stories for use by NYTimes News Service clients.  For questions about stories, please contact Frank Perrotta at the Boston Globe, 617-929-2597. For individual purchase of budgeted graphics or photos please call 212-556-4204 or 888-603-1036.  All stories will bear the BOS designator.  INTERNATIONAL (i)  FALUN-GONG (Undated) _ The Falun Gong cult started out trying to eschew politics but, in the face of sustained Chinese attempts at repression, it's trotting out a sharper and more sophisticated political response. By Charles Radin. 1130 words.  CHINA-WEB (Undated) _ As tensions between rise after the crash landing of a US spy plane on a Chinese island, expatriate Chinese are keenly interested in events back home. Many stay connected through independent Chinese websites that in recent years have become important conduits of information. By Megan Tench. 740 words.  AFRICA-AIDS (Pretoria) _ In the aftermath of the collapse of the pharmaceutical industry suit over access to cheaper AIDS drugs, South Africa faces tough decisions on how to improve treatment and prevention. By Kurt Shillinger. 985 words.  JAPAN-ELECTION (Tokyo) _ Japanese politicians are starting to worry about the repercussions of ignoring the popular will. By Sharon Moshavi. 650 words.  FOREIGN-JOURNAL (Sarajevo) _ Some people joke about war-crimes suspect Radovan Karadzic. But he's is no joke for those looking for the Balkans' most wanted man. By Brian Whitmore. 850 words.  WASHINGTON (w)  AIDS-RESEARCH (Undated) _ Universities with lucrative patent rights for AIDS drugs have taken considerable heat recently. They collect profits while neglecting to help lower prices for the drugs in the Third World, critics say. But one such patent holder has escaped attention: the US government. By Raja Mishra. 1860 words. (w and i coding)  NATIONAL (a)  ENERGY-AVOCADO (Fallbrook, Calif.) _ Rising energy prices in California are putting a financial squeeze on avocado growers, who need to run pumps yearround to irrigate their perennial crop. By Lynda Gorov. 1300 words.  MISSING-SON (Lowell, Mass.) -- For Walter Poirier Jr.'s parents every day is a mix of anguish and anger. Anguish over the fate of their son, a Peace Corps volunteer who on Feb. 22 walked out of the mayor's office in La Paz, Bolivia and vanished. Anger at what the parents believe is the inadequate search by Bolivian authorities and US Embassy officials. By Marcella Bombardieri. 1060 words.  COMMENTARY (k)  MCNAMARA-COLUMN (Undated) _ Straight talk did not begin in modern politics with Senator John McCain of Arizona; it began with Governor Meldrim Thomson of New Hampshire. By Eileen McNamara.  JACOBY-COLUMN (Undated) _ These operations _ you put your ground troops in, you pull your ground troops out _ will do nothing to enhance Israel's security, and less than nothing to deter Palestinian violence. By Jeff Jacoby.  GREENWAY-COLUMN (Undated) _ Playing bluff with selling arms to Taiwan. By H.D. S. Greenway.  JORDAN-COLUMN (Undated) _ President Bush quietly drops his school-voucher idea. By Robert A. Jordan.  (Eds.: Thomas Oliphant's column is unavailable today.)  ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS (e)  TV-VIDEO-VIXENS (Undated) _ Watch a few minutes of BET or MTV and you're bombarded with images of scantily clad women, shot from the most lascivious angles. The genre has produced its own stars, its own tribute songs _ and a backlash. By Vanessa Jones. 1420 words.  w/  TV-STRIPPERS (Undated) _ Television only pays attention to strippers when telling morality tales about girls gone wrong. Except for HBO, with the series, ``G-String Divas,'' not to mention a powerful story line involving one of the dancers at the Bada Bing, the club featured in ``The Sopranos.'' By Matthew Gilbert. 770 words.  w/  WEB-NAKED (Undated) _ Nakednews.com is a very popular Web site in which news anchors read the headlines in the nude. By Patti Hartigan. 920 words.  MUSIC-JACKSON (Undated) _ ``All About You,'' Janet Jackson's new album, shows an artist struggling with divorce but still delivering musically. By Renee Graham. 870 words.  BOOK-LASTTIME (Undated) _ In a sex 'n' doom oeuvre that has quickened countless pulses, most of them female, over the past decade, Anita Shreve has taken singular advantage of this portent of misery, offering in her novels a plane crash a drowning and an adulterous scandal of Hester Prynne proportion. By Gail Caldwell. 1050 words.  BOOK-FUNHOUSE (Undated) _ ``The Funhouse Mirror: Reflections on Prison,'' is a powerful account of what it's like to be a teacher behind bars. By Dick Lehr.  MOVIE-VIDEOS (Undated) _ Good and bad in video films. By Globe staff.  WORKPLACE (f)  WORKING-COMPETE (Undated) _ Back in the salad days of the new economy, many workers blithely signed noncompete agreements. But these employment agreements have come back to haunt some of their signers in an economy that now seethes with knowledgable people laid off by troubled companies. By Jerry Ackerman. 1700 words. By Kenneth Hooker.  The Boston Globe </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010423.0275 type=multi > <DATELINE>  (BC-WORLD-BIZ-BRIEFS-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> WORLD BUSINESS NEWS IN BRIEF c.2001 New York Times News Service  AMERICAS  BRAZIL: OIL COMPANY FINED  Brazil's state-owned oil company Petroleo Brasileiro SA, or Petrobras, was fined a total of $8.9 million by federal environmental regulators after recent accidents in two offshore rigs spilled nearly 400,000 gallons of oil into the sea 120 miles off the coast of Rio de Janeiro. Petrobras was also cited for inappropriately using detergents while cleaning up the smaller of the two spills, caused by an uncontrolled gush of oil earlier this month. A final report on the cause of the explosion that killed eleven workers and sank the company's largest oil platform in March is still pending.  EUROPE  GERMANY: CONFIDENCE GAUGE FALLS  A closely watched barometer of German business confidence dropped again in March, providing new evidence that the U.S. economic slowdown has affected Europe. The IFO index of business confidence, based on a monthly survey by the IFO research institute in Munich, dropped for the ninth month in a row and reached its lowest level in 12 months. But the decline was much smaller than last month, and it merely seemed to corroborate expectations that economic growth in Germany, Europe's biggest economy, will drop from about 3 percent last year to nearly 2 percent this year. Despite signs of trouble, the European Central Bank reiterated its view that European growth would remain relatively healthy and that there was no need to emulate the United States in lowering interest rates.  BRITAIN: HOTEL ACQUISITION  As hotel operators compete for trade among Europe's business travelers, Hilton Group PLC, which owns the Hilton chain outside the United States, said it would buy Sweden's Scandic Hotels AB for $890 million, adding 133 hotels in Scandinavia and 21 in other parts of Europe. The price represented a 31 percent premium over Scandic's closing price last Friday. The Swedish company's stock rose by as much as 34 kronor to a record 144 kronor, and Hilton's stock was up 18 pence in London at 238.5 pence. Hilton's chief executive, David Michels, said he was seeking acquisitions in Europe. As hotel groups consolidate in Europe, Marriott International and Bass PLC's Holiday Inns are also moving to extend chains on the continent.  ITALY: PHONE DIRECTORY PURCHASE  Seeking European dominance in the telephone directory business, Italy's acquisitive Seat Pagine Gialle SpA said it had agreed to buy Sweden's Eniro AB for $2.7 billion, a 36 percent premium over Friday's closing price. Analysts said the price was high, and Seat PG stock fell by 10 percent to 1.33 euros, compounding big losses over the past 12 months. Eniro's stock rose by up to 12.4 per cent to 136 kronor. The deal will give Seat PG new business in northern and eastern Europe and sharpen competition with British Telecommunications PLC and Telefonica SA of Spain in online directory services, analysts said.  ASIA  KOREA: MORE BAILOUT MONEY  South Korea's finance minister, Jin Nyum, said Monday that the government would have to plow another 28 trillion won, more than $20 billion, into banking institutions this year to keep them afloat. The government has already spent 134.7 trillion won ($102 billion) trying to put the country's financial sector back on a firm footing since the onset of the economic crisis in late 1997. Many banks in South Korea are overstaffed and inefficient and have huge amounts of bad debt on their books. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010423.0276 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-HEARST-NEWS-BUDGET-1STLD-WRITETHRU-HNS) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Monday, May 31, 2001  Editors  The Hearst News Service will file the following for Tuesday. By KAREN MASTERSON. By TODD ACKERMAN.  WALKER-OBIT (Houston) _ Former astronaut David Walker, who made four space shuttle flights, including the 1989 flight that launched a probe that mapped the surface of Venus, died Monday at the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston. By SUSAN BARDWELL. By CLAY ROBISON. By ARMANDO VILLAFRANCA. But other county officials say the situation is not that dire. By TERRY KLIEWER. Soon none of them will be alive to see it. The N.Y. Times News Service night supervisor is Pat Ryan; phone: (888) 346-9867; e-mail: patryan(at)nytimes.com.  INTERNATIONAL  (Will move in ``i'' news file.)  TAIWAN-U.S. (Washington) _ President Bush is expected to accept the recommendation of his defense secretary and not sell Taiwan high-tech destroyers equipped with the Aegis combat radar system, two government officials said Monday. The officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Pentagon has recommended that Taiwan get four Kidd-class destroyers. Those vessels have a much less potent ship-borne radar system but would still be a step forward for Taiwan's navy. The officials did not disclose Bush's decision, but said it was expected that he would follow Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld's lead. (Summary from wires) By David E. Sanger.  PERU-U.S. (Washington) _ The United States and Peru offered scant information Monday about the downing of an American missionary flight, playing down what the White House called an ``isolated incident'' and trying to keep it from scuttling one of its few successful counterdrug operations. U.S. officials said three civilian CIA employees aboard a U.S. aircraft had tried to stop a Peruvian jet from firing on the aircraft. But officials stopped short of blaming Peru outright for the incident, which killed a missionary and her daughter. By Steven Lee Myers and Christopher Marquis.  NATIONAL GENERAL  (Will move in ``a'' news file.)  SUBMARINE-COLLISION (Honolulu) _ Commander Scott Waddle will meet with Adm. Thomas Fargo to receive punishment for the collision between a U.S. Navy submarine and a Japanese trawler. By John Kifner.  SCIENCE  (Will move in ``a'' news file.)  SCI-TELLER-HBOMB (Undated) _ After a heart attack, Dr. Edward Teller sat down with a friend and a tape recorder and discussed the secret history of the hydrogen bomb. The first design, he said, ``was made by Dick Garwin.'' Teller, now 93, was not ceding the laurels for devising the bomb _ a glory he claims for himself. But he was rewriting how the rough idea became the world's most feared weapon. His tribute, made more than two decades ago but just now coming to light, adds a surprising twist to a dispute that has roiled historians and scientists for decades: Who should get credit for designing the H-bomb? A transcript of the conversation was made available to The Times. By William J. Broad. (2100 words)  With photos, NYT1,2.  SPORTS  (Will move in ``s'' news file.) I haven't done a lot of frivolous stuff.'' </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, she said,	 She named 3M Co., Johnson &AMP; Johnson, McDonald's, IBM and Ford Motor Co. as examples of good corporate citizens. Being socially responsible can take various forms, she said, from donating computers to local schools, to giving employees time off with pay to volunteer for a charity. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, she said,	 Korologos, who sits on the board of directors for such corporate giants as Microsoft, Kellogg Co. and Host Marriott Corp., said when hiring top executives, companies should look for an impeccable sense of integrity, a strong record of accomplishment and solid education background. Also, she said, they must have a will to lead, an inspirational presence and a hypersensitivity to change, foreseeing trends before they become obvious. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, I thought,	 I then rushed to the Arthur M. Sackler Museum down the street. I wandered through lovely collections of Japanese, Chinese and Korean landscape scrolls. Upstairs I passed an intricate Burmese stele with scenes from the life of Buddha, and relief fragments from Persepolis. A weekend looking at art, I thought, is like living in the tension between change and continuity. It is a form of expression that is of its place and age, while simultaneously transcending time, language and culture. (Seeing a great deal of it also requires a certain physical fortitude.) </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz

, he said,	 Social scientists have pointed out that the 86 percent success rate of Teen Challenge does not count the people who dropped out during the program. And like many religious and private charities, Teen Challenge picks its clients. Before they are accepted in Teen Challenge, most of the addicts have already been through detoxification programs, said the Rev. John D. Castellani, president of Teen Challenge International U.S.A. In the program's first four month phase, he said, 25 to 30 percent drop out, and in the next eight months, 10 percent more leave. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
