(NYT33) NEW YORK -- April 23, 2001 -- BKN-KNICKS-WARD -- Faced with continuing criticism over published comments he made about Jews, including a harsh rebuke Monday from Commissioner David Stern, Charlie Ward of the Knicks issued an apology last night, saying again that he did not intend to offend anyone with his remarks. In a statement released by the Knicks, Ward said: ``I want to truly apologize to everybody who was offended by the New York Times Magazine story. I will say again that I would never condemn or criticize any group or religion. That is not who I am.'' Ward at Madison Square Garden in New York. Stern declined to fine or suspend him. (Barton Silverman/The New York Times)  (NYT32) EWING, N.J. -- April 23, 2001 -- NJ-POLICE -- State troopers along the southern segment of the New Jersey Turnpike have nearly stopped making the kind of highway vehicle searches that are the focus of charges of racial profiling, according to figures compiled by the state police. Officials with the state police and the state troopers' union differ over whether the drop indicates better police procedures or a force that has been intimidated by the furor over racial profiling. Edward H. Lennon, president of the State Troopers Fraternal Association of New Jersey at a trooper barracks in Ewing, N.J. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)  (NYT31) WASHINGTON -- April 23, 2001 -- CHINA-DETAINEE-COX-2 -- Andrew Xue, age 5, walked the halls of Congress with his father Donghua Xue Monday, to remind senators that his mother has been held captive in China for more than 70 days. The family was arrested last February in Beijing as they were preparing to return to their Virginia home after a vacation in China. Andrew's mother, sociologist Gao Zhan has been held ever since under suspicion of spying. In Washington, Andrew holds a copy of a Senate bill which seeks to grant citizenship to Gao Zhan. (Rick McKay/Cox News Service)  (NYT30) WASHINGTON -- April 23, 2001 -- CHINA-DETAINEE-COX -- Andrew Xue, age 5, left, walked the halls of Congress with his father Donghua Xue Monday, to remind senators that his mother has been held captive in China for more than 70 days. The family was arrested last February in Beijing as they were preparing to return to their Virginia home after a vacation in China. Andrew's mother, sociologist Gao Zhan has been held ever since under suspicion of spying. Andrew and Donghua Xue in Washington. (Rick McKay/Cox News Service)  (NYT29) SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador -- April 23, 2001 -- THIRD-WORLD-LABOR-3 -- In 1995, workers at the Charter factory in San Salvador, El Salvador spent 18-hour days in an unventilated factory with undrinkable water. Today, workers have access to bathrooms and can complain to a board of independent monitors if they feel abused. The changes are the result of efforts by Gap, the big clothing chain, to improve working conditions at one of the many factories that supply its clothes. Despite the changes workers are only making 5 cents more an hour than they did six years ago. Abigail Mart(CT)inez, a Charter worker, right, watches her mother cook in their two-room house, shared by seven family members. She was among the workers who protested the abusive conditions in 1995. (Cindy Karp/The New York Times)  (NYT28) SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador -- April 23, 2001 -- THIRD-WORLD-LABOR-2 -- In 1995, workers at the Charter factory in San Salvador, El Salvador spent 18-hour days in an unventilated factory with undrinkable water. Today, workers have access to bathrooms and can complain to a board of independent monitors if they feel abused. The changes are the result of efforts by Gap, the big clothing chain, to improve working conditions at one of the many factories that supply its clothes. Despite the changes workers are only making 5 cents more an hour than they did six years ago. Employees pass the guarded gate of the Charter factory, which makes clothing for Gap. (Cindy Karp/The New York Times)  (NYT27) NOVOGROZNENSKY, Russia -- April 23, 2001 -- RUSSIA-CHECHNYA -- The sound of the explosion followed by gunfire in this Chechen town of 14,000 last month sent Saikhan Israilov bolting out of his kitchen to the primary school next door just as the Russian armored personnel carrier was bearing down on the building. Saikhan Israilov was shot in the arm by a Russian soldier in Novogrozensky. It happened after an armored personnel carrier was heading for a school, he said, and he yelled, ``Don't shoot - there are children here!'' (James Hill/The New York Times)  (NYT26) ADI TEKELEZAN, Eritrea -- April 23, 2001 -- ERITREA-DEVELOP-2 -- Eritreans are mulling over the post-war stage in their nation's young life and seeing it as different from what they had imagined. It is a future that many Eritreans say they now face with clearer, more grown-up eyes. An Eritrean child at a veterans' cemetery in the village of Adi Tekelezan, with a mural depicting fighters for the country's independence. (Tyler Hicks/The New York Times)  (NYT25) ASSAB, Eritrea -- April 23, 2001 -- ERITREA-DEVELOP-1 -- Eritreans are mulling over the post-war stage in their nation's young life and seeing it as different from what they had imagined. It is a future that many Eritreans say they now face with clearer, more grown-up eyes. Port workers in Assab, Eritrea, sitting alongside idle cranes. The port, which was once the source of 20 percent of the government's revenue, has not been functioning since the end of the war with Ethiopia in June. Now his art collection is doing a gig here. Enshrined in the fancy gallery of the Bellagio Hotel, the collection is correctly characterized by its owner as ``an extremely personal group of pictures.'' Martin's collection is a wildly, eclectic 20th-century mix that runs from Picasso and Seurat to Robert Crumb, a once-underground but now celebrated comic book artist. Picasso's ``Seated Woman'' (1938) is part of Martin's collection. (Robert McKeever/The New York Times)  (NYT22) LAS VEGAS -- April 23, 2001 -- STEVE-MARTIN-COLLECTOR -- As a stand-up comedian, Steve Martin often played Las Vegas. They are the flesh-eating flip side of the norm in the plant world -- exotic organisms that lure live meat into their leafy traps, then drown, drain, dissolve or squeeze the unsuspecting victims into a meal. The savage techniques vary among the species. Jack Police, a Houston resident is fascinated by carnivorous plants. Police examines the Texas pitcher plants thriving in one of the bogs in his Houston area home garden. (E. (Rina Castelnuovo/The New York Times)  (NYT7) PALO ALTO, Calif. -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-HEART-TRAINING -- Health clubs and even cardiologists all over the country compute the maximum heart rate by subtracting a person's age from 220. Trouble is that formula doesn't work for at least 40 percent of the population, and that has ramifications for cardiac testing. Even Dr. William Haskell, right, who devised the formula, who is now a professor of medicine at Stanford, says it's only an approximation that has taken on a life all its own. Haskell with Jeff Myll studying heart rate variations. (Peter DaSilva/The New York Times) MAGS OUT, NO SALES  (NYT6) SAO PAULO -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-BRAZIL-GENOMICS -- The Research Support Foundation of the State of Sao Paulo is rapidly becoming a powerhouse in genomics and a model for scientific investigation in the third world. In July, a Brazilian consortium organized and financed by the foundation became the first anywhere to decode the genome of a plant pathogen, Xylella fastidiosa, an insect-borne bacteria that infests oranges. Doctor Jose Fernando Perez, the foundation's scientific diretor, poses next to a photo of the cover of the science magazine Nature which featured the genome story. (Silvio Ferreira/Research Support Foundation of the State of Sao Paulo)  (NYT5) NEW YORK -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-OMEGA3-DIET -- A type of fat called Omega-3, found mostly in fish, is emerging as essential to good health. Lack of it may play a role in a number of modern maladies. Cured salmon is sliced to order in a Manhattan delicatessen. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)  (NYT4) NEW YORK-- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-VENTILATION-HEALTH -- As the population ages and medical technology gets better, the number of patients in the United States receiving long-term mechanical ventilation has been rising, from 6,000 in the mid-1980's to at least 12,000 and perhaps 20,000 or more today, experts on critical care say. The number of centers caring for these patients has also grown, from about 100 in 1990 to 240 today. Dr. John Vecchione tests the blood oxygen levels of his patient, Awadalla Ireibi at Goldwater Rehabilitation Hospital in February. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)  (NYT3) UNDATED -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-TELLER-HBOMB-3-B&AMP;W -- After a heart attack, Dr. Edward Teller sat down with a friend and a tape recorder and discussed the secret history of the hydrogen bomb. (University of Florida/The New York Times)  (NYT2) UNDATED -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-TELLER-HBOMB-2 -- After a heart attack, Dr. Edward Teller sat down with a friend and a tape recorder and discussed the secret history of the hydrogen bomb. The first design, he said, ``was made by Dick Garwin.'' Teller, now 93, was not ceding the laurels for devising the bomb -- a glory he claims for himself. But he was rewriting how the rough idea became the world's most feared weapon. His tribute, made more than two decades ago but just now coming to light, adds a surprising twist to a dispute that has roiled historians and scientists for decades: Who should get credit for designing the H-bomb? The first hydrogen bomb is tested in 1952 on an atoll in the Pacific. (U.S. Air Force/The New York Times)  (NYT1) UNDATED -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-TELLER-HBOMB-1-B&AMP;W -- After a heart attack, Dr. Edward Teller sat down with a friend and a tape recorder and discussed the secret history of the hydrogen bomb. It is a future that many Eritreans say they now face with clearer, more grown-up eyes. Port workers in Assab, Eritrea, sitting alongside idle cranes. The port, which was once the source of 20 percent of the government's revenue, has not been functioning since the end of the war with Ethiopia in June. (Tyler Hicks/The New York Times)  (NYT24) SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador -- April 23, 2001 -- THIRD-WORLD-LABOR -- In 1995, workers at the Charter factory in San Salvador, El Salvador spent 18-hour days in an unventilated factory with undrinkable water. Today, workers have access to bathrooms and can complain to a board of independent monitors if they feel abused. The changes are the result of efforts by Gap, the big clothing chain, to improve working conditions at one of the many factories that supply its clothes. Despite the changes workers are only making 5 cents more an hour than they did six years ago. Garment workers sewing T-shirts for the Gap in the Charter factory. (Cindy Karp/The New York Times)  (NYT23) LAS VEGAS -- April 23, 2001 -- STEVE-MARTIN-COLLECTOR-2 -- As a stand-up comedian, Steve Martin often played Las Vegas. Now his art collection is doing a gig here. Enshrined in the fancy gallery of the Bellagio Hotel, the collection is correctly characterized by its owner as ``an extremely personal group of pictures.'' Martin's collection is a wildly, eclectic 20th-century mix that runs from Picasso and Seurat to Robert Crumb, a once-underground but now celebrated comic book artist. Picasso's ``Seated Woman'' (1938) is part of Martin's collection. (Robert McKeever/The New York Times)  (NYT22) LAS VEGAS -- April 23, 2001 -- STEVE-MARTIN-COLLECTOR -- As a stand-up comedian, Steve Martin often played Las Vegas. Now his art collection is doing a gig here. Enshrined in the fancy gallery of the Bellagio Hotel, the collection is correctly characterized by its owner as ``an extremely personal group of pictures.'' Martin's collection is a wildly, eclectic 20th-century mix that runs from Picasso and Seurat to Robert Crumb, a once-underground but now celebrated comic book artist. ``The Little Splash'' (1966) by David Hockney, is part of Martin's collection. (Robert McKeever/The New York Times)  (NYT21) HOUSTON -- April 23, 2001 -- GARDEN-CARNIVOROUS-HNS-2 -- Carnivorous plants are not passive. They are the flesh-eating flip side of the norm in the plant world -- exotic organisms that lure live meat into their leafy traps, then drown, drain, dissolve or squeeze the unsuspecting victims into a meal. The savage techniques vary among the species. Jack Police, a Houston resident is fascinated by carnivorous plants. Police examines the Texas pitcher plants thriving in one of the bogs in his Houston area home garden. (E. Joseph Deering/The Houston Chronicle)  (NYT20) UNDATED -- April 23, 2001 -- GARDEN-CARNIVOROUS-HNS -- Carnivorous plants are not passive. The savage techniques vary among the species. The cobra plant, which has puffed hoods and tubular pitchers, drowns its victims.(E. After publishing her first novel in 1998, Mills is now the author of seven novels, four novellas and other works. She is also a founder and treasurer of the year-old American Christian Romance Writers, an online service to assist and encourage women writers. The covers of Mills' novels. Although the two clans have crossed paths from time to time -- as when Republican Prescott Bush served in the Senate with Democrat John F. Kennedy -- the Bushes have now become the dominant dynasty. (The Boston Globe)  (NYT8) KFAR SABA, Israel -- April 23, 2001 -- MIDEAST-ISRAEL-VIOLENCE -- Funeral services were held Monday for Dr. Mario Goldin who was killed Sunday when a Palestinian militant detonated a bomb near a bus in the town of Kfar Saba, near Tel Aviv. Fifty people were injured in the blast. Ilan Goldin consoles his sister Tamara at their father's funeral. (Rina Castelnuovo/The New York Times)  (NYT7) PALO ALTO, Calif. -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-HEART-TRAINING -- Health clubs and even cardiologists all over the country compute the maximum heart rate by subtracting a person's age from 220. Trouble is that formula doesn't work for at least 40 percent of the population, and that has ramifications for cardiac testing. Even Dr. William Haskell, right, who devised the formula, who is now a professor of medicine at Stanford, says it's only an approximation that has taken on a life all its own. Haskell with Jeff Myll studying heart rate variations. (Peter DaSilva/The New York Times) MAGS OUT, NO SALES  (NYT6) SAO PAULO -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-BRAZIL-GENOMICS -- The Research Support Foundation of the State of Sao Paulo is rapidly becoming a powerhouse in genomics and a model for scientific investigation in the third world. In July, a Brazilian consortium organized and financed by the foundation became the first anywhere to decode the genome of a plant pathogen, Xylella fastidiosa, an insect-borne bacteria that infests oranges. Doctor Jose Fernando Perez, the foundation's scientific diretor, poses next to a photo of the cover of the science magazine Nature which featured the genome story. (Silvio Ferreira/Research Support Foundation of the State of Sao Paulo)  (NYT5) NEW YORK -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-OMEGA3-DIET -- A type of fat called Omega-3, found mostly in fish, is emerging as essential to good health. Lack of it may play a role in a number of modern maladies. Cured salmon is sliced to order in a Manhattan delicatessen. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)  (NYT4) NEW YORK-- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-VENTILATION-HEALTH -- As the population ages and medical technology gets better, the number of patients in the United States receiving long-term mechanical ventilation has been rising, from 6,000 in the mid-1980's to at least 12,000 and perhaps 20,000 or more today, experts on critical care say. The number of centers caring for these patients has also grown, from about 100 in 1990 to 240 today. Dr. John Vecchione tests the blood oxygen levels of his patient, Awadalla Ireibi at Goldwater Rehabilitation Hospital in February. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)  (NYT3) UNDATED -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-TELLER-HBOMB-3-B&AMP;W -- After a heart attack, Dr. Edward Teller sat down with a friend and a tape recorder and discussed the secret history of the hydrogen bomb. Dr. Stanislaw M. Ulam, Teller's rival in developing the bomb, in a 1976 photo. (University of Florida/The New York Times)  (NYT2) UNDATED -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-TELLER-HBOMB-2 -- After a heart attack, Dr. Edward Teller sat down with a friend and a tape recorder and discussed the secret history of the hydrogen bomb. The first design, he said, ``was made by Dick Garwin.'' Teller, now 93, was not ceding the laurels for devising the bomb -- a glory he claims for himself. But he was rewriting how the rough idea became the world's most feared weapon. His tribute, made more than two decades ago but just now coming to light, adds a surprising twist to a dispute that has roiled historians and scientists for decades: Who should get credit for designing the H-bomb? The first hydrogen bomb is tested in 1952 on an atoll in the Pacific. (U.S. Air Force/The New York Times)  (NYT1) UNDATED -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-TELLER-HBOMB-1-B&AMP;W -- After a heart attack, Dr. Edward Teller sat down with a friend and a tape recorder and discussed the secret history of the hydrogen bomb. His tribute, made more than two decades ago but just now coming to light, adds a surprising twist to a dispute that has roiled historians and scientists for decades: Who should get credit for designing the H-bomb? Teller, right, in 1957, and Garwin in 1954. (Courtesy of Richard L. (NYT33) NEW YORK -- April 23, 2001 -- BKN-KNICKS-WARD -- Faced with continuing criticism over published comments he made about Jews, including a harsh rebuke Monday from Commissioner David Stern, Charlie Ward of the Knicks issued an apology last night, saying again that he did not intend to offend anyone with his remarks. In a statement released by the Knicks, Ward said: ``I want to truly apologize to everybody who was offended by the New York Times Magazine story. I will say again that I would never condemn or criticize any group or religion. That is not who I am.'' Ward at Madison Square Garden in New York. Stern declined to fine or suspend him. (Barton Silverman/The New York Times)  (NYT32) EWING, N.J. -- April 23, 2001 -- NJ-POLICE -- State troopers along the southern segment of the New Jersey Turnpike have nearly stopped making the kind of highway vehicle searches that are the focus of charges of racial profiling, according to figures compiled by the state police. Officials with the state police and the state troopers' union differ over whether the drop indicates better police procedures or a force that has been intimidated by the furor over racial profiling. Edward H. Lennon, president of the State Troopers Fraternal Association of New Jersey at a trooper barracks in Ewing, N.J. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)  (NYT31) WASHINGTON -- April 23, 2001 -- CHINA-DETAINEE-COX-2 -- Andrew Xue, age 5, walked the halls of Congress with his father Donghua Xue Monday, to remind senators that his mother has been held captive in China for more than 70 days. The family was arrested last February in Beijing as they were preparing to return to their Virginia home after a vacation in China. Andrew's mother, sociologist Gao Zhan has been held ever since under suspicion of spying. In Washington, Andrew holds a copy of a Senate bill which seeks to grant citizenship to Gao Zhan. (Rick McKay/Cox News Service)  (NYT30) WASHINGTON -- April 23, 2001 -- CHINA-DETAINEE-COX -- Andrew Xue, age 5, left, walked the halls of Congress with his father Donghua Xue Monday, to remind senators that his mother has been held captive in China for more than 70 days. The family was arrested last February in Beijing as they were preparing to return to their Virginia home after a vacation in China. Andrew's mother, sociologist Gao Zhan has been held ever since under suspicion of spying. Andrew and Donghua Xue in Washington. (Rick McKay/Cox News Service)  (NYT29) SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador -- April 23, 2001 -- THIRD-WORLD-LABOR-3 -- In 1995, workers at the Charter factory in San Salvador, El Salvador spent 18-hour days in an unventilated factory with undrinkable water. Today, workers have access to bathrooms and can complain to a board of independent monitors if they feel abused. The changes are the result of efforts by Gap, the big clothing chain, to improve working conditions at one of the many factories that supply its clothes. Despite the changes workers are only making 5 cents more an hour than they did six years ago. Abigail Mart(CT)inez, a Charter worker, right, watches her mother cook in their two-room house, shared by seven family members. She was among the workers who protested the abusive conditions in 1995. (Cindy Karp/The New York Times)  (NYT28) SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador -- April 23, 2001 -- THIRD-WORLD-LABOR-2 -- In 1995, workers at the Charter factory in San Salvador, El Salvador spent 18-hour days in an unventilated factory with undrinkable water. The changes are the result of efforts by Gap, the big clothing chain, to improve working conditions at one of the many factories that supply its clothes. Despite the changes workers are only making 5 cents more an hour than they did six years ago. Employees pass the guarded gate of the Charter factory, which makes clothing for Gap. Saikhan Israilov was shot in the arm by a Russian soldier in Novogrozensky. It happened after an armored personnel carrier was heading for a school, he said, and he yelled, ``Don't shoot - there are children here!'' (James Hill/The New York Times)  (NYT26) ADI TEKELEZAN, Eritrea -- April 23, 2001 -- ERITREA-DEVELOP-2 -- Eritreans are mulling over the post-war stage in their nation's young life and seeing it as different from what they had imagined. It is a future that many Eritreans say they now face with clearer, more grown-up eyes. An Eritrean child at a veterans' cemetery in the village of Adi Tekelezan, with a mural depicting fighters for the country's independence. (University of Florida/The New York Times)  (NYT2) UNDATED -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-TELLER-HBOMB-2 -- After a heart attack, Dr. Edward Teller sat down with a friend and a tape recorder and discussed the secret history of the hydrogen bomb. The first design, he said, ``was made by Dick Garwin.'' Teller, now 93, was not ceding the laurels for devising the bomb -- a glory he claims for himself. But he was rewriting how the rough idea became the world's most feared weapon. His tribute, made more than two decades ago but just now coming to light, adds a surprising twist to a dispute that has roiled historians and scientists for decades: Who should get credit for designing the H-bomb? The first hydrogen bomb is tested in 1952 on an atoll in the Pacific. (U.S. Air Force/The New York Times)  (NYT1) UNDATED -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-TELLER-HBOMB-1-B&AMP;W -- After a heart attack, Dr. Edward Teller sat down with a friend and a tape recorder and discussed the secret history of the hydrogen bomb. The first design, he said, ``was made by Dick Garwin.'' Teller, now 93, was not ceding the laurels for devising the bomb -- a glory he claims for himself. But he was rewriting how the rough idea became the world's most feared weapon. His tribute, made more than two decades ago but just now coming to light, adds a surprising twist to a dispute that has roiled historians and scientists for decades: Who should get credit for designing the H-bomb? Teller, right, in 1957, and Garwin in 1954. (Courtesy of Richard L. Garwin, left, and Library of Congress)  The New York Times News Service </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010423.0505 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-PHOTO-UPDATE-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> ATTENTION EDITORS:  The following photos have been sent as part of tonight's New York Times Photo Package, moving Monday, 04/23/01. (NYT33) NEW YORK -- April 23, 2001 -- BKN-KNICKS-WARD -- Faced with continuing criticism over published comments he made about Jews, including a harsh rebuke Monday from Commissioner David Stern, Charlie Ward of the Knicks issued an apology last night, saying again that he did not intend to offend anyone with his remarks. In a statement released by the Knicks, Ward said: ``I want to truly apologize to everybody who was offended by the New York Times Magazine story. I will say again that I would never condemn or criticize any group or religion. That is not who I am.'' Ward at Madison Square Garden in New York. Stern declined to fine or suspend him. (Barton Silverman/The New York Times)  (NYT32) EWING, N.J. -- April 23, 2001 -- NJ-POLICE -- State troopers along the southern segment of the New Jersey Turnpike have nearly stopped making the kind of highway vehicle searches that are the focus of charges of racial profiling, according to figures compiled by the state police. Officials with the state police and the state troopers' union differ over whether the drop indicates better police procedures or a force that has been intimidated by the furor over racial profiling. Edward H. Lennon, president of the State Troopers Fraternal Association of New Jersey at a trooper barracks in Ewing, N.J. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)  (NYT31) WASHINGTON -- April 23, 2001 -- CHINA-DETAINEE-COX-2 -- Andrew Xue, age 5, walked the halls of Congress with his father Donghua Xue Monday, to remind senators that his mother has been held captive in China for more than 70 days. The family was arrested last February in Beijing as they were preparing to return to their Virginia home after a vacation in China. Andrew's mother, sociologist Gao Zhan has been held ever since under suspicion of spying. In Washington, Andrew holds a copy of a Senate bill which seeks to grant citizenship to Gao Zhan. (Rick McKay/Cox News Service)  (NYT30) WASHINGTON -- April 23, 2001 -- CHINA-DETAINEE-COX -- Andrew Xue, age 5, left, walked the halls of Congress with his father Donghua Xue Monday, to remind senators that his mother has been held captive in China for more than 70 days. The family was arrested last February in Beijing as they were preparing to return to their Virginia home after a vacation in China. Andrew's mother, sociologist Gao Zhan has been held ever since under suspicion of spying. Andrew and Donghua Xue in Washington. (Rick McKay/Cox News Service)  (NYT29) SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador -- April 23, 2001 -- THIRD-WORLD-LABOR-3 -- In 1995, workers at the Charter factory in San Salvador, El Salvador spent 18-hour days in an unventilated factory with undrinkable water. Today, workers have access to bathrooms and can complain to a board of independent monitors if they feel abused. The changes are the result of efforts by Gap, the big clothing chain, to improve working conditions at one of the many factories that supply its clothes. Despite the changes workers are only making 5 cents more an hour than they did six years ago. Abigail Mart(CT)inez, a Charter worker, right, watches her mother cook in their two-room house, shared by seven family members. She was among the workers who protested the abusive conditions in 1995. (Cindy Karp/The New York Times)  (NYT28) SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador -- April 23, 2001 -- THIRD-WORLD-LABOR-2 -- In 1995, workers at the Charter factory in San Salvador, El Salvador spent 18-hour days in an unventilated factory with undrinkable water. Today, workers have access to bathrooms and can complain to a board of independent monitors if they feel abused. The changes are the result of efforts by Gap, the big clothing chain, to improve working conditions at one of the many factories that supply its clothes. Despite the changes workers are only making 5 cents more an hour than they did six years ago. Employees pass the guarded gate of the Charter factory, which makes clothing for Gap. (Cindy Karp/The New York Times)  (NYT27) NOVOGROZNENSKY, Russia -- April 23, 2001 -- RUSSIA-CHECHNYA -- The sound of the explosion followed by gunfire in this Chechen town of 14,000 last month sent Saikhan Israilov bolting out of his kitchen to the primary school next door just as the Russian armored personnel carrier was bearing down on the building. Saikhan Israilov was shot in the arm by a Russian soldier in Novogrozensky. It happened after an armored personnel carrier was heading for a school, he said, and he yelled, ``Don't shoot - there are children here!'' (James Hill/The New York Times)  (NYT26) ADI TEKELEZAN, Eritrea -- April 23, 2001 -- ERITREA-DEVELOP-2 -- Eritreans are mulling over the post-war stage in their nation's young life and seeing it as different from what they had imagined. It is a future that many Eritreans say they now face with clearer, more grown-up eyes. An Eritrean child at a veterans' cemetery in the village of Adi Tekelezan, with a mural depicting fighters for the country's independence. (Tyler Hicks/The New York Times)  (NYT25) ASSAB, Eritrea -- April 23, 2001 -- ERITREA-DEVELOP-1 -- Eritreans are mulling over the post-war stage in their nation's young life and seeing it as different from what they had imagined. It is a future that many Eritreans say they now face with clearer, more grown-up eyes. Port workers in Assab, Eritrea, sitting alongside idle cranes. The port, which was once the source of 20 percent of the government's revenue, has not been functioning since the end of the war with Ethiopia in June. (Tyler Hicks/The New York Times)  (NYT24) SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador -- April 23, 2001 -- THIRD-WORLD-LABOR -- In 1995, workers at the Charter factory in San Salvador, El Salvador spent 18-hour days in an unventilated factory with undrinkable water. Today, workers have access to bathrooms and can complain to a board of independent monitors if they feel abused. The changes are the result of efforts by Gap, the big clothing chain, to improve working conditions at one of the many factories that supply its clothes. Despite the changes workers are only making 5 cents more an hour than they did six years ago. Garment workers sewing T-shirts for the Gap in the Charter factory. (Cindy Karp/The New York Times)  (NYT23) LAS VEGAS -- April 23, 2001 -- STEVE-MARTIN-COLLECTOR-2 -- As a stand-up comedian, Steve Martin often played Las Vegas. Now his art collection is doing a gig here. Enshrined in the fancy gallery of the Bellagio Hotel, the collection is correctly characterized by its owner as ``an extremely personal group of pictures.'' Martin's collection is a wildly, eclectic 20th-century mix that runs from Picasso and Seurat to Robert Crumb, a once-underground but now celebrated comic book artist. Picasso's ``Seated Woman'' (1938) is part of Martin's collection. (Robert McKeever/The New York Times)  (NYT22) LAS VEGAS -- April 23, 2001 -- STEVE-MARTIN-COLLECTOR -- As a stand-up comedian, Steve Martin often played Las Vegas. Now his art collection is doing a gig here. Enshrined in the fancy gallery of the Bellagio Hotel, the collection is correctly characterized by its owner as ``an extremely personal group of pictures.'' Martin's collection is a wildly, eclectic 20th-century mix that runs from Picasso and Seurat to Robert Crumb, a once-underground but now celebrated comic book artist. ``The Little Splash'' (1966) by David Hockney, is part of Martin's collection. (Robert McKeever/The New York Times)  (NYT21) HOUSTON -- April 23, 2001 -- GARDEN-CARNIVOROUS-HNS-2 -- Carnivorous plants are not passive. They are the flesh-eating flip side of the norm in the plant world -- exotic organisms that lure live meat into their leafy traps, then drown, drain, dissolve or squeeze the unsuspecting victims into a meal. The savage techniques vary among the species. Jack Police, a Houston resident is fascinated by carnivorous plants. Police examines the Texas pitcher plants thriving in one of the bogs in his Houston area home garden. (E. Joseph Deering/The Houston Chronicle)  (NYT20) UNDATED -- April 23, 2001 -- GARDEN-CARNIVOROUS-HNS -- Carnivorous plants are not passive. They are the flesh-eating flip side of the norm in the plant world -- exotic organisms that lure live meat into their leafy traps, then drown, drain, dissolve or squeeze the unsuspecting victims into a meal. The savage techniques vary among the species. The cobra plant, which has puffed hoods and tubular pitchers, drowns its victims.(E. Joseph Deering/The Houston Chronicle)  (NYT19) HOUSTON-- April 23, 2001 -- RELIGION-ROMANCEWRITER-HNS -- For years, Christian romance novelist DiAnn Mills, top, wrote stories to entertain her sons and plays for children at a Houston child-care center where she was director. After publishing her first novel in 1998, Mills is now the author of seven novels, four novellas and other works. She is also a founder and treasurer of the year-old American Christian Romance Writers, an online service to assist and encourage women writers. The covers of Mills' novels. (John Everett/The Houston Chronicle)  (NYT18) WASHINGTON-- April 23, 2001 -- BUSH-TEACHER -- President Bush hands Michele Forman the 2001 Teacher of the Year award during a ceremony in the Rose Garden of the White House on Monday. Forman teaches social studies at Middlebury Union High, in Middlebury, Vermont. (Wendy Maeda/The Boston Globe)  (NYT14) UNDATED-- April 23, 2001 -- THE-BUSHES-II-2-B&AMP;W -- Like the Kennedys, the Bushes rose to power in the middle of the 20th Century with a patriarch's fortune behind them and an abiding thirst for politics. Although the two clans have crossed paths from time to time -- as when Republican Prescott Bush served in the Senate with Democrat John F. Kennedy -- the Bushes have now become the dominant dynasty. A photo of the Bush extended family, Prescott S. Bush, middle row, center, wife Dorothy, to his right; son George H. W. Bush, top row, left, and grandson George W. Bush, middle row, left. Although the two clans have crossed paths from time to time -- as when Republican Prescott Bush served in the Senate with Democrat John F. Kennedy -- the Bushes have now become the dominant dynasty. George Herbert Walker in an undated photo. (The Boston Globe)  (NYT8) KFAR SABA, Israel -- April 23, 2001 -- MIDEAST-ISRAEL-VIOLENCE -- Funeral services were held Monday for Dr. Mario Goldin who was killed Sunday when a Palestinian militant detonated a bomb near a bus in the town of Kfar Saba, near Tel Aviv. Fifty people were injured in the blast. Ilan Goldin consoles his sister Tamara at their father's funeral. (Rina Castelnuovo/The New York Times)  (NYT7) PALO ALTO, Calif. -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-HEART-TRAINING -- Health clubs and even cardiologists all over the country compute the maximum heart rate by subtracting a person's age from 220. Trouble is that formula doesn't work for at least 40 percent of the population, and that has ramifications for cardiac testing. Even Dr. William Haskell, right, who devised the formula, who is now a professor of medicine at Stanford, says it's only an approximation that has taken on a life all its own. Haskell with Jeff Myll studying heart rate variations. (Peter DaSilva/The New York Times) MAGS OUT, NO SALES  (NYT6) SAO PAULO -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-BRAZIL-GENOMICS -- The Research Support Foundation of the State of Sao Paulo is rapidly becoming a powerhouse in genomics and a model for scientific investigation in the third world. In July, a Brazilian consortium organized and financed by the foundation became the first anywhere to decode the genome of a plant pathogen, Xylella fastidiosa, an insect-borne bacteria that infests oranges. Doctor Jose Fernando Perez, the foundation's scientific diretor, poses next to a photo of the cover of the science magazine Nature which featured the genome story. (Silvio Ferreira/Research Support Foundation of the State of Sao Paulo)  (NYT5) NEW YORK -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-OMEGA3-DIET -- A type of fat called Omega-3, found mostly in fish, is emerging as essential to good health. Lack of it may play a role in a number of modern maladies. Cured salmon is sliced to order in a Manhattan delicatessen. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)  (NYT4) NEW YORK-- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-VENTILATION-HEALTH -- As the population ages and medical technology gets better, the number of patients in the United States receiving long-term mechanical ventilation has been rising, from 6,000 in the mid-1980's to at least 12,000 and perhaps 20,000 or more today, experts on critical care say. The number of centers caring for these patients has also grown, from about 100 in 1990 to 240 today. Dr. John Vecchione tests the blood oxygen levels of his patient, Awadalla Ireibi at Goldwater Rehabilitation Hospital in February. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)  (NYT3) UNDATED -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-TELLER-HBOMB-3-B&AMP;W -- After a heart attack, Dr. Edward Teller sat down with a friend and a tape recorder and discussed the secret history of the hydrogen bomb. Dr. Stanislaw M. Ulam, Teller's rival in developing the bomb, in a 1976 photo. (University of Florida/The New York Times)  (NYT2) UNDATED -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-TELLER-HBOMB-2 -- After a heart attack, Dr. Edward Teller sat down with a friend and a tape recorder and discussed the secret history of the hydrogen bomb. Kennedy Museum and Library/The New York Times)  (NYT15) SOUTHBOROUGH, Mass. -- April 23, 2001 -- WORKING-COMPETE-BOS -- A heavy reliance by downsized or failed dot-com companies on youthful employees has created a generation of workers who, innocent about business or law, signed ``noncompete'' agreements without understanding their implications.EarthWeb Inc. sought to block Mark Schlack from taking a new job at competitor ITworld.com. (Wendy Maeda/The Boston Globe)  (NYT14) UNDATED-- April 23, 2001 -- THE-BUSHES-II-2-B&AMP;W -- Like the Kennedys, the Bushes rose to power in the middle of the 20th Century with a patriarch's fortune behind them and an abiding thirst for politics. Although the two clans have crossed paths from time to time -- as when Republican Prescott Bush served in the Senate with Democrat John F. Kennedy -- the Bushes have now become the dominant dynasty. A photo of the Bush extended family, Prescott S. Bush, middle row, center, wife Dorothy, to his right; son George H. W. Bush, top row, left, and grandson George W. Bush, middle row, left. (The Boston Globe)  (NYT13) NEW HAVEN, Conn. -- April 23, 2001 -- THE-BUSHES-II-1-B&AMP;W -- Like the Kennedys, the Bushes rose to power in the middle of the 20th Century with a patriarch's fortune behind them and an abiding thirst for politics. George Herbert Walker in an undated photo. (The Boston Globe)  (NYT8) KFAR SABA, Israel -- April 23, 2001 -- MIDEAST-ISRAEL-VIOLENCE -- Funeral services were held Monday for Dr. Mario Goldin who was killed Sunday when a Palestinian militant detonated a bomb near a bus in the town of Kfar Saba, near Tel Aviv. Fifty people were injured in the blast. Ilan Goldin consoles his sister Tamara at their father's funeral. (Rina Castelnuovo/The New York Times)  (NYT7) PALO ALTO, Calif. -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-HEART-TRAINING -- Health clubs and even cardiologists all over the country compute the maximum heart rate by subtracting a person's age from 220. Trouble is that formula doesn't work for at least 40 percent of the population, and that has ramifications for cardiac testing. Even Dr. William Haskell, right, who devised the formula, who is now a professor of medicine at Stanford, says it's only an approximation that has taken on a life all its own. Haskell with Jeff Myll studying heart rate variations. (Peter DaSilva/The New York Times) MAGS OUT, NO SALES  (NYT6) SAO PAULO -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-BRAZIL-GENOMICS -- The Research Support Foundation of the State of Sao Paulo is rapidly becoming a powerhouse in genomics and a model for scientific investigation in the third world. In July, a Brazilian consortium organized and financed by the foundation became the first anywhere to decode the genome of a plant pathogen, Xylella fastidiosa, an insect-borne bacteria that infests oranges. Doctor Jose Fernando Perez, the foundation's scientific diretor, poses next to a photo of the cover of the science magazine Nature which featured the genome story. (Silvio Ferreira/Research Support Foundation of the State of Sao Paulo)  (NYT5) NEW YORK -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-OMEGA3-DIET -- A type of fat called Omega-3, found mostly in fish, is emerging as essential to good health. Lack of it may play a role in a number of modern maladies. Cured salmon is sliced to order in a Manhattan delicatessen. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)  (NYT4) NEW YORK-- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-VENTILATION-HEALTH -- As the population ages and medical technology gets better, the number of patients in the United States receiving long-term mechanical ventilation has been rising, from 6,000 in the mid-1980's to at least 12,000 and perhaps 20,000 or more today, experts on critical care say. The number of centers caring for these patients has also grown, from about 100 in 1990 to 240 today. Dr. John Vecchione tests the blood oxygen levels of his patient, Awadalla Ireibi at Goldwater Rehabilitation Hospital in February. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)  (NYT3) UNDATED -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-TELLER-HBOMB-3-B&AMP;W -- After a heart attack, Dr. Edward Teller sat down with a friend and a tape recorder and discussed the secret history of the hydrogen bomb. Dr. Stanislaw M. Ulam, Teller's rival in developing the bomb, in a 1976 photo. (University of Florida/The New York Times)  (NYT2) UNDATED -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-TELLER-HBOMB-2 -- After a heart attack, Dr. Edward Teller sat down with a friend and a tape recorder and discussed the secret history of the hydrogen bomb. The first design, he said, ``was made by Dick Garwin.'' Teller, now 93, was not ceding the laurels for devising the bomb -- a glory he claims for himself. But he was rewriting how the rough idea became the world's most feared weapon. His tribute, made more than two decades ago but just now coming to light, adds a surprising twist to a dispute that has roiled historians and scientists for decades: Who should get credit for designing the H-bomb? The first hydrogen bomb is tested in 1952 on an atoll in the Pacific. (U.S. Air Force/The New York Times)  (NYT1) UNDATED -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-TELLER-HBOMB-1-B&AMP;W -- After a heart attack, Dr. Edward Teller sat down with a friend and a tape recorder and discussed the secret history of the hydrogen bomb. The first design, he said, ``was made by Dick Garwin.'' Teller, now 93, was not ceding the laurels for devising the bomb -- a glory he claims for himself. But he was rewriting how the rough idea became the world's most feared weapon. His tribute, made more than two decades ago but just now coming to light, adds a surprising twist to a dispute that has roiled historians and scientists for decades: Who should get credit for designing the H-bomb? Teller, right, in 1957, and Garwin in 1954. (Courtesy of Richard L. (NYT33) NEW YORK -- April 23, 2001 -- BKN-KNICKS-WARD -- Faced with continuing criticism over published comments he made about Jews, including a harsh rebuke Monday from Commissioner David Stern, Charlie Ward of the Knicks issued an apology last night, saying again that he did not intend to offend anyone with his remarks. In a statement released by the Knicks, Ward said: ``I want to truly apologize to everybody who was offended by the New York Times Magazine story. I will say again that I would never condemn or criticize any group or religion. That is not who I am.'' Ward at Madison Square Garden in New York. Stern declined to fine or suspend him. (Barton Silverman/The New York Times)  (NYT32) EWING, N.J. -- April 23, 2001 -- NJ-POLICE -- State troopers along the southern segment of the New Jersey Turnpike have nearly stopped making the kind of highway vehicle searches that are the focus of charges of racial profiling, according to figures compiled by the state police. Officials with the state police and the state troopers' union differ over whether the drop indicates better police procedures or a force that has been intimidated by the furor over racial profiling. Edward H. Lennon, president of the State Troopers Fraternal Association of New Jersey at a trooper barracks in Ewing, N.J. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)  (NYT31) WASHINGTON -- April 23, 2001 -- CHINA-DETAINEE-COX-2 -- Andrew Xue, age 5, walked the halls of Congress with his father Donghua Xue Monday, to remind senators that his mother has been held captive in China for more than 70 days. The family was arrested last February in Beijing as they were preparing to return to their Virginia home after a vacation in China. Andrew's mother, sociologist Gao Zhan has been held ever since under suspicion of spying. In Washington, Andrew holds a copy of a Senate bill which seeks to grant citizenship to Gao Zhan. (Rick McKay/Cox News Service)  (NYT30) WASHINGTON -- April 23, 2001 -- CHINA-DETAINEE-COX -- Andrew Xue, age 5, left, walked the halls of Congress with his father Donghua Xue Monday, to remind senators that his mother has been held captive in China for more than 70 days. The family was arrested last February in Beijing as they were preparing to return to their Virginia home after a vacation in China. Andrew's mother, sociologist Gao Zhan has been held ever since under suspicion of spying. Andrew and Donghua Xue in Washington. (Rick McKay/Cox News Service)  (NYT29) SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador -- April 23, 2001 -- THIRD-WORLD-LABOR-3 -- In 1995, workers at the Charter factory in San Salvador, El Salvador spent 18-hour days in an unventilated factory with undrinkable water. Today, workers have access to bathrooms and can complain to a board of independent monitors if they feel abused. The changes are the result of efforts by Gap, the big clothing chain, to improve working conditions at one of the many factories that supply its clothes. Despite the changes workers are only making 5 cents more an hour than they did six years ago. Abigail Mart(CT)inez, a Charter worker, right, watches her mother cook in their two-room house, shared by seven family members. She was among the workers who protested the abusive conditions in 1995. (Cindy Karp/The New York Times)  (NYT28) SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador -- April 23, 2001 -- THIRD-WORLD-LABOR-2 -- In 1995, workers at the Charter factory in San Salvador, El Salvador spent 18-hour days in an unventilated factory with undrinkable water. Today, workers have access to bathrooms and can complain to a board of independent monitors if they feel abused. The changes are the result of efforts by Gap, the big clothing chain, to improve working conditions at one of the many factories that supply its clothes. Despite the changes workers are only making 5 cents more an hour than they did six years ago. Employees pass the guarded gate of the Charter factory, which makes clothing for Gap. (Cindy Karp/The New York Times)  (NYT27) NOVOGROZNENSKY, Russia -- April 23, 2001 -- RUSSIA-CHECHNYA -- The sound of the explosion followed by gunfire in this Chechen town of 14,000 last month sent Saikhan Israilov bolting out of his kitchen to the primary school next door just as the Russian armored personnel carrier was bearing down on the building. Saikhan Israilov was shot in the arm by a Russian soldier in Novogrozensky. It happened after an armored personnel carrier was heading for a school, he said, and he yelled, ``Don't shoot - there are children here!'' (James Hill/The New York Times)  (NYT26) ADI TEKELEZAN, Eritrea -- April 23, 2001 -- ERITREA-DEVELOP-2 -- Eritreans are mulling over the post-war stage in their nation's young life and seeing it as different from what they had imagined. It is a future that many Eritreans say they now face with clearer, more grown-up eyes. An Eritrean child at a veterans' cemetery in the village of Adi Tekelezan, with a mural depicting fighters for the country's independence. (Tyler Hicks/The New York Times)  (NYT25) ASSAB, Eritrea -- April 23, 2001 -- ERITREA-DEVELOP-1 -- Eritreans are mulling over the post-war stage in their nation's young life and seeing it as different from what they had imagined. It is a future that many Eritreans say they now face with clearer, more grown-up eyes. Port workers in Assab, Eritrea, sitting alongside idle cranes. The port, which was once the source of 20 percent of the government's revenue, has not been functioning since the end of the war with Ethiopia in June. (Tyler Hicks/The New York Times)  (NYT24) SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador -- April 23, 2001 -- THIRD-WORLD-LABOR -- In 1995, workers at the Charter factory in San Salvador, El Salvador spent 18-hour days in an unventilated factory with undrinkable water. Today, workers have access to bathrooms and can complain to a board of independent monitors if they feel abused. The changes are the result of efforts by Gap, the big clothing chain, to improve working conditions at one of the many factories that supply its clothes. Despite the changes workers are only making 5 cents more an hour than they did six years ago. Garment workers sewing T-shirts for the Gap in the Charter factory. (Cindy Karp/The New York Times)  (NYT23) LAS VEGAS -- April 23, 2001 -- STEVE-MARTIN-COLLECTOR-2 -- As a stand-up comedian, Steve Martin often played Las Vegas. Now his art collection is doing a gig here. Enshrined in the fancy gallery of the Bellagio Hotel, the collection is correctly characterized by its owner as ``an extremely personal group of pictures.'' Martin's collection is a wildly, eclectic 20th-century mix that runs from Picasso and Seurat to Robert Crumb, a once-underground but now celebrated comic book artist. Picasso's ``Seated Woman'' (1938) is part of Martin's collection. (Robert McKeever/The New York Times)  (NYT22) LAS VEGAS -- April 23, 2001 -- STEVE-MARTIN-COLLECTOR -- As a stand-up comedian, Steve Martin often played Las Vegas. Now his art collection is doing a gig here. Enshrined in the fancy gallery of the Bellagio Hotel, the collection is correctly characterized by its owner as ``an extremely personal group of pictures.'' Martin's collection is a wildly, eclectic 20th-century mix that runs from Picasso and Seurat to Robert Crumb, a once-underground but now celebrated comic book artist. ``The Little Splash'' (1966) by David Hockney, is part of Martin's collection. (Robert McKeever/The New York Times)  (NYT21) HOUSTON -- April 23, 2001 -- GARDEN-CARNIVOROUS-HNS-2 -- Carnivorous plants are not passive. They are the flesh-eating flip side of the norm in the plant world -- exotic organisms that lure live meat into their leafy traps, then drown, drain, dissolve or squeeze the unsuspecting victims into a meal. The savage techniques vary among the species. Jack Police, a Houston resident is fascinated by carnivorous plants. Police examines the Texas pitcher plants thriving in one of the bogs in his Houston area home garden. (E. Joseph Deering/The Houston Chronicle)  (NYT20) UNDATED -- April 23, 2001 -- GARDEN-CARNIVOROUS-HNS -- Carnivorous plants are not passive. They are the flesh-eating flip side of the norm in the plant world -- exotic organisms that lure live meat into their leafy traps, then drown, drain, dissolve or squeeze the unsuspecting victims into a meal. The savage techniques vary among the species. The cobra plant, which has puffed hoods and tubular pitchers, drowns its victims.(E. After publishing her first novel in 1998, Mills is now the author of seven novels, four novellas and other works. She is also a founder and treasurer of the year-old American Christian Romance Writers, an online service to assist and encourage women writers. The covers of Mills' novels. I will say again that I would never condemn or criticize any group or religion. That is not who I am.'' Ward at Madison Square Garden in New York. Stern declined to fine or suspend him. Andrew's mother, sociologist Gao Zhan has been held ever since under suspicion of spying. Andrew and Donghua Xue in Washington. (Rick McKay/Cox News Service)  (NYT29) SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador -- April 23, 2001 -- THIRD-WORLD-LABOR-3 -- In 1995, workers at the Charter factory in San Salvador, El Salvador spent 18-hour days in an unventilated factory with undrinkable water. Today, workers have access to bathrooms and can complain to a board of independent monitors if they feel abused. The changes are the result of efforts by Gap, the big clothing chain, to improve working conditions at one of the many factories that supply its clothes. Despite the changes workers are only making 5 cents more an hour than they did six years ago. Abigail Mart(CT)inez, a Charter worker, right, watches her mother cook in their two-room house, shared by seven family members. She was among the workers who protested the abusive conditions in 1995. (Cindy Karp/The New York Times)  (NYT28) SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador -- April 23, 2001 -- THIRD-WORLD-LABOR-2 -- In 1995, workers at the Charter factory in San Salvador, El Salvador spent 18-hour days in an unventilated factory with undrinkable water. Despite the changes workers are only making 5 cents more an hour than they did six years ago. Employees pass the guarded gate of the Charter factory, which makes clothing for Gap. (Cindy Karp/The New York Times)  (NYT27) NOVOGROZNENSKY, Russia -- April 23, 2001 -- RUSSIA-CHECHNYA -- The sound of the explosion followed by gunfire in this Chechen town of 14,000 last month sent Saikhan Israilov bolting out of his kitchen to the primary school next door just as the Russian armored personnel carrier was bearing down on the building. Saikhan Israilov was shot in the arm by a Russian soldier in Novogrozensky. It happened after an armored personnel carrier was heading for a school, he said, and he yelled, ``Don't shoot - there are children here!'' (James Hill/The New York Times)  (NYT26) ADI TEKELEZAN, Eritrea -- April 23, 2001 -- ERITREA-DEVELOP-2 -- Eritreans are mulling over the post-war stage in their nation's young life and seeing it as different from what they had imagined. Trouble is that formula doesn't work for at least 40 percent of the population, and that has ramifications for cardiac testing. Even Dr. William Haskell, right, who devised the formula, who is now a professor of medicine at Stanford, says it's only an approximation that has taken on a life all its own. Haskell with Jeff Myll studying heart rate variations. (Peter DaSilva/The New York Times) MAGS OUT, NO SALES  (NYT6) SAO PAULO -- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-BRAZIL-GENOMICS -- The Research Support Foundation of the State of Sao Paulo is rapidly becoming a powerhouse in genomics and a model for scientific investigation in the third world. Doctor Jose Fernando Perez, the foundation's scientific diretor, poses next to a photo of the cover of the science magazine Nature which featured the genome story. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)  (NYT4) NEW YORK-- April 23, 2001 -- SCI-VENTILATION-HEALTH -- As the population ages and medical technology gets better, the number of patients in the United States receiving long-term mechanical ventilation has been rising, from 6,000 in the mid-1980's to at least 12,000 and perhaps 20,000 or more today, experts on critical care say. The number of centers caring for these patients has also grown, from about 100 in 1990 to 240 today. Dr. John Vecchione tests the blood oxygen levels of his patient, Awadalla Ireibi at Goldwater Rehabilitation Hospital in February. The first design, he said, ``was made by Dick Garwin.'' Teller, now 93, was not ceding the laurels for devising the bomb -- a glory he claims for himself. But he was rewriting how the rough idea became the world's most feared weapon. His tribute, made more than two decades ago but just now coming to light, adds a surprising twist to a dispute that has roiled historians and scientists for decades: Who should get credit for designing the H-bomb? The first hydrogen bomb is tested in 1952 on an atoll in the Pacific. The PMs news desk, 212-556-1927, opens at 7 a.m. Eastern Time. To get story repeats before this hour call 212-621-1595 for reruns on AP DataFeatures or 214-980-8305 or 8367 for repeats on UPI DataNews.  NYT News Service  INTERNATIONAL _ (Moved in ``i'' category)  THIRD-WORLD-LABOR (San Salvador, El Salvador) _ The lesson from Gap's experience in El Salvador is that competing interests among factory owners, government officials, American managers and middle-class consumers _ all with their eyes on the lowest possible cost _ make it difficult to achieve even basic standards, and even harder to maintain them. By Leslie Kaufman and David Gonzalez.  Special Report, 2,900 words; an ABRIDGED version will also move.  (ART ADV: Photo NYT24 is being sent to NYT photo clients.)  PERU-CRASH (Lima) _ Peru has been largely silent about the incident in which a plane carrying U.S. missionaries was shot down after being mistaken for a drug smuggling plane. By Clifford Krauss.  And  PERU-FAMILIES (Muskegon, Mich.) _ On the families of the missionaries who were on the downed plane.  RUSSIA-CHECHNYA (Novogroznensky, Russia) _ The land mine that blew up a Russian APC here last month exacted terrible retribution, Chechens say: six civilians executed without interrogation or any assertion of their link to the blast. By Patrick E. Tyler.  MONTENEGRO-VOTE (Podgorica) _ Montenegro's governing pro-independence coalition won a narrow victory in the parliamentary election on Sunday, but the unexpectedly small margin left President Milo Djukanovic weakened in his push for secession from Yugoslavia. By Carlotta Gall.  NATIONAL _ GENERAL (Moved in ``a'' category)  TEXAS-AFTER-BUSH (Houston) _ Even though he's no longer governor, George W. Bush is having and unusually tough time with the Texas Legislature. Lawmakers who passed tax cuts when Bush was governor are now talking about future tax increases. Legislators in both parties agree that the state's charter schools, one of Bush's pet programs, need to be fixed. His signature environmental initiative is regarded as weak and legislators are debating how much it should be toughened. Lawmakers also are expected to streamline enrollment in Medicaid a move resisted during Bush's tenure so more poor children can be covered. And lawmakers are moving forward on several death penalty reforms, including a bill similar to one Bush vetoed two years ago that sponsors say would help provide better lawyers for indigent criminal defendants. By Jim Yardley. 1,500 words.  RELIGION-CHARITY (Philadelphia) _ With Congress about to begin hearings on President Bush's plan for faith-based charities, Professor Byron Johnson, an expert on faith-based organizations, is deluged with requests for the data to support the claims made by President Bush and others that religious programs can transform the lives of drug addicts, criminals, welfare recipients and troubled teenagers. But the truth is that such data does not exist. By Laurie Goodstein. 1,200 words.  KAN-TORNADO (Hoisington, Kan.) _ A tiny town on the Plains recovers after one person is killed, dozens injured and about a quarter of the town is damaged by a surprise twister late Saturday night.  BUSINESS DAY _ (Moved in ``f'' category)  AIDS-DRUGS (Undated) _ A few foreign drug manufacturers, working in the shadows to make copycat versions of patented AIDS medicines, are shedding new light on how little these medicines cost to make. These drug makers sell their products to countries like Brazil, India and Argentina, which have largely ignored the patents that the world's largest makers depend on for a monopoly and for wide latitude in setting prices. By Melody Petersen. 1,800 words.  (ART ADV: Graphics are being sent to NYT graphics clients.)  DELTA-PILOTS (Undated) _ Looking at the details in the tentative agreement between Delta Air Lines and its pilots and what it may mean for the company and the industry. By Laurence Zuckerman.  NUCLEAR-ENERGY (Cambridge, Mass.) _ Some regions of the United States are short of electric power, and the price of natural gas, the most popular fuel for new plants, has doubled. Nuclear reactors are now so desirable that when old ones go up for sale, bidding wars have broken out, and the Bush administration's energy plan, due out soon, is expected to include strong support for new reactor construction. After a 30-year hiatus, the time may be drawing closer to reconsider nuclear power. By Matthew L. Wald.  (ART ADV: Graphic is being sent to NYT graphic clients.)  BROKERS-COMPLAINT (New York) _ A prominent Wall Street brokerage is being accused of pressuring some clients into a risky investment strategy. By Gretchen Morgenson.  INVESTORS-MARKETPLACE (New York) _ The bulls have not surrendered yet. After one of the biggest months of withdrawals from stock funds since October 1987, investors have been speedily heading back into stock funds in April. By Danny Hakim.  CONFERENCE-AD-COLUMN (Undated) _ A look at some of the highlights, lowlights and sidelights of the 2001 management conference of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, held last week in Naples, Fla. By Stuart Elliott. JEEPS-OHIO (Toledo, Ohio) _ DaimlerChrysler opens a new Jeep Liberty factory here, the first built from scratch by a more-or-less American automaker in some years. By Keith Bradsher.  COMMENTARY (Moved in ``k'' category)  FRIEDMAN-COLUMN _ Thomas L. Friedman writes about the summit meeting in Quebec.  COLLINS-COLUMN _ Gail Collins on computers and Sesame Street.  SPORTS (Moved in ``s'' category)  BKN-BERKOW-COLUMN (New York) _ Sports of The Times column on Charlie Ward, and the repercussions from his remarks about Jews, Jesus Christ and the Bible, remarks that have offended many Jews and led to Ward being booed through much of Sunday's playoff game between the Knicks and Toronto Raptors. By Ira Berkow.  BBA-MARINERS-JAPAN (Seattle, Wash.) _ A look at the popularity, here and in Japan, of Ichiro Suzuki and Kazuhiro Sasaki. By Sam Howe Verhovek.  SCIENCE TIMES (Moved in ``a'' category)  SCI-AUTISM-REPORT (Undated) _ A new report on autism is released. By Sandra Blakeslee.  SCI-TELLER-HBOMB (Undated) _ After a heart attack, Dr. Edward Teller sat down with a friend and a tape recorder and discussed the secret history of the hydrogen bomb. The first design, he said, ``was made by Dick Garwin.'' Teller, now 93, was not ceding the laurels for devising the bomb _ a glory he claims for himself. But he was rewriting how the rough idea became the world's most feared weapon. His tribute, made more than two decades ago but just now coming to light, adds a surprising twist to a dispute that has roiled historians and scientists for decades: Who should get credit for designing the H-bomb? A transcript of the conversation was made available to The Times. By William J. Broad. (2100 words)  (ART ADV: Photos NYT1,2 are being sent to NYT photo clients.)  SCI-BRAZIL-GENOMICS (Sao Paolo) _ The Research Support Foundation of the State of Sao Paulo is rapidly becoming a powerhouse in genomics and a model for scientific investigation in the third world. In July, a Brazilian consortium organized and financed by the foundation became the first anywhere to decode the genome of a plant pathogen, Xylella fastidiosa, an insect-borne bacteria that infests oranges. A few months later, the foundation, known as Fapesp, announced it had completed the genetic sequence of a second pest that plagues this country's thriving fruit export industry, Xanthomonas citri, or citrus canker. The twin successes not only established its international reputation but also led to collaborations with other important research agencies. By Larry Rohter. (1590 words)  (ART ADV: Photo NYT6 is being sent to NYT photo clients.)  SCI-HEART-TRAINING (Undated) _ Health clubs and cardiologists all over the country compute the maximum heart rate by subtracting a person's age from 220. Trouble is that formula doesn't work for at least 40 percent of the population, and that has ramifications for cardiac testing. Even the man who devised the formula says it's only an approximation that has taken on a life all its own. By Gina Kolata. (1750 words)  SCI-IONIC-LIQUIDS (Undated) _ Substances with chemical structures similar to table salt _ but look and flow like water _ may one day become environmentally friendly replacements for some of the noxious solvents used by industry. They're called ionic liquids, essentially salts with low melting temperatures. Although still years away from widespread industrial use, ionic liquids are attracting the interest of Exxon Mobil, BP Amoco and other companies. By Kenneth Chang. (890 words)  SCI-MESOSCALE-BIOLOGY (Undated) _ One submicropscopic area remains largely a mystery to experts: This is the region containing matter on a scale of 10 to 1,000 angstroms (an angstrom being one billionth of a meter) _ bigger than a simple molecule but smaller than a living cell. This is the realm in which the constituents of cells interact with one another. Now scientists are trying to penetrate that realm, known as the mesoscale. By Sandra Blakeslee. (1585 words)  SCI-DOG-BARKS (Undated) _ A small band of researchers around the world, trying to separate fact from speculation, are finding that dogs almost always bark for a reason, even if that reason isn't apparent to humans. Dog barks can be noisy, harmonic or a combination of the two, depending on their context and purpose. One study shows how different barks express different emotions, including loneliness, fear, distress, stress and pleasure, as well as a need for care among puppies _ and serve to alert other dogs, people or animals to changing external circumstances. By Mark Derr. (1100 words)  SCI-STEM-CELLS (Undated) _ Secretary Tommy Thompson of Health and Human Services tells the National Institutes of Health to hold off on considering grants for embryonic stem cell research, pending a legal review of the issue by HHS. By Nicholas Wade. (450 words)  SCI-WATCH (Undated) _ News and notes on science: Items on the genome of cheese, female elderly elephants and their role in the family, and toxic waste sites. By Henry Fountain. (680 words)  SCI-OMEGA3-DIET (Undated) _ A type of fat called Omega-3 and found mostly in fish is emerging as essential to good health. Lack of it may play a role in a number of modern maladies, including cardiac arrhythmia, irritable bowel syndrome and rheumatoid arthritis. Late last year the American Heart Association recommended that everyone include salmon or tuna in his diet at least twice a week, the first time the organization has departed from a general guideline to recommend a specific food. By Jim Robbins. (1200 words)  (ART ADV: Photo NYT5 is being sent to NYT photo clients.)  SCI-VENTILATION-HEALTH (Undated) _ As the population ages and medical technology gets better, the number of patients in the United States receiving long-term mechanical ventilation has been rising, from 6,000 in the mid-1980s to at least 12,000 and perhaps 20,000 or more today, experts on critical care say. The number of centers caring for these patients has also grown, from about 100 in 1990 to 240 today. Their care is expensive, and some tough decisions have to be made about financing it. By Sandeep Jauhar. (1465 words)  (ART ADV: Photo NYT4 is being sent to NYT photo clients.)  SCI-BRODY-HEALTH (Undated) _ Second of two Personal Health columns on getting sober. People who have mastered alcohol abstinence explain how they do it, and it isn't necessarily one day at a time. By Jane E. Brody.  SCI-BIKING-UP-EVEREST (Undated) _ This exercise group calls it Mount Everest. It's a four-hour stationary bike climb becoming increasingly popular at health clubs. A first-person account of what it involves. By Gina Kolata. (850 words)  (ART ADV: Photo NYT7 is being sent to NYT photo clients.)  SCI-VITAL-SIGNS (Undated) _ News and notes on health and fitness. By Eric Nagourney.  _ In a report that has implications for both commercial woodworkers and people who doing repairs at home, federal health authorities say they have found evidence that significant amounts of lead may remain in a piece of wood even after a solvent removes lead-based paint. (240 words)  _ Light therapy for seasonal affective disorder may benefit tissues as well as the eyes. (220 words)  _ Researchers at Duke and Veterans Affairs say they have evidence that many people who have trouble staying asleep may be better served by taking sleep training in which they learn to change their behavior. (265 words)  _ If you just can't get a certain song out of your head, it may not be because the tune is particularly catchy. It could be a brain aneurysm. Mayo Clinic reported on just such a case recently. The aneurysms were repaired and the music went away. (175 words)  _ Why is the rate of obesity going up in America? One explanation may be as simple as tearing open a bag of corn chips: snacking. (215 words)  SCI-Q&AMP;A (Undated) _ A science question answered: Is there any treatment for vitiligo, the loss of skin pigment that leaves white patches on the body, and, what causes it? By C. Claiborne Ray. (285 words)  ENTERTAINMENT (Moved in ``e'' category)  VENEZUELA-CULTURE (Caracas) _ The museum Sofia Imber built from scratch and directed for more than 25 years continues to bear her name and imprint, at least for the moment. But she herself has become the most prominent victim and symbol of the ``cultural revolution'` that president Hugo Chavez has unleashed here as part of his campaign to free Venezuela from a ``rancid oligarchy.'' By Larry Rohter.  BRAZIL-MUSIC (Recife, Brazil) _ At Abril Pro Rock, the annual music festival that grew out of the mangue beat scene. By Ben Ratliff.  STEVE-MARTIN-COLLECTOR (Las Vegas) _ As a stand-up comedian, Steve Martin often played Vegas. Now it's his art collection that's doing a gig here. By Grace Glueck.  LOVE-BOOK-REVIEW (Undated) _ From gaps in the story of Ovid's life, Jane Alison has constructed a wonderfully seductive first novel, ``The Love Artists.'' It's a novel that shimmers with the musical artifice of Ovid's poetry while evoking the darker tragedies of his life. Reviewed by Michiko Kakutani. The Ballerina and Petrouchka expertly and un-self-consciously spun into pirouettes, still dressed in their underclothes. Working with Twist, the costume designer known as David was finishing the Ballerina's elegant gold lace tutu and Petrouchka's red and blue checkered pants and tasseled blue hat, modeled after Nijinksy's in the original Ballets Russes production. ``I thought I'd only use these puppets for rehearsals and make new ones for Lincoln Center,'' Twist said. ``But now we love them very much, so I just keep replacing their parts when they become damaged.'' , it said,	 In addition, it said, women are more sensitive to certain types of pain, and a woman may feel more or less pain from the same stimulus at different stages of the menstrual cycle. These differences have important implications for the treatment of illnesses, the panel said. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, it said,	 The panel urged scientists to investigate sex differences at the level of cells and molecules, not only in the reproductive system, but in other parts of the body, for, it said, ``every cell has a sex'' _ every cell contains a full set of chromosomes, including the sex chromosomes. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, it said,	 The panel said it had found many intriguing and significant sex differences. Women, it said, are more likely than men to recover language ability after suffering a stroke that affects the left side of the brain. Likewise, it said, estrogen, the female sex hormone, appears to improve the reading ability of post-menopausal women. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010424.0456 type=story > <HEADLINE> MARKET PLACE: LUCENT LEARNS ITS LESSONS </HEADLINE> <DATELINE>  (BC-LUCENT-MARKETPLACE-1STLD-WRITETHRU-NYT) </DATELINE> <TEXT> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, he noted,	 ``This particular period is unparalleled,'' Belt said. Before the court-ordered breakup of AT&AMP;T, he noted, telecom companies were usually considered to be utilities. But in recent years, the sector has boomed as companies tried to rapidly build out networks to serve everything from cellular phones to high-speed Internet access. But when the dot-coms started collapsing, so did much of the interest in building out huge data networks. And many of the sales predictions have fallen short of reality. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, he explained,	 Looking backward, JDS fell victim to a chain of events, Langley said. The telecommunications service providers were hit first, he explained, cutting back their orders to equipment-makers, who then in turn wound up buying fewer parts from companies like JDS, putting it at the back of a line of tumbling dominos. </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, he said,	 Wu noted, though, that the muted reaction to the American decision was somewhat misleading. INTERNATIONAL (i)  TAIWAN-MILITARY (Hong Kong) _ Taiwan military officials wake up to better news than nearly any of them had dared hope for: In arms sales, as in life, you don't always get what you ask for, but sometimes you get exactly what you need. By Indira A.R. Lakshmanan. 850 words.  FOOT-TOURISM (Satterthwaite, England) _ Tourists are drawn by the indelible images of Romantic poets like William Wordsworth, who found inspiration here. But while Wordsworth's old home, Dove Cottage, is open, the fields and paths where hikers love to ramble are not. That's because of foot and mouth disease. By Kevin Cullen. 965 words.  CUBA-HAVANA (Havana) _ Cuba is rebuilding long-neglected Old Havana with a blend of capitalist urban planning and communist central planning. The first beneficiaries will be foreign tourists and the cash they bring. By Richard Chacon. 1290 words.  NATIONAL (a)  ANTISMOKING-LEADER (Boston) _ King James I of England, declaring cigarette smoking ``loathsome,'' ``hateful'' and ``harmful.'' In 1631 ordered the practice banned in the Massachusetts Bay Colony. The prohibition lasted only a few years but, in a sense, it foreshadowed a role Massachusetts would play again almost four centuries later: Precedent-setter in curbing tobacco use. By Adam Pertman. 1900 words.  RELIGION-DOGMA (Cambridge, Mass.) _ The Rev. Roger Haight, a well-known theologian, is the only American theologian known to be currently under Vatican investigation. Haight, it appears, has stepped squarely into the hottest debate now roiling the arcane world of Catholic theology: How to describe the role Jesus plays in salvation for non-Christians. By Michael Paulson. 1390 words.  CLONING-PETS (Undated) _ Scientists still haven't perfected the process of cloning cows and sheep. But that hasn't stopped people from selling the possibility that someday a pet can be duplicated. By Joanna Weiss. 1300 words. PHOTO  COMMENTARY (k)  RELIGION-QUESTION (Undated) _ Question of the week. By Michael Paulson.  (Eds.: Michael Paulson and Derrick Jackson are not writing today.)  LIFESTYLE (l)  TEENS-CREDIT (Undated) _ Attempting to cash in on the lucrative teen credit market, financial institutions have begun issuing credit cards that introduce teens to the pleasure of plastic. By Vanessa Jones. 1775 words; includes credit card and spending text tables. PHOTO  NEW-DIRECTION (Undated) _ Jim Langevin was determined to be a police officer or an FBI agent. Instead, the wheelchair-bound Rhode Island Democrat wound up a US congressman. By Wayne Washington. 1300 words.  ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS (e)  BOOK-DEMOCRATS (Undated) _ It is only natural that veteran journalist Sara Miles's four-year chronicle of Silicon Valley's unlikely romance with politics should reflect its surroundings: the supercharged ups and downs. By Robert L. Turner.  MAGAZINE-REVIEW (Undated) _ The latest in pop magazines. By Globe Staff.  FOOD (d)  FOOD-LACOMBE (Les Eyzies-de-Tayac, France) -- Wendely(cq) Harvey and her husband Robert Cave-Rogers have established a cooking school called La Combe, where teachers, mostly from America, conduct classes in English using local ingredients. By Sheryl Julian. 1725 words.  FINANCIAL (f)  UPROMISE-BRONNER (New York) _ Michael Bronner, ex-CEO of Digitas Inc., was in his element and in the spotlight Tuesday, herding a handful of corporate America's biggest names on and off the stage at the Citigroup Conference Center in Manhattan. The occasion was the official launch of UPromise Inc., a relationship marketing program offering kickbacks to your kids' college fund. By Scott Bernard Nelson. 620 words.  DISAPPEARING-FISHERMEN (Beal's Island, Maine) _ Since 1994 federal dollars have gone toward coaxing Northeastern fishermen into jobs on land. The government's secret weapons in the campaign are men like Vernal Woodward, 94, who weekly heads out to find new fisherman to bring the message to. By Ellen Barry. 1520 words.  ONBUSINESS-COLUMN (Undated) _ EMC Corp. expects to spend $750 million to develop new software products this year alone, a big bet even for a company of its industry-leading stature. By Steven Syre and Charles Stein.  (Eds.: Finance-Hooker is unavailable today.) , he says,	 Regardless of how he identifies his racial and ethnic heritage, Savoy editor-in-chief Roy S. Johnson maintains Woods has the chance to ``change our thoughts on race in the 21st century.'' Like Jackie Robinson, Muhammad Ali, and Arthur Ashe, Woods could become ``a rare race sportsman,'' Johnson writes. ``He can even force us to accept the prickly and potentially combustible issues surrounding the growing acknowledgment of ethnically mixed Americans, and the practical, intellectual and political impact of this new category of citizens upon each of us.'' Woods, he says, can become ``one of the pivotal figures of his time,'' only if he ``accepts the opportunity he has to draw our myriad cultures toward a peaceful co-existence.'' </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, he says,	 The summer movie season is almost upon us, and as much as we love to cheer the hero, we need a bad-to-the-bone villain to sneer. But in Movieline, always-hilarious Joe Queenan argues that in too many recent movies, ``the villain is not sufficiently villainous.'' Standards of villainy have dropped so much, what we are left with, he says, is Matt Damon in ``The Talented Mr. Ripley,'' as ``the giggliest, nerdiest, least disturbing psychopath since Dr. Evil,'' in the ``Austin Powers'' movies. ``The world as we know it is still evenly divided between good and evil people, and recognizing this, Hollywood has always attempted to depict the epic struggle for the human soul as a part of everyday life. But it has also understood that for the triumph of Good to resonate, Evil must be a worthy adversary, a countervailing force to the hero,'' Queenan writes. ``Otherwise, it's the Yankees ganging up on the Astros.'' </P> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
, he says,	 The best recent movie villain, he says, was one moviegoers never saw _ the Blair Witch of ``The Blair Witch Project.'' ``By refusing to identify who was responsible for the murders taking place in the wilds of rural Maryland, the filmmakers forced the audience to confront their own personal demons, and construct highly personal images of the murderer.'' And what highly personal image of the Blair Witch did Queenan construct for himself? ``A 150-year-old leprosy-ravaged succubus with the body of Oprah Winfrey and the personality of Courtney Love. And I haven't slept well for the 18 months since I saw the film.'' </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010425.0147 type=story > <HEADLINE> MILES PLUGS INTO VALLEY BOYS' POLITICAL NETWORK </HEADLINE> <DATELINE>  (BC-BOOK-DEMOCRATS-BOS) </DATELINE> <TEXT> 	nyt_eng_200104.gz
