The Boston Globe </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20010425.0153 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-HEARST-NEWS-BUDGET-HNS) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Wednesday, April 25, 2001  Editors  The Hearst News Service will file the following for Thursday. If you have questions, please call Susie McBee or Tim Spence at 202-298-6920.  (The ``HNS'' tag appears in all sluglines.)  WASHINGTON NEWS (``w'' category)  AIRPORTS-CAPACITY (Washington) _ A new FAA report lists New York's LaGuardia airport, Chicago's O'Hare and airports in Newark, N.J. and San Francisco as the top four in delayed flights. The study, covering the nation's 31 busiest U.S. airports, rated airports in Honolulu, Memphis, Tampa and Salt Lake City as having the fewest delays. The report was released at a House hearing called to spotlight gridlock in air travel. By DAN FREEDMAN.  COURT-TOBACCO (Washington) _ Supreme Court justices debate whether a Massachusetts ban on outdoor signs advertising tobacco products within 1,000 feet of a public playground or school violates the right of cigarette and cigar companies to promote their products. Massachusetts officials say the ban is a reasonable use of state power to protect children from predatory product promotion. By MARK HELM.  MEXICO-ORPHANAGE (Washington) _ Students from Nye Elementary School in Laredo, Texas, receive a $10,000 ``Make A Difference Day'' award for their charitable work in Mexico. The children, mostly poor themselves, received the prize from USA Weekend, a newspaper supplement published by USA Today. They plan to use the money to continue helping 120 orphans in the neighboring Mexican city of Nuevo Laredo. By LARA JAKES.  COMMENTARY (``k'' category)  HELEN-THOMAS (Washington) _ In his first 100 days in office President Bush has initiated policies to move the country to the right domestically and in foreign affairs. But he has shown a remarkable ability to reverse himself in certain cases when there is an uproar over his attempts to roll back environmental and health safety rules. Bush is also a pragmatic politician who has cut his losses and not let them fester. , he said,	 Most mesh fencing products range in height from 3{ to 5 feet, he said, with the bottom edge nearly touching the ground. The price, installed, is from $16 to $20 a foot; better-quality fences carry a 30-year warranty. For Immediate Release  The Boston Globe plans to move the following FEATURE stories for use by NYTimes News Service clients.  For questions about stories, please contact Frank Perrotta at the Boston Globe, 617-929-2597. For individual purchase of budgeted graphics or photos please call 212-556-4204 or 888-603-1036.  All stories will bear the BOS designator.  INTERNATIONAL (i)  TAIWAN-MILITARY (Hong Kong) _ Taiwan military officials wake up to better news than nearly any of them had dared hope for: In arms sales, as in life, you don't always get what you ask for, but sometimes you get exactly what you need. By Indira A.R. Lakshmanan. 850 words.  FOOT-TOURISM (Satterthwaite, England) _ Tourists are drawn by the indelible images of Romantic poets like William Wordsworth, who found inspiration here. But while Wordsworth's old home, Dove Cottage, is open, the fields and paths where hikers love to ramble are not. That's because of foot and mouth disease. By Kevin Cullen. 965 words.  CUBA-HAVANA (Havana) _ Cuba is rebuilding long-neglected Old Havana with a blend of capitalist urban planning and communist central planning. The first beneficiaries will be foreign tourists and the cash they bring. By Richard Chacon. 1290 words.  NATIONAL (a)  ANTISMOKING-LEADER (Boston) _ King James I of England, declaring cigarette smoking ``loathsome,'' ``hateful'' and ``harmful.'' In 1631 ordered the practice banned in the Massachusetts Bay Colony. The prohibition lasted only a few years but, in a sense, it foreshadowed a role Massachusetts would play again almost four centuries later: Precedent-setter in curbing tobacco use. By Adam Pertman. 1900 words.  RELIGION-DOGMA (Cambridge, Mass.) _ The Rev. Roger Haight, a well-known theologian, is the only American theologian known to be currently under Vatican investigation. Haight, it appears, has stepped squarely into the hottest debate now roiling the arcane world of Catholic theology: How to describe the role Jesus plays in salvation for non-Christians. By Michael Paulson. 1390 words.  CLONING-PETS (Undated) _ Scientists still haven't perfected the process of cloning cows and sheep. But that hasn't stopped people from selling the possibility that someday a pet can be duplicated. By Joanna Weiss. 1300 words. PHOTO  COMMENTARY (k)  RELIGION-QUESTION (Undated) _ Question of the week. By Michael Paulson.  (Eds.: Michael Paulson and Derrick Jackson are not writing today.)  LIFESTYLE (l)  TEENS-CREDIT (Undated) _ Attempting to cash in on the lucrative teen credit market, financial institutions have begun issuing credit cards that introduce teens to the pleasure of plastic. By Vanessa Jones. 1775 words; includes credit card and spending text tables. PHOTO  NEW-DIRECTION (Undated) _ Jim Langevin was determined to be a police officer or an FBI agent. Instead, the wheelchair-bound Rhode Island Democrat wound up a US congressman. By Wayne Washington. 1300 words.  ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS (e)  BOOK-DEMOCRATS (Undated) _ It is only natural that veteran journalist Sara Miles's four-year chronicle of Silicon Valley's unlikely romance with politics should reflect its surroundings: the supercharged ups and downs. By Robert L. Turner.  MAGAZINE-REVIEW (Undated) _ The latest in pop magazines. By Globe Staff.  FOOD (d)  FOOD-LACOMBE (Les Eyzies-de-Tayac, France) -- Wendely(cq) Harvey and her husband Robert Cave-Rogers have established a cooking school called La Combe, where teachers, mostly from America, conduct classes in English using local ingredients. By Sheryl Julian. 1725 words.  FINANCIAL (f)  UPROMISE-BRONNER (New York) _ Michael Bronner, ex-CEO of Digitas Inc., was in his element and in the spotlight Tuesday, herding a handful of corporate America's biggest names on and off the stage at the Citigroup Conference Center in Manhattan. The occasion was the official launch of UPromise Inc., a relationship marketing program offering kickbacks to your kids' college fund. By Scott Bernard Nelson. 620 words.  DISAPPEARING-FISHERMEN (Beal's Island, Maine) _ Since 1994 federal dollars have gone toward coaxing Northeastern fishermen into jobs on land. The government's secret weapons in the campaign are men like Vernal Woodward, 94, who weekly heads out to find new fisherman to bring the message to. By Ellen Barry. 1520 words.  ONBUSINESS-COLUMN (Undated) _ EMC Corp. expects to spend $750 million to develop new software products this year alone, a big bet even for a company of its industry-leading stature. By Steven Syre and Charles Stein.  (Eds.: Finance-Hooker is unavailable today.)  SPORTS (s)  BBA-REDSOX-LOWE (Boston) _ With almost every letter he opens, closer Derek Lowe discovers some token offered by a fandom trying to help the struggling pitcher. By Gordon Edes. 730 words.  BBA-RYAN-COLUMN (Boston) _ Here's all you need to know about the 2001 Minnesota Twins: Everyday Eddie Guardado is ready to file for workman's comp. By Bob Ryan. 1050 words. If you have questions, please call Susie McBee or Tim Spence at 202-298-6920.  (The ``HNS'' tag appears in all sluglines.)  For Thursday:  WASHINGTON NEWS (``w'' category)  TERROR-ECONOMY (Washington) _ President Bush and Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill unveil an emergency proposal for up to $75 billion in added federal spending and tax breaks to lift the economy from a threatened recession aggravated by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. By STEWART M. POWELL.  TERROR-BIOCHEMICAL (Washington) _ Health and Human Services Secretary Tommy G. Thompson tells Americans to be calm about any prospects of a biochemical attack. But he also warns that people should be vigilant and check any unusual cold symptoms with a doctor. By JUDY HOLLAND.  TERROR-WORKERS (Washington) _ Aviation workers, saying they were left out of a $15 billion bailout for the airline industry, urge Congress to pass a separate relief package to help more than 100,000 people in their industry who have lost their jobs. Several lawmakers support their pleas. By DAVID EGGERT.  FINANCIAL/BUSINESS NEWS (``f'' category)  COURT-PLANTS (Washington) _ Wading into the world of genetically engineered plants, the Supreme Court examines whether seeds from such plants should be awarded the kinds of patents that usually cover mechanical, electrical or chemical inventions. By MARK HELM.  COMMENTARY (``k'' category)  HELEN-THOMAS (Washington) _ I don't think you'll be hearing President Bush attack the federal government or bash Washington bureaucrats again any time soon. The world has changed for him, as it has for all of us. More than ever, he needs a strong government in Washington. By HELEN THOMAS.  For Sunday:  WASHINGTON NEWS (``w'' category)  TERROR-BIN-LADEN (Washington) _ Osama bin Laden views the United States as a weak and decadent nation whose armed forces suffer from what he once described as ``low spiritual morale.'' Terrorism experts say that in launching the Sept. 11 attacks, bin Laden expected either a withdrawal of U.S. forces from the Gulf region, or a U.S.-led air war that would be ineffective and indiscriminate in its casualties. That, he thought, would lead the Arab world to unite against America. By DAN FREEDMAN.  COMMENTARY (``k'' category)  THOMPSON-COLUMN (Washington) _ There are times when the best politics is to be non-political. This is one of those times _ when Americans expect their leaders to band together in a non-partisan manner. Al Gore and Bill Clinton have, in recent weeks, abided by the axiom that politics stops at the water's edge. By ROBERT E. THOMPSON. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20011003.0125 type=story > <HEADLINE>     COMMENTARY </HEADLINE> <DATELINE>  (BC-LILEKS-PROTEST-NNS ) </DATELINE> <TEXT> "	"nyt_eng_200110.gz"
"97599"	"he"	"thought"	" Story Filed By Cox Newspapers </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20011003.0171 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-HEARST-NEWS-BUDGET-1STLD-WRITETHRU-HNS) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Wednesday, Oct. 3, 2001  Editors  The Hearst News Service will file the following for Thursday and Sunday. If you have questions, please call Susie McBee or Tim Spence at 202-298-6920.  (Adds: AFGHAN-WEATHER; TERROR-DRUGS; OLYMPIC-SECURITY; BUS-ATTACK; STOLEN-FLAGS; TERROR-ARMY; TERROR-BROADWAY; BATHTUB-SLAYINGS; JAILED-JOURNALIST; and MEXICO-CASINOS.)  For Thursday:  INTERNATIONAL NEWS (``i'' category)  AFGHAN-WEATHER (Kahoja Dahauddian, Afghanistan) _ When units of the U.S. Army's 10th Mountain Division deploy to this region, its most formidable foe won't be the Taliban. It will be the weather. Blinding sandstorms that engulfed this town in rebel-held territory this week are not uncommon throughout the country. Wind-whipped sand sometimes blocks the sun and brings air travel to a halt. By JIM MICHAELS.  TERROR-DRUGS (Undated) _ The U.S.-led war on terrorism will initially target Islamic extremists based in Afghanistan _ but law enforcement sources say an important battle will be combatting the lucrative heroin trade that fuels key terrorist groups. By BILL WALLACE.  WASHINGTON NEWS (``w'' category)  TERROR-ECONOMY (Washington) _ President Bush and Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill unveil an emergency proposal for up to $75 billion in added federal spending and tax breaks to lift the economy from a threatened recession aggravated by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. By STEWART M. POWELL.  OLYMPIC-SECURITY (Washington) _ Organizers of the 2002 Winter Olympics were planning to spend $265 million on security before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States. Now the Salt Lake City organizers are asking congressional leaders for millions more to guard against terrorism. By KATHRYN A. WOLFE.  TERROR-BIOCHEMICAL (Washington) _ Health and Human Services Secretary Tommy G. Thompson tells Americans to be calm about any prospects of a biochemical attack. But he also warns that people should be vigilant and check any unusual cold symptoms with a doctor. By JUDY HOLLAND.  TERROR-WORKERS (Washington) _ Aviation workers, saying they were left out of a $15 billion bailout for the airline industry, urge Congress to pass a separate relief package to help more than 100,000 people in their industry who have lost their jobs. Several lawmakers support their pleas. By DAVID EGGERT.  NATIONAL NEWS (``a'' category)  BUS-ATTACK (Undated) _ A Greyhound bus crashes after one of the passengers slit the driver's throat, killing six of the 38 people aboard and prompting Greyhound to temporarily halt all service nationwide as a precaution. The response to this attack and crash, while apparently not linked to terrorism, was amplified by the aerial attacks three weeks ago. By MICHAEL HEDGES.  STOLEN-FLAGS (Tacoma, Wash.) _ Is this a sign of our times? A national cemetery south of Seattle is reporting that professional-like burglars managed to get into its secure premises and steal 38 American flags that had draped the coffins of veterans and were donated to the cemetery by their families. By ELAINE PORTERFIELD.  TERROR-ARMY (Fort Bragg, N.C.) _ The war against the terrorists, President Bush says, will be a war like no other and to fight it, the United States has an Army like no other in its history. The U.S. Army is smaller, older, smarter than it was even 10 years ago. It is more like a family (half the soldiers are married) and it is more at peace with itself. But there are few soldiers around today with the ultimate military experience _ combat. By CARL NOLTE.  TERROR-BROADWAY (New York) _ Broadway is springing back to life, the lights are back on and the theaters are filling back up. By ERIC BRAZIL.  BATHTUB-SLAYINGS (Houston) _ A district judge sets a Jan. 7 trial date for Andrea Pia Yates, who is accused of drowning her five children in the bathtub. Last month, a jury found the 37-year-old mother competent to stand trial on capital murder charges. By CAROL CHRISTIAN.  JAILED-JOURNALIST (Houston) _ The federal government's decision to imprison self-described journalist Vanessa Leggett sends the wrong message to a world that looks to the United States as a beacon of free speech, a South American media advocate says after meeting with the writer. Leggett was jailed more than a month ago for refusing to turn over to a federal grand jury taped recordings of her interviews with a suspect in a murder trial. By EDWARD HEGSTROM.  BUSINESS/FINANCIAL NEWS (``f'' category)  COURT-PLANTS (Washington) _ Wading into the world of genetically engineered plants, the Supreme Court examines whether seeds from such plants should be awarded the kinds of patents that usually cover mechanical, electrical or chemical inventions. By MARK HELM.  MEXICO-CASINOS (Mexico City) _ Hard times in the Mexican tourism business are creating a new push for more casinos to help bring back American visitors. By JENALIA MORENO.  COMMENTARY (``k'' category)  HELEN-THOMAS (Washington) _ I don't think you'll be hearing President Bush attack the federal government or bash Washington bureaucrats again any time soon. The world has changed for him, as it has for all of us. More than ever, he needs a strong government in Washington. By HELEN THOMAS.  For Sunday:  WASHINGTON NEWS (``w'' category)  TERROR-BIN-LADEN (Washington) _ Osama bin Laden views the United States as a weak and decadent nation whose armed forces suffer from what he once described as ``low spiritual morale.'' Terrorism experts say that in launching the Sept. 11 attacks, bin Laden expected either a withdrawal of U.S. forces from the Gulf region, or a U.S.-led air war that would be ineffective and indiscriminate in its casualties. That, he thought, would lead the Arab world to unite against America. By DAN FREEDMAN. This is one of those times _ when Americans expect their leaders to band together in a non-partisan manner. Al Gore and Bill Clinton have, in recent weeks, abided by the axiom that politics stops at the water's edge. By ROBERT E. If you have questions, please call Susie McBee or Tim Spence at 202-298-6920.  For Thursday:  INTERNATIONAL NEWS (``i'' category)  AFGHAN-WEATHER (Kahoja Dahauddian, Afghanistan) _ If U.S. military forces deploy to this region, its most formidable foe won't be the Taliban. It will be the weather. Blinding sandstorms that engulfed this town in rebel-held territory this week are not uncommon throughout the country. Wind-whipped sand sometimes blocks the sun and brings air travel to a halt. By JIM MICHAELS. (Already filed.)  WASHINGTON NEWS (``w'' category)  TERROR-ECONOMY (Washington) _ President Bush and Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill unveil an emergency proposal for up to $75 billion in added federal spending and tax breaks to lift the economy from a threatened recession aggravated by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. By STEWART M. POWELL. (Already filed.)  OLYMPIC-SECURITY (Washington) _ Organizers of the 2002 Winter Olympics were planning to spend $265 million on security before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States. Now the Salt Lake City organizers are asking congressional leaders for millions more to guard against terrorism. By KATHRYN A. WOLFE.  TERROR-BIOCHEMICAL (Washington) _ Health and Human Services Secretary Tommy G. Thompson tells Americans to be calm about any prospects of a biochemical attack. But he also warns that people should be vigilant and check any unusual cold symptoms with a doctor. By JUDY HOLLAND. (Already filed.)  TERROR-WORKERS (Washington) _ Aviation workers, saying they were left out of a $15 billion bailout for the airline industry, urge Congress to pass a separate relief package to help more than 100,000 people in their industry who have lost their jobs. Several lawmakers support their pleas. By DAVID EGGERT. (Also filed in ``f'' category.)  NATIONAL NEWS (``a'' category)  BUS-ATTACK (Undated) _ A Greyhound bus crashes after one of the passengers slit the driver's throat, killing six of the 38 people aboard and prompting Greyhound to temporarily halt all service nationwide as a precaution. The response to this attack and crash, while apparently not linked to terrorism, was amplified by the aerial attacks three weeks ago. By MICHAEL HEDGES.  STOLEN-FLAGS (Kent, Wash.) _ Is this a sign of our times? A national cemetery south of Seattle is reporting that professional-like burglars managed to get into its secure premises and steal 38 American flags that had draped the coffins of veterans and were donated to the cemetery by their families. By ELAINE PORTERFIELD. (Already filed.)  DRUGS-HEROIN (Undated) _ The U.S.-led war on terrorism will initially target Islamic extremists based in Afghanistan _ but law enforcement sources say an important battle will be combatting the lucrative heroin trade that fuels key terrorist groups. By BILL WALLACE. (Already filed.)  TERROR-ARMY (Fort Bragg, N.C.) _ The war against the terrorists, President Bush says, will be a war like no other and to fight it, the United States has an Army like no other in its history. The U.S. Army is smaller, older, smarter than it was even 10 years ago. It is more like a family (half the soldiers are married) and it is more at peace with itself. But there are few soldiers around today with the ultimate military experience _ combat. By CARL NOLTE.  TERROR-BROADWAY (New York) _ Broadway is springing back to life, the lights are back on and the theaters are filling back up. By ERIC BRAZIL.  BATHTUB-SLAYINGS (Houston) _ A district judge sets a Jan. 7 trial date for Andrea Pia Yates, who is accused of drowning her five children in the bathtub. Last month, a jury found the 37-year-old mother competent to stand trial on capital murder charges. By CAROL CHRISTIAN.  JAILED-JOURNALIST (Houston) _ The federal government's decision to imprison self-described journalist Vanessa Leggett sends the wrong message to a world that looks to the United States as a beacon of free speech, a South American media advocate says after meeting with the writer. Leggett was jailed more than a month ago for refusing to turn over to a federal grand jury taped recordings of her interviews with a suspect in a murder trial. By EDWARD HEGSTROM.  BUSINESS/FINANCIAL NEWS (``f'' category)  COURT-PLANTS (Washington) _ Wading into the world of genetically engineered plants, the Supreme Court examines whether seeds from such plants should be awarded the kinds of patents that usually cover mechanical, electrical or chemical inventions. By MARK HELM. (Also filed in ``w'' category.)  MEXICO-CASINOS (Mexico City) _ Hard times in the Mexican tourism business are creating a new push for more casinos to help bring back American visitors. By JENALIA MORENO.  COMMENTARY (``k'' category)  HELEN-THOMAS (Washington) _ I don't think you'll be hearing President Bush attack the federal government or bash Washington bureaucrats again any time soon. The world has changed for him, as it has for all of us. More than ever, he needs a strong government in Washington. By HELEN THOMAS. (Already filed.)  For Sunday:  WASHINGTON NEWS (``w'' category)  TERROR-BIN-LADEN (Washington) _ Osama bin Laden views the United States as a weak and decadent nation whose armed forces suffer from what he once described as ``low spiritual morale.'' Terrorism experts say that in launching the Sept. 11 attacks, bin Laden expected either a withdrawal of U.S. forces from the Gulf region, or a U.S.-led air war that would be ineffective and indiscriminate in its casualties. That, he thought, would lead the Arab world to unite against America. By DAN FREEDMAN. (2ndl-writethru filed.)  COMMENTARY (``k'' category)  THOMPSON-COLUMN (Washington) _ There are times when the best politics is to be non-political. This is one of those times _ when Americans expect their leaders to band together in a non-partisan manner. Al Gore and Bill Clinton have, in recent weeks, abided by the axiom that politics stops at the water's edge. By ROBERT E. THOMPSON. Celia was with me and Calvin kissed her goodbye, then me. He said, `Try to have a good day today, get some rest.' He normally takes the cell phone and drives to work. I found out later that he took the train, and I still don't know why. I went back to sleep until the phone rang, and it was my sister-in-law saying, `Are you watching television?' When I saw the smoke I was thinking maybe he got out. I was trying to count those little squares, down from the top of the building. I called his cell phone, and when it rang in the next room, I realized he hadn't taken it. When I saw that second building fall, I thought, What am I watching?' "103670"	"I"	"thought"	" When Jennifer Star, 32, an executive recruiter, was shopping last year for an apartment on the Upper East Side, she never considered a prewar building. She eventually found a 1,000-square-foot one-bedroom place with an alcove in a white-brick building for $350,000; the seller was a rabbi who had inherited the place from an older unmarried woman in his congregation who had lived there since the 1960s. ``Who thinks of a prewar anymore?'' Star said. ``You adjust your tastes completely. This apartment was totally a mess when I first saw it. I wound up gutting it completely. But the minute I walked through the door that first day, I thought, this is fabulous.'' </P> "	"nyt_eng_200201.gz"
"103685"	"she"	"thought"	" Just below them were women like Karen L. Hendricks, who stepped down as the chief executive of the Baldwin Piano &AMP; Organ Co. last February after clashing over strategy with a large investor four months before the company filed for bankruptcy protection, and Deborah C. Hopkins, the chief financial officer of Lucent _ and, she thought, chief executive-in-waiting _ who was ousted last May, essentially for being perceived as too pushy. </P> "	"nyt_eng_200201.gz"
"103868"	"I"	"thought"	" Sharon said his chief goal as prime minister has been to achieve peace. ``There was one thing I wanted to accomplish: to reach a political settlement which will lead to peace with the Palestinians and the rest of the Arab world,'' he said. ``That, I thought, would be the last thing I would do in a political life. Then I would have been glad to go back to the farm, ride the horses.'' </P> "	"nyt_eng_200201.gz"

Unfortunately, I left my pocketbook in the cab, which we chased but were unable to catch. "105644"	"I"	"thought"	" ``I was raised to avoid the dependency thing at all costs,'' Olson went on. ``And what I learned is that the only thing worse is independence. I was a poster child for it. Finally, I thought, `What have I proven?' My generation went out of the gate full tilt, propelled to have a career, and for some number maybe that choice didn't reflect who we were. I felt very propelled by my mother's frustration. She was meant to be a warrior, and my father was uncomfortable with the idea of her working. I would have just liked to have had 10 kids.'' </P> "	"nyt_eng_200202.gz"

Tommy R. Franks, the commander of the U.S. military operation in Afghanistan, testifies for the first time before Congress on the status of the war. By Eric Schmitt and Thom Shanker. (With photos)  KIDNAPPED-JOURNALIST (Islamabad, Pakistan) _ A News Analysis: The odd mixture of bravado and inscrutability with which Pakistani officials have addressed the case of the kidnapped American journalist are being closely watched here as signs of the intense pressures the abduction has placed on a government only beginning to feel its way into fresh territory. By Douglas Jehl.  With  JOURNALIST-SUSPECT (New Delhi, India) _ Indian interrogation records dating from when Sheik Omar Saeed, the chief suspect in the abduction of the Wall Street Journal report Daniel Pearl, was arrested in a 1994 kidnapping case reveal much about his beliefs and his sytle of terrorism. By Celia W. Dugger.  ARGENTINA-FLIGHT (Buenos Aires, Argentina) _ Developing: A United Airlines flight from Miami to Buenos Aires was disrupted by a passenger who tried to enter the cockpit. By Larry Rohter.  MIDEAST-BUSH-SHARON (Washington) _ Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon met with President Bush on Thursday. (Staff byline to come)  With  MIDEAST (Hamra, West Bank) _ At this tiny, isolated Jewish settlement, a Palestinian gunman disguised as an Israeli soldier entered a house on Thursday, leading to a gunbattle that left him, an Israeli woman and her 11-year-old daughter dead. The assault marked the first time in 16 months of fighting that Israelis were killed in their home. In response, Israeli F-16 warplanes fired two missiles at a government complex in the West Bank, wounding 11 Palestinians. By James Bennet.  NIGERIA-DEMOCRACY (Lagos, Nigeria) _ After a week in which more than 600 people were killed by explosions at an arms depot and another 100 were left dead in ethnic clashes, residents of this commercial capital say democracy is not all it's cracked up to be. Even as the British prime minister, Tony Blair, arrived here, a surprising number of Nigerians in interviews call for a return of military rule. By Norimitsu Onishi.  CARIBBEAN-U.S. (Nassau, Bahamas) _ U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell, attending a meeting on trade and terrorism with Caribbean foreign ministers, said the Bush administration will not free up hundreds of millions of dollars in international aid to Haiti, citing continuing political unrest. By Christopher Marquis.  WORLD-BRIEFS (Undated) _ World news in brief.  UNITED STATES _ General  (Will move in `a' category or as noted)  CHARITY-RELIGION (Washington) _ President Bush is embracing compromise legislation to help religious charities, although supporters have yet to resolve how they will pay for the scaled-back initiative. By Elisabeth Bumiller. (Summary from wires)  (Will move in ``w'' category)  OHIO-ABORTION (Washington) _ The Bush administration is backing efforts by Ohio to ban what opponents calls partial-birth abortion. By Linda Greenhouse.  (Will move in ``w'' category)  NY-FASHION-WEEK (New York) _ Fashion Week begins on Friday, and the watchword is ``appropriate.'' The organizers are using the events of 9/11 to justify a smaller, more subdued show. And many fashion designers are using their own showrooms instead of participating in the organized Fashion Week shows. By Terry Pristin.  With photos.  Enron-related stories:  ENRON (Washington) _ Developments in the collapse of Enron and the investigations. (Staff byline to come) (With photos)  (An early version of this story will move by 3 p.m. EST.)  And  ENRON-PENSIONS (Washington) _ On the politics of the competing plans to revamp pension proposals. By Robin Toner.  SCI-BIOLOGICAL-CLOCK (Undated) _ Scientists have discovered a new class of light-sensing cells in the mammalian retina, which apparently work to re-set the master biological clock each day. By Sandra Blakeslee.  SCI-OVARIAN-CANCER (Undated) _ Researchers have reported that they have taken the first step toward developing a blood test to detect ovarian cancer, including cases that are still early enough to be curable. By Denise Grady.  BUSINESS  (Will move in ``f'' news category)  EUROPE-BANK-EXEC (Frankfurt, Germany) _ Wim Duisenberg, president of the European Central Bank, announced on Thursday that he would retire in July 2003, opening a new phase in what has already become a tangled succession struggle. By Edmund L. Andrews.  (An early version of this story will move by 3 p.m. EST.)  IRELAND-BANK (Undated) _ Developments in the Allied Irish/Allfirst rogue trader situation. By Jonathan Fuerbringer with Brian Lavery.  PRINCESS-CARNIVAL (London) _ The pressure is growing in the takeover battle for P&AMP;O Princess as Carnival sweetens its bid a third time, but with a very short deadline. By Suzanne Kapner.  WORLD-BIZ-BRIEFS (Undated) _ Short items on business news from around the world.  ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS  (Will move in ``e'' news category or as indicated)  CARNIVAL-PUPPETS (New York) _ The new production of a musical that calls on the respective talents of man and marionette, ``Carnival,'' the 1961 show about a puppeteer on the midway who falls in love with a young woman adrift and alone, is one of the few musicals in which traditional puppets, manipulated and ``voiced'' by trained puppeteers, can count on work. By Peter Marks. (With photos)  SURREALISM-DESIRE (New York) _ The Metropolitan Museum of Art's big new show, ``Surrealism: Desire Unbound,'' begins logically enough with Dada and de Chirico; it ends with the vast international Surrealist exhibition organized by Andre Breton and Marcel Duchamp in 1959. By Michael Kimmelman. (With photos)  BRAZILIAN-DRAWINGS (New York) _ Two exhibitions of the work of the Italian-born Brazilian artist Anna Maria Miaolino provide a tantalizing introduction to a career that is almost unknown in the United States while shedding more light on the ferment of Brazilian art in the 1960s and '70s. By Roberta Smith.  ANTIQUES-COLUMN (Undated) _ The Antiques Column: Despite the recession, Sotheby's and Christie's had highly successful sales last month of Americana, which includes American furniture, folk art, silver and Chinese Export porcelain. By Wendy Moonan.  HESTER-BOOK-REVIEW (Undated) _ ``Hester Among the Ruins'' is Binnie Kirshenbaum's enticing, brainy and dark novel about one of the entangling enigmas of modern history. How wide did guilt for the Holocaust extend among the German people, and how deep did it descend? That is one part of it. The other is: how long does it take, if ever, for history to be over? Reviewed by Richard Eder.  LIAR-FILM-REVIEW (Undated) _ In the comedy ``Big Fat Liar,'' two young actors display an easygoing, screwball rapport as they dash around Tinseltown wreaking ludicrous havoc. Reviewed by Stephen Holden.  COLLATERAL-FILM-REVIEW (Undated) _ In ``Collateral Damage,'' Arnold Schwarzenegger plays Gordy, a Los Angeles firefighter who finds out exactly how ineffectual the U.S. government is when his wife and young son are killed by a Colombian terrorist. Reviewed by Elvis Mitchell.  SCOTLAND-FILM-REVIEW (Undated) _ ``Scotland, Pa.'' is a clever comic riff on ``Macbeth.'' By Stephen Holden.  SHIRI-FILM-REVIEW (Undated) _ The U.S. film industry may be the world's leading purveyor of violent action blockbusters, but ``Shiri,'' a new movie by the South Korean director Kang Je-Gyu, is the latest evidence that Hollywood does not hold a monopoly on fireballs, reckless driving and automatic-weapons fire. By A.O. Scott.  SPORTS  (Will move in ``s'' category)  OLY-ARATON-COLUMN (Salt Lake City) _ Sports of The Times column on Doug Robbins, who has spent the last three days looking at 1,000 urine and blood samples. He's a little tired and ready to to retire to Tuscany. By Harvey Araton.  OLY-OVERVIEW (Salt Lake City) _ A broad overview of the 2002 Winter Games, including these main themes: countries likely to win the most medals, how much the United States has spent in order to win the 20 medals it wants; and the sports likely to generate the most buzz. By Bill Pennington.  FOR ADDITIONAL INFORMATION please contact Josephine Schmidt (international editor), e-mail jossch(at)nytimes.com; 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927. Please check your level of service to determine which stories you will receive.) </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20020207.0102 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (SUNDAY-EARLY-BUDGET) </DATELINE> <TEXT> The New York Times News Service will move the following entertainment/arts and travel articles for release Feb. 10, 2002. Photo numbers and graphic notes will be added to SUNDAY-FINAL-BUDGET which will move about 8 p.m. Friday. If you have questions about stories, call 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927. For questions about photos, call 888-603-1036 or 212-556-4204.  ENTERTAINMENT &AMP; ARTS  (Coded `e')  COVER STORIES  SHAKESPEARE-DEBATE (Undated) _ It was not the Bard of Stratford-on-Avon. It was Edward de Vere, the 17th Earl of Oxford. For Oxfordians, this is the answer to ``Who Wrote Shakespeare?'' It is a position long argued, and one that has gathered momentum in recent years. Most of the academic world has ignored the authorship question for generations, or belittled it as the obsession of idiosyncratic amateur scholars, while building altars in students' minds to the image the tragedian David Garrick promoted during the 1769 Shakespeare jubilee that created the Stratford tourism business: the man of humble origins who rose to the top of the literary pantheon. The vast majority of academics still subscribe to that belief. By William S. Niederkorn.  With photo.  THEATER-SHAKESPEARE (Los Angeles) _ The debate over who actually wrote Shakespeare's works is not generally a laughing matter. For the most part, literary scholars soberly consider and reconsider the scant details of Shakespeare's life, hoping they can finally prove, or disprove, his links to what many consider the greatest plays in Western literature. But the playwright Amy Freed has opted for a different approach; she has found humor in the authorship debate. Her comedy ``The Beard of Avon,'' which received its premiere last June at South Coast Repertory in Costa Mesa, Calif., and closes Feb. 10 at the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco, portrays Shakespeare as a dim but determined bumpkin who abandons country life in Stratford for the excitement of London. By David Mermelstein.  With photo.  FILM-SHAKESPEARE (Undated) _ Into the ``who was Shakespeare'' fray now comes a documentary film _ Michael Rubbo's ``Much Ado About Something,'' which opens on Feb. 13.  FILM  FILM-COLLATERAL-DAMAGE (Undated) _ The Arnold Schwarzenegger revenge picture ``Collateral Damage,'' which opens on Feb. 8 had its original release date in November postponed when Warner Brothers executives speculated that the sight of the hero's wife and young son being blown up by terrorists would be in poor taste. That it would be in poor taste at any other time probably hadn't occurred to them _ and why should it have? It might turn out that, far from being traumatized by the horrors of ``Collateral Damage,'' audiences will find themselves reassured to see terrorist attacks on American soil framed in so familiar a way: as more grist for an endless stream of movies that use the murder of women and children to justify wanton vigilante retribution. By David Edelstein.  With photo.  DANCE  DANCE-MONTREAL-BALLET (Montreal) _ When Gradimir Pankov arrived from Europe two years ago to be the artistic director of Les Grands Ballets Canadiens de Montreal, he found a company beset with problems. Morale was low among its 35 dancers. The company had endured a decade of cutbacks in an effort to eliminate a roughly $600,000 deficit. Audiences were shrinking despite a generally well-danced repertory of short works by internationally acclaimed choreographers. Then 60, Pankov, at an age when many are planning to retire, began immediately to transform the 45-year-old company. By Linde Howe-Beck.  THEATER  THEATER-BEA-ARTHUR (New York) _ ``I figured since I'm not going to retire, because I'm old'' _ Bea Arthur deliberately raised the volume on that last word _ ``that rather than wait around for the next great role, which may or may not ever come around again, I thought, well, we'll do this.'' Arthur, 78, is alluding to her show ``Bea Arthur on Broadway: Just Between Friends,''which began previews on Jan. 29 and opens Feb. 17 at the Booth Theater for a six-week run. By Anita Gates.  With photo.  MUSIC  ROCK-STARS-REDUX (Undated) _ Aging rock stars have long chased younger audiences, of course, often hiring producers half their age. But this kind of strategic repurposing _ the selling of postrelevance _ is something new. By John Leland.  OPERA-TITLES (Undated) _ Supertitles: salvation, or the end of opera as we used to know it? By Matthew Gurewitsch.  MUSIC-SAN-FRANCISCO (San Francisco) _ The San Francisco Symphony Orchestra has become increasingly exciting during Michael Tilson Thomas' seven-year tenure as music director. In a city that prizes mavericks, Thomas, at 57, has found a congenial home. By James R. Oestreich.  TELEVISION  TV-HUEY-NEWTON (Undated) _ Huey P. Newton spent much of his life trying to escape the constricting labels of ``hero'' and ``criminal'' affixed to him by both political friends and political enemies. So it's no surprise that ``A Huey P. Newton Story,'' which will be broadcast by PBS on Feb. 13 at 9 p.m. to commemorate the 60th anniversary of his birth (on Feb. 17), is a work that defies categorization. By Ron Jenkins.  PHOTOGRAPHY  PHOTOGRAPHY-CHIC-CLICKS (Boston) _ You might think ``but is it art?'' is as outdated a question as ``is the bride a virgin?,'' but don't be too sure. The Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston puts an up-to-the-minute slant on the first question in ``Chic Clicks: Creativity and Commerce in Contemporary Fashion Photography,'' on view through May 5. By Vicki Goldberg.  BESTSELLERS, CHILDREN'S-BESTSELLERS and PAPERBACKS moved on Monday, Feb. 4.  TRAVEL  (Coded `t')  (Editors: All clients receive all budgets, but only full-service clients receive all stories. Please check your level of service to determine which stories you will receive.)  (Coded `t')  COVER STORIES  TRAVEL-CALIF-DESERT (Undated) _ March is the time to catch the wildflower bloom in this vast desert state park in Southern California. By Lisa Fugard.  INSIDE THE SECTION  AIRLINE-FOOD (Undated) _ Eat up before boarding. What used to be lunch may now be a bag of pretzels. By Mark Bittman with Susan Catto.  TRAVEL-LOS-ANGELES (Los Angeles) _ The Venice and Santa Monica neighborhoods of Los Angeles have sand, surf, dining and shopping for the budget-minded traveler. By Daisann McLane.  TRAVEL-BRITAIN-MILLS (London) _ When Britons look back on the Industrial Revolution that spread their influence and their empire, they reserve a special place for the textile mill _ the clattering red brick institution that, along with railways and smokestacks, became the emblem of the nation's new and global economic power in the 19th century. By Alan Cowell.  REGULAR FEATURES  TRAVEL-BRIEFS (Undated) _ Lead item: Baseball fans unable to wait for opening day on March 31 can catch their favorite Major League teams at spring training camps in Florida and Arizona from Feb. 27 through March. Older fans can take part in one of Elderhostel's spring training programs in either state. In addition to taking in preseason games, participants have the opportunity to learn about various aspects of baseball from retired players and coaches, league executives, and sportswriters and broadcasters.  CYBER-TRAVEL (Undated) _ More single travelers are looking for companions on the Web. By Bob Tedeschi.  TRAVEL-Q&AMP;A (Undated) _ Travel questions and answers on paying bills while away from home, archaeological tours in Cyprus and freighter travel between Marseille and Barcelona. By Paul Freireich.  PRACTICAL-TRAVELER (Undated) _ Missed your connection? It could take you a while to get the next one. By Susan Stellin.  TRAVEL-BARGAINS (Undated) _ Special prices on rail travel come in the form of passes and tours, in North America and Europe. By Joseph Siano. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20020207.0103 type=story > <HEADLINE> FUTURE SHOCK IS CRUEL, BUT NOT SO TERRIBLY SHOCKING </HEADLINE> <DATELINE>  (BC-ROLLBALL-FILM-LADN) </DATELINE> <TEXT> "	"nyt_eng_200202.gz"

By David Edelstein.  With photos NYT46 and 47.  DANCE  DANCE-MONTREAL-BALLET (Montreal) _ When Gradimir Pankov arrived from Europe two years ago to be the artistic director of Les Grands Ballets Canadiens de Montreal, he found a company beset with problems. Morale was low among its 35 dancers. The company had endured a decade of cutbacks in an effort to eliminate a roughly $600,000 deficit. Audiences were shrinking despite a generally well-danced repertory of short works by internationally acclaimed choreographers. Then 60, Pankov, at an age when many are planning to retire, began immediately to transform the 45-year-old company. By Linde Howe-Beck.  THEATER  THEATER-BEA-ARTHUR (New York) _ ``I figured since I'm not going to retire, because I'm old'' _ Bea Arthur deliberately raised the volume on that last word _ ``that rather than wait around for the next great role, which may or may not ever come around again, I thought, well, we'll do this.'' Arthur, 78, is alluding to her show ``Bea Arthur on Broadway: Just Between Friends,''which began previews on Jan. 29 and opens Feb. 17 at the Booth Theater for a six-week run. By Anita Gates.  With photo NYT48.  MUSIC  ROCK-STARS-REDUX (Undated) _ Aging rock stars have long chased younger audiences, of course, often hiring producers half their age. But this kind of strategic repurposing _ the selling of postrelevance _ is something new. By John Leland. with photo NYT50.  OPERA-TITLES (Undated) _ Supertitles: salvation, or the end of opera as we used to know it? By Matthew Gurewitsch. With photo NYT49.  MUSIC-SAN-FRANCISCO (San Francisco) _ The San Francisco Symphony Orchestra has become increasingly exciting during Michael Tilson Thomas' seven-year tenure as music director. In a city that prizes mavericks, Thomas, at 57, has found a congenial home. By James R. Oestreich.  TELEVISION  TV-HUEY-NEWTON (Undated) _ Huey P. Newton spent much of his life trying to escape the constricting labels of ``hero'' and ``criminal'' affixed to him by both political friends and political enemies. So it's no surprise that ``A Huey P. Newton Story,'' which will be broadcast by PBS on Feb. 13 at 9 p.m. to commemorate the 60th anniversary of his birth (on Feb. 17), is a work that defies categorization. By Ron Jenkins.  PHOTOGRAPHY  PHOTOGRAPHY-CHIC-CLICKS (Boston) _ You might think ``but is it art?'' is as outdated a question as ``is the bride a virgin?,'' but don't be too sure. The Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston puts an up-to-the-minute slant on the first question in ``Chic Clicks: Creativity and Commerce in Contemporary Fashion Photography,'' on view through May 5. By Vicki Goldberg.  BESTSELLERS, CHILDREN'S-BESTSELLERS and PAPERBACKS moved on Monday, Feb. 4.  TRAVEL  (Coded `t')  (Editors: All clients receive all budgets, but only full-service clients receive all stories. Please check your level of service to determine which stories you will receive.)  (Coded `t')  COVER STORIES  TRAVEL-CALIF-DESERT (Undated) _ March is the time to catch the wildflower bloom in this vast desert state park in Southern California. By Lisa Fugard.  INSIDE THE SECTION  AIRLINE-FOOD (Undated) _ Eat up before boarding. What used to be lunch may now be a bag of pretzels. By Mark Bittman with Susan Catto.  TRAVEL-LOS-ANGELES (Los Angeles) _ The Venice and Santa Monica neighborhoods of Los Angeles have sand, surf, dining and shopping for the budget-minded traveler. By Daisann McLane. with photos NYT 29, 30 and 31.  TRAVEL-BRITAIN-MILLS (London) _ When Britons look back on the Industrial Revolution that spread their influence and their empire, they reserve a special place for the textile mill _ the clattering red brick institution that, along with railways and smokestacks, became the emblem of the nation's new and global economic power in the 19th century. By Alan Cowell.  REGULAR FEATURES  TRAVEL-BRIEFS (Undated) _ Lead item: Baseball fans unable to wait for opening day on March 31 can catch their favorite Major League teams at spring training camps in Florida and Arizona from Feb. 27 through March. Older fans can take part in one of Elderhostel's spring training programs in either state. In addition to taking in preseason games, participants have the opportunity to learn about various aspects of baseball from retired players and coaches, league executives, and sportswriters and broadcasters.  CYBER-TRAVEL (Undated) _ More single travelers are looking for companions on the Web. By Bob Tedeschi.  TRAVEL-Q&AMP;A (Undated) _ Travel questions and answers on paying bills while away from home, archaeological tours in Cyprus and freighter travel between Marseille and Barcelona. By Paul Freireich.  PRACTICAL-TRAVELER (Undated) _ Missed your connection? It could take you a while to get the next one. By Susan Stellin.  TRAVEL-BARGAINS (Undated) _ Special prices on rail travel come in the form of passes and tours, in North America and Europe. By Joseph Siano.  FINANCIAL  (Coded `f')  (Coded `f')  ON THE COVER  ENRON-REFORM (Undated) _ Nothing's perfect, including Corporate America, and Enron has revealed several areas that need policy fixes in areas, including the SEC; accounting practices; 401(k) and pension plans; banking regulation/Glass-Steagall issues; energy regulation; corporate governance; regulation/oversight of derivatives; restrictions on analysts; securities litigation. Various writers assess different aspects of the Enron debacle and need for reform. WITH GRAPHIC.  MARKET-WATCH (New York) _ Since Enron imploded, it has become clear that an investor did not have to own Enron shares to have been hurt by the scandal. Each revelation about Enron has fueled suspicions that Enron may not be an anomaly in Corporate America, that much greater risk resides in stocks today than investors had thought. So it is not surprising that stock prices have sunk. By Gretchen Morgensen. WITH GRAPHIC.  ADDITIONAL FEATURES  WHISTLEBLOWER-WOES (Undated) _ Sherron Watkins became an overnight icon of workplace integrity, celebrated as a corporate insider who had the courage to confront her boss about possible wrongdoing in high places. For warning Enron's chief executive last summer that the energy company could ``implode in a wave of accounting scandals,'' Watkins has been called a fearless upholder of business ethics. Other whistle-blowers should be so lucky. Though Watkins has been basking in the glow of the media's softest lights, experts say such hero treatment is far from the norm, and retaliation is likely. By Marci Alboher Nusbaum.  SIMULATED-MARKET-RESEARCH (South Pomfret, Vt.) _ MIT business students, participating in a mock stock exchange, received instant feedback from the wireless network that linked them. The students were not trading securities but the traits of various goods and services, like automobiles and ski resorts. The exercise was part of an effort to prove that simulated trading could answer that most basic of all product development questions: What do consumers want? By Barnaby J. Feder. WITH PHOTO NYT9.  AGGRESSIVE-JOBHUNTERS (Undated) _ Business specialists say the recession has created a new, onerous chore for corporate executives: coping with more intrusive, insistent pleas for work than ever before. ``All the rules of networking have flown out the window,'' said Andrea Nierenberg, a consultant. ``It's as if they've forgotten their manners.'' The most shocking aspect of the trend, experts say, is the experience level of the people who most often commit these networking faux pas: they are not scrappy, young executives, but senior-level ones who should know better. By Melinda Ligos.  CORPORATE-MUNI-BONDS (Undated) _ When Kmart filed for bankruptcy protection, more than $214 million in municipal bonds across the country went into default. The troubled bonds belong to a class of quirky securities issued by municipalities but dependent on corporations for their stream of payments. When corporate revenues falter, the bonds can decline in value. A.G. Edwards calls them ``corporate munis,'' and includes in the category industrial development bonds, like those issued for Kmart, as well as bonds to finance construction of projects for airlines. Many investors who thought they were holding safe, steady municipal bonds have had some unpleasant surprises. By Abby Schultz. WITH GRAPHIC.  DAYTRADER-BOOK-REVIEW (London) _ Thrillers blending business dealings and derring-do form a genre in their own right, and ``The Day Trader,'' by Stephen Frey, fits admirably into this high-octane niche. It is a tale of market-scams and murder with characters ranging from traders shorting stocks to table-dancers dealing in quite different commodities. By Alan Cowell.  INVESTING  INVEST-COMMODITIES (Undated) _ Stocks have recovered moderately well since the post-Sept. 11 sell-off, but commodities have not. That may be an opportunity for adventurous investors, for two reasons. One is that if the economy is set for a rebound, a rally could be in store because commodity prices are very low. The other is that commodities tend, over time, to move in the opposite direction of stocks, so they are a good way to bring diversification to a portfolio. By Jonathan Fuerbringer. WITH GRAPHIC.  INVEST-EUROPE (Undated) _ To stock investors, the United States has been a more rewarding place than Europe for several years. Since the market lows in September, however, Europe has begun to close the gap, and there is a consensus among market strategists in Europe and on Wall Street that European stocks will benefit more than domestic ones if the U.S. economy rebounds out of recession. By Conrad de Aenlle. WITH GRAPHIC.  INVEST-INSIGHT-DEFENSE (Undated) _ Howard A. Rubel, aerospace and defense analyst at Goldman Sachs, is interviewed about the industry and which companies are best positioned to benefit from President Bush's proposed increase in military spending. By Robert D. Hershey Jr.  INVEST-LIBERTY-ACORN (Undated) _ John H. Park, who runs the $100 million Liberty Acorn Twenty fund, isn't overly concerned about labels like growth and value. ``We'll buy whatever's out of favor,'' Parks said from his office in Chicago. ``We tend to shift between growth and value stocks depending on where they are in the cycle.'' Despite high fees, the fund has soundly beaten its peer group. By Carole Gould. WITH GRAPHIC.  COLUMNS  ECON-COLUMN (Undated) _ With surpluses giving way to deficits and the prospects evaporating for reducing the national debt, the debate over President Bush's budget will focus new attention on a fundamental difference between the two parties. Do budget deficits and rising debt inherently harm the economy by pushing up long-term interest rates? Or are deficits, and a reasonable level of debt, acceptable prices to pay for taking steps like cutting taxes that will help the economy in the long run? By Richard W. Stevenson. WITH GRAPHIC.  AUTOS  ABOUTCARS-INTERNET (Undated) _ A pesky reality that car-selling sites have struggled with since their inception: buyers use the Internet for research, but that the moment of truth tends to occur at their local dealers. By Catherine Greenman. WITH GRAPHIC.  AUTO-SHOW (Undated) _ Chicago's auto show is no longer the nation's pre-eminent industry gathering _ Detroit gets the spotlight now _ but the domestic manufacturers made themselves at home in the Windy City during previews last week.  STYLE  (Coded `L')  BROOKLYN-DATING (New York) _ For decades Brooklynites have put on their slinky best and commuted to Manhattan to visit clubs in the hope of meeting Mr. or Ms. Right. Now, in a reversal of the old bridge-and-tunnel migration, young Manhattanites discouraged by the sky-high expectations of the opposite sex in their home borough are dressing down, in faded jeans and vintage leather, and heading to bars and loft parties in Brooklyn. There, where lower rents have encouraged an influx of arty postcollegiates, dating success doesn't require a big bankroll or blinding beauty. Many young women in Manhattan have their own set of complaints about the warped expectations of men from their borough who think life is a hip-hop video with bikini-wearing girls and luxury cars. By Julia Chaplin.  WTC-DEPARTMENT-STORE (New York) _ To thousands of New Yorkers and visitors from abroad, Century 21, the discount department store near the World Trade Center, was retailing's holy of holies. Some still wax effusive about the store, calling it a shrine, a temple of style and a mecca. Their descriptions attest to a cultish devotion that it inspires even now, some five months after the Sept. 11 attacks forced it to close. Kim France, a magazine editor, observed: ``Once you had been there, there was never any going back to conventional shopping. It was the gold standard of stores like that.'' The eulogy is premature. Century 21 stands intact, cleared of dust and other debris, and ready to reopen this month. By Ruth La Ferla.  FASHION-FAUXPAS (New York) _ As Fashion Week gets under way, the tents will once again be packed with some of the world's most coolly chic women, joined skinny hip to hip before the catwalks. The famous editors and important retailers will look, to the outside world, impossibly well put together, but every one of them has had her moments of fashion shame and has spent as many anxious minutes throwing on different outfits in the morning as the average woman. Fashion faux pas: every woman has committed them. By Kate Betts.  FASHION-GHESQUIERE (New York) _ Nicolas Ghesquiere, the designer of Balenciaga, might just be fashion's most ambiguous star. That he is a star in that small world mainly comprised of editors and photographers is undisputed. His pencil-slim pants and eccentrically embellished tops, his lariat handbags and 1980s-style blouson jackets have been copied everywhere. And already there are waiting lists at stores for his springtime cargo pants, now done in a pastel mix of silk and corduroy and costing $1,000. He is showin in New York for the first time. By Cathy Horyn.  WITH PHOTO NYT10.  (Editors: All clients receive all budgets, but only full-service clients receive all stories. "107070"	"he"	"thought"	" (Miles Benson can be contacted at miles.benson(at)newhouse.com) </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20020220.0124 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-NYT-WORLD-BUDGET) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Editors at publications outside the United States may find the following stories from the New York Times News Service for Thursday, Feb. 21, of particular interest:  INTERNATIONAL  (Will move in `i' news category)  EGYPT-TRAIN-FIRE (Ayyat, Egypt) _ A blazing train jammed with holiday travelers sped through the Egyptian night early Wednesday, killing more than 370 passengers and injuring dozens more as flames engulfed car after car and some travelers leapt to their deaths on the tracks. By Neil MacFarquhar.  (An early version of this story will move by 3 p.m. EST.)  TERROR-ITALY (Rome) _ The Italian police said they had arrested four Moroccans in possession of large quantities of the deadly poison cyanide and maps of Rome highlighting the U.S. Embassy and the city's water supply. The police said they are probing possible links to Osama bin Laden. By Melinda Henneberger.  TERROR-MEDIA (Washington) _ The Defense Department official in charge of the new Office of Strategic Influence defends its mission, saying that no Pentagon officials will be allowed to lie to the public or the press. But he leaves open the possibility that private firms could be contracted to spread disinformation overseas and says no one should be ``naive'' about the military's need to mislead the enemy during times of war, which includes the present. By James Dao.  MIDEAST (Dateline to come) _ Israel launched fierce reprisal attacks with warplanes, warships and helicopter gunships in pre-dawn raids on Wednesday, killing at least 15 Palestinians. The assaults hit Palestinian security installations across the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Officials in a village in the southern Gaza Strip said that the Israelis had begun house-to-house searches on Wednesday. By James Bennet.  ISRAEL-JEWISH-IDENTITY (Jerusalem) _ In a landmark decision on the question of who is a Jew, the Israeli Supreme Court ruled that people who have undergone Conservative and Reform conversions to Judaism should be listed as Jews in the Israeli population registry. Until now only Orthodox conversions were recognized for registration purposes. The ruling was another step toward official recognition of the Conservative and Reform movements in Israel, and further chipped away at the influence of the Orthodox rabbinate here. By Joel Greenberg.  BUSH-CHINA (Beijing) _ President Bush arrived in China, where he was scheduled to meet Thursday with the Chinese leader, Jiang Zemin. By Elisabeth Bumiller.  MILOSEVIC-WARCRIMES (The Hague, Netherlands) _ Slobodan Milosevic challenged prosecutors to provide solid evidence that he had ordered Serb atrocities against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo in 1999. By Ian Fisher.  WORLD-BRIEFS (Undated) _ World news in brief.  UNITED STATES _ General  (Will move in `a' category or as noted)  AMERICAN587-CRASH-REPORT (Washington) _ The Federal Aviation Administration is scheduled on Wednesday to release a tape of transmissions between the tower at JFK airport and American Flight 587, which crashed shortly after takeoff last year. By Matthew L. Wald.  BUSINESS  (Will move in ``f'' news category)  PHILIPPINES-STOCKS (Manila, Philippines) _ The Manila Stock Exchange, the hottest in the world at the moment, is trying to raise its profile for institutional investors by extending trading hours to something like a full day (in two sessions). By Wayne Arnold.  ENRON (Dateline to come) _ Developments in the collapse of Enron and the investigations. (Byline to come)  TV-NETWORKS (Undated) _ The broadcast network business, once believed to be an endangered species, will likely get a big boost from the change in broadcast rules. With the ability to add stations, the networks should significantly increase profits and get increased leverage in the syndication market and over affiliates. By Bill Carter.  ALLIED-IRISH (Dateline to come) _ Allied Irish Bank says that the unauthorized currency trading at its U.S. subsidiary went on for five years. Two weeks ago, the bank said the trading went on for a year. Other developments. (Staff byline to come)  DAIMLERCHRYSLER-OUTLOOK (Detroit) _ DaimlerChrysler says that its effort to turn around Chrysler is ahead of schedule despite recent weakness in sales and that the parent company will return to profitability this year. DaimlerChrysler reports a loss of $34 million for the fourth quarter. By Danny Hakim.  WORLD-BIZ-BRIEFS (Undated) _ Short items on business news from around the world.  ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS  (Will move in ``e'' news category or as indicated)  ALGERIAN-ARMY-WRITER (Paris) _ As an Algerian army officer, Mohamed Moulessehoul was required to present his manuscripts for approval by military censors. To circumvent this rule, he adopted a woman's pseudonym. So it was as Yasmina Khadra that he became known in Algeria and Western Europe. It was only a year ago, after retiring from the army and moving to the South of France, that Moulessehoul revealed his true identity. Now, he thought, he could at last savor the life of a writer. But if Moulessehoul believed that his double life was over, he was wrong. By Alan Riding.  ARTIST-OFILI-ELEPHANTS (New York) _ On Chris Ofili, the British artist of Nigerian descent who often uses elephant dung in his works. By Carol Vogel.  HELL-BOOK-REVIEW (Undated) _ ``Hell to Pay,'' by George Pelecanos, reviewed by Janet Maslin.  JAPAN-TEMPLE-CARVER (Westminster West, Vt.)_ Iwao Nakajima traveled to a remote mountainside workshop here to teach carpenters the mysterious habits of the master temple carpenter _ known as a toryo. A toryo specializes in the elaborate carving and joining of temples, tea houses, homes and furniture, largely without nails or glue. By Bradford McKee.  (Will move in ``l'' category)  SURREALISM-FAN (New York) _ Robert Couturier, the French architect and decorator, could be the last of the Surrealists at home: the end of an eccentric line that began in the 17th and 18th centuries with the rich folly of kings' taste and lastly decorated the dreams of Surrealist art in the 20th century. By William L. Hamilton.  (Will move in ``l'' category)  OLYMPIC-VILLAGE (Salt Lake City) _ The fortress of war here has been overrun by envoys of peace. What the U.S. military dubbed Fort Douglas after the Civil War has been reborn as the Olympic Village. For all the high-minded talk of the village bringing the world together, it is fundamentally a place for athletes to rest between practices, hash out strategy with coaches and meet their all-important dietary needs. By Edward Wong.  (Will move in ``l'' category)  SPORTS  (Will move in ``s'' category)  OLY-SLALOM-WOMEN (Salt Lake City) _ The women's slalom competition. By Bill Pennington.  OLY-SKELETON (Salt Lake City) _ The return of skeleton, head-first sliding for men and women. By Edward Wong.  OLY-HKN-MEN (Salt Lake City) _ The men's quarterfinals. By Joe Lapointe. "107097"	"he"	"thought"	" Story Filed By Cox Newspapers </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20020220.0212 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (BC-ENTERTAINMENT-NYT-BUDGET) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Entertainment and culture stories from The New York Times News Service for Thursday, Feb. 21.  ARTIST-OFILI-ELEPHANTS (New York) _ Chris Ofili, the British artist of Nigerian descent who often uses elephant dung in his works, will auction one of his pieces here to benefit the Zoological Society of London. It was an Ofili painting of the Virgin Mary that enraged New York's former mayor, Rudy Giuliani, when it appeared in the ``Sensation'' show at the Brooklyn Museum two years ago. By Carol Vogel.  ALGERIAN-ARMY-WRITER (Paris) _ As an Algerian army officer, Mohamed Moulessehoul was required to present his manuscripts for approval by military censors. To circumvent this rule, he adopted a woman's pseudonym. So it was as Yasmina Khadra that he became known in Algeria and Western Europe. It was only a year ago, after retiring from the army and moving to the South of France, that Moulessehoul revealed his true identity. Now, he thought, he could at last savor the life of a writer. But if Moulessehoul believed that his double life was over, he was wrong. By Alan Riding.  HELL-BOOK-REVIEW (Undated) _ ``Hell to Pay,'' by George Pelecanos, reviewed by Janet Maslin.  For information and repeats call the News Service at (888) 346-9867 or (212) 556-1927. And be sure to look for other entertainment stories from our partners: The Boston Globe, Cox News Service, Hearst Newspapers, The Houston Chronicle, The Arizona Republic, Kansas City Star, Fort Worth Star-Telegram, Los Angeles Daily News, San Francisco Chronicle and Seattle Post-Intelligencer. For questions about stories, please call Jean Conley at the Boston Globe, 617-929-2597. For individual purchase of budgeted graphics or photos please call 212-556-4204 or 888-603-1036.  All stories will bear the BOS designator.  INTERNATIONAL (i)  ATTACK-PEARL (Islamabad) _ Islamic militants are using the kidnapping of Daniel Pearl as a rallying point for opposition to Pervez Musharraf, despised by the radicals for supporting the US campaign against terrorism. By Colin Nickerson. 1250 words.  ATTACK-AFGHAN (Kabul) _ Contradicting interim President Hamid Karzai, Foreign Minister Abdullah Abdullah says that enraged pilgrims were partly responsible for the brutal slaying of cabinet minister Abdul Rahman last week on the tarmac at the Kabul Airport. By Marcella Bombardieri. 900 words.  MIDEAST-JEW (Jerusalem) _ The Israeli Supreme Court, wading into the long-simmering debate over who is a Jew, yesterday issued a hotly-contested ruling declaring that the state must recognize as Jews people converted by Reform and Conservative rabbis. By Charles Radin and Michael Paulson. 1300 words.  MIDEAST-STRATEGY (Jerusalem) _ Without elaborating, Sharon declares after a meeting of Israel's security Cabinet that he would embark on a ``different course of action'' against the Palestinians. Other news of the day. By Charles Radin. 900 words.  CHINA-BUSH (Beijing) _ President Bush arrives in Beijing Thursday for the culmination of his three-country Asian tour, seeking cooperation in the war on terrorism from a country that just a year ago was branded by the Bush administration the biggest looming threat. By Indira Lakshmanan and Anne Kornblut. dvlpg.  WASHINGTON (w)  SCOTUS-VOUCHER (Washington) - A thin majority appears to be forming on the Supreme Court to uphold the constitutionality of taxpayer-financed school vouchers, one of the most controversial experiments in education. By Lyle Denniston. 900 words.  SCOTUS-DEATH (Wasington) - The court indicates it has changed its view since 1989 and appears likely to endorse a ban on the death penalty for the mentally retarded. The signals came in arguments in a Virginia case. By Lyle Denniston. 700 words.  NATIONAL (a)  HARVARD-AP (Undated) _ The Harvard University faculty has decided to stop giving college credit to students who score a 4 on high school Advanced Placement exams, a policy change that raises questions about the academic value and meaning of a test taken by nearly a million high school students last year. The new Harvard policy takes effect in fall 2003. By David Abel. dvlpg.  OLY-DIVERSITY (Salt Lake City) _ On front pages of newspapers and television stations across the world Tuesday beamed the faces of Vonetta Flowers, Michelle Kwan and Derek Parra, members of minority groups not traditionally associated with The Olympic Winter Games. That non-white athletes are twirling, pushing and sprinting America to greater athletic heights this year is no coincidence. By Tatsha Robertson.  SPORTS (s)  OLY-SKELETON-US (Salt Lake City) _ Third-generation Olympian Jim Shea wins gold in skeleton. By Bob Ryan.  OLY-RYAN-COLUMN (Salt Lake City) _ Commentary on women's skeleton. By Bob Ryan.  OLY-SPEEDSKA-WOMEN (Salt Lake City) _ Christine Witty and Jennifer Rodriguez compete in the 1,500-meter event. By Michael Holley.  OLY-SLALOM-BODE (Salt Lake City) _ Previewing the men's giant slalom and Bode Miller's gold medal hopes. By Tony Chamberlain.  OLY-SKATE-WOMEN (Salt Lake City) - Previewing the women's long program. Burris.  OLY-HOCKEY-WOMEN (Salt Lake City) - Previewing the US-Canada gold medal ice hockey game. Burris.  BBA-REDSOX (Fort Myers, Fla.) _ Red Sox gather for Joe Kerrigan's first meeting of spring training. Manny Ramirez and Rickey Henderson were missing. By Bob Hohler.  MACMULLAN-COLUMN _ Joe Thornton is sitting home in Canada while his country's team needs him at the Olympics. By Jackie MacMullan.  The Boston Globe </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20020220.0254 type=advis > <DATELINE>  (AM-ADD-NYT-BUDGET) </DATELINE> <TEXT> Add New York Times News Service budget for papers of THURSDAY, Feb. 21.  HOME (``l'' code)  Adding:  SURREALISM-FAN (New York) _ Robert Couturier, the French architect and decorator, could be the last of the Surrealists at home: the end of an eccentric line that began in the 17th and 18th centuries with the rich folly of kings' taste and lastly decorated the dreams of Surrealist art in the 20th century. By William L. Hamilton.  SHOPPING-MALL-LIVING (San Jose, Calif.) _ Christine Franz, 35, a software consultant who looks like Meg Ryan, was exactly what developers had in mind when they started Santana Row, a Silicon Valley crest in the latest, most ambitious wave of shopping malls. Franz, demographic perfection, stared out through fashionable sunglasses at the muddy Main Street of the 21-acre site, now concrete and steel. By August, when the $475 million ``lifestyle village'' is scheduled to open, Santana Row's 17 city blocks will boast 100 specialty shops, including Gucci, Tourneau and Burberry. But shopping is only the start. Santana Row will also be home to the people who live above the stores in 1,200 studios, lofts, town houses and villas. By William L. Hamilton.  JAPAN-TEMPLE-CARVER (Westminster West, Vt.) _ Iwao Nakajima traveled to a remote mountainside workshop here to teach carpenters the mysterious habits of the master temple carpenter _ known as a toryo. A toryo specializes in the elaborate carving and joining of temples, tea houses, homes and furniture, largely without nails or glue. Two shows about Japanese teahouses _ traditional and modern _ will open in New York next month, at the Japan Society and at the Asia Society. The pared-down look of Japanese temples vastly influenced designers like Greene &AMP; Greene, Charles Rennie Mackintosh and Frank Lloyd Wright. By Bradford McKee.  OLYMPIC-VILLAGE (Salt Lake City) _ The fortress of war here has been overrun by envoys of peace. What the U.S. military dubbed Fort Douglas after the Civil War has been reborn as the Olympic Village. For all the high-minded talk of the village bringing the world together, it is fundamentally a place for athletes to rest between practices, hash out strategy with coaches and meet their all-important dietary needs. By Edward Wong.  GARDEN-Q&AMP;A (Undated) _ Garden questions answered. By Dora Galitzki.  CIRCUITS (``a'' code)  CIR-CRIME-TIPS (Undated) _ Investigators are increasingly setting up Web sites for tips on wrongdoing _ from terrorism to the Enron debacle _ and report they are getting 10 times the traffic of phone tips. Looking at whether there is quality to go along with the quantity of information. By Lisa Guernsey.  CIR-ROBOTIC-TOY (Undated) _ On Mark Tilden, the creator of a robotic toy, BIO Bugs, and the joys and frustrations of being an analog guy in a world that worships digital. By Barnaby J. Feder.  CIR-CIRCUITS-COLUMN (Undated) _ The weekly column: Voice-dialing systems for the home. By David Pogue.  CIR-GEEK-NOTES (Undated) _ Techno news and notes.  CIR-EBOOKS (Undated) _ E-books find an audience in libraries. By Lisa Guernsey.  CIR-ONLINE-SHOPPING (Undated) _ The weekly feature: Finding buttons online. By Michelle Slatalla.  CIR-Q&AMP;A (Undated) _ Techno questions answered: The steps involved in obtaining a Web site domain; connecting a PC to an Apple AirPort station. By J.D. Biersdorfer.  CIR-VIRTUAL-PETS (Undated) _ Neopets.com, a sort of Sim City for virtual pets, has become an online rage among teenagers. By Marc Weingarten.  CIR-GAME-THEORY (Undated) _ The weekly column: Pickman and Munch's Oddessey. By Charles Herold.  CIR-COMPUTER-BACKUP (Undated) _ Backing up a computer ranks somewhere between cleaning the oven and checking the batteries in the smoke detector on most people's long-avoided to-do lists. They are all good ideas but, for some reason, you never follow through on any of them. By Susan Stellin.  CIR-SKI-TECH (Undated) _ On self-braking skis. By Ian Austen.  CULTURE AND ENTERTAINMENT (``e'' code)  ARTIST-OFILI-ELEPHANTS (New York) _ Chris Ofili, the British artist of Nigerian descent who often uses elephant dung in his works, will auction one of his pieces here to benefit the Zoological Society of London. It was an Ofili painting of the Virgin Mary that enraged New York's former mayor, Rudy Giuliani, when it appeared in the ``Sensation'' show at the Brooklyn Museum two years ago. By Carol Vogel.  ALGERIAN-ARMY-WRITER (Paris) _ As an Algerian army officer, Mohamed Moulessehoul was required to present his manuscripts for approval by military censors. To circumvent this rule, he adopted a woman's pseudonym. So it was as Yasmina Khadra that he became known in Algeria and Western Europe. It was only a year ago, after retiring from the army and moving to the South of France, that Moulessehoul revealed his true identity. Now, he thought, he could at last savor the life of a writer. But if Moulessehoul believed that his double life was over, he was wrong. By Alan Riding.  HELL-BOOK-REVIEW (Undated) _ ``Hell to Pay,'' by George Pelecanos, reviewed by Janet Maslin.  SPORTS (``s'' code)  OLY-SLALOM-WOMEN (Salt Lake City) _ The women's slalom competition. By Bill Pennington.  OLY-SKELETON (Salt Lake City) _ The return of skeleton, head-first sliding for men and women. By Edward Wong.  OLY-FIG-WOMEN (Salt Lake City) _ Folo on the women's short program, in which Kwan finished first, Slutskaya was second, Cohen was third and Hughes was fourth. By Selena Roberts.  With  OLY-FIG-WOMEN-FANS (Philadelphia) _ A look of how some American fans watching TV together judged Tuesday night's short program in women's figure skating, compared with the official nine judges. By Jere Longman.  OLY-HKN-MEN (Salt Lake City) _ The men's quarterfinals. By Joe Lapointe.  OLY-BIATHLON (Soldier Hollow, Utah) _ Nowary's Ole Einar Bjoerndahlen goes for his fourth biathlon gold medal, this one in a relay. By Charlie LeDuff.  OLY-SPEED-SKATING-WOMEN (Kearns, Utah) _ The women's 1,500-meter race. By Liz Robbins.  QUESTIONS OR RERUNS: (888) 346-9867 or (212) 556-1927:  The day supervisor is Gary E. The PMs news desk, 212-556-1927, opens at 7 a.m. Eastern Time. To get story repeats before this hour call 212-621-1595 for reruns on AP DataFeatures or 214-980-8305 or 8367 for repeats on UPI DataNews.  NYT News Service  INTERNATIONAL _ (Moved in ``i'' category)  AFGHAN-STABILITY (Washington) _ The Bush administration weighs its policy options in Afghanistan as Hamid Karzai, the leader of the transitional government, works to maintain order in a nation that is rife with weapons, self-appointed warlords and rival tribes. By Michael R. Gordon.  TERROR-MEDIA (Washington) _ The Defense Department official in charge of the new Office of Strategic Influence defends its mission, saying that no Pentagon officials will be allowed to lie to the public or the press. But he leaves open the possibility that private firms could be contracted to spread disinformation overseas and says no one should be ``naive'' about the military's need to mislead the enemy during times of war, which includes the present. By James Dao.  NATIONAL _ GENERAL (Moved in ``a'' category)  NY-DEBT (Albany, N.Y.) _ New Yorkers say their region stands alone in all sorts of ways, but few citizens of this sprawling city and state know it is the undisputed leader in a less exalted arena: government debt. By Richard Perez-Pena and James C. McKinley Jr.  SCI-VACCINE-RISK (Washington) _ An Institute of Medicine report says that while there is no evidence that vaccines are dangerous to children, at least 25 percent of parents think their kids are getting too many vaccines and they may be harmful. The Institute calls for a panel to investigate parents perceptions on this issue. By Sheryl Gay Stolberg.  SPACE-STATION-GLENN (Washington) _ Forty years after his historic orbit round the Earth, John Glenn has a chat with the astronauts on the space station. By Warren E. Leary.  BUSINESS DAY _ (Moved in ``f'' category)  ENRON-INSURE (Undated) _ Some of Enron's many woes are insurance-related. By Jonathan D. Glater and Michael Brick.  ENRON-MARKETPLACE _ Executives at large commercial banks are telling analysts and investors to anticipate more detailed disclosures in their year-end filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. It is all part of the Enron fallout. By Riva D. Atlas.  ENRON-MARKETPLACE (Undated) _ The daily column: Investors are paying extra attention to the fine print in banks' annual reports, bracing themselves for a long list of footnotes and other detailed explanations of off-balance sheet financings. With some short sellers targeting companies whose finances they find opaque, executives at many companies are promising analysts and investors that their year-end filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, anticipated within the next few weeks, will be more detailed than in the past. By Riva D. Atlas.  TV-NETWORKS-ASSESS (Undated) _ The broadcast network business, once believed to be an endangered species, will likely get a big boost from the change in broadcast rules. With the ability to add stations, the networks should significantly increase profits and get increased leverage in the syndication market and over affiliates. By Bill Carter.  PENSION-ECONSCENE (Undated) _ The weekly Economic Scene column on some stunning facts: Two-thirds of American households did not increase their retirement wealth at all since 1983 or experienced a drop in the value of their pensions. By Jeffrey Madrick.  PHILIPPINES-STOCKS (Manila, Philippines) _ The Manila Stock Exchange, the hottest in the world at the moment, is trying to raise its profile for institutional investors by extending trading hours to something like a full day (in two sessions, as elsewhere in Asia). A look at how it went the first day, why the brokerage business looks so good here now and what forces are driving the still-small market. By Wayne Arnold.  LIQUOR-AD-COLUMN (Undated) _ Two major imported brands of distilled spirits are emerging with campaigns from new agencies intended to help them keep up in the highly competitive ``white goods'' category of the American liquor market. By Stuart Elliott.  COMMENTARY (Moved in ``k'' category)  Op-Ed column by William Safire.  Bob Herbert is on vacation.  SPORTS (Moved in ``s'' category)  OLY-FIG-WOMEN-FANS (Philadelphia) _ A look of how some American fans watching TV together judged Tuesday night's short program in women's figure skating, compared with the official nine judges. By Jere Longman. There was only one quibble, really. With me being an ex-soccer player, I thought, oh, that's a bit near the mark.
