"111703"	"I"	"thought"	" BOOKS-BLACK _ Merle Black became a political scientist sometime in elementary school. It happened this way: On an election night in the early '50s, Black idled behind a guy who ran the voting precinct in Hopkins County, Texas, and watched him steal the election. The race was for a local judge's seat. The precinct chief read each vote aloud, with Black's mother and several other women seated at a table nearby, recording the count. One candidate was Baptist. The other was Methodist. So was the precinct chief. ``So I'm watching when he came to one of the votes for the Baptist candidate and read it as a Methodist vote,'' Black remembers. ``The first time, I thought, `Hmm. Maybe I didn't see that right.' But after he did it several times, it finally dawned on me: This is what they call cheating. (Jubera, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED. </P> "	"nyt_eng_200204.gz"

We love the fantasy that it is, but it's not. My walls fall down; my kids leave garbage on the table. The turning point for me was when I couldn't take care of my garden anymore. "114944"	"I"	"thought"	" The story begins and ends with her carrying out her husband's dying wishes. ``On a cold January morning before dawn, in the holy village of Rishikesh in northern India, I scattered Charles Mingus's ashes in the Ganges as he had asked me to do, immersing myself with them in the freezing river according to Hindu custom, certain that the raw air beneath the dark range of Himalayas was made for the life of the spirit and for reincarnation, as he believed,'' she begins. ``I walked to my one-room house on the Ganges, shivering and dripping water along the sand, and . . . imagined that one day I would nail a small sign above the entrance with his name and dates and the title of one of his tunes, `Tonight at Noon.' That was musician talk for time displacements on the gig, the topsy-turvy hours of work, an acknowledgment of a reversal in the order of things. Perhaps, I thought, it was the new life he had already imagined.'' </P> "	"nyt_eng_200205.gz"

Miang som oo turned out to be a combination of crab and pomelo (the citrus ancestor of grapefruit), with roasted coconut and caramel dressing. It showed, I thought, how many different tastes we describe as sweet. A salad of squid, grilled pork and young ginger was equally unconventional _ savagely hot and sour. Hoi shenn pat khaa orn was more familiar, gentler and highly aromatic, a stir-fry of scallops with Thai basil. NEW YORK _  Dear Diary:  I'm a recreation therapist at a hospital in Manhattan. An acquaintance brought me a large spray of rue from his back yard. I put it in a vase and admired it from time to time.  One day I noticed a black and yellow caterpillar on a stem. Then there was another one.  I looked them up in an insect book and discovered they were black swallowtail butterflies. The book said they ate parsley, but these guys looked very happy eating the bitter rue.  After a week or two, one morning I came in to see a large, greenish splat next to the vase and one missing caterpillar.  A few days later, another splat. I thought maybe the cumulative effect of the bitterness of the herb had done them in. I threw out the much-chewed-on bouquet.  A week, two weeks went by. I was working on a Sunday when I noticed movement by the window. I was dumbstruck by what I saw _ two 5-inch-wingspan, velvety black swallowtails in my office!  I just stared at them for several minutes and then decided they needed to be set free. I captured one, and before I released it I showed it to the security guard.  When I returned, I thought, ``Take a picture!'' I took a photograph of the other one among my windowsill treasures before I set it free, too. I found one empty chrysalis on the hidden side of a brown mailing tube _ I wonder where the other one is.  _ LINN SCHLAIFER  Overheard by Louise Heikes: A young woman on her cell phone, near the Great Lawn in Central Park at the start of a New York Philharmonic concert, obviously trying to find a friend: ``I'm standing near a tree!''  Dear Diary:  I mentor an 11-year-old girl through the 52nd Street Project, which matches children of Hell's Kitchen with professional actors. Like me, she loves to read, so I decided to take her on a tour of the libraries in Manhattan.  She had never been to the main public library on Fifth Avenue, so one day we went. I showed her the renovated reading room, the computerized catalogs and all the other wonderful things the library has to offer. I then topped it off by introducing her to Patience and Fortitude, the two stone lions on guard in front of the building.  I thought she was unimpressed with all of it, until one night when I invited her to my home for dinner. She told the other guest about our trip to the various libraries and especially the one to the main library. ``We saw the reading room,'' she said, ``and then we saw the two lions, Patience and Attitude.''  _ KIM SYKES  Dear Diary:  In the early '60s, I worked in Florida and took a few business trips to New York. One October, I was in the subway in my normal Florida get-up: a suntan and a light shirt. An elderly woman across the aisle quizzed me on why I was not wearing a coat, since it was rather cold.  I tried to explain Florida weather, but she would have none of it. Out of the side of her mouth, looking at me but directing her comment to the man next to her, she said, ``Harry, give the kid your coat.''  Harry was flabbergasted and protested that he needed his coat. She paid no attention and commanded, ``Harry, give the kid your coat; he needs it in this weather.''  As Harry started to struggle out of his coat, the subway stopped and I said, ``This is my stop, my hotel is just upstairs, and there's a store and I'll buy a coat.'' This seemed to satisfy the woman.  As I went out, Harry whispered, ``Thanks a lot, kid.''  _ LEO COLLINS  Dear Diary:  Observing children of the millennium always brings a smile to me.  While on the corner of Fifth Avenue and 15th Street, I saw a toddler (probably about 18 months old) in her stroller. Her executive-type mother was wheeling her toward the curb, where I was waiting for the light to change.  Without any sign from the pretty mother, the child raised her right hand and very loudly said, ``Taxi!''  _ GABRIELLA BUCCIERI  I FORGOT MY UMBRELLA!  I know it's raining out  Because the elevator smells like  Wet messenger.  _ JEFF MILES  Dear Diary:  After bringing in our luggage for a stay at my cousin's 20th-floor apartment in the East Village while he was away on vacation, my husband and I got locked in. I had casually turned the knob on the bottom lock, then couldn't open it. Mild panic set in while we struggled with the lock, imagining our week's stay shut in against our will. Pliers found in a drawer, used to force the inside knob, only made things worse.  Then my clever husband remembered Houdini and his motto of success: Locks are made to keep you out, not in. Screwdriver, please! Off came the lock plate and knob, and after a few careful wiggles of the interior mechanism we were free. Later, as my husband walked into a nearby hardware store, lock cylinder in hand, the clerk handed him a new lock from the shelf. Neither man uttered a word. Must happen all the time.  _ KATIE HAMMER  Dear Diary:  On my way home from work in the financial district, I stopped to buy a cantaloupe and a honeydew. I don't normally shop for these items downtown, because they're too heavy and bulky to take on the subway. But being in the mood for fruit salad, I bought them.  When I arrived at my train station at 96th Street, I lifted the bag and the honeydew rolled out. I watched in horror as it rolled all the way down the car (everyone laughed hysterically). As I made my way through the car, I noticed that the honeydew had stopped rolling under the feet of a man. As I approached him, he reached down, picked up the honeydew, put it into my bag and said, ``I prefer watermelon.''  _ VIVIAN ROSENBERG </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20020922.0184 type=story > <HEADLINE> IN NEW JERSEY, SOME DRY TOWNS START TO THINK ABOUT GOING WET </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> WILLINGBORO, N.J. These business stories for release Wednesday, October 9, 2002, are moving today to clients of the New York Times News Service.  Stories are moving in the financial (f) category. Stories also moving in lifestyle will be marked with (f, l).  Separate budgets move daily with spot news, features, sports and commentary.  If you have questions or need a resend, please call CoxNet, the Cox News Service, at 404-526-5456.  PORTS -- SAN DIEGO -- Developments in the labor dispute at West Coast ports. (Keefe, Cox News Service).  EDs: Moving in (a) national and (f) financial categories.  LAYOFFS-SURVIVORS -- ATLANTA -- By now, everyone is well acquainted with the plight of the unemployed, those who've had the misfortune of drawing the short straw on their employers' reorganization or layoff lists. But little is ever said about the layoff survivors, those left behind to do the work that piles up with each monthly unemployment report. (Joyner, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 35.  HARTSFIELD-DIRT -- ATLANTA -- Millions of tons of red Georgia clay and rock are being carried to Hartsfield International Airport to form the base for the airport's fifth runway, the most expensive runway ever built in the U. S. Starting next month, a 5-1/2 mile-long conveyer belt will begin operating almost around the clock -- snaking over streams and roadways, up and down hills and even crossing an interstate highway. Tagami, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 35. WITH PHOTOS.  LATAM-BELLSOUTH -- BUENOS AIRES, ARGENTINA _ BellSouth is losing millions in South America, but it can't afford to get out. (Brister, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 25.  DOWDOW -- ATLANTA -- President Bush gave the market a modest boost _ not because of his speech about Iraq but because of his intervention in the West Coast port lockout. The stocks of retailers and others directely affected by the shipping shutdown rallied, pushing market averages higher for the first time in days. But nothing has changed fundamentally, including Wall Street's anxiety over war prospects with Iraq. Earnings warnings also abound to keep a lid on enthusiasm. (Atlanta Journal-Constitution)  COXNET BUDGET INFORMATION FOR SUBSCRIBERS OF THE NYT NEWS SERVICE  Spot news budgets move daily at 2 p.m. and 6 p.m. Eastern. Additionally, separate features and commentary budgets move at 10 a.m., and sports and business budgets at 6 p.m. Additional updates are possible if news developments warrant.  All times are Eastern unless otherwise noted. If stories will move after 9:30 p.m., an ETA will be given. LIFESTYLE  GETAWAY-DC -- WASHINGTON, D.C. -- A trip through Washington, D.C.'s new International Spy Museum. It's a slick, bizarre place, giving equal weight to real-life espionage and fabricated pop-culture spy opiates. Where else can you visually inspect cigarette packs from the 1950s that hold tiny assassination weapons and then moments later peruse ``secret print putty'' from TV's hokey ``The Man From U.N.C.L.E.''? (BLongino, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 30. WITH PHOTOS.  WINE-FALL -- GRAND JUNCTION, Colo. -- Fall is when many winemakers start releasing their latest vintages, replacing those already on the shelves with something that (hopefully) will reflect their talents working with the grapes that were given them by nature. (Grand Junction Daily Sentinel). 18.  FASHION-PARIS -- PARIS -- Two of the biggest and most prestigious names in the world of French ready-to-wear, Karl Lagerfeld for Chanel and Valentino, showed their collections Tuesday at the Carousel du Louvre. (Janjigian, Palm Beach Daily News). 18. MOVED.  EDs: WITH PHOTOS for Cox papers only. Photos available in the Palm Beach Daily News database.  SUSMAN-COLUMN -- WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Women were yet again emotionally put through the ringer with the release of the results of a huge study in China that found breast self-exam didn't save lives from breast cancer. The study of 260,000 women found that teaching them self-exams didn't result in the women finding lumps early enough to affect mortality. (Susman, Palm Beach Post). 25. MOVED. THE WEEKEND DUTY EDITORS ARE:  IN ATLANTA: Diane Fall, 404-234-9636  IN ATLANTA AT AJC GRAPHICS: Walter Cumming (2-10, 404-526-7006); Katie Ridley (4-midnight, 404-526-5484 )  IN WASHINGTON: Art Dalglish, 301-460-6176, 301-996-3036 (cell).  NATIONAL  CONGRESS -- WASHINGTON -- The new Congress convenes Tuesday, the first in nearly 50 years to be under Republican control during a Republican presidency. In the short term, its task is to renew unemployment benefits and to provide fresh funds before a temporary budget resolution expires Saturday. The long-term agenda includes major social and economic legislation. (Shepard, Cox News Service)  WAN: Atlanta, National, U.S. Government  STROM-THURMOND -- EDGEFIELD, S.C. -- Outgoing Sen. Strom Thurmond (R.-S.C.) returns home this week once his successor is sworn in. How does the town feel about the brouhaha over Trent Lott's comments about Strom at his 100th birthday? (Riddle, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution)  NC-REP-CLAYTON -- LITTLETON, N.C. -- When Eva Clayton entered Congress in 1993, she captured attention with her election as president of the 69-member Democratic freshman class. That election, combined with the notoriety she drew as North Carolina's first black woman in the House, left many wondering how high Clayton's star would rise on the national level. The 1994 election brought a Republican revolution to Congress, and Clayton's circumstances changed. As a member of the minority party, leadership opportunities faded, and Clayton's focus turned to farmers, rural residents and the poor. With her retirement from Congress becoming official last Friday, her work in those areas will be the legacy she leaves behind, political allies and analysts said. (Livingston, Greenville Daily Reflector) MOVED.  TER-PRINTS -- WASHINGTON -- A fingerprint found on a gun in Montgomery, Ala., might have prevented -- or shortened -- the Washington-area snipers' spree. But it didn't because Alabama, like 30 other states, can't directly communicate with the nation's fingerprint computer. Now, as the nation turns its eye to homeland security, fingerprinting will be an important part of tracking would-be terrorists. A look at the National AIFIS fingerprint database, how expensive it is to hook up and why more states haven't done it. (Tofig, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution)  AVIATION-MUSEUM -- DAYTON, Ohio -- Do you know which pilot can claim the first romantic tryst in mid-air? And why in the name of NASA did astronaut Gus Grissom wear a panty girdle on his first flight into space? You'll discover the answer to these and many other intriguing aviation questions, as well as a variety of interactive exhibits to test your piloting skills, at the new $7.5-million Learning Center of the National Aviation Hall of Fame. (DeBrosse, Dayton Daily News) MOVED.  OPED/EDITORIAL  EDIT-DIESEL -- ATLANTA -- You can stop pinching yourself now. The Bush administration is drafting new rules for diesel, off-road vehicles that will actually help reduce pollution to the delight of environmentalists. (Harris, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.  BLACKBURN-EDIT -- WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. -- In my youth, I promised not to complain in old age about the world heading down the Styx on a steamboat. But Jumping Jehoshaphat, the whole country has adopted the ethical standards of a pack of hyenas. (Blackburn, Palm Beach Post) MOVED.  BUSINESS  CREATIVE-RESUME -- ATLANTA -- You've followed all the resume rules: White- or buff-colored paper. Buzzwords and keywords galore -- and industry-specific, of course. Proper formatting for easy electronic scanning. Plenty of action words. And still that crafted-by-the-rules resume has turned up no interviews. Maybe it's time for a change, suggests Ralph Mobley, director of career services at Georgia Tech. Maybe it's time to get creative. (Mallory White, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.  LIFESTYLE  ALONE -- ATLANTA -- After her husband died in a plane crash also carrying golfer Payne Stewart, Dixie Fraley desperately sought solace. She neatly arranged the gold fish, meditation book and Bible she'd received from sympathetic friends. She joined a widows group. ``But I would hear more sad stories and I would leave with more sadness,'' said the 44-year-old Fraley. Besides her anguish, she felt overwhelmed by tax filings, legal issues and other details relating to selling her husband's successful business. What widows and other single women need, she thought, was not only a place to share their grief, but also a comfortable environment to get advice on practical issues. (Oliviero, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution) 30.  WIGGINS-COLUMN -- WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Here in South Florida I note two seasons: Summer and It Should Go On Forever. Summer begins in late May on the first day the thermometer reaches 90, and It Should Go On Forever begins in November on the first day the temperature dips below 70. (Wiggins, Palm Beach Post) MOVED.  FAMILY-WISE -- DAYTON, Ohio -- Parenting tips column. This week: Reluctant spelling-bee champ might need a friendly push. (Ramey, Dayton Daily News) MOVED.  EDs: Weekly parenting column by Dayton child psychologist Gregory Ramey.  NEWS FOR KIDS  NFK-CHECKITOUT -- Items include: this week in history, birthday of the week and word of the week. (The Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.  NFK-BOOKSHELF -- ATLANTA -- How can you wow friends and influence people? By spending about $10 of your hard-earned holiday money on Scholastic's ``Book of World Records 2003.'' Bright and colorful, it has more than 300 pages packed with photos, graphs and other information relating to world records and record-holders. Categories include sports, food, animals, movies, natural wonders and disasters, and video games. (Bookman, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution) 25. MOVED.  NFK-BULLY -- ATLANTA -- Are you a bully or a bully's victim, or have you watched a bully pick on someone? Psychologists and teachers who study types of bullying -- which include teasing, rumor-spreading, name-calling, keeping others out of a group and trashing property -- say it's likely that you've been in at least one of these groups. (Woolsey, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.  ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS  GRAMMY-PICKS -- ATLANTA -- Who will the Recording Academy honor with Grammy nominations this year? In advance of the Tuesday morning announcement, we'll take a shot at predicting the nominees for a few major categories: album of the year, record of the year and best new artist. (The Atlanta Journal-Constitution) 15.  TV-LOUD -- ATLANTA -- Review of ``Lance Loud! A Death in an American Family,'' an hour-long documentary by the makers of the original granddaddy of reality shows, chronicling the last days and death of the outspoken son who made TV history by coming out in the 12-hour, 1973 series. (Murray, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution) 15.  REALITY-TV -- WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. -- From `Joe Millionaire' to `The Bachelorette,' get ready for a fresh round of schemes and dreams, heartbreak and humiliation -- and humongous ratings. (Thompson, Palm Beach Post) MOVED.  TV-MOLE -- WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. -- ``The Mole'' is the Rodney Dangerfield of reality shows. It gets no respect. Survivor, while not as popular as it once was, still generates considerable watercooler buzz. Over 18 million viewers watched the first edition of ``The Bachelor.'' MTV's ``Real World'' has been on the air for, like, 35 years. ``Fear Factor'' continues to capture a sizable audience as does ``The Amazing Race.'' No one, it seems, cares about ``The Mole'' -- not even its own network. ABC yanked it after only two episodes the last time around. (Thompson, Palm Beach Post) MOVED.  REALITY-TV-LIST -- WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Here's the rundown on more new reality-based shows. (Thompson, Palm Beach Post) 20. MOVED.  HOLLOWAY-TVCOLUMN -- AUSTIN, Texas -- Observations on the television industry from a leading commentator. This week: It's out with the new and in with the newer, as television gears up this week for a major midseason. If you've finally memorized the prime-time schedule introduced in September, you'll need to start over this month. The networks are introducing 17 new series and shuffling a few established ones in an attempt to strengthen their ratings. (Holloway, Austin American-Statesman) MOVED.  ROKY -- AUSTIN, Texas -- For decades, cult music icon Roky Erickson was practically paralyzed by schizophrenia. He played multiple televisions and radios at the same time. He rarely left home. His hair was wild, beard full, teeth rotten. Eighteen months ago -- over the objections of other family members -- his younger brother Sumner had Roky declared incompetent and became his legal guardian. Today, Roky is on his meds, has had his teeth fixed, and occasionally makes public appearances. Meanwhile, a movie, documentary and book about his life are in the works. (Ball, Austin American-Statesman) WITH PHOTOS. MOVED.  FLA-CHURCHILL -- MANALAPAN, Fla. -- One of the handful of paintings done by Winston Churchill in the United States has a Manalapan connection -- it was painted at the historic Casa Alva, former home of Consuelo Vanderbilt Balsan. (Rogers, Palm Beach Daily News) 26. MOVED.  ALPHABET-COLLAGE -- PALM BEACH, Fla. -- About five years ago, Bruce Helander made a set of collages based on the letters of the alphabet for a show at a West Palm Beach art gallery. ``Jane Buffett bought the B for Jimmy,'' Helander said. ``Someone else bought the C. The show sold out in 24 hours.'' Helander's publisher recognized a hit. He asked the artist to make a different set of letters so that they could be made into prints. Helander created two print editions, which have been exhibited in more than 19 one-man shows across the country. (Sjostrom, Palm Beach Daily News) 22. MOVED.  COW-SCULPTURE -- PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Zach and Marilyn Morfogen were having a get-together recently at their home in Palm Beach. While other guests munched sandwiches, olives and cheese, Zach Morfogen led his neighbor Martin Karlin to the balcony to meet the star attraction. There, with her big eyes framed by curly eyelashes, stood a life-sized sculpture of a Holstein cow. Zach Morfogen commissioned the cow in 1991 from artist Henry Loustau as a present to his wife for their 35th anniversary. (Sjostrom, Palm Beach Daily News) 26. MOVED.  SPORTS  PRO FOOTBALL  FBN-FALCONS -- ATLANTA -- The weather might be colder, and the opponent will surely be tougher next go round for the Falcons. Atlanta, fresh off upset victory over Green Bay, plays at Philadelphia Saturday night. (Winkeljohn,The Atlanta Journal-Constitution)  FBN-BROWNS -- PITTSBURGH -- Browns game against Pittsburgh Steelers. (Dayton Daily News)  FBN-SPURRIER -- ATLANTA -- Whenever and wherever it is Steve Spurrier begins his NFL coaching career, he will likely hear snickers from established NFL coaches wondering how he'll ever succeed without an NFL background. But the jump from colleges to a head coaching job in the NFL has successfully been made before. ``It's still the game of football,'' said Cleveland Browns coach Butch Davis. (Sugiura, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution)  COXNET BUDGET INFORMATION  This budget moves at 2:30 p.m. and 6 p.m. ET and afterwards as necessary based on news developments. If stories will move after 8 p.m., an ETA will be given. All times are Eastern unless otherwise noted.  HOW TO REACH US  Questions should be directed to COXnet, the Cox News Service, in Atlanta at 404 572-1800 M-F 8 am.-5 p.m. ET. After 5 p.m ET. and on weekends and holidays, call 404 526-5456. We are staffed 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. Monday-Friday, and 1-10 p.m. on weekends and holidays.  Managing editor Tom Oder, 404-572-1961, toder(at)coxnews.com.  News editor Alan Gordon, 404-526-7282, agordon(at)coxnews.com  Cox Washington Bureau:  News editor Carl Rauscher, 202-887-8307, crausher(at)coxnews.com  Foreign editor Chuck Holmes, 202-887-8320, chuckh(at)coxnews.com  Bureau chief Andy Alexander, 202-887-8334, andya(at)coxnews.com  Story Filed By Cox Newspapers  For Use By Clients of the New York Times News Service </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20030105.0047 type=advis > <HEADLINE> COXnet Cox News Service budget </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> 01-05-03 14:54:00EST (BC-SPOT-BJT-1STLEDE-0106) </DATELINE> <TEXT> All articles by Cox Newspapers employees c. 2003 Cox News Service.  THE WEEKEND DUTY EDITORS ARE:  IN ATLANTA: Diane Fall, 404-234-9636  IN ATLANTA AT AJC GRAPHICS: Walter Cumming (2-10, 404-526-7006); Katie Ridley (4-midnight, 404-526-5484 )  IN WASHINGTON: Art Dalglish, 301-460-6176, 301-996-3036 (cell).  EDS: Adds: ISRAEL-BOMBINGS  INTERNATIONAL  ISRAEL-BOMBINGS -- JERUSALEM -- Two suicide bombers killed at least 18 people Sunday in a working-class area of Tel Aviv, shaking Israel as national elections approach. (Kaplow/Krosney Ben-Zeev, Cox News Service)  WAN: Atlanta, International, Other  NATIONAL  CONGRESS -- WASHINGTON -- The new Congress convenes Tuesday, the first in nearly 50 years to be under Republican control during a Republican presidency. In the short term, its task is to renew unemployment benefits and to provide fresh funds before a temporary budget resolution expires Saturday. The long-term agenda includes major social and economic legislation. (Shepard, Cox News Service)  WAN: Atlanta, National, U.S. Government  STROM-THURMOND -- EDGEFIELD, S.C. -- Outgoing Sen. Strom Thurmond (R.-S.C.) returns home this week once his successor is sworn in. How does the town feel about the brouhaha over Trent Lott's comments about Strom at his 100th birthday? (Riddle, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution)  NC-REP-CLAYTON -- LITTLETON, N.C. -- When Eva Clayton entered Congress in 1993, she captured attention with her election as president of the 69-member Democratic freshman class. That election, combined with the notoriety she drew as North Carolina's first black woman in the House, left many wondering how high Clayton's star would rise on the national level. The 1994 election brought a Republican revolution to Congress, and Clayton's circumstances changed. As a member of the minority party, leadership opportunities faded, and Clayton's focus turned to farmers, rural residents and the poor. With her retirement from Congress becoming official last Friday, her work in those areas will be the legacy she leaves behind, political allies and analysts said. (Livingston, Greenville Daily Reflector) MOVED.  TER-PRINTS -- WASHINGTON -- A fingerprint found on a gun in Montgomery, Ala., might have prevented -- or shortened -- the Washington-area snipers' spree. But it didn't because Alabama, like 30 other states, can't directly communicate with the nation's fingerprint computer. Now, as the nation turns its eye to homeland security, fingerprinting will be an important part of tracking would-be terrorists. A look at the National AIFIS fingerprint database, how expensive it is to hook up and why more states haven't done it. (Tofig, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution)  AVIATION-MUSEUM -- DAYTON, Ohio -- Do you know which pilot can claim the first romantic tryst in mid-air? And why in the name of NASA did astronaut Gus Grissom wear a panty girdle on his first flight into space? You'll discover the answer to these and many other intriguing aviation questions, as well as a variety of interactive exhibits to test your piloting skills, at the new $7.5-million Learning Center of the National Aviation Hall of Fame. (DeBrosse, Dayton Daily News) MOVED.  OPED/EDITORIAL  EDIT-DIESEL -- ATLANTA -- You can stop pinching yourself now. The Bush administration is drafting new rules for diesel, off-road vehicles that will actually help reduce pollution to the delight of environmentalists. (Harris, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.  BLACKBURN-EDIT -- WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. -- In my youth, I promised not to complain in old age about the world heading down the Styx on a steamboat. But Jumping Jehoshaphat, the whole country has adopted the ethical standards of a pack of hyenas. (Blackburn, Palm Beach Post) MOVED.  BUSINESS  CREATIVE-RESUME -- ATLANTA -- You've followed all the resume rules: White- or buff-colored paper. Buzzwords and keywords galore -- and industry-specific, of course. Proper formatting for easy electronic scanning. Plenty of action words. And still that crafted-by-the-rules resume has turned up no interviews. Maybe it's time for a change, suggests Ralph Mobley, director of career services at Georgia Tech. Maybe it's time to get creative. (Mallory White, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.  LIFESTYLE  ALONE -- ATLANTA -- After her husband died in a plane crash also carrying golfer Payne Stewart, Dixie Fraley desperately sought solace. She neatly arranged the gold fish, meditation book and Bible she'd received from sympathetic friends. She joined a widows group. ``But I would hear more sad stories and I would leave with more sadness,'' said the 44-year-old Fraley. Besides her anguish, she felt overwhelmed by tax filings, legal issues and other details relating to selling her husband's successful business. What widows and other single women need, she thought, was not only a place to share their grief, but also a comfortable environment to get advice on practical issues. (Oliviero, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution) 30.  WIGGINS-COLUMN -- WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Here in South Florida I note two seasons: Summer and It Should Go On Forever. Summer begins in late May on the first day the thermometer reaches 90, and It Should Go On Forever begins in November on the first day the temperature dips below 70. (Wiggins, Palm Beach Post) MOVED.  FAMILY-WISE -- DAYTON, Ohio -- Parenting tips column. This week: Reluctant spelling-bee champ might need a friendly push. (Ramey, Dayton Daily News) MOVED.  EDs: Weekly parenting column by Dayton child psychologist Gregory Ramey.  NEWS FOR KIDS  NFK-CHECKITOUT -- Items include: this week in history, birthday of the week and word of the week. (The Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.  NFK-BOOKSHELF -- ATLANTA -- How can you wow friends and influence people? By spending about $10 of your hard-earned holiday money on Scholastic's ``Book of World Records 2003.'' Bright and colorful, it has more than 300 pages packed with photos, graphs and other information relating to world records and record-holders. Categories include sports, food, animals, movies, natural wonders and disasters, and video games. (Bookman, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution) 25. MOVED.  NFK-BULLY -- ATLANTA -- Are you a bully or a bully's victim, or have you watched a bully pick on someone? Psychologists and teachers who study types of bullying -- which include teasing, rumor-spreading, name-calling, keeping others out of a group and trashing property -- say it's likely that you've been in at least one of these groups. (Woolsey, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.  ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS  GRAMMY-PICKS -- ATLANTA -- Who will the Recording Academy honor with Grammy nominations this year? In advance of the Tuesday morning announcement, we'll take a shot at predicting the nominees for a few major categories: album of the year, record of the year and best new artist. (The Atlanta Journal-Constitution) 15.  TV-LOUD -- ATLANTA -- Review of ``Lance Loud! A Death in an American Family,'' an hour-long documentary by the makers of the original granddaddy of reality shows, chronicling the last days and death of the outspoken son who made TV history by coming out in the 12-hour, 1973 series. (Murray, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution) 15.  REALITY-TV -- WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. -- From `Joe Millionaire' to `The Bachelorette,' get ready for a fresh round of schemes and dreams, heartbreak and humiliation -- and humongous ratings. (Thompson, Palm Beach Post) MOVED.  TV-MOLE -- WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. -- ``The Mole'' is the Rodney Dangerfield of reality shows. It gets no respect. Survivor, while not as popular as it once was, still generates considerable watercooler buzz. Over 18 million viewers watched the first edition of ``The Bachelor.'' MTV's ``Real World'' has been on the air for, like, 35 years. ``Fear Factor'' continues to capture a sizable audience as does ``The Amazing Race.'' No one, it seems, cares about ``The Mole'' -- not even its own network. ABC yanked it after only two episodes the last time around. (Thompson, Palm Beach Post) MOVED.  REALITY-TV-LIST -- WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Here's the rundown on more new reality-based shows. (Thompson, Palm Beach Post) 20. MOVED.  HOLLOWAY-TVCOLUMN -- AUSTIN, Texas -- Observations on the television industry from a leading commentator. This week: It's out with the new and in with the newer, as television gears up this week for a major midseason. If you've finally memorized the prime-time schedule introduced in September, you'll need to start over this month. The networks are introducing 17 new series and shuffling a few established ones in an attempt to strengthen their ratings. (Holloway, Austin American-Statesman) MOVED.  ROKY -- AUSTIN, Texas -- For decades, cult music icon Roky Erickson was practically paralyzed by schizophrenia. He played multiple televisions and radios at the same time. He rarely left home. His hair was wild, beard full, teeth rotten. Eighteen months ago -- over the objections of other family members -- his younger brother Sumner had Roky declared incompetent and became his legal guardian. Today, Roky is on his meds, has had his teeth fixed, and occasionally makes public appearances. Meanwhile, a movie, documentary and book about his life are in the works. (Ball, Austin American-Statesman) WITH PHOTOS. MOVED.  FLA-CHURCHILL -- MANALAPAN, Fla. -- One of the handful of paintings done by Winston Churchill in the United States has a Manalapan connection -- it was painted at the historic Casa Alva, former home of Consuelo Vanderbilt Balsan. (Rogers, Palm Beach Daily News) 26. MOVED.  ALPHABET-COLLAGE -- PALM BEACH, Fla. -- About five years ago, Bruce Helander made a set of collages based on the letters of the alphabet for a show at a West Palm Beach art gallery. ``Jane Buffett bought the B for Jimmy,'' Helander said. ``Someone else bought the C. The show sold out in 24 hours.'' Helander's publisher recognized a hit. He asked the artist to make a different set of letters so that they could be made into prints. Helander created two print editions, which have been exhibited in more than 19 one-man shows across the country. (Sjostrom, Palm Beach Daily News) 22. MOVED.  COW-SCULPTURE -- PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Zach and Marilyn Morfogen were having a get-together recently at their home in Palm Beach. While other guests munched sandwiches, olives and cheese, Zach Morfogen led his neighbor Martin Karlin to the balcony to meet the star attraction. There, with her big eyes framed by curly eyelashes, stood a life-sized sculpture of a Holstein cow. Zach Morfogen commissioned the cow in 1991 from artist Henry Loustau as a present to his wife for their 35th anniversary. (Sjostrom, Palm Beach Daily News) 26. MOVED.  SPORTS  PRO FOOTBALL  FBN-FALCONS -- ATLANTA -- The weather might be colder, and the opponent will surely be tougher next go round for the Falcons. Atlanta, fresh off upset victory over Green Bay, plays at Philadelphia Saturday night. (Winkeljohn,The Atlanta Journal-Constitution)  FBN-BROWNS -- PITTSBURGH -- Browns game against Pittsburgh Steelers. (Dayton Daily News)  FBN-SPURRIER -- ATLANTA -- Whenever and wherever it is Steve Spurrier begins his NFL coaching career, he will likely hear snickers from established NFL coaches wondering how he'll ever succeed without an NFL background. But the jump from colleges to a head coaching job in the NFL has successfully been made before. ``It's still the game of football,'' said Cleveland Browns coach Butch Davis. (Sugiura, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution)  COXNET BUDGET INFORMATION  This budget moves at 2:30 p.m. and 6 p.m. ET and afterwards as necessary based on news developments. If stories will move after 8 p.m., an ETA will be given. All times are Eastern unless otherwise noted. (Tofig, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution)  PRISON-WISDOM _ AUSTIN, Texas _ If you go to prison act like a nerd. Take classes in whatever. Hide in the library. Pray in chapel. This is prison wisdom. The advice comes from a former prison guard and also a former inmate who work for two different businesses that provide consulting to people entering prison. (Osborn, Austin American-Statesman) 31.  TREASURE-SHIP _ WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. _ At first glance, it may look like any number of legal motions filed at the federal courthouse. Except the defendant in the case isn't a person or a corporation _ it's a centuries-old ship wreck. And that makes the legal document somewhat akin to a modern treasure map, one that holds the location via longitude and latitude of what is believed to be the remains of an 18th century merchant ship known as the Notre Dame de Deliverance. The Deliverance could hold a fortune that would make Florida's richest ship wreck look like a toddler's piggy bank. (Palm Beach Post)  AVIATION-MUSEUM -- DAYTON, Ohio -- Do you know which pilot can claim the first romantic tryst in mid-air? And why in the name of NASA did astronaut Gus Grissom wear a panty girdle on his first flight into space? You'll discover the answer to these and many other intriguing aviation questions, as well as a variety of interactive exhibits to test your piloting skills, at the new $7.5-million Learning Center of the National Aviation Hall of Fame. (DeBrosse, Dayton Daily News) MOVED.  OPED/EDITORIAL  EDIT-DIESEL -- ATLANTA -- You can stop pinching yourself now. Yet Governor Gray Davis will be subject to a recall election on Oct. 7. He ought to prevail, not because he has been an effective governor but because a victory for him would discourage further attempts to destabilize state government.  California's political society was far simpler in 1911 when Governor Hiram Johnson inserted the recall provision into the state Constitution along with for initiative petitions allowing voters to make laws. Johnson felt that the biggest problem facing the state was control by the railroads. Once their power was reduced, he thought, voters could be counted upon to act wisely.  That might have made sense in 1911, when California was more homogeneous and lightly populated with 3.4 mise.  Instead, California gets democracy by blunt plebiscite. Once the voters approved Proposition 13 in 1978 to limit property taxes, they put a straitjacket on local government and discouraged the state from raising other taxes by requiring approval by a two-thirds majority in the Legislature.  Davis, already unpopular for his handling of California's electricity crisis, won reelection last year mainly because he financed an ad campaign to block his strongest rival from winning the Republican nomination. This year he deserves the voters' scorn for failing to put aside enough money during the Internet boom to cushion the blow of the recession.  The same could be said about New York's George Pataki, Massachusetts's Paul Cellucci (had he not resigned to become US ambassador to Canada), and no doubt other governors. Hiram Johnson's recall amendment, which has never been$ucgd against a statewide official in California, ought to be reserved for malfeasance, not miscalculation.  Unless the California Supreme Court discovers fraudulent signatures on the recall petitions, voters will be able to reject Davis on Oct. 7 and on the same ballot choose a replacement from a long list of candidates, almost all Republicans. A new governor could be chosen with a fraction of the 3.1 million votes Davis gained as a Democrat in the 2002 final election.  The California Senate is working on an agreement to close a $38 billion budget gap. This would require further negotiations and more revenue in succeeding years. Davis should be trying to solve this crisis, not fighting for political survival. The recall is a distraction as the state faces a financial shortfall that dwarfs anything that politicians of the Hiram Johnson era could have envisioned. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20030724.0052 type=advis > <HEADLINE> FORGOTTEN FAMILIES </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> 07-24-03 19:16:00EDT (BC-EDITORIAL-CHILD-BOS) </DATELINE> <TEXT> President Bush showed his disdain for the working poor Thursday with his visit to a federal check processing center in Philadelphia from which the first batch of child tax credit checks will be mailed to middle-income families. To the 6.5 million families who aren't getting a check because their wages are too low, the photo op was an inauspicious reminder that the president recently signed a $330 billion tax cut that left them out.  Bush should correct the problem by insisting that the House and Senate work out their differences before the House leaves for summer vacation and give him a bill to sign that would extend child care tax credits to low-income families without further exploding the deficit.  A compromise proposal that three senators offered to House leaders on Tuesday would do more damage than good: a $50 billion, 10-year fix for a problem that requires $3.5 billion to repair. Under the proposal, higher-income families would get three times more in benefits than low-income families. Nearly $11 billion in new tax cuts would go to families with incomes exceeding $110,000; just $3.5 billion would go to the working poor.  House Democrats were right this week to object to that proposal and use one of the few toore credits to the working poor. These families should never have been excluded from the tax cut to begin with. Republicans who argue the fact that low-wage earners do pay regressive payroll taxes, property taxes, and sales taxes.  Despite soaring prosperity for some, it is still easy to work full-time in America and not earn $27,000 _ $519 a week. Indeed, those left out of the child tax benefit include millions of hard-working waitresses, farm workers, health aides, cabdrivers, and secretaries, according to the Children's Defense Fund.  The most sensible solution is for Bush to press for the bill the Senate approved in early June. It would provide $10 billion for child tax credits for the working poor paid for through Customs Department fees charged to process passengers and merchandise. The House-passed bill is laughable; it proposes to solve the problem by adding $82 billion over 10 years to the deficit, mostly through additional tax cuts for the wealthy, and does not raise offsetting revenue.  For the next three Fridays, some 25 million Americans will be receiving $400 rebate checks for each child. The checks will bear the phrase: ``Tax relief for America's families.'' The only way the working poor can truly be considered part of the American family is if they, too, receive those checks. </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20030724.0053 type=story > <HEADLINE> Compensation picture to change </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> ATLANTA  (BC-OPTIONS-0727-COX) </DATELINE> <TEXT> "	"nyt_eng_200307.gz"

NEW YORK -  Dear Diary:  I was at a hip New York bar recently celebrating my boyfriend's birthday.  At the table next to us were a group of out-of-towners discussing their plans to visit the Empire State Building the following day.  Needing help with transportation, one of the women turned to our party and said, ``Do y'all ride the subway?''  Before we could answer, she asked a follow-up question: ``Oh, wait, are y'all from here?''  Our group replied in unison, ``Yes.''  The thoughtful tourist paused for a moment and then quickly rephrased her question: ``Excuse me, do youse guys ride the subway?''  - JAMIE L. RUBIN  Observed by Richard Valeriani at a stationery store in Manhattan, after a woman had just bought a large calendar desk pad:  Clerk: Do you want a bag for that?  Woman: Yes, please.  Clerk: We don't have a bag for that.  Dear Diary:  Though it is over 30 years ago and I now do my foreign film viewing in Berkeley, Calif., I can still vividly see Zero Mostel, then the title character in ``Rhinoceros,'' stalking into the downstairs film theater at the Museum of Modern Art.  He quietly sat a few rows back in a middle seat, gently tapped the shoulder of the man in front of him and said, ``Please remove your head.''  The man looked over his shoulder at the familiar hulk and moved, probably never to come to the Museum of Modern Art again.  - TED KRAUS  Dear Diary:  While visiting New York from Florida over the Christmas holidays with my folks and my daughter, we took in Rockefeller Center. I wanted to get a picture of the tree with my mother and daughter - who have almost the same name - so I said, ``Turn around, Martha!''  With that my mother (Martha), my daughter (Marthe) and three other women turned around. Seems the other three were three generations of Marthas enjoying the city as well. What are those odds?  - DEBBIE CHURCH  SAX ADVICE  In the cold distance he tooted his horn  Up the deep caverns of Fifth Avenue  Hearing from across the street I was torn  The time was nigh, my burning question due  I dropped a folded dollar  To match the other in his case  He bluiry  ``My tuneless horn's lost its cause,  Is there advice you can give me?''  Wound sillybwith rubber bands  Duct tape bound his instrument's keys  After twenty years of playing with gloved hands  He held his horn at ease  ``They're all minor adjustments,'' he said.  All minor adjustments, I thought, until you're dead.  - ANDREW BAST  Dear Diary:  Sunday morning, Brooklyn Heights: Sara was in line at a bagel store on Montague Street. Ahead of her was a tall, well-dressed woman with a strong Midwestern accent. She was ordering her breakfast bagel and clearly didn't want much cream cheese on it.  The Hispanic man behind the counter looked puzzled as the customer's nasal twang requested ``a sesame bagel with just a teensy, weeensy, weeeeensy bit of low-fat cream cheese, please.''  After saying several times in a strong Latino accent, ``I don't understand,'' the counterman looked even more perplexed.  The woman mimed the universal finger and thumb sign for just a little bit as she repeated slowly and patiently, ``A little, teensy bit of cream cheese.''  Suddenly, the man's face lit up. ``Ah!'' he said. ``You want a schmeer!'' - TONY AND SARA SOLL  Dear Diary:  Being a teacher and writer of Irish Gaelic - a minority language even in Ireland - and new to the New York area, I was Eagur to find out if there were other Irish speakers in the city. I found, to my delight, that a group met regularly in a Midtown bar.  Having first arranged by e-mail to meet them, I arrived at the bar and scanned the clientele. Indeed, around a table was a group deep in conversation, and I asked them in Irish if I could join them. ``Why not?'' came the reply in Irish, and I sat down with them and ordered a drink. It seemed strange to me that none of their names were familiar, but they seemed more than happy to talk to me, if a little puzzled.  After five minutes of inconclusive stop-start conversation, however, one of them finally asked me why I, a total stranger, had joined their group.  Beginning to realize my error, and somewhat embarrassed, I looked around the bar again. This time, behind a screen in the restaurant at the end of the bar, I found my Internet colleagues on their second bottle of wine and amazed to learn that I had, quite by accident, blundered into another group of Irish speakers.  The first group, no less astonished, came up to us before they left the bar and, amid much laughter, we wondered how many more of us were lurking around the city's corners.  - BRIAN O'BROIN  Dear Diary:  Updating Blanche DuBois, I am learning to depend on the kindness and generosity of computers. During a recent trip to New York, to maintain propriety, I found I needed a new belt, size 34. To gird /y midsection, I headed south of Midtown to what may be America's best-known department store.  I found a suitable belt, marked $27.50, and carried it to a nearby clerk. He turned to the computer and scanned the belt's bar code. Doing a small double take at the readout, surprised but dutiful, he said, ``It reads, `1 cent.''' And that's what I paid for the new belt, a penny. The receipt states, ``Total Amount Due Store $0.01,'' and the employee was trained to obey electronic commandments.  As I left, the clerk said, ``I think I should get me one of those belts.''  - ROY MEADOR </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20040202.0001 type=story > <HEADLINE> GOV. You'll read about the saga of the late president and his lady from their first meeting to their marriage in 1952. In 1949, Reagan was in a deep funk. He and actress Jane Wyman had divorced a year earlier, and his personal life was a shambles. Although he was president of the Screen Actors Guild, his film career was on the skids. That fall, a friend of Reagan asked him, as SAG chief, to defend new starlet Nancy Davis against claims that she was -- incredibly, it seems now -- a Communist sympathizer. "142091"	"I"	"thought"	" (Terry Pace is the entertainment editor of the TimesDaily in Florence, Ala) </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20040902.0170 type=advis > <HEADLINE> EDITORS, PHOTOS ARE AVAILABLE OF JULIE BENZ IN THE CURRENT NYTRNG GRAPHICS FOLDER OF THE ART LIBRARY. ----- </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> ATLANTA, Ga. </DATELINE> <TEXT> Julie Benz spent eight years walking a fine line between the living and the dead.  Between memorable movie roles in Jawbreaker and As Good As It Gets, the versatile young actress originated the role of seductive, centuries-old bloodsucker Darla on television's supernatural cult favorite, Buffy the Vampire Slayer.  As the longtime lover of Angel -- a vampire-with-a-soul played by David Boreanaz -- both the character and the actress later crossed over to the show's eerie spinoff, Angel.  Over the course of the two series, the former ice dancer from Pittsburgh developed the complex, constantly changing Darla from an evil immortal into a sensitive, compassionate human being. The character made a dramatic and emotional exit from the franchise as the self-sacrificing mother of the first baby born to undead parents.  When you work with writers like Joss Whedon and David Greenwalt, they come up with such amazing ideas and you just go along for the ride, says Benz, one of the scheduled guests for Dragon Con, the annual science-fiction, fantasy and horror expo that begins Friday and continues through Monday in downtown Atlanta.  Playing Darla has been such an amazing roller-coaster ride, added Benz, who made her debut as Darla after losing the leading role of teenage vampire hunter Buffy to subsequent series star Sarah Michelle Gellar. The Darla character dates back to the Buffy pilot episode that aired in 1997.  At first I was just known as 'Vampire Girl,' and then I got a name, Benz explained in a phone interview. I died and was brought back to life, and then I had a baby and died again. Every time I died, I thought, 'This is it.' I couldn't see past what was put in front of me. I just don't think as big as the writers do.  Benz will be joined at Dragon Con by her husband of six years, John Kassir, perhaps best known for voicing the creepy Tales from the Crypt host known as the Cryptkeeper.  We have an amazing team going, Benz remarked. We're best friends and fellow actors, and we support each other through everything. For me, having a stable home life allows me to go out and take chances as an actress. He's my touchstone and my soulmate and he's a huge influence on my work. I feel very lucky to have the right person in my life.  Something for everyone  Each year's Dragon Con festivities -- which encompass two downtown hotels -- draw more than 30,000 fans of Buffy, Angel, Star Trek, Star Wars, Lord of the Rings, Doctor Who, The X-Files, Harry Potter, The Muppets and other aspects of sci-fi, horror, fantasy, comics, anime, music, art, space and science.  The thing that has put Dragon Con above all other Southern conventions is that it's put on by the fans and done for the fans, says Brooke Perry, a Florence, Ala.-based writer, actor, director, teacher and sci-fi and horror enthusiast who plans to attend this year's convention.  Everything is planned with the fans in mind, whether you're into 'Buffy,' 'X-Files,' 'Farscape,' 'Star Trek,' gory slasher films, 'Lord of the Rings,' classic horror, 'Star Wars,' whatever, Perry explained. There's something there for everyone who's a fan of the different genres.  Activities includes an independent film competition, an art show, a writing workshop, a costume contest, concerts and specialized programs with titles like Queer Eye for the Trek Guy: The Missing Minority, Elf Ears and Other Makeup Tips, Oh, Muse! Where Art Thou? and How to Make a Zombie (Or Anything Unreal) Real. There's even a Miss Klingon Beauty Pageant.  Last year was my first year at Dragon Con, noted Jason Behel, a University of North Alabama art student from Tuscumbia, Ala. I'm not like a Trekkie or anything, so I kind of had a preconceived idea about it. But I was really impressed, especially with the art show -- it was amazing.  Behel was so inspired by the pieces he saw that he entered his own work in this year's Dragon Con art show.  I'm doing some science-fiction-inspired pottery for the show, and I've got a small booth there, he added. I'm more into the older science fiction and fantasy, like H.P. Lovecraft and Tolkien and things along that line. I have a piece there that's inspired by Lovecraft.  All-star guest lineup  In addition to Benz and Kassir, this year's eclectic lineup of Dragon Con celebrity guests includes comedy legend Soupy Sales, musical madman Dr. Demento, jazz pianist Chick Corea, authors Harlan Ellison and Anne McCaffrey, artists Olivia, Bernie Wrightson and Bill Stout, Playboy model Sandra Taylor and actors David Carradine (Kill Bill, Vol. 2), Ernie Hudson (Ghostbusters), Peter Davison (Doctor Who), Dee Wallace Stone (E.T.), Glenn Shadix (Beetlejuice), Garrett Wang (Star Trek: Voyager), Adam Baldwin (Firefly), Peter Mayhew (Chewbacca from Star Wars), Virginia Hey (Farscape), June Lockhart(Lost in Space), Marc Singer (The Beastmaster), Margot Kidder (Superman), Gil Gerard (Buck Rogers) and Dean Haglund (The X-Files).  The most meaningful part of doing these shows is getting the chance to say 'hi' and meet the fans, says Haglund, who played the Ramones-loving computer geek Langley, one of the Lone Gunmen trio of government-conspiracy theorists who made their debut assisting Mulder (David Duchovny) and Scully (Gillian Anderson) on The X-Files before starring in their own short-lived spinoff.  The Lone Gunmen played a special role in the 'X-Files' world, Haglund believes. We were basically there for all those people who couldn't relate to two gorgeous-looking FBI agents who happen to be hunting aliens. I think the appeal of the Lone Gunmen is that we look like Hanson 20 years later.  (Terry Pace is the entertainment editor of the TimesDaily in Florence, Ala.)  What: Dragon Con 2004, an annual expo of science fiction, fantasy, horror, gaming, comics, art, literature, music and film  When: Friday through Monday (Labor Day)  Where: Hyatt Regency, 265 Peachtree St. N.E., and Marriott Marquis, 265 Peachtree Center Ave., both in Atlanta, Ala.  Guests: David Carradine, Harlan Ellison, Chick Corea, Glenn Shadix, Dee Wallace Stone, Anne McCaffrey, Soupy Sales, Margot Kidder, Garrett Wang, Sybil Danning, June Lockhart, Dr. Demento, Mark Goddard, Virginia Hey, Ernie Hudson, Bernie Wrightson, Marc Singer, Jeremy Bulloch, Bill Stout, Gil Gerard, Erin Gray, Lorenzo Lamas, Daniel Logan, Peter Mayhew, Nathan Fillion, Sala Baker, Larry Elmore, Peter David, Carmine Infantino, Richard Hatch, Bob May, Ghoultown, Tom Savini and many others  Admission: $85 for all four days (Friday through Monday), $70 for three days (Saturday through Monday), $50 for two days (Sunday and Monday), $30 (Friday, Saturday or Sunday) and $25 for one day (Monday)  Details: Visit www.dragoncon.com, or purchase tickets at www.ticketmaster.com (tickets are also available at the door) </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20040902.0171 type=story > <HEADLINE> REPUBLICANS LEAVE NEW YORK ENERGIZED FOR COMPANY </HEADLINE> <DATELINE> NEW YORK </DATELINE> <TEXT> "	"nyt_eng_200409.gz"

"143626"	"I"	"thought"	" In a New Yorker profile a couple of weeks ago, Teresa Heinz Kerry got some grief for her grasp of English idiom after she called her detractors scumbags. I doubt that she knows the literal meaning of 'scumbag,' wrote the reporter, Judith Thurman, but perhaps, after forty years in America, nearly thirty of them as a political wife . . . she should have learned it. Thurman does not, however, enlighten her audience; maybe she assumes that all New Yorker readers know what Heinz Kerry does not. If so, I suspect she's wrong: When I wrote about the word in 1998, after Indiana congressman Dan Burton called President Clinton a scumbag, dozens of people who knew scumbag told me they'd had no idea of its origins. Though it's now usually just an all-purpose derogation, a cop-show synonym for dirtbag or creep or lowlife, scumbag originally meant condom (to many, used condom -- scum being slang for semen). But if lots of Americans, including Teresa Heinz Kerry, don't know this, do we really want to spread the word? Or are we better off letting scumbag enjoy life as a nonspecifically nasty term of abuse? A few slang words, after all, have outrun their unsavory origins. Bollix for mess up is no longer vulgar, having left ballocks in the dust; nuts (though it used to be euphemized nerts) is likewise untainted by its past. Screw up is now acceptable, though other uses of screw vary in their vulgarity ratings. Futz around, which may be either a euphemism for you-know-what or a descendant of the Yiddish arumfarzen (no translation necessary), is not uncommon in print nowadays, and even putz around is gaining ground. (Its resemblance to putter may make it seem milder than futz, though in fact its root is Yiddish slang for penis.) Origins are not, in any case, what makes a term taboo; it was cultural consensus, not any secret meaning, that once made bloody Britain's worst swear word. These days, though, consensus can be hard to find. Newspapers try to hold a conservative line on language -- The New York Times, for instance, will print crap shoot, but you can't say crap unless you're Lyndon Johnson (and dead). But print editors are the Canutes of usage, trying to turn back the usage tide rolling in from TV, pop music, and the Internet. For would-be gatekeepers, the speed of slang evolution keeps reviving the essential scumbag question: How dirty can a word be if nobody knows it's dirty? For the past decade, the slang word most delicately balanced on this usage bubble has been sucks, as in Mom, these sneakers suck. Seven years ago, when I first wrote about it, I was sure it was headed for respectability: The kids using the term had no sense of any sexual meaning, after all, and (as my then-teenage daughter pointed out) the new usage was intransitive; there was no grammatical object being sucked. Sucks may have been borrowed from the slang for fellating, but innocent employment, I thought, would neutralize its iffy past. It had respectable relatives, too. Sucks to you! (origin unknown) had been ordinary British youthspeak since the early 20th century, and suck up to, though probably of indelicate ancestry, was so thoroughly domesticated that in 1953, C.S. Lewis used it in one of his Narnia books for children. Besides, suck has so many standard uses that you can't really quarantine the syllable. Sucker meaning dupe, for instance, is merely a babe in the woods, a still-suckling newborn; and to children in many parts of the country, a sucker is an innocent lollipop. But I didn't reckon with the literalists, who decided kids should know this was a bad word, even if they'd prefer that someone else explained why. We could have told the kids sucks was short for sucks lemons and left well enough alone, but no: Parents banned it, then Red Sox fans adopted it for their (increasingly pathetic) slogan, and some of them, just to show that they really meant to be crude, wore their Yankees suck T-shirts with Jeter swallows on the back. This is a shame, for though every civilization needs a store of taboo words, sucks is a useful slang verb. The finger-waggers say we should use more descriptive words -- that movie was execrable, perhaps, and the Yankees are evil -- but in fact, sucks energetically fills a syntactical role that would otherwise belong to to be, that essential but uninspiring verb. Strunk and White (Use the active voice) would have to approve, and so do I. </P> </TEXT> </DOC> <DOC id=NYT_ENG_20041005.0068 type=story > <HEADLINE> IF FRIGHT EXCITES YOU, HERE'S THE TRICK </HEADLINE> <TEXT> 	nyt_eng_200410.gz

, he believed,	 Like Ford, Fuller designed his own automobile, a polliwog-shaped wonder called the Dymaxion Car (only three were ever built); more ambitiously, he sought to bring the principles of mass production to bear on housing. It was absurdly wasteful, he believed, to construct houses onsite, each one compromised by the limitations of the builder and the availability of materials. </P> 	nyt_eng_200510.gz
, he argued,	 In his privately published 1928 manifesto, 4D Timelock, Fuller sketched out a future in which houses would roll off assembly lines and be delivered fully built by zeppelin (trains, he argued, couldn't carry a house of any width and ships couldn't go inland). Cities would disappear as dirigible-distributed homes spread into a worldwide carpet of habitation. Thanks to Dymaxion Cars with retractable wings (a design element that did not make it into his prototypes), there would be no need for a connecting grid of roads. So enamored was Fuller of his delivery system that he proposed that a house's foundation be dug from the air as well: A bomb would be dropped on the desired site, and the home lowered into the resulting crater. </P> 	nyt_eng_200510.gz
, he wrote,	 Of all his brainstorms, Fuller had the greatest hopes for tensegrity, a modular tension-based structural system discovered by one of his students in 1948. Everything from the smallest subatomic particle to the spinning of the solar system, Fuller claimed, would eventually be understood to work on tensegrity principles. Tensegrity spheres, he wrote, were so light and strong that one could build lighter-than-air cities out of them that could be moored to mountaintops. Or they might simply drift, allowing humans, as Gorman puts it, to migrate like birds. </P> 	nyt_eng_200510.gz
, he hopes,	 That delivery should last him two or three months. And, he hopes, it may take up to 80 percent off his December and January gas bills. </P> 	nyt_eng_200510.gz

The Zapatista rebellion pushed the plight of poor indigenous communities in front of the rest of Mexico, and the world. They came from villages of despair, where tired children linger as Mexico modernizes. (Essdras M. , they said,	 Several State Department officials said the primary challenge that the United States faced in Latin America was the fragility of democratic governments in the region, which makes them vulnerable to populist leaders who, they said, were almost by definition anti-American. Those leaders, the officials said, also tended to chip away at democratic freedoms. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, in an interview with CNN on Monday, said: The issue for us is, will the new Bolivian government govern democratically? Are they open to cooperation that, in economic terms, will undoubtedly help the Bolivian people, because Bolivia cannot be isolated from the international economy? And so from our point of view, this is a matter of behavior. </P> 	nyt_eng_200512.gz

For the latest photos and graphics from The New York Times, go to www.nytimages.com.  INTERNATIONAL (i code)  IRAQ-SADDAM (Baghdad) -- As his trial continued, Saddam Hussein charged in open court that he has been beaten and tortured while in American custody and still has the marks on his body. In one of the most specific and direct accusations in testimony, a witness testified Wednesday that Saddam's half-brother, Barzan Ibrahim al-Tikriti, ate grapes while a man screamed in agony in a torture chamber. By John F. Burns.  MIDEAST(Jerusalem) -- Worried about the rising political strength of Hamas, Israel threatened to prevent Palestinians in East Jerusalem from voting in the Jan. 25 elections, a move that prompted officials of the Palestinian Authority to threaten a delay in the vote. By Greg Myre.  AFGHAN (Kabul, Afghaniztan) -- President Karzai's chief political rival wins a vote to be speaker of the lower house of parliament; Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld confirms a 3,000-member American troop reduction during a visit to Kabul, deflects questions about detainee abuse. By Carlotta Gall.  IRAN-NUKES (Berlin) -- Talks resume between Iran and the European Union on the Iranian nuclear program. By Richard Bernstein.  RUSSIA-RIGHTS (Moscow) -- Parliament approves amendments to soften a bill restricting non-governmental organizations at the request of President Vladimir V. Putin, reacting to an outcry by Western governments and rights groups. By Steven Lee Myers.  BRITAIN-ELTON (Windsor, England) -- If there were any anti- or pro-gay demonstrators in the crowd, they were being unusually shy. No one was screaming religious slogans, carrying angry placards, wearing in-your-face outfits or loudly forecasting the end of civilization as we know it. The most striking thing, in fact, about the people gathered along the streets here on Wednesday for Sir Elton John's civil partnership ceremony with his boyfriend, David Furnish, was how little they appeared to care, one way or the other, about the couple's sexuality. By Sarah Lyall.  WASHINGTON (w code)  CONGRESS (Washington) -- The Senate passed the budget on Wednesday morning, with Vice President Dick Cheney casting the tie-breaking vote. By Carl Hulse.  .PATRIOT-ACT (Washington) -- The vote on the extension of the Patriot Act goes down to the wire. By Sheryl Gay Stolberg.  BUDGET-STUDENT-AID (Washington) -- One-third of all the savings in the budget bill come from student aid. College students and their families will pay higher interest rates on loans. Banks will get lower subsidies. And Congress creates a new grant program for low-income students, provided they go to college full time, have a B average and major in math, science or engineering. By Robert Pear.  DOMESTIC-SPYING (Washington) -- Developments in the Bush administration's decision to eavesdrop without warrants on communications from the United States to other countries. By Eric Lichtblau and James Risen.  .NATIONAL GENERAL (a code)  KATRINA-HOTELS (Columbia, S.C.) -- While most hurricane evacuees have moved out of their hotels, getting the problem children into apartments is among the thorniest problems in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina. Even in states like South Carolina, where a relative handful remain in hotels, some officials have begun to throw up their hands. The people who could fend for themselves, they said, have moved on; rooms are now occupied mainly by the elderly, disabled or mentally ill. Many are felons whose applications for apartments are routinely rejected, or people with a string of evictions who seem to be waiting to be tossed out again. By Jodi Wilgoren.  SANTA-PHONE-CALL (Atlanta) -- Parents may have found an antidote to the growing sophistication of the grade-school set. Increasingly, they are turning to commercial services that provide phone calls from a Santa who knows not only what is on the child's wish list, but the names of siblings, friends and teachers and what was under the tree last year. By Shaila Dewan.  EVOLUTION-ASSESS (Harrisburg, Pa.) -- After Tuesday's court ruling in Pennsylvania, where does the intelligent design movement go from here? By Laurie Goodstein.  With:  EVOLUTION-TEXAS (Odessa, Texas) -- A dispute over what textbook to use to teach a Bible elective course is just beginning in a school district in Odessa, Texas. The trustees voted late Tuesday to adopt the textbook from the National Council on Bible Curriculum in Public Schools, endorsing the recommendation of the schools superintendent and rejecting the opinion of teachers and administrators who had favored a different book. A parent has threatened a lawsuit over the course. By Barbara Novovitch.  NY-TRANSIT-STRIKE (New York) -- Lede-all on the New York City transit strike, now in its second day. By Janny Scott and Steven Greenhouse.  NY-STRIKE-SUFFER (New York) -- A look at the growing misery of the transit strike. The first day was one of adventure, stiff-upper lips, whatever. The second was, well, exponentially worse. By Richard Perez-Pena.  SCIENCE (a' category)  DIABETES (Undated) -- A 17-year federal study answered one of the most pressing questions about diabetes: Can tight control of blood sugar prevent heart attacks and strokes? The answer, reported in the New England Journal of Medicine, is yes. Intense control can reduce the risk of heart attacks and strokes by nearly half. By Gina Kolata.  VIET-FLU (Undated) -- Two fatal cases of avian flu in Vietnam were resistant to the drug Tamiflu, New England Journal reports. By Lawrence K. Altman and Andrew Pollack.  FINANCIAL (f code)  DEUTSCHE-BANK (Frankfurt) -- The head of Deutsche Bank, Josef Ackermann, will be sent back to court for a retrial over windfall bonuses he approved for departing executives of Mannesmann, the German federal court said. He and five others had been acquitted by a regional court last year of wrongdoing in paying almost 60 million euros ($71 million) in bonuses and benefits five years ago. By Mark Landler.  TIME-WARNER (Undated) -- Time Warner names Jeff Bewkes president and chief operating officer. Don Logan, chairman of the media and communications group, will retire at the end of the year and become nonexecutive chairman of Time Warner Cable. By Richard Siklos.  QATAR-NATURAL-GAS (Doha, Qatar) This tiny emirate, no bigger than Connecticut, is elbowing aside other energy-rich countries to become the leader in the emerging international market for natural gas. By Simon Romero.  KAZAHKSTAN-ECON (Almaty, Kazakhstan) -- The Kazahk economy is colored by the close entwinement of business and politics, corruption, lack of transparency and a small oligarchic class as in neighboring Russia, and significantly, a prominent role for members of the president's immediate family. By Richard E. Kramer. "163945"	"I"	"thought"	" Cox News Service DUNWOODY, Ga. -- Everything looked normal Tuesday morning at Jeff Williams' home on a quiet cul-de-sac in Dunwoody. Only the constant ringing of the telephone let slip that this was an unusual day for the 19-year-old University of Georgia freshman. It was, it still is, insane, said a barefoot, still sleepy Williams. When the 'Today' show called, I thought, 'Oh my gosh, this is crazy.' Friends and media outlets began calling and visiting as soon as Williams and his parents, Dave and Cindi Williams, arrived home Monday evening from Monaco, where he won $1 million over the weekend at the European Poker Tour main event. It was his first live tournament. He beat almost 300 other card sharks. Williams, a soft-spoken, slender young man with a wide smile, said he remembers very little of the winning moment: I know I yelled, but I'll have to watch the video to see what else. He said his winning hand -- an ace of spades and a 10 of clubs -- was not a bluff, and that he had played his final opponent before, online. I knew he was very aggressive and I knew he would go all in. I had only bet a third of my chips, so even if I lost that hand, I would still have a shot. Williams said he played about 2,000 hands of Texas Hold 'Em during the tournament. He hasn't played since winning the pot, mostly because of visits from friends and family and calls from media outlets. He also said he needed to take a break from the intense concentration required to win. Two thousand hands, and everyone of them I could have gone broke on, Williams recalled. I really had to pay attention. Williams' parents -- mom's a real estate agent and dad's a regional manager for a security firm -- flew to Monaco to surprise him when they realized how close he was to winning the tournament. Cindi Williams said Tuesday that she and her husband always talked honestly with their children, Jeff and his 16-year-old sister, Amanda, about everything, including gambling. That kept him from gambling behind their backs, she said. Basically, we've tried to make them look at the consequences of their behavior, whether it was good or bad, Cindi Williams said. She said they also stressed that he should never wager more than you can lose. So far, that advice has stuck. Williams spent just $40 to enter the first of two online tournaments that earned him a spot in the Monaco tournament. Entry into that tournament was bankrolled by PokerStars.com, which paid $12,000 apiece for the top nine players in the second online tournament to play in Monaco. Williams said he will probably spend the remainder of this week, the last of his spring break, in New York where he was invited to tape a segment for NBC's Today show. That would be another once-in-a-lifetime experience, he said. In one week, going from being an average college student to making an appearance on national TV. Williams attributes his poker prowess to practice. He had been playing cards with his sister and their mother, mostly gin rummy and quarter poker, for most of his life. He began playing online poker two years ago, but only seriously six months ago. Williams said he preferred Texas Hold 'Em to other poker games because, It has the most skill in it. The math whiz was able to take on more seasoned players, he said, because he can play four to six hands at a time online. That gives me a lot of practice so I can kind of catch up to guys who have been playing for 20 years and it helps me see a lot of hands, said Williams, who added that he's always had a good memory for cards. Perhaps improbably, Williams studies neither mathematics nor statistics at UGA. He's a political science major who's already laughing about the benefits that a world-class poker face could bring to a desired career in politics. I'd like to run for office someday, but if not that, maybe something in the Department of State, or Defense, he said. In the interim, he doesn't plan any Pentagon-size spending sprees. Once he gets the money in hand, Williams said, he'll set aside about $400,000 to pay taxes, and plans to invest most of the rest. My mom's a real estate agent so I think I'll get a few condominiums that I can rent and leverage that for investments, Williams said, adding that he would put the rest in mutual funds. He also might treat himself to a few good dinners, although there's not yet a girlfriend to share them. I thought about a new car, something pretty and fast, maybe an Infiniti, but I'm not going to do that now. The 1993 brown Honda Accord sitting in his driveway is just fine, he said, for now. </P> "	"nyt_eng_200603.gz"
