The NYT frontpage advisory, with layout description, will move by 8 p.m. ET. The night supervisor for The New York Times News Service is Jill Taylor, phone: 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927; e-mail: taylor@nytimes.com. BUSH (Washington) -- The overhaul of the White House staff intensified on Wednesday as Karl Rove, one of the president's most powerful and feared advisers, gave up day-to-day control over administration policy to concentrate on the midterm elections and Scott McClellan, the White House press secretary, said he was stepping down. The departure of McClellan gives President Bush a chance to put a new public face on the White House at a time when it is beset by problems. But Rove's changed status may be the more telling sign of the extent of the shakeup being undertaken by Bush and his new chief of staff, Joshua B. Bolten. Bumiller. With photos, NYT1-4.  Subs slug; an early story, BUSH-RESIGN, leading with McClellan, has moved.  NEGROPONTE-INTEL (Washington) -- For months the top Republican and Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee have been deeply divided over everything from pre-war reports on Iraq to the National Security Agency's domestic eavesdropping. Rep. Peter Hoekstra of Michigan, the Republican chairman, and Rep. Jane Harman of California, the ranking Democrat, have come together in a remarkable show of unity on one issue: their disquiet with the first-year performance of John D. Negroponte, the director of national intelligence. They fear the intelligence czar's office is becoming just what critics feared it might -- another blanket of bureaucracy that muffles rather than clarifies the government's view of the world. DNI staffers deny the charge and Negroponte himself will have a chance on Thursday to defend his record in what even critics say is an impossible job in an appearance at the National Press Club. By Scott Shane.  ITALY-POLITICS (Rome) -- Italy's highest court on Wednesday upheld the narrow victory of Romano Prodi as the country's next prime minister, apparently ending the five-year reign of Silvio Berlusconi -- except that the mercurial prime minister still would not concede defeat. We acknowledge the decision, said Sandro Bondi, national coordinator for Berlusconi's Forza Italia Party. But, he said, the reservations we advanced continue to stand. Earlier in the day, Bondi floated a proposal that some political experts believe is the real force behind Berlusconi's reluctance to acknowledge the election results. He suggested that Berlusconi be made the president of Italy, a position that would give him great prestige, keep him in politics and allow him to protect any attack by a new government on his vast holdings in media, publishing and sports. By Ian Fisher.  NY-TRAM-RESCUE (New York) -- For 30 years, a red cage sat below the Roosevelt Island Tramway station. On Tuesday afternoon, with 68 people trapped in a pair of gondolas hundreds of feet above their heads, rescue workers were faced with a nerve-wracking puzzle: how to turn the jungle-gym-like contraption into a moving platform that would travel across the cables, pull up alongside the swaying gondolas and bring the passengers safely back. When officials realized it would take another two hours to reassemble the cage and remove passengers stuck in the second gondola, the city officials tracked down the owner of a Queens crane company at dinner and asked him to send over a 20-ton monster that could reach passengers. Half an hour later, a Hydraulic All Terrain Crane arrived, a contract was hastily signed and rescue workers set to work figuring how they might turn the crane into a Deus Ex Machina. So it went in one of the stranger rescue operations in the history of New York City. By Andrew Jacobs.  STORMS-TEXAS (Houston) -- To the long list of adjectives used to describe Texans since last summer's hurricanes -- munificent, intrepid, scrappy -- add one more: fed up. Seven months after two hurricanes blew through the Gulf Coast region, elected officials, law enforcement agencies and many residents say that Texas is nearing the end of its ability to play good neighbor without compensation. Houston is straining along its municipal seams from the 150,000 new residents from New Orleans, officials say. Crime has spiked, and the schools are struggling to educate thousands of new children. To the east, Texans argue that the fallout from Hurricane Rita, which took an unexpected turn away from Houston shortly after Katrina last fall to wreak havoc elsewhere in the state, has been forgotten in the swirl of attention given to New Orleans' devastation. By Jennifer Steinhauer.  With a photo.  DISABLED-ROMANCE (Undated) -- In what experts say is the latest frontier in the disability rights movement, many young men and women in their 20s and 30s, who once would have been given sex education only to protect them from exploitation and disease, are being prepared by social workers to have successful romantic and intimate relationships, sometimes over the objections of protective parents and agencies more likely to stress the prevention of abuse, disease and pregnancy. By Jane Gross.  With a photo.  (Editors: Budgets and advisories are internal documents not for publication or redistribution outside of client news organizations. , I said,	 Answer: It's the colors. It's attitudes. I just came back from Bali. It's the way they dress, with the clay, muddy, earthy red the girls wear during ceremonial dances. Everywhere you go in the world, people have, for lack of a better word, a uniform, a way of dressing that's conducive to the climate. In Africa, the Masai wear bright colored blankets so they can be seen out in the fields, and it also protects them from the sun. In India, the bright colors can signify where you're from. In China, the traditional Mao jacket, that's a uniform that's become fashionable. The variations on colors and the stages the Mao jacket has gone through over the years, that's an evolution. I just came back from Europe, and I've picked next spring's fabric. I was in Milan, and a friend invited me to go to Portofino. When I saw those buildings, I said, 'That's it, I've got my color stories.' Portofino has a spirit, a soul. So the next collection is going to be called Diana Ross goes to Portofino. (Wilkerson laughs.) </P> 	nyt_eng_200604.gz

On the Cover  Editors: The cover stories will be budgeted on Friday. Stories under consideration are ...  MYSPACE-ADS (Santa Monica, Calif.) -- Almost on a lark, Chris DeWolfe bought the Internet address MySpace.com in 2002, figuring that it might be useful someday. DeWolfe noticed the popularity of Friendster, a rapidly growing Web site that let people communicate with their friends and meet the friends of their friends. What might happen, he wondered, if he combined this type of social networking with the sort of personal expression enabled by other sites for creating Web pages or online journals? The site grew quickly. Now, with a new owner in Rupert Murdoch, DeWolfe faces more pressure to wring a profit out MySpace.com. By Saul Hansell.  INSIDER-TRADING (New York) -- A look at how three young Wall Street traders were arrested for insider trading. By Jenny Anderson and Andrew Ross Sorkin.  YELLOW-TAIL-WINE (Undated) --How Yellow Tail has transformed the wine industry. By Frank J. Prial.  Commentary  MARKET-WATCH (Undated) -- Weekly Wall Street commentary. By Gretchen Morgenson.  EVERYBODYS-BUSINESS (Undated) -- Hedge funds are having their day, but they're still not such a great investment. By Ben Stein.  ECON-COLUMN (Undated) -- The weekly Economic View column: Considering the nation's muddled campaign finance system, it's hardly a surprise that voters have taken a shine to a few wealthy entrepreneurs. There is an abiding American respect for people who build and manage big businesses, and rich politicians can also claim to avoid conflicts of interest by financing their own campaigns. But does experience back them up? The question is worth considering, said Amitai Etzioni, a professor at George Washington University, given the millions of dollars that candidates raise, even for relatively minor congressional races. By Daniel Altman.  Features  CARS-RENT (Undated) -- Sometimes, renting a car may be a better choice than owning. Kate Murphy.  SPAS-MEN (Undated) -- Men are starting to discover the joys of time at the spa. By Annie Eisenberg.  Investing  INVEST-UTILITIES (Undated) -- In Utility stocks, dividends are no the only draw. By Tim Gray.  ABOUT-CARS-LUCERNE (Undated) -- A review of the 2006 Buick Lucerne, the new flagship for one of GM's most troubled divisions. The Lucerne replaces two full-size cars, the LeSabre and Park Avenue, and comes with either a V6 or V8 engine the first V8 in a Buick car in many years. While a new big Buick is unlikely to set anyone's heart racing, the Lucerne seems well engineered, nicely put together and rather engaging to drive. By Bob Knoll. The desk supervisor for The New York Times News Service is Lynn Hoogenboom, followed by Ray Krueger; phone: 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927; e-mail: lyhoog@nytimes.com or krueger@nytimes.com. TOP Lede story: IRAQ (Baghdad, Iraq) -- In a sudden reversal, the embattled Iraqi prime minister, Ibrahim al-Jaafari, said Thursday that he was willing to relinquish his job, a move that was described by some other political leaders as a potential breakthrough in the stalemate that has fueled the country's bitter sectarian violence. After his announcement, a planned session of parliament was canceled to allow for the Shiite coalition to which al-Jaafari belongs to vote on whether to choose another candidate. Hussein al-Shahristani, a member of the Shiite coalition, said at a news conference outside the legislative hall that the group would act very soon.very soon. (EDS: an early version of this story has moved; the 2ndLd-Writethru is scheduled to move by 8:30 p.m. ET in i news file.)  Top center:  CHINA-U.S. (Washington) -- President Bush and Chinese President Hu Jintao, meeting at the White House for the first time on Thursday, pledged closer cooperation on fighting nuclear proliferation and addressing their massive trade imbalance, but broke little new ground on a host of disputes that have strained the relationship between the United States and China in recent years. Their meeting, which required more than a year of intensive diplomacy to arrange and was postponed by Hurricane Katrina, did more to emphasize the long list of tensions between the world's richest country and its fastest rising rival than it did to offer fresh solutions. The two presidents did not announce any new agreements after their 90-minute meeting in the Oval Office. By Joseph Kahn.  With photos, NYT 1-12.  (EDS: an early version of this story has moved; the 1stLd-Writethru is scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in i news file.)  Off-lede:  FDA-MARIJUANA (Washington) -- The FDA said Thursday that no sound scientific studies support the medical use of marijuana, providing ammunition to federal officials who are trying to squelch state efforts to legalize medical uses. A spokesman for John Walters, the federal drug czar, hailed the FDA statement. But the FDA statement contradicts years of research as well as a 1999 review by the National Academy of Sciences, the nation's most prestigious scientific evaluative agency. The national academy found that marijuana is moderately well suited for particular conditions, such as chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting and AIDS wasting. That the FDA would involve itself in this debate baffled some observers and suggested to others that it was yet another sign that the agency has become increasingly political. By Gardiner Harris.  GASOLINE-POLITICS (Washington) -- There's little good in a gallon of gasoline selling for $3. But even this far from the November midterm elections, Democrats are making it a prime campaign issue, answering voter alarm with accusations that Republicans have undermined the economy and squeezed family budgets. A look at how the issue is overtaking the war in Iraq and plaguing an administration that had been pointing to a robust economy as a bright spot on an otherwise bleak policy landscape. By Michael Janofsky.  POLYGAMY-TAXES (Hildale, Utah) -- Thousands of polygamist offshoots of the Mormon Church are engaged in a highly unusual standoff here over property taxes that could ultimately cost them their homes or thrust them into a mainstream America they fear and despise. In one corner is a group of 8,000 or so adherents of the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, the country's largest polygamist community that had long paid the property taxes of its members. At the other corner is an accountant from Salt Lake City named Bruce R. Wisan who says he is determined to help the church members even if they do not want it. The church hierarchy is in chaos. Its former leader is on the run facing criminal charges of arranging sex between a minor and an adult in a polygamous marriage, leaving the old tax collection system in shambles. Now the property taxes for hundreds of homes -- around $1.3 million -- are overdue and mounting. The church's remaining leaders have told people living in the homes not to pay. Wisan has vowed to make them. By Kirk Johnson.  With photo.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in a news file.)  IMMIG-EMPLOYERS (Washington) -- The apprehension on Wednesday of more than 1,100 illegal immigrants employed by a Houston-based pallet supply company, as well as the arrest of seven of its managers, represents the kickoff of a more aggressive federal campaign intended to hold employers accountable, Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff said on Thursday. Describing the hiring of millions of undocumented workers as a form of organized crime, Chertoff, a former federal prosecutor, said the government would try to crack down on the practice with techniques similar to those used to shut down the mob. His remarks came just days before the Senate is to reconvene and perhaps restart a debate over a comprehensive rewriting of immigration laws. By Eric Lipton.  TRIBECA-FILM-FEST (New York) -- Imagine you are at the multiplex. There are 18 movies -- indies, comedies, dark dramas, foreign films and documentaries. Most have something to recommend them, and all would meet at least someone's fancy. Surveying the options, you wonder where to look. Now multiply by 10, and you have some idea of the scope and reach of the TriBeCa Film Festival, the downtown cinema orgy that begins with the premiere of United 93 on April 25. The festival, conceived as a civic gesture to help the neighborhood get back on its feet after the Sept. 11 attacks, has mushroomed into the film fest that ate downtown; last year it sold 135,000 tickets to 700 screenings. By David Carr.  With photos.  (Story has moved in e news file.)  ENRON-SKILLING (Houston) -- Jeffrey K. Skilling's laser-sharp intelligence and know-it-all self-assurance helped propel him to transform Enron from a no-nonsense pipeline company into an energy colossus. But in his eight days on the witness stand, jurors in the federal trial here also saw a side of him that had increasingly bothered managers at Enron: someone who did not like to be questioned, to be told he was wrong, to be cut off when he was speaking. The joint defense team for Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay is counting on the more human portrait of Skilling that emerged in his testimony to sway jurors that Skilling is not a criminal. By Alexei Barrionuevo.  With photos, NYT 14-16.  (Scheduled to move by 8:30 p.m. ET in f news file.)  WTC-MEMORIAL (Undated) -- A new report concludes that the design for the memorial at ground zero leaves it vulnerable to a terrorism attack. By David W. Dunlap.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in a news file.)  RUMSFELD-GENERALS (Washington) -- In defending himself against his critics, Donald H. Rumsfeld has described himself as an agent of change and suggested that the complaints come from old thinkers who oppose reforming the military. But as a half-dozen retired Army and Marine generals have called for Rumsfeld's resignation in recent weeks, some are criticizing him in his own terms. The change-agent defense secretary, they say, is himself resistant to change. By Michael R. Gordon.  With photo.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in w news file.)  BUSH (Washington) -- Joshua B. Bolten, the new White House chief of staff, has raised the possibility of moving Harriet E. Miers from her job as President Bush's counsel as part of the continuing shake-up of the West Wing, an influential Republican with close ties to Bolten said Thursday. By Elisabeth Bumiller and Jim Rutenberg.  CHAD-REBELS (N'djamena, Chad) -- After beating back a rebel assault on this dusty capital last week, President Idriss Deby pointed steely eyed across the desert and loudly accused Sudan, his neighbor and longtime rival, of trying to do him in. The truth is hardly so simple. By Marc Lacey.  With photos.  (Scheduled to move by 8:45 p.m. ET in i news file.) By Neil A. Lewis.  (Scheduled to move by 9 p.m. ET in a news file.) , she added,	 While this pneumo-hydrostatic skeleton (as the researchers call it) provides support, it makes the crab something less than a spring chicken, lacking its normal agility. The crab's body is designed to work as a rigid system, Taylor said. , they said,	 Last fall, a team of scientists tied bats to the deadly SARS outbreaks. Bats in China, they said, are likely where the virus hides between human outbreaks. Then, in December, another group of researchers suggested that bats in Africa serve as a reservoir for the vicious virus for Ebola hemorrhagic fever, which causes its human victims to bleed to death. Bats have also been definitively tied to two other recently discovered viruses that are lethal to humans: Nipah and Hendra. </P> 	nyt_eng_200604.gz
, they reported,	 After the 2003 outbreaks of SARS, which attacks the respiratory system, scientists initially identified an animal known as a civet as the disease's reservoir, the place where the virus sustains itself between outbreaks in humans. But further testing found that civets were not widely infected. In a paper published online by the journal Science last September, a team that included Epstein and scientists from China and Australia named a new suspect: cave-dwelling horseshoe bats. These bats, they reported, carry a family of viruses very similar to the one that causes SARS. </P> 	nyt_eng_200604.gz
, he said,	 But why did this happen when it did? One intriguing possibility is that it is linked to China's economic boom, according to Peter Daszak, a co-author of the SARS paper who is executive director of the Consortium for Conservation Medicine. With the newfound wealth there, he said, animal markets have grown as more people can afford fresh animal meat. As the markets grow, so grow the chances that a virus will jump from one species to the next. </P> 	nyt_eng_200604.gz

, he says,	 Combine passionate intellect and boyish enthusiasm and you have Edward Hirsch, who shares with us some of his favorite poems in these brief essays drawn from a series of columns he wrote over three years for the Washington Post Book World. He started the series just after 9/11, and the large response to it showed, he says, that poetry sustains us in hard times. But if many of his choices here are about loss, there's an almost playful quality to the scope of the selections. He focuses on everything from poems by international writers unfamiliar to most mainstream readers, to poems about sports, Nebraska, insomnia and New York City. As in his 1999 book, How to Read a Poem, the unifying thread is his pleasure in telling us about them. If one of the great joys of reading poetry is sharing your favorites, talking about them and trading them like baseball cards, Hirsch can count himself a happy man. BBN-METS-ZAMBRANO (San Francisco) -- As the Mets got dressed in their clubhouse on Tuesday afternoon to prepare for their night game against the Giants, they could look up at any number of TV sets and see ex-Met phenom Scott Kazmir pitching live in Yankee Stadium. The same scene unfolded last week in San Francisco, when Kazmir pitched in Fenway while the Mets prepared for a game against the Padres. Everywhere, it seems, the Mets turn, there is a constant reminder of the July 31, 2004 trade the Mets made, when they sent Kazmir to Tampa Bay for Victor Zambrano, the pitcher who now depresses the Mets every five days when he takes the mound. By Ben Shpigel.  BBN-BONDS (San Francisco) -- Barry Bonds had already told reporters that he was not talking on Monday night and now he was one simple act away from bolting out of the Giants' clubhouse. All Bonds had to do was put on his white sneakers. But, these days, nothing seems simple for Bonds. As Bonds sat in a chair, he hunched forward while carefully slipping his right foot into a sneaker. Then Bonds tried to do the same thing with his left foot. But Bonds had to put his hand on the big screen television by his locker to steady himself before he could finally push his foot into place. The snapshot, about a minute in the day of a player with 709 homers and seven Most Valuable Player Awards, was one more reminder that Bonds' body is weakening and that 41, in baseball years, can be very old. By Jack Curry.  BKN-ARATON-COLUMN (East Rutherford, N.J.) -- Sports of The Times column on Game 2 of the Nets-Pacers playoff series. By Harvey Araton.  BKN-NETS-PACERS (East Rutherford, N.J.) -- Game 2 of the New Jersey Nets-Indiana Pacers series. By John Eligon.  BKN-CAVS-WIZARDS (Cleveland) -- LeBron James and the Cavaliers try to go up 2-0 in their first-round series with the Washington Wizards. By Liz Robbins.  BKN-CLIPPERS-BRAND (Los Angeles) -- An off-day story on the Clippers' Elton Brand, who is leading the way as the Clippers, up 2-0 on the Denver Nuggets in their first-round playoff series, attempt to get to the second round of the postseason for the first time in Clipper history. By Howard Beck.  HKN-RANGERS (Greenburgh, N.Y.) -- An off-day story on the Rangers-Devils series, including a look at Jaromir Jagr, who, injured shoulder and all, is probably the Rangers' last hope in a series that is beginning to look like a four-game Devils sweep. By Lee Jenkins.  HKN-DEVILS (West Orange, N.J.) -- An off-day story on the Devils, including a look at John Madden, New Jersey's terrific two-way player. Madden scored two shorthanded goals in Game 2 on Monday night. By Dave Caldwell.  SOCCER-REPORT (Undated) -- The weekly soccer report. By Jack Bell.  For information and repeats call the News Service at (888) 346-9867 or (212) 556-1927. FOREIGN  With story BC-JAPAN-VILLAGES-NYT  Eight elderly residents comprise the remote village of Ogama, Japan and are selling it to a landfill company, a metaphor for the broader issue of an aging and shrinking population in Japan.  In a state prone to earthquakes, wildfires, floods and mudflows, many Californians would consider a road closed by rockslides a minor nuisance. Unless they live near Devil's Slide, a coastal bluff along Pacific Coast Highway known as much for its precarious pitch as its panoramic vistas.  Steven L. Burton does not envision himself posing for the before and after shots in a diet ad. But he has reluctantly become something of a poster boy for GlaxoSmithKline's foray into the lucrative weight-loss business. While leading Glaxo's effort to market an over-the-counter version of the prescription weight loss drug Xenical, Burton is also using the drug himself. And he can offer personal testimony to its benefits -- and its drawbacks.  For visitors, Sofia offers a pleasant combination of urbane relaxation and awe-inspiring buildings and museums. In the summer, stylish Bulgarians fill the leafy boulevards and parks. Cell phones are everywhere, still juxtaposed with the occasional donkey cart. Hip teenagers, indistinguishable from their Western counterparts, shred the skate park that surrounds a Communist-era monument.  As he neared his 78th birthday, Edward Albee, an award-winning playwright marked the occasion with a trip to the remote outpost of Easter Island, a journey nearly 50 years in the making.  What happens in Saigon, as it's still known, stays in Saigon. No one understood this better than Marguerite Duras, the French writer who was born in colonial Indochina in 1914 and spent her childhood there. EXP-IRAQ-TAPE (Baghdad, Iraq) -- A man identifying himself as Abu Musab al-Zarqawi appeared in a videotape released on Tuesday, denouncing the American effort in that country as a crusader campaign and calling on Muslims around the world to join him in waging a holy war. By Dexter Filkins.  EXP-EGYPT-TERROR (Dahab, Egypt) -- Developments in the aftermath of Monday's triple bombings in this Egyptian seaside resort, including the arrest of 10 suspects. By Michael Slackman. By Michael Slackman.  EXP-NEPAL (Katmandu, Nepal) -- A day after the king said he would return power to them, Nepal's politicians prepared Tuesday for the unenviable challenge of crafting peace, but faced pressure from protesters as well as from Maoist rebels, who called the parties' acceptance of the king's concession a historic blunder. By Somini Sengupta.  EXP-IRAN-NUKES (Tehran, Iran) -- Iran's supreme leader said on Tuesday in a meeting with the Sudanese president that Iran was ready to share its nuclear technology with other countries. By Nazila Fathi.  EXP-RICE (Ankara, Turkey) -- Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice assured Turkish leaders on Tuesday that the United States would step up efforts to stop Kurdish insurgents from Iraq from infiltrating into Turkey, but she cautioned the Turkish government not to send troops to Iraq to do the job. By Steven R. Weisman.  EXP-BUSH (Washington) -- President Bush announced a series of short-term steps on Tuesday that he said might slightly ease energy prices, including a suspension of government purchases to refill the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, a relaxation of environmental rules for the refining of gasoline and investigations into possible price gouging and price fixing. By David E. Sanger.  EXP-IRAQ-PRISON-ABUSE (Washington) -- The Army plans to charge Lt. Col. Steven L. Jordan, the former head of the interrogation center at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq, with dereliction of duty, lying to investigators and conduct unbecoming an officer, the officer's lawyer said Tuesday. By Eric Schmitt.  NEW-ORLEANS-LEVEES (New York) -- The Bush administration has added about $2 billion to its supplemental budget request for additional levee construction around New Orleans. But the state will be asked to contribute a portion as well. By John Schwartz and Adam Nossiter.  EXP-ENRON-TRIAL (Houston) -- Enron Corp. was a victim of a witch hunt that unfairly criticized the giant energy company's business and drove it toward bankruptcy, former Chairman and Chief Executive Kenneth Lay testified at his criminal trial on Tuesday. By Alexei Barrionuevo.  EXP-ECON-REPORT (Undated) -- Sales of previously owned homes edged up in March but not enough to keep the inventory of unsold homes from hitting a record high as the housing market continued to signal a slowdown. By Vikas Bajaj.  EXP-NISSAN-EARNINGS (Tokyo) -- Nissan Motor posted its sixth consecutive year of record profits and said it would begin an offensive of new vehicle releases to seize market share from struggling General Motors and Ford. By Martin Fackler. For information, phone: 888-346-9867 or 212-556-1927. INTERNATIONAL (Will move in the i news file.) CANADA-CASUALTIES (Toronto) -- Prime Minister Stephen Harper faced a storm of criticism on Tuesday for his decision to halt the flying of the flag at half-staff for Canadian troops killed in Afghanistan, and for refusing to allow news coverage of the return of the bodies of four soldiers recently killed there. Opposition political figures and some family members of the four soldiers, whose bodies were returned to a Canadian military base on Tuesday evening, say Harper is trying to blunt negative images that may erode public support for Canada's increasingly dangerous combat role in Afghanistan. It is an effort, they say, that mirrors President Bush's decision to limit coverage of returning military coffins from the war in Iraq.coffins from the war in Iraq.  MOSCOW-TRAFFIC-POLICE (Moscow) -- They are creatures of urban legend and the target of endless jokes in this exhaust-filled, car-clogged megalopolis. Burly men in baggy uniforms, Moscow's traffic inspectors are lampooned for creating monstrous traffic jams and their readiness to take or solicit a bribe, and blamed for everything from bad roads to terrorist attacks. Such fear do they strike in drivers that a life-size mock-up of a traffic officer in a city south of Moscow was enough to cut violations significantly. A Moscow journal by Sophia Kishkovsky.  TERROR-WIRETAP (Washington) -- A federal appeals court on Tuesday returned the criminal case against an Islamic scholar to a trial judge to determine whether the Bush administration's domestic spying program was used to gather evidence against him. In a two-page order, a three-judge panel of the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals granted a request from Ali al-Timimi, a suburban Washington Islamic cleric, to let a federal judge determine whether the government secretly intercepted his conversations or those of others who were key to his case. Al-Timimi, who is serving a life sentence, was convicted last year of urging young Muslim men to join the Taliban and fight U.S. troops overseas in statements he made at a dinner shortly after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. (Summary from wires) By Eric Lichtblau.  TERROR-PORTS (Washington) -- Ridiculing port security plans advocated by the Bush administration, Democrats on Capitol Hill called on Tuesday for the inspection of every ship container headed to the United States. The Democrats, who are energized by the embarrassment caused to the president by the failed plan by a Dubai-based company to take over the management of six American ports terminals, have made clear that they will continue their election-year push to make domestic security an issue they can call their own. By Eric Lipton.  NATIONAL GENERAL  (Will move in a news file.)  CALIF-ROCKSLIDES (Montara, Calif.) -- In a state prone to earthquakes, wildfires, floods and deadly mudflows, many Californians would consider a road closed by rockslides as a minor nuisance. Unless they live near Devil's Slide, a breathtaking coastal bluff along Pacific Coast Highway south of San Francisco, known as much for its precarious pitch as its panoramic vistas. Devil's Slide has been something of a recurring nightmare for residents living here and in several other coastal towns separated from San Francisco by it. Rain or shine, the Slide, as it is known, has been inching down the San Pedro Mountains in an uncontrollable march toward the sea, gradually taking with it a stretch of the coastal highway. , he said,	 Traditionally, one of the most cinematically exploitable aspects of New York has been its reputation as a cauldron of organized crime, corruption and narcotics. The author and screenwriter Nicholas Pileggi (GoodFellas) said Hollywood reflected, or at least dramatized, this reality in the '30s with gangster films like The Roaring Twenties. In the '50s, he said, it was the corrupt city exemplified by 'Sweet Smell of Success,' with its malevolent gossip columnist, J.J. Hunsecker. In the '60s, narcotics arrive, and the city becomes a horrendous place. The director William Friedkin memorably hammered home this point in 1971 with The French Connection, in which the hero cop, played by Gene Hackman, is nearly as corrupt and brutish as the criminals he's chasing. </P> 	nyt_eng_200604.gz

, he said,	 At first, he said, he took slosh to be a synonym for splash. But as he pondered the port-infused cheese, he decided that a slosh was probably a copious amount, since small measures do not slosh - at any rate, more than a splash. Is this something that sober minds have taken the measure of? he asks. </P> 	nyt_eng_200612.gz
, it seems,	 And a fall menu in the Daily Telegraph specified a slosh of olive oil in one recipe and a glug in the next. The slosh, it seems, has always been a matter of interpretation: The Oxford English Dictionary defines it simply as a quantity of some liquid, though the earliest citation - corn-cake washed down with a generous slosh of whisky, from 1888 - gives a rough idea of a single-serving slosh. </P> 	nyt_eng_200612.gz
, she said,	 However, she said, it's no mystery that we all hear a slosh as bigger than a splash. Both words are onomatopoetic, she notes - imitative of sound - and the fatter vowel of slosh, phonetics research says, suggests a larger amount. The a [of splash] being a more fronted, higher frequency vowel, it 'sounds smaller' than the back, lower frequency o. When you say slosh your mouth has a bigger hollow place for the liquor to slosh around in. </P> 	nyt_eng_200612.gz

"174518"	"I"	"thought"	" Eating more whole grains was one of my resolutions last year. No problem, I thought, since I'd been breakfasting on toasted When Pigs Fly 100 percent whole-wheat bread for more than a year. But now and then, I strayed. The Maine bread bakers put out a great six-grain loaf; those crunchy pumpkinseeds really added zip to the morning. Still, the ingredient list on the package label starts with unbleached white flour. I wasn't being completely true to my pledge. On one trip to the market, I noticed When Pigs Fly Whole Wheat 6-Grain bread ($3.99). It's delicious, toasted and spread with a little honey or peanut butter. Now the breakfast routine has the perfect blend of zip and virtue. Available at Whole Foods Markets; and Crosby's Market, 118 Washington St., Marblehead, 781-631-1741. </P> "	"nyt_eng_200612.gz"
